fields.headline: Televised football is a deal of two halves
fields.trailText: The BBC have negotiated a fantastic new deal with Sky which divides the domestic Football League calendar between the two of them. Sky get May to August, and the BBC get June and July.
fields.body:
Contrary to popular belief, tonight will not see the last ever Match of the Day. The BBC have negotiated a fantastic new deal with Sky which divides the domestic Football League calendar between the two of them. Sky get May to August, and the BBC get June and July. So during the close season at least, Gary and the boys will still be able to give us their expert analysis on all the latest action from the Premiership grounds: "And welcome back to Theatre of Dreams, where you join us for this crucial relaying of the Old Trafford pitch. Trevor - this new head groundsman that United have signed from the council - looking pretty tasty, isn't he?"

"World class, Gary, world class - and we can see this again in slow motion - there's the big square hole in the grass - and bang! In goes the new piece of turf, he knows exactly where he wants to place it and he doesn't mess about. Magic."

Close Season Match of the Day will join other BBC sporting highlights such as inter-schools netball, Pro-celebrity Morris Dancing and the Over-60s Music and Movement Classes live from the George V Memorial Hall, Eastbourne. This time last year they abandoned Grandstand because there were no more sports left for them to show and BBC1 screened My Fair Lady in its place. And during the famous scene at Ascot racecourse, a caption across the screen said "Pictures courtesy of Sky Sport".

A month later the BBC was finally relegated to the broadcasters' Third Division when they lost the auction to show Premiership highlights to ITV. Greg Dyke was interviewed immediately afterwards and said he was totally gutted for the lads: "We gave it 100% but at the end of the day, it just wasn't to be, Brian." Match of the Day is 37-years-old, which is about the age that most professional footballers give up the game as well. Now it can look forward to running a struggling sportswear business or training at soccer schools in Canada.

So how did it come about that in 10 short years the nation's favourite sports broadcaster lost all the televised sport? The key mistake was continuing to see ITV as the main enemy after the launch of Sky. In order to beat off its historic rival, the BBC did a deal to share football coverage with the then loss-making Sky TV. Sky Sport got some live matches and the BBC got to keep Match of the Day. Ten years later the BBC has learned that he who sups with the devil needs a long spoon. And he who sups with Rupert Murdoch needs a spoon tied on the end of a scaffolding pole. "Coming soon on Sky Extreme Sports Extra, a demolition derby special; watch as monster trucks and wrecking balls smash up public service broadcasting before your very eyes."

But who could have predicted that a viewing public that moaned about a small increase in the licence fee would pay any amount of money to watch football on satellite television. Obviously we'd rather watch BBC period costume dramas, if only Moll Flanders' ball control wasn't quite so useless. Who can resist the thrilling climax of the English football season, when millions of us sit on the edge of our seats wondering whether this year's champions will be Manchester United or Manchester United? The technology of digital television is now so impressive that watching it on a widescreen digital television is apparently just like being at the match. So now you can recline at home on the sofa asking the bloke in front to sit down, waiting for half time so you can queue for 20 minutes to use the disgusting toilets, and pay £4.50 for a tasteless slice of cold pizza.

So much television money has gone into football that an average Premiership footballer can now expect to earn £20,000 a week. It's hard to imagine what they do with all this money; there are only so many white leather sofas you can buy. But there's never been a better time to be selling mock-Tudor car ports or jacuzzis with gold taps. Maybe the clubs should make the players pay for their own soccer shirts - that would recoup a sizeable chunk of their salaries.

But football is now so tied up with big business that they might as well do away with the players altogether. Fans could gather on the terraces to watch the club accountants auditing and investing so that they could cheer their every move. "Yes!!!!! Did you see how Touche-Ross re-invested stock dividends, leasing back funds previously set aside for loan repayments?!"

And the fans will hug one another and weep with joy because their beloved club has gone up another couple of points on the FTSE 100 before they head off to buy replica pin-stripe accountants suits now available in the clubshop. It might not be quite so entertaining to watch, but at least the BBC could afford the rights to screen it once again.

webTitle: A life in writing: Max Hastings

fields.headline: Marching to different tunes
fields.standfirst: Max Hastings talks to David Horspool about work, war and writing
fields.trailText: Max Hastings talks to David Horspool about work, war and writing
fields.body:
Max Hastings started writing life early, leaving university after a year to the join the London Evening Standard , and publishing his first book when only 21. But he had not always wanted to be a writer. "I went through a phase in my teens when I thought that I'd like to be a soldier. Luckily I discovered before it was too late that I wasn't cut out for that at all." In his memoir, Going to the Wars , he explains how, as a Territorial on a punishing exercise in Cyprus, he committed the cardinal sin of buying water, and then not offering it to those around him. His father, the war correspondent Macdonald Hastings, had expected Max to follow in his footsteps ("he used to urge me to write something in the school holidays"), and it may have been that which, initially, put him off. "A lot of my family for three generations had been writers. I think I probably was not terribly sure whether I was going to be good enough to live up to the family reputation."

For several years, during which he travelled to 60 countries and covered 11 wars for the BBC and the Standard , writing took second place to the sheer excitement of being a "fireman", a journalist sent to hotspots (there is a Barry Fantoni cartoon which shows one Nicaraguan saying to another, "Things must be bad amigo. I think I just saw Max Hastings"). There were books of reportage on civil rights in the US and on Ulster, which he regards without much pride: "I go to great lengths nowadays to prevent any of my friends getting hold of them if they didn't read them at the time". The experience of war corresponding from Israel, Saigon, Biafra, Rhodesia seemed "as about as exciting a life as one could possibly ask for, but I often blush at how naive a lot of the stuff I did as a fireman was. It may have got on the front pages, but I'm not sure how much it added to the sum of human knowledge."

Having written a biography of the Marquis of Montrose, Charles I's lieutenant-general in Scotland, Hastings acquired a taste for the "long-researched" book, and so he jumped at the chance when commissioned by George Weidenfeld to write a biography of Yoni Netanyahu, the Israeli officer killed leading the successful raid on Entebbe, Uganda, in 1976 which freed 103 Israeli hostages from a plane hijacked by Palestinian terrorists. The success of the book which followed, Bomber Command , re-ignited his passion for writing military history and helped him to stick, for the moment, to his resolution to stay away from war corresponding. "The first book I'm still proud of, and which did have a real success, was my book on the bomber offensive . . . I think most of us have to learn how to do it."

It was at this point, when established "as a reasonably successful journalist, and a reasonably successful writer", that he had what he calls his "fantastic stroke of fortune". In 1982, the Falklands were invaded and a taskforce dispatched, and Hastings became "absolutely obsessive about wanting to go, even though I had given up that kind of foreign corresponding some years before, after the fall of Saigon. And I believed that if I could go, I could do something that would be very important, to me". He travelled to the Falklands as the Standard 's correspondent, but he was also the most experienced print journalist, so his copy was often reproduced in other newspapers. One act, however, made him part of the story itself: "I'll never forget looking up the road from the British lines in Port Stanley on the last day of the war and thinking, if I can walk up that road and get there first and survive and not get shot, I can bore everybody to death for the next 20 years talking about it." It was an act of typical bravado, driven, he freely admits, by "pure, naked ambition", and he is equally sure that without it, "I don't think for a moment I would have become editor of the Daily Telegraph or editor of the Evening Standard ".

One of the few things he misses now is spare time to write those "long-researched" books. "Most people engaged simply in journalism have a moment of self-disgust at some point, when they wonder whether what they are doing is really worth the candle because of its utterly ephemeral nature.

"For God's sake, how many editors are remembered for five minutes after they have stopped editing? And rightly so. But you can kid yourself that writing books gives one a millisecond longer in people's recollections. I get enormous pleasure, when about once a month I get a letter from a reader about something I wrote in a book 20 years ago."

He has to satisfy his literary energies by taking an active interest in the Standard 's books pages, which, he says, "have always tended to operate a notch above the intellectual level of the rest of the paper. I enormously admire the way that David Sexton [the literary editor] has maintained that tradition, as AN Wilson did before him. I'm always poking around there, and I think one of the things David probably finds, or all literary editors who work for me have found a considerable strain, is that I rely on them to help me with my literary education. I try and make sure that they put on my desk anything they think I ought to read."

He knows that people don't expect "anyone who can admit that he enjoys the novels of GA Henty" to be a reader of Proust, but it seems entirely in character for the man who, while sheltering behind a boulder during the Yom Kippur War, got out his copy of Middlemarch.

fields.headline: The Last Sonnet About Slavery
fields.trailText:
Put your hand on my shoulder, dear
mistress.
Hands as delicate should not hang in the air...
fields.body:
Put your hand on my shoulder, dear
mistress.
Hands as delicate should not hang in the air
But find ample places to pose and
rest.
And since my shoulders, my head, the hair
In it, all belong to you, let those hands
Settle anywhere on me, but do not let
them float
Aimlessly, nor be idle, nor stand
Out as if they had no greater goal.
Hands that don't know the scrubbing
brush,
Or weight of any thing, other than a
necklace
Or dress, stocking or shift that they adjust
Are not hands, but butterflies on a leash.
Let them wave and dart if you must, but
please,
When they settle, let their good luck fall on me.

webTitle: On Green Dolphin Street by Sebastian Faulks

fields.headline: On Green Dolphin Street by Sebastian Faulks
fields.standfirst:
(Hutchinson, £16.99)
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at a discount at BOL
fields.trailText: Embassy wife and US hack develop their own special relationship, but choose not to come in from the cold
fields.body:
Charlie van der Linden looked at his empty Martini. His hands were still shaking. "Time for a Scotch." The last party of the 50s in DC was in full swing.

"Meet Frank Renzo," Charlie said to his wife, Mary. "He's a reporter from New York." Mary smiled and went upstairs to watch her children as they lay sleeping. "I really am the happiest woman in the world," she thought.

A few days later the phone rang. It was Frank. "I'm writing a feature on embassy life. I'd like to take you to lunch."

"I'll need to check," Mary countered.

"If ever you're in New York, I'd be happy to show you round," Frank announced casually over a coffee.

It had been the most amazing three days in Manhattan. "Check out Kind of Blue," smoothed Frank.

"Nice," Mary replied. She hesitated. "You are the most remarkable man."

"I love you, too," he answered as their lips met. "We mustn't," she sighed, pressing herself tighter to him.

"You're right," he groaned, cupping her breasts in his hands.

"Donchew worra bout me," slurred Charlie, as he washed down a fistful of barbiturates and Tylenol with a half-bottle of Scotch.

"I've got bad news," said Frank, pulling Mary close. "John Coltrane's split from Miles Davis. Oh, and I'm not going to be able to see you so often. I've been put on the Kennedy election campaign trail."

"I won't be able to see you for a while, either," she replied, her eyes moistening. "My mother's dying of cancer, and I must fly back to London to be with her."

At least the separation will give us plenty of pages to reflect on their angst.

"I'm being posted to Moscow to brief the embassy on the new president," said Charlie, his whole body trembling.

"Bad news, Mrs van der Linden," barked a Foreign Office official. "Your husband's had a breakdown. We need you to bring him back from Moscow."

"I love you so much, Charlie," Mary cried, as her husband came out of the psychiatric hospital.

"You'd better go back to Washington to close up the house," he replied.

"I love you so much, Frank, I'll stay in the US." This was even tougher than Guadalcanal. "I love you, too," he said. "But you must go back to London."

"I've changed my mind," he sobbed, as her plane flew overhead.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested...

fields.headline: Political decisions
fields.standfirst: John Dugdale takes a look at The Letters of Kingsley Amis edited by Zachary Leader, and Boris Yeltsin's Midnight Diaries
fields.trailText: John Dugdale takes a look at The Letters of Kingsley Amis edited by Zachary Leader, and Boris Yeltsin's Midnight Diaries
fields.body:
The Letters of Kingsley Amis
ed Zachary Leader
(HarperCollins, £14.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Tracing Amis's political journey from wartime communist to ultra-Thatcherite, this collection of correspondence includes notes to his then mistress (later second wife) Elizabeth Jane Howard and a stiff missive to his first wife's lover. But it's dominated by letters to Philip Larkin, which mix literary gossip, pervy pinings for pin-ups and schoolgirls and surprisingly Joycean verbal improvisations inspired by the jazz they both loved. Like Alan Clark's diaries, they're in turn dazzling, obnoxious, touching, puerile and hilarious - and liable to induce such explosions of laughter that reading them in public is not advisable.

Midnight Diaries
Boris Yeltsin
(Phoenix, £8.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Not diaries, despite the title, but memoirs based on journals and preserving much of their informality, from Yeltsin's re-election in 1996 to the handover to Putin - a not uneventful period including the second Chechen war, the Kosovo crisis, the 1998 financial crash, sex and sleaze scandals, threatened impeachment and quintuple heart surgery. By topping and tailing the book with the seemingly sure-footed choice of Putin as successor, Yeltsin does his best to suggest he spent these five years working purposively towards a single end, but the chaotic comings and goings of premiers tell a different story.

webTitle: Pick of the week: The Smiling School for Calvinists by Bill Duncan

fields.headline: The Smiling School for Calvinists by Bill Duncan
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  finds magic in kelp harvests and talking dogs
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard finds magic in kelp harvests and talking dogs
fields.body:
The Smiling School for Calvinists
Bill Duncan
(Bloomsbury, £9.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The first epigraph to this collection of short stories purports to be taken from an 1856 book called Northern Jaunts by Dr Alexander Jamieson, and gives you a flavour of what to expect from the book. We read of a Broughty Ferry kelp harvester: "Decades of exposure to sea and weather had created upon his left temple a ridge of small but perfectly formed barnacles. This singular decoration he displayed with a quiet pride and nursed in an affectionate and proprietary fashion with regular dousings of Tay seawater . . ." This took me in for a while, until I began to wonder whether anyone ever harvested kelp. (Actually, they still do.)

These stories play with one's credulity at first, in the manner of the best magical realist fiction. Set around Broughty Ferry, a fishing village which abuts the high-rise outskirts of Dundee, the collection engineers productive clashes between contemporary urban and rural blight. One character is seen at home, a place full of "oars, creels, seal traps, harpoons and flensing knives . . . blubber-curing racks . . . Through the smoky glow of the whale-oil lamp, the Mathematician could discern the smiling, relaxed figure of Boat Rab, reclining in his rowing boat, smoking a pipeful of kelp." There is more kelp in this collection than in any I can recall reviewing, as well as conversations like this one, about the best way to flay a seal: "'Personally, eh wid aye mak the wan incision wi a flensin knife jist below the snout, an peel the skin off in twa equal sections . . .'

'Naw. That's fine fur a porpoise, but fur a seal what's required is a twa-centimetre groove cut roond the neck wi a freshly honed halibut gaff, an the hail skin comes aff in a wanner, flippers an aa.'" The fact that this conversation is alleged to take place between Boat Rab and his supernaturally gifted dog should make you realise that this isn't a book which seriously proposes seal-skinning as a diversion or a way of life.

One never knows much about Boat Rab, or the Mathematician, or any of the other colourfully named characters who prop up the bar of the Flenser's Arms and flit in and out of these deadpan, incredible stories. "The Maist Ignorant Man in the World", "The One-Man Crowd", "The Submarine Commander", "Big Sheila" - they're all aspects of Duncan's bizarre imagination. The poet Don Paterson, quoted on the jacket, is right in comparing Duncan to Borges. Borges is more about ideas than characters, and in Duncan's book there is as much individuality in the array of dangerous pets kept by the tower-block inhabitants as there is in the inhabitants themselves. His characters' vagueness doesn't prevent Duncan from making good use of one of his key ingredients, a tender fascination with the recklessness of childhood - the awful cat-torturings, clandestine firework launches and lift-shaft pranks his narrators fondly recall. Interleaved with stories of bizarre animals meeting unlikely ends are touching evocations of the moment in adolescence when boys tremble between vandalism and love. His capacity for gross and surreal comedy, as well as touching yet honest evocations of teenage years, shows that Duncan should be capable of something great. In the meantime, this collection will serve very nicely indeed as an introduction.
fields.bodyText: The Smiling School for Calvinists Bill Duncan (Bloomsbury, £9.99) Buy it at a discount at BOL The first epigraph to this collection of short stories purports to be taken from an 1856 book called Northern Jaunts by Dr Alexander Jamieson, and gives you a flavour of what to expect from the book. We read of a Broughty Ferry kelp harvester: "Decades of exposure to sea and weather had created upon his left temple a ridge of small but perfectly formed barnacles. This singular decoration he displayed with a quiet pride and nursed in an affectionate and proprietary fashion with regular dousings of Tay seawater . . ." This took me in for a while, until I began to wonder whether anyone ever harvested kelp. (Actually, they still do.) These stories play with one's credulity at first, in the manner of the best magical realist fiction. Set around Broughty Ferry, a fishing village which abuts the high-rise outskirts of Dundee, the collection engineers productive clashes between contemporary urban and rural blight. One character is seen at home, a place full of "oars, creels, seal traps, harpoons and flensing knives . . . blubber-curing racks . . . Through the smoky glow of the whale-oil lamp, the Mathematician could discern the smiling, relaxed figure of Boat Rab, reclining in his rowing boat, smoking a pipeful of kelp." 'Naw. That's fine fur a porpoise, but fur a seal what's required is a twa-centimetre groove cut roond the neck wi a freshly honed halibut gaff, an the hail skin comes aff in a wanner, flippers an aa.'" fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.standfirst: Maxim Jakubowski investigates The Falls by Ian Rankin, Dialogues of the Dead by Reginald Hill, A Sea of Troubles by Donna Leon, and Candyland by Evan Hunter and Ed McBain
fields.trailText: Maxim Jakubowski investigates The Falls by Ian Rankin, Dialogues of the Dead by Reginald Hill, A Sea of Troubles by Donna Leon, and Candyland by Evan Hunter and Ed McBain
fields.body:
In Ian Rankin's 12th Inspector Rebus novel, The Falls (Orion, £16.99), the murder of an Edinburgh art history student leads the hapless cop, now saddled with a new superior intolerant of his drinking and unconventional methods, on a trail of internet mischief and the customary riddles of the past in which the solution to today's criminal woes is buried. Rankin masterfully pulls his fascinating plot together, and his sense of place casts a powerful shadow on this subtle tale of the recurrence of evil. The unopposed champion of the British police procedural field.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Reginald Hill's Dialogues of the Dead (HarperCollins, £16.99), the latest outing for cantankerous Dalziel and suave Pascoe, also comes up trumps with a witty demonstration of wordplay by the Yorkshire cop duo. A man drowns, another dies in a motorcycle crash; seemingly two accidents, but entries to a story competition in a local newspaper indicate otherwise. Soon the pair are playing catch-up with a sinister opponent known only as the Wordman. Hill, tongue firmly in cheek, spins clever variations on the traditional cop thriller and never ceases to surprise, even on the 17th time around the block with his inimitable characters.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Donna Leon's Commissario Guido Brunetti finds himself in A Sea of Troubles (Heinemann, £15.99) when he unsettles the peace of mind of the closely knit island community of Palestrina, a stretch of sand separating the Venetian lagoon from the Adriatic. Two clam fishermen have died in a suspicious explosion and outsiders are decidedly unwelcome; Brunetti is drawn into a morass of crooked local politics, pollution and secrets. The hero is a tenacious underdog and his journey through Italian venality and administrative woes is always rewarding.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Candyland (Orion, £16.99) is a "collaboration" between two of crime writing's biggest names, psychological thriller writer Evan Hunter and the author of the classic 87th Precinct cop sagas Ed McBain - the joke being that they are one and the same man. Steady husband and father Benjamin Thorpe is also a man obsessed: alone in New York, he spends an empty night searching for female companionship. A teenage hooker whose path had crossed Thorpe's during the night is found murdered in an alley the next day; enter McBain and the cops for a painstaking investigation in sharp contrast to the earlier leisurely unfolding of plot and dissection of Thorpe's troubled soul. An ingenious way for Hunter/McBain to demonstrate both sides of his storytelling talents - and the collaborators, presumably, never argued.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

fields.headline: Opium and erotica
fields.standfirst: Isobel Montgomery looks at The Merciful Women by Federico Andahazi, Jitterbug Perfume by Tom Robbins, The Way People Run by Christopher Tilghman, and Our Dancing Days by Lucy English
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery looks at The Merciful Women by Federico Andahazi, Jitterbug Perfume by Tom Robbins, The Way People Run by Christopher Tilghman, and Our Dancing Days by Lucy English
fields.body:
The Merciful Women
Federico Andahazi
(Black Swan, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A flickering candle seen across an angry lake, storm clouds like cathedrals (Gothic, of course), and the arrival of a pair of English poets. We know how Byron, Shelley, his wife Mary and her step-sister Claire Clairmont sat out that miserable July in 1816, but what of John William Polidori, Byron's secretary, who stumbles after them? Andahazi introduces Pollydolly to Annette Legrand, who proposes a simple exchange: she will write a novel to rival Mary Shelley's Frankenstein, he provides her with a vital fluid. The result of Andahazi's bargain plunges easily into the Romantic sensibility, while holding fast to a modern wit.

Jitterbug Perfume
Tom Robbins
(No Exit, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This is the sort of pseudo-mystical, intricate novel that one intense adolescent slips to another as a kinship offering. It's a fictionalised Golden Bough with sub-plots set in a Paris perfume manufacturer's, a mysterious New Orleans apothecary's and a Seattle restaurant. The unifying threads that pull this sprawling saga together are beetroot, Robbins's sassy one-liners, the search for immortality, a blue glass bottle, and a convoluted treatise on perfume and desire. Robbins has an enviable gift for creating an ever-entertaining read that teasingly promises far more insight than it reveals.

The Way People Run
Christopher Tilghman
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The last two in this collection have made it into yearbooks of the "best American short-stories"; it's not hard to see why. Here men return home determined to communicate, but fall, as usual, for diversionary tactics, or flounder in empty phrases. The tone of the title story is set by "an apple pie, scarred by the removal of a single triangle, revolving in solitary repetition". Closely observed small-town survivors and big city refugees are Tilghman's familiar protagonists in this collection about that moment when standing, not running, is the only option left. The real heroes, though, are Tilghman's quietly observed, unforgiving landscapes.

Our Dancing Days
Lucy English
(Fourth Estate, £5.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

It is not so much events that trip English up, as their absence. Tessa and Deedee are two stoned hippy chicks living in 60s London, when their friend Don inherits a chunk of east Anglia. New decade, new ideas, so why not form a commune? We know that Tessa survives it all, because we see her three decades on, doing watercolours of the old place for a coffee table book, and we know a death, a disappearance and a divorce did for idealism. Rewind and replay. Sex, gardening, the personal politics of the 70s ought to make good subjects, but Tessa is an infuriatingly unreflective narrator.

webTitle: Thirty-three Years in the Trenches: Memoirs of a Sussex Working Man, by Peter Richards and Nick Osmond

fields.headline: Thirty-three Years in the Trenches: Memoirs of a Sussex Working Man, by Peter Richards and Nick Osmond
fields.trailText: Oral history is tricky to get right - it can so easily be banal or, at least, so specialised as to be of interest only to the most local of local history societies
fields.body:
(White Cockade Publishing, £8.99)

Oral history is tricky to get right - it can so easily be banal or, at least, so specialised as to be of interest only to the most local of local his tory societies. Alternatively, it can seem patronising, contrived. But here's a find. Peter Richards was a a gas "ganger", got married, had kids. He is tetchy, shrewd, and candid about his shortcomings (which include occasionally punching his wife). Most unusually, he manages to articulate the rages of inarticulacy, which, if you think about it, is no small tribute to the trust and understanding between Richards and his recordist, Nick Osmond.

webTitle: Reviews: Hooky Gear by Nick Barlay and Off Duty by Victor Headley

fields.headline: I is a gangsta
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  gets herself set for a contract killing with Hooky Gear by Nick Barlay and Off Duty by Victor Headley
fields.trailText: Alex Clark gets herself set for a contract killing with Hooky Gear by Nick Barlay and Off Duty by Victor Headley
fields.body:
Hooky Gear
Nick Barlay
309pp, Sceptre, £10.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Off Duty
Victor Headley
323pp, Hodder & Stoughton, £10.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

As exercises in noir urban thrillers pile up around us, perhaps the most rigorous challenge for practitioners of this proliferating, baggy genre is to provide their work with a protective coating - to arm it against cliché, pastiche, self-parody and the subtle lure of bathos. Otherwise, what do you get? Moody cat-and-mouse exchanges between cons and police, rain-sodden council estates, endless dull accounts of duller drug deals enlivened by gaudy splashes of comic-book violence. In other words, a ready-made landscape that soon becomes as cosy and trite as any village green or suburban semi.

For Nick Barlay, whose "loose people of a loose trilogy" make their final appearance in Hooky Gear , one senses that the fear of falling into cliché is a major motivation. Rarely does one read writing so inventive, yet so tensed against habituation; so exuberant, but so obsessed with the business of conveying depression, hopelessness and failure. As this trilogy has progressed, one has been aware of Barlay's talent both enlarging and relaxing, and with his finale, the riskiest of all three in terms of its style, one sees a writer really coming into his own.

"Look at the futality [sic] of your situation," a mate urges J, the novel's dubious hero, and that about sums up what the reader is forced to do throughout. From the moment J and his accomplice Duane are interrupted in the middle of a burglary on the Haringey Ladder, we're aware that things are not going well on the "High Road to the Big Coin". By the time J has been turned over to the police by his wife Monica, abandoned by Uncle, the shadowy Mr Big of the piece, and spent nine months in Wormwood Scrubs, we've cottoned on to the fact that they're going to get worse; and when a newly freed J begins to mount his convoluted revenge on all his betrayers, we realise that "worse" might be very bad indeed.

What elevates Barlay from the crowds of undistinguished caper-writers is an extraordinary facility for creating and sustaining individual voices; in Crumple Zone for realising the edgy anxieties of teacher Cee Harper, and here for conveying the swaggering anecdotage and the blunted intelligence of J. "Understand I got a wife an kids an in a way a whole empire and I'm a king an hittin 30 years," he tells us. "But sometime a king must prove all over how he got to be a king." So J is delivered to us a self-mythologising petty criminal, a garrulous domestic imperialist.

The obvious fact is that J isn't a king - nor even a prince in Uncle's bloodthirsty, oblique kingdom. He's a pawn, albeit a pawn with a nice sense of interior décor, the hooky gear of the title: "My antiques - hooky; carpet - hooky; domestic appliances - hooky; toys an childrenwear - hooky; duvets an general beddin - hooky. Etc. etc. etc. an so forth. Well I got connections an that's how it is wha can I say? You dont need no intelligence to act."

With an entire narrative delivered in this unpunctuated, hardcore demotic, it takes great skill to ensure that it never becomes gimmicky or irritating. Conversely, its energy requires of the reader an immense concentration, an alertness to the gaps between what appears to be being said and what is actually going on, and a pleasurable surrender to an unexpected form of articulacy. With its broken-down sentences, free-flowing dialogue and apparent formlessness, this is a brilliantly literary novel, utterly absorbed by the connections between experience and expression, and between language and morality. As the tale trundles on to its downbeat end ing, via crosses and double-crosses at Tilbury Docks, we are left in little doubt as to the unrecuperable sadnesses of J's life, standing in the tattered ruins of his existence.

Barlay started his writing career at the X Press, the small independent firm which was also responsible for first publishing Victor Headley. Barlay and Headley have both moved on to the large grazing pastures offered by bigger corporations, a change that Headley makes a curious deal out of in the afterword to his new novel, Off Duty . The X Press, he claims, encouraged him to "write three 'Yardie' novels a year, get paid and don't worry about the rest!" The reverse logic of moving to a larger publisher in order to ensure greater creative freedom is somewhat perplexing, and indeed, Off Duty doesn't immediately appear to break new ground.

What we are given is a lusty thriller split between Kingston, Jamaica, in the early 1980s, when the connections between politics and gangster politicking saw a speedy escalation in violence and turf warfare, and London in the mid-1990s, to where many of the protagonists have relocated. Headley's story involves the efforts of a Jamaican detective, Carlton Nash, to track down the killers of his former boss and brother-in-law Rico Glenford, whom we see gunned down on a London street at the start of the novel.

The plot's ingredients are promising: a narrator who has been on both sides of the law and now finds himself frustratingly sidelined by his temporary residence in an alien country; an intriguing back story, thickened with semi-dormant antagonisms and collusions; and a straight- forward murder mystery. But although Headley remains committed to that plot - driving it forward by a combination of reve lations and blind alleys - Off Duty is let down by the slackness and inattention of its prose. A fatal fascination with the exclamation mark, clunking clichés and contrived scene-setting all make this a peculiarly bloodless affair, its potentially forceful themes of corruption and redemption never quite given the air they need. Neither Nash nor Glenford are strong enough characters to carry a whole novel; J, on the other hand - well, we could have an entire trilogy about him.

fields.headline: Word to the wise
fields.trailText: It's a case of third time lucky for the Word, London's beleaguered literary festival
fields.body:
 It's a case of third time lucky for the Word, London's beleaguered literary festival. After a poor first two years, its organisers have come up with an International Writers season, which will run from October to December, rather than a concentrated series of events. Writers will appear on a weekly basis at the Gielgud Theatre, with the Word director Peter Florence explaining that "what London audiences want is megastars". Whether or not the world of books will have anything to follow the Gielgud's current bill of fare - Amanda Donohoe stripping off in The Graduate - remains to be seen.

 An eagle-eyed reader copies the Loafer in on a letter to Bloomsbury, in which she queries an entry in their recent book Lost Classics. Sybille Bedford, we hear, "published her remarkable autobiographical novel, Jigsaw, when she was seventy-eight, a few years before her death." Au contraire, our reader retorts, Bedford is alive and well and living in Chelsea. Slapped wrists for the Bloomsbury fact-checkers, and a bunch of flowers for Ms Bedford, one hopes.

 Novelist Tibor Fischer calls in with a vignette from the writer's life, which is not, as it turns out, all Captain Corelli and Bridget Jones. Fischer's New Year celebrations were enlivened this year by the arrival of a cheque from The Wylie Agency, who used to represent him. The dosh was for the renewal of a film option for his novel The Collector Collector, but appeared, on closer inspection, to fall somewhat short of expectations. The reason? The legendarily generous Jackal had paid 20% to Fischer's old publishers Polygon in error and promised to embark on a programme of debt recovery. Five months on, and Fischer is still out of pocket; the Loafer is planning emergency food parcels forthwith.

 Two members of the Guardian books department are in receipt of an interesting invitation to celebrate Jonathan Rice's book One Hundred Lord's Tests. The event will take place at Lord's itself, courtesy of the MCC. Our invitees feel even luckier given that they are both women - not that, we understand, they will be given access to the Long Room. Who knows what guerrilla activities the uppity little misses will get up to, though?

Writers will appear on a weekly basis at the Gielgud Theatre, with the Word director Peter Florence explaining that "what London audiences want is megastars". Whether or not the world of books will have anything to follow the Gielgud's current bill of fare - Amanda Donohoe stripping off in The Graduate - remains to be seen.  An eagle-eyed reader copies the Loafer in on a letter to Bloomsbury, in which she queries an entry in their recent book Lost Classics. Sybille Bedford, we hear, "published her remarkable autobiographical novel, Jigsaw, when she was seventy-eight, a few years before her death." Au contraire, our reader retorts, Bedford is alive and well and living in Chelsea. Slapped wrists for the Bloomsbury fact-checkers, and a bunch of flowers for Ms Bedford, one hopes.  Novelist Tibor Fischer calls in with a vignette from the writer's life, which is not, as it turns out, all Captain Corelli and Bridget Jones. Fischer's New Year celebrations were enlivened this year by the arrival of a cheque from The Wylie Agency, who used to represent him. The dosh was for the renewal of a film option for his novel The Collector Collector, but appeared, on closer inspection, to fall somewhat short of expectations. The reason? The legendarily generous Jackal had paid 20% to Fischer's old publishers Polygon in error and promised to embark on a programme of debt recovery. Five months on, and Fischer is still out of pocket; the Loafer is planning emergency food parcels forthwith.  Two members of the Guardian books department are in receipt of an interesting invitation to celebrate Jonathan Rice's book One Hundred Lord's Tests. The event will take place at Lord's itself, courtesy of the MCC. Our invitees feel even luckier given that they are both women - not that, we understand, they will be given access to the Long Room. Who knows what guerrilla activities the uppity little misses will get up to, though?

webTitle: Review: Landor's Tower by Iain Sinclair

fields.headline: A magus marooned
fields.standfirst: In Landor's Tower, Iain Sinclair has lost his magic, laments  Ian Penman
fields.trailText: In Landor's Tower, Iain Sinclair has lost his magic, laments Ian Penman
fields.body:
Landor's Tower
Iain Sinclair
345pp, Granta, £15.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Iain Sinclair writes ghost stories, of a sort: whatever his subject, there is always a low, persistent note of something mourned, spectral, lost. Sinclair's early work - the parklife grimoire of Lud Heat , the genre-defying bestiary of White Chappell, Scarlet Tracings - is haunted by the death of the 60s dream: all it could have been, and failed to secure. In the 70s, running his own Albion Press, Sinclair resisted the easy lure of beanbag metaphysics and found thornier corridors to crawl. He risked derisive laughter with his talk of star charts over Greenwich and Osiris reborn in Limehouse, so got his retaliation in first, wisping a fine skein of self-mockery around his wilder theories. But there was no denying the ritual charge: when you read these books, you "knew" you had been somewhere.

It is important to state just how key Sinclair was for many of us, at a certain point in the 80s, as a prickly alternative to the dully polished hegemony of Amis, Barnes et al. A true Anglo revelation: the sentences jumped like Ellroy or Vollmann, but the patrimony was Blake, Dee, De Quincey. Sinclair texts were like internet sites before the fact, full of links for the interested reader to follow. (I wasn't the only one to trace the spinal curvature of Hawksmoor's churches, Lud Heat in one hand, A-Z in the other.) Flip over Sinclair Magus and you found a taxonomist: from Lud Heat to Lights Out For The Territory , he built up an alt.rolodex of contemporary mystics and mummers. He may have masked his journalist heart behind a gibbous saloon-bar persona - quizzical, sarcastic, bamboozled - but Iain was strolling the avant-garde perimeter before Charles Saatchi knew what a "concept" was. No one else did such a good job of keeping in touch with the margins. It's not overstating the case to say that Sinclair kept the hopes of a certain culture alive.

Which makes the task of navigating his new work all the more depressing. Landor's Tower is being pushed as the big follow-up to Lights Out For The Territory - his "bestselling" essay-suite on subcult London - and this alone seems to have put him on the defensive. Landor's Tower is all paranoid asides and sighing disclaimers which, taken together, spell out a weary "wish I wasn't here". Sinclair is strung out on an insanely self-pitying tic: his Narrator can't eat breakfast or pick up a paperback without stepping back to comment on how boring and distasteful it is to have to turn such things into literature. Landor's Tower is less a novel than a series of manic-depressive Post-It notes from the author to himself, reminders never to do this again.

Plot? The boorish Narrator has been commissioned to do a book on obscure mystic Walter Savage Landor (which hardly squares with Sinclair's bleak view of a purely profit-based books world). On his grudging travels, he meets a dark and deeply allegorical woman called Prudence. There's a sexual charge here which might have taken, if the narrative weren't riven with all this pratfall stuff, unfunny funny business about books and dogs and dope. The only thing Sinclair seems truly to engage with as a topic is Hay-on-Wye, which is set up, not once but an unbelievable and unendurable twice, for the topographical equivalent of character assassination. Sinclair ends up lost in the kind of prissy book-world "goss" he previously held in contempt, settling such petty in-house scores that it will signify only to half-a-dozen subcult bores. It baffles me why Sinclair cares about this stuff, or thinks that we will.

Narrative urgency might have overridden the more extreme unlikelihoods (beneficent publishers? aesthete policemen?), but Sinclair never picks a fever dream to follow and Landor's Tower fails to forge a self-contained Gothic symmetry. He can hardly bear to be on the same page as half his characters - conspiracy fruits and service-station nuts who barely open their mouths before being consigned to a cartoon oblivion consonant with their cartoon names. The narrative is measured in miles from home; he itches to be back in London. What there is of a plot, he's done better before: secret-state shadowplay was the icily humorous domain of Radon Daughters while the bookdealers-go-wild-in-the-country thing was nailed, definitively, in White Chappell .

This is a work of palpable disenchantment; magical realism, only without the magic. The spell hasn't taken: the evoked demons blank the Magus. Sinclair is tapping the table among all this babble, trying to relocate his own lost voice. There is a hint of that voice in the book's final section, where things finally feel innate rather than forced. Here are the only passages worthy of other Sinclair books: a melancholy meditation on family inheritance, and a vivid and genuinely moving portrait of a utopian community felled by the changing cultural seasons. Sinclair's sentences finally gain a recognisable shape and force; images perplex and startle; the text's heart jumps into meaty life. You want to know more about this Sinclair, his Wales, his "interior" journey, its fearful darkness standing out against the flippancy and spite of the most part. You want to know more because finally, it seems, so does he.

He is also on the money about the move west: various romancers slouching towards Bristol, the Channel, Wales. A return to soil magick, sea dreams, golden dawns; rendered by the Sinclair of old, this western noir could have shone like a dark midnight sun. Here, transcribed as if by a peculiarly bitchy and self-alienated amanuensis, it reads like any other work of London hi-lit snobbery. Which is not the Sinclair I know, or read, or want to read. Sinclair Magus, please return.

webTitle: Mid-table respectability is lost on the Premiership

fields.headline: Mid-table respectability is lost on the Premiership
fields.trailText: In the Premiership, it seems, there is no longer any such thing as middle-class, mid-table respectability. Either a team is mixing in high society or it is panhandling on skid row.
fields.body:
Coventry City's probable departure from the Premiership must surely send a chill of apprehension through those finishing just above them. If the great survivors can no longer hang on, then what chance will there be next time for others of limited means who suspect even now that they are in for another season of toil and tears.

Everton are not about to break the British transfer record this summer and nor are Derby County, although with Middlesbrough one never knows. West Ham, for all Harry Redknapp's optimism, are still one short of the 40-point safety margin; 39 should be enough this time but they have still cut it fine.

And while 45 points were enough to keep Leicester City in fifth place at the beginning of March the subsequent loss of eight successive league games by Peter Taylor's side has left Filbert Street counting its pre-Christmas blessings.

In the Premiership, it seems, there is no longer any such thing as middle-class, mid-table respectability. Either a team is mixing in high society or it is panhandling on skid row.

When Coventry were promoted in 1967 they were a breath of fresh air. Their rebuilt stadium was a gleaming example of grounds to come (although sadly most did not come until after Hillsborough and the Taylor report). Jimmy Hill was a new breed of media-friendly, fan-focused football manager even if he did switch to television soon afterwards.

Above all Coventry confirmed the strength of English league football's drift away from its roots in the Lancashire industrial towns, the mines and shipyards of the north-east and the steel foundries of Sheffield - a process hastened by the earlier successes, in league and cup, of Ipswich Town and Norwich City.

This season the continued revival of Ipswich and their precocious challenge in the Premiership has struck a similar chord. And long may Southampton stay up for, if they were ever relegated, there would no longer be a first-class football presence south of London.

Yet it will be of little comfort to next season's relegation possibles to know that of the clubs coming up from the Nationwide at least two, Fulham and Blackburn Rovers, will enjoy the sort of financial backing that the Derbys, Southamptons, Leicesters and, yes, the Evertons can only dream about.

At Ewood Park Jack Walker's legacy should enable Graeme Souness to consolidate a Rovers team which must still have a few wrinkles left over from the halcyon days of the mid-90s. Fulham, bankrolled by Mohamed Al Fayed, can buy anything they want - apart, that is, from a British passport for the chairman.

Maybe money cannot buy success but, when it comes to staying up or going down, it can go a heck of a long way. Any chance Bradford City had of confounding the odds against them for a second time vanished when they had to start selling players they still needed.

Coventry's 34-year defiance of Isaac Newton's law has bucked a growing trend; they have usually sold more expensively than they have bought. Theirs has been a worthy innings and, if the worst happens at Villa Park this afternoon, the natural disappointment of their supporters should be mingled with feelings of exaltation for having stayed up so long.

Football, however, is not like that and at Highfield Road this season Gordon Strachan has been subjected to fist-in-the-face abuse by the sort of fan who leaves his brain at home.

It is to be hoped the Coventry board appreciate that Strachan represents their best chance of a quick return should the team be relegated. For all his touchline histrionics, the little Scot is one of the game's more profound thinkers, as much off the pitch as he was on it.

Coventry could do worse than follow the examples of Charlton, Sunderland and Ipswich, all of whom have kept faith with their managers after going down, all of whom have since returned to the Premiership and all of whom look like finishing in the top half now.

If darkness descends on Coventry this afternoon, they will be leaving the Premiership with a side of comparable strength to the one which on a sunny April afternoon in 1967 beat Wolverhampton Wanderers, who had won promotion with them, 3-1 at Highfield Road to win the Second Division championship.

The crowd that day was 51,455 and kids sat six deep around the running track. After the game a reporter asked Jimmy Hill if he thought a team containing such worthies as George Curtis, Ernie Machin, Bobby Gould, Mick Kearns and Dietmar Bruck could hack it in the First.

"I consider that an impertinent question," sniffed Jim and the last 34 years have proved him right, even if Coventry did set a trend the following season when they were a point away from going straight back whence they came.

Hill once suggested firing a sky-blue rocket every time his team scored but Birmingham air traffic control objected. Perhaps, if Coventry stay up now, Elmdon should beware low-flying pigs in a pastel shade.

webTitle: Sweatily drifting off with a monkey on my back

fields.headline: Sweatily drifting off with a monkey on my back
fields.trailText: Ron Manager: Ho ho I'm back! ... refreshed! ... on the ball! ... and contrary to rumour in the press ... I have not been at the Priory ...
fields.body:
Ho ho I'm back! ... refreshed! ... on the ball! ... and contrary to rumour in the press ... I have not been at the Priory ... Right ho! ... lets start with ... Ron's Where are they now? "Does anyone remember a well-groomed Swedish chap who turned up at every game for a couple of months?" ... ho ho! I wrote it myself actually ... well everyone else does don't they? ... but we don't see so much of Sven checking out the talent do we? .. hmm? ... maybe laying low after that dour tussle against Albania? ... tail between his legs? ... hmm?

... And another reader's letter! ... a postcard! ... from Barbados! ... er: "Halsa alla din, Sven och Nancy" ... eh?

Off to White Hart Lane to watch Hoddle's toddlers! ... Willem Korsten! ... just needs a bit of a push! ... "There's a player there waiting to get out" ... Good for Glenn! ... that'll boost the lad's confidence a bit! ... the very words Walter Winterbottom used to me ... still bursting with pride as he barged me out of the dressing-room doorway!

Anthony Gardner! ... already got the right attitude ... "Thou shalt not pass!" ... ho ho! ... always best to elaborate on that one Glenn! ... ask Kev. The Hoddle revolution's under way! Spurs 0 Villa 0 ... marvellous!

But football's not just about the final score ... hmm? ... if you see something that makes you chuckle or even brings a little tear to your eye... write to ... Ron's Nuggets! ... let's get 'em rolling!

Here's some pithy emails posted to "ronsmagicmoments@lodapith.com" this week!

Rev Spooner ... and his wife Rita write!: "Peter Reid on the bench - wondering how to mark Pahars" ... eh? ... well not for long ... a physical tussle against the Mackems? ... hmm? ... maybe caretaker boss Stuart Gray decided ... "Marian" didn't have the stomach for it! ... plumped for Le Tissier! ... another defeat for the Saints! ... Stuart's doing it his way ... "I don't feel that Glenn's a monkey on my back" ... at last! ... some common sense at the Dell!

The monkey on my back at Fulham was Jimmy Hill! ... oo-er ... I still wake in a cold sweat ... the feel of those nails digging in ... "Come on Ron ... Come on Ron" ... that prickly sensation ... the hair on his chinny-chin chin ... Ho ho ... "Who's afraid of the big bad wolf? ... er me actually ... hypnotherapy isn't it? ... Ho ho! ... marvellous! ... and if like myself you're thinking ... that big gold watch ... "You are feeling very very sleepy" ... zzzzzzz ... eh? ... where am I? ... er Yes! ... Ron's back! ... and he's firing on all cylinders ! ... Ho ho points and plugs isn't it hmm? ... er and I must stress I have not been anywhere near the Priory!

Down to the PFA Awards! ... time to chew the fat with all the er ... great and good! ... glum faces? ... marvellous!

Sir Alex! ... musing over the mighty Reds' European exit ... "We want to swing on a star" ... ho ho! ... carry moonbeams home in a jar? ... isn't it? ... would you rather be a pig? ... "Little pig ... little pig ... let me in" ... Help! ... Mummy!

Solskjaer! ... "Supersub"! ... sick of being typecast ... that's what you get for having the knack of coming off the bench to score timely goals - I was known for suddenly raising myself from my torpor to pop one in the last minute ... "Consolation Ron" ... hmm? ... Mrs Manager still calls me it! ... ho ho! ... marvellous!

Alan Shearer! ... er no ... He's beetled off to Colorado for knee surgery! ... marvellous ... isn't it? ... far cry from the magic sponge! ... modern surgery techniques ... hmm? ...how about ... Ron's through the Keyhole! ... "Whose tendons are these?" ... zzzzzz ... eh? ... ooooh ... er ... sorry ... I've always been a bit squeamish about the thought of blood ...

Sven! ... Blimey! ... presenting an award to Teddy Sheringham! ... ho ho! bet that's got Sven thinking ... Sheringham and Shearer? ... old heads hmm?

Right! ... time for ...Another Reader's letter! _ A Rev Spooner of ... er ... Chiswick? ... writes: "Ron, Sheringham's wit and Shearer's height ..." - er ... go away Mark ... you haven't quite got the hang of this have you?

Back to Ron's Nuggets ... It's an emotional old game sometimes hmm? Let's have another "magic moment" ... from Mr Royle of Manchester:

"McAllister morose 'celebrations' as his wonder-goal pushes Coventry closer to the brink" ... not so uncommon hmm? ... Denis Law's deft back-heel which sent the mighty Reds tumbling ... Ron Manager in the pomp of his twilight years! ... scoring the goal which condemned my first ever club to relegation ... the moment made doubly poignant by the fact that I'd only recently rejoined them on a free transfer ...

Ron dips his toe in the Nationwide

Pompey for the drop? ... far cry from West London for Graham Rix ... no place in the starting line-up for Crowe and Nightingale ho ho! ... a couple of birds on the bench? ... er better than one in the Bush! ... marvellous!

Fulham! ... the bubbly and the bunting! ... er ... not when the conductor of Mohammed's orchestra's around! ... Jean Tigana! ... nickname "La couverture humide"! ... Well the silverware is in the bag ... money is no object ... They're puttin' on the Ritz ... ho ho! ... Fred and Ginger isn't it? ... "polishing my white tie ... putting on my bed-pants" ...Top Hat! ... Officer Dibble ... ho ho! ... Come on Jean! ... one's not going to hurt you! ... marvellous!

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Prediction rewind: back to August again to recall the views of Terry Venables, who was confident that Chelsea would reap the benefits of managerial stability this season.
fields.body:
Prediction rewind: back to August again to recall the views of Terry Venables, who was confident that Chelsea would reap the benefits of managerial stability this season. "Chairman Ken Bates has been magnificent in his support of Vialli and that will continue until it becomes clear the Italian cannot take the club further forward," Tel wrote. Which turned out to be all of four weeks later. Marcello Lippi then clarified Vialli's future: "He will stay away from the game for a few months and then he will return. It will be with a big club. I do not believe he would be interested in anything else. And he will only do that in Italy." Almost right on all counts.

Unlucky Ian Pearce suffered concussion in West Ham's game at Manchester City last week. The Hammers' doctor realised something was seriously wrong when Pearce displayed symptoms of grotesque hallucinations. "Initially he seemed all right," Ges Steinbergs said. "But then he said he thought we were winning 3-0."

An urgent memo reaches us from Charlton's Football in the Community scheme. "Following an incident yesterday where one of our coaches nearly ran over the first-team manager, Alan Curbishley, I have been informed that all coaches are now banned from driving into the training ground through the Sparrows Lane entrance." Presumably they mean the kind with wheels, rather than Mervyn Day or Keith Peacock.

More cheery news from the Valley is that the Swedish tenor Bjorn Arvidsson will make his annual appearance at the last game of the season against Liverpool. As well as Charlton's dreadful Valley Floyd Road (to the strains of Mull of Kintyre), Bjorn will perform You'll Never Walk Alone after fans sportingly voted two to one in favour of the Liverpool anthem.

The FA's publicity for the current Under-16 event claims it will "allow young players to sample a tournament atmosphere in a variety of top-class stadia". Perhaps the Wembley saga has affected our idea of what a top-class stadium looks like, but you can imagine the bewilderment felt by Europe's top teens when they found the promised classy venues included Harrogate's Wetherby Road, New Ferens Park in Durham and the prestigious South Leeds stadium.

Berkhamsted Town and Taunton Town have been preparing in different ways for tomorrow's FA Vase final at Villa Park. Demob-happy Graham Taylor popped down the road for the launch of the "Berko Sizzler", a gourmet pork sausage created to celebrate the Lilywhites' achievement. Taunton, on the other hand, have been gloomily thumbing the record books. Since 1974 they have been in 18 cup finals - Western League Cup (5), Alan Young Cup (2), Somerset Premier Cup (6), Western League Floodlit Cup (4), FA Vase (1) - and lost every one. Jenny Agutter, the Peacocks' most famous fan, cannot bear to watch the 19th time around, but has promised she will be wearing their claret and blue colours tomorrow.

webTitle: Hendrie looks up to a wiser future

fields.headline: Hendrie looks up to a wiser future
fields.trailText: St Mirren manager Tom Hendrie is the manager of the month for April and has been offered a five-year contract, despite the fact that his club are bottom of the Premier League.
fields.body:
The St Mirren manager Tom Hendrie is just off the telephone. He is already inquiring about possible signings for next season. Whether he pays Premier League wages or First Division, however, is a moot point. "If you don't start looking now and wait until the end of the season, you might miss out," he reasons. "Players and agents appreciate the situation we are in."

They currently sit bottom of the Premier League, although a win at lacklustre St Johnstone this afternoon would see them leapfrog Dundee United, who play tomorrow. Earlier this week St Mirren's refusal to give up without a fight was reflected in Hendrie's choice as manager of the month for April. Last week St Mirren collected their first away win of the season, at Dunfermline.

Just over two years ago Hendrie was a principal teacher of maths at a secondary school in East Lothian who had done little as a player but, as a part-time manager, had guided two clubs - Alloa Athletic and Berwick Rangers - to promotion. When St Mirren became his third promoted club at the end of last season, comparisons were being made with St Mirren's most famous managerial old boy, Alex Ferguson.

"We knew it would be a big step up from the First Division and it has been a chasm," says Hendrie. "Unlike Dunfermline [also promoted last season], we didn't have the money to splash out on new players.

"We knew we had a First Division squad, that it would take a certain number of games to get used to it and that some players would adjust quicker and better than others. It's a different type of football to win the First Division than to survive in the SPL. We are now a reasonably good SPL club. We would be a much better team next season if we stayed up."

Hendrie is supported by a chairman, Stewart Gilmour, with a refreshingly realistic perspective. "We have given Tom pea-shooters to take on howitzers, but we simply don't have the money," he says. "This board inherited massive debt when it took over three years ago. It has not been possible to give Tom the resources he deserves. Tom has been told if he wants a five-year contract starting now, he can have one."

Hendrie adds: "Going down to the First Division would require us to adjust again. The argument that we could regroup in the First Division and return stronger doesn't apply to St Mirren. I'm a better manager now than I was this time last year. I know exactly what needs to be done to the squad so it makes an impact. At the start of the season I didn't."

Colin Hendry will have the support of the Scottish Football Association in his appeal to Fifa against a six-match international ban imposed for an elbowing incident with a San Marino player during March.

The SPL has suspended next season's winter break to help get finished in time for the World Cup, which starts in South Korea on May 31, 2002.

webTitle: Bald fear of drop grips Smith the survivor

fields.headline: Bald fear of drop grips Smith the survivor
fields.trailText: A quick glance at the Premiership table would suggest that Derby, four points clear of Manchester City and five of Coventry City, should survive with something to spare. Yet look deeper, and the relegation issues become engulfed by a fascinating potential for late intrigue.
fields.body:
Jim Smith will have been a football manager next month for 32 years which, it could be pointed out, is longer than most people get for murder. It has been, as he puts it, a "bloody good innings" since those early days at Boston United where his job also entailed driving the team's coach and, before one cup tie, glueing on the seat numbers at their ground.

Yet it is not his style to practise self- indulgence and, as Derby County's durable old manager can testify, for every high point there is always a low lurking nearby. Like at Portsmouth, perhaps, where his reward for getting the club into the First Division play-offs and extending Liverpool to a replayed FA Cup semi-final was to be summoned by the board and asked how he would feel about taking "a sabbatical".

At Oxford, maybe, where the euphoria of successive promotions was tempered by the megalomaniac tendencies of Robert Maxwell, whose death he still struggles to believe was suicide. Or now, having re-established Derby among the top flight, to be consumed by the bilious fear that the Premiership is about to chew them up and spit them out.

A quick glance at the Premiership table would suggest that Derby, four points clear of Manchester City and five of Coventry City, should survive with something to spare. Yet look deeper, as Smith finds himself doing, and the relegation issues become engulfed by a fascinating potential for late intrigue.

While Derby must travel to Manchester United today, before hosting Ipswich on May 19, Coventry have a decidedly easier double-header at Aston Villa this afternoon followed by a home game against relegated Bradford.

Across at Maine Road, meanwhile, City's recent form has invigorated their hopes of survival before travelling to Ipswich on Monday and entertaining Chelsea in two weeks.

For Smith, it is football's form of purgatory. "You find yourself looking at the table, checking on all the different permutations. Can this team do that? What if this happens or what about a shock there?" he says.

"Sometimes you think to yourself: 'Yeah, we're going to be all right, the others are the ones really in the shit' and then other times you can see it going the other way, the worst-case scenario.

"It's constantly on your mind. People talk about restless nights but, to be honest, I'm tiring myself out thinking about it so much that I'm having no problems getting off to sleep. By the end of the day I'm usually worn out.

"What has been annoying is that the weather's been so bloody awful that I've hardly had a chance to relax. When I need to get away from things I normally get into the garden but it's been almost impossible this year."

Two more defeats and the suspicion persists he may have plenty more time for pruning the roses next season. Lionel Pickering, the Derby chairman, is hardly known for his tolerance and Smith is realistic enough to know that the murmurs of discontent around the city - one local radio station ran a newsflash in October saying he had been sacked - would be displaced by voluble dissent if they were to be demoted.

It is a prospect he does not want to entertain but one conversation with Pickering, at a time when the local phone-ins were crackling with caustic animosity, inspires hope. "Stick with it Jim," the chairman told him. "Because when you go, I go."

If all goes according to plan, Smith wants at least another year before relinquishing his duties, with his assistant Colin Todd being primed for the step up. For it to be taken out of his hands, at this stage of his nomadic career, would be a grubby way to bow out.

"I'm trying not to think about it that way, but every manager in this situation knows that, yes, there could be a final twist in the tale and the possibilities of what could happen if the wheels did come off.

"If the worst does happen, I would obviously have to sit down with the chairman and discuss what we wanted to do. But, for the moment, that's all been left in abeyance until the end of the season. We're trying to be positive rather than negative and I would certainly rather be in our position than in Manchester City's or Coventry's."

Nevertheless these are uneasy times. It has been a tempestuous season and, given Derby's predicament, the popular picture of Smith puffing an elephantine cigar could be the inspiration for a Hamlet advert.

In mitigation, the 60-year-old could argue that only Everton and Leeds have had a comparable injury list while only Southampton have spent less.

Yet Smith, an alumnus of the old school, is not one for rattling off convenient excuses. "The simple fact is that we have tossed away too many careless points, shot ourselves in the foot too many times and missed too many golden opportunities to get to 41 points and safety," he says.

Today, as he does every match day, Smith will take with him a handkerchief his father Jimmy gave him 42 years ago for good luck. He has read that Gordon Strachan has a "plan B" ready in case Coventry take the drop but he has not reached that stage yet. As he says: "There is only one plan . . . pray!"

fields.headline: O'Leary renews attack on 'sour' Arsenal
fields.trailText: The Leeds manager has reopened the conflict with his old club by repeating his charge that Arsenal are bad losers.
fields.body:
The Leeds manager David O'Leary might have chosen the eve of his return to Arsenal to smooth the ill-feeling that has built up between the two clubs. Instead the Irishman cranked up the animosity by repeating his charge that Arsenal are bad losers.

Relations between the sides have been strained since a stormy game at Elland Road in November. That match featured eight bookings (seven for Arsenal), a clash between Patrick Vieira and Olivier Dacourt for which Vieira was later punished by the Football Association, and bad blood between O'Leary and Robert Pires.

O'Leary has claimed since that 1-0 Leeds win that his former club can be "very sour" in defeat. He made his feelings clear again yesterday as he prepared to take on Arsenal this afternoon with a weakened side, resting players ahead of Tuesday's Champions League semi-final second leg in Valencia. "If we get beaten we will lose with good grace and not whinge," he said.

Pires's reaction to a Leeds defeat could be interesting. He was furious to see O'Leary blow kisses at him at Elland Road and had to be restrained from making his way towards the Leeds manager in the tunnel.

"We can go to Arsenal with our heads held high," O'Leary said. "There were no charges brought against anyone at Leeds that day, so we have nothing to be ashamed of."

O'Leary insisted that match had been "forgotten" and the slate "wiped clean", and his opposite number Arsene Wenger was careful not to be drawn into an argument. He too said the "minor incidents" of six months ago were long forgotten and he brushed aside O'Leary's accusations.

"I behave like I think it's right to behave. I'm here to win every game for Arsenal and when we lose I'm not happy," Wenger said.

Dave Watson ended his 15-year association with Everton yesterday when he accepted an offer from Tranmere Rovers to become their manager.

Watson, who is a coach at Everton, has signed a two-year deal to fill the void left by John Aldridge's resignation after a home defeat by Barnsley six weeks ago. Kevin Sheedy has been caretaker. Tranmere are being relegated to the Second Division for next season.

Middlesbrough are preparing another bid to take Benito Carbone to the Riverside in the summer. They failed with a £2.5m offer before the transfer deadline but Bradford City must unload Carbone because of his high wages.

fields.headline: Barnet brought to the brink
fields.trailText: The mother of all relegation battles reaches its climax in Hertfordshire and today's battle with Torquay is to avoid the worst drop of all.
fields.body:
Ten years ago Barnet announced their arrival in the Football League with a 7-4 home defeat by Crewe and life at Underhill has rarely been dull since. Eight managers have held the reins, threats of expulsion from the league have been overcome and the late chairman Stan Flashman even brawled with photographers. But even by those standards today's fare looks remarkable.

In Hertfordshire this afternoon unfolds the mother of all relegation battles. Barnet, 24th and bottom of the Third Division, take on Torquay, 23rd. Tonight one of them will no longer be a league club. Barnet need a win, Torquay a point. Little wonder Barnet's director of football John Still has given his players relaxation tapes. Impossible Dream they are entitled.

This, though, is more the unbearable nightmare. Not even a lorryful of aromatherapy oils and a team of masseurs could make relaxation an easy exercise. The Conference, which awaits the country's worst league side, is seen as football's equivalent of the Gulag.

It was 10 years ago yesterday that the then manager Barry Fry danced across the pitch at Fisher to embrace Flashman as Barnet, after several near misses, finally escaped the chill of non-league football. Returning from whence they came is a daunting prospect for the club, particularly as the league may not let them back up unless they find a new ground. Underhill does not meet the 6,000 capacity requirement and the dispensation Barnet have to stay while they seek a new site would no longer apply.

"I can't explain how it feels," says Barnet's longest-serving player Warren Goodhind. "It's the biggest game of the season. People might say, 'What about the FA Cup final?' But if you lose a final you know the next season you'll have another chance. We're playing for our careers. We're playing for the right to call ourselves professional footballers."

No one at Barnet can believe it has come to this. In November, amid great excitement, Still moved upstairs to make way for Tony Cottee. The former England striker's first home game as player-manager brought a 7-0 win over Blackpool and took Barnet to eighth. Talk was of making the play-offs for the third time in four seasons. Relegation seemed as likely as buying Rivaldo.

Yet by mid-March Cottee had resigned amid crumbling results (11 points from 19 matches) and dipping morale. A 3-2 defeat at Blackpool last Saturday - Barnet's 15th consecutive away defeat - left the club bottom for the first time. The chairman Tony Kleanthous had seen Cottee as the "final piece in the jigsaw" to win promotion. Instead everything fell apart.

"We had been very much a team," says Still, who is likely to move back upstairs and make way for a new manager. "If you broke it down, people might say, 'He's not the best player and he's not the finest'. But we were a good team, fit and organised. We had a saying: 'If they can't break our spirit, they can't beat us.'

"But that spirit and togetherness went completely. When I came back, I asked the players what they felt the problems were. They told me they thought they were lacking fitness and organisation. They didn't really feel they had been given the right coaching work, the right development work."

webTitle: Nailbiting for four, the big drop for one

fields.headline: Nailbiting for four, the big drop for one
fields.trailText: With the top two already drenched in champagne and play-off berths long since settled, four clubs wallowing near the foot of the First Division face a nail-biting final afternoon tomorrow.
fields.body:
With the top two already drenched in champagne and play-off berths long since settled, four clubs wallowing near the foot of the First Division face a nail-biting final afternoon tomorrow.

Grimsby and Huddersfield need a point for safety from tricky home games against Fulham and Birmingham while Crystal Palace and Portsmouth are level on points with each other, separated by the narrowest margin on goal difference.

Pompey, in the relegation zone for the first time all year and reeling from Wednesday's 4-2 home defeat by Palace, host mid-table Barnsley, who are likely to include three ex-Palace players in Neil Shipperley, Bruce Dyer and Kevin Miller. Palace, meanwhile, travel to Stockport.

"The scars from the Palace game will not heal for a long time," said the Portsmouth chairman Milan Mandaric, who has invested £22m in the club and stands to lose another £ ;6.5m if relegated. "They have cut me to my heart. Against Palace the players let everyone down and I felt betrayed. I was disgusted."

Portsmouth have gone nine games without success, a dire sequence stretching two months. Two years ago a worse run - 14 without a win under the management of Alan Ball, Bob McNab and finally Tony Pulis - ended with a 3-0 thumping of Barnsley.

Unless Pompey can boost their goal difference by two in relation to Palace, a win at Stockport will be enough to prevent Palace dropping out of the top two divisions for the first time since 1977.

Their caretaker manager Steve Kember was promoted from his role of chief scout last weekend to inspire that win at Fratton Park. "I hoped and dreamt it would be hunky-dory down there and I can't praise the boys enough for their performance," said Kember. "We've given ourselves a real chance but now's not the time for complacency. If we win, Portsmouth have got a lot to do. It's in our hands."

Of the three former Eagles much will depend upon Miller. The goalkeeper played 66 times for Palace before leaving the club - in administration and capping players' wages at the time - at the start of last season, threatening to strike to force his move to Oakwell.

Palace fans will be fretting more over the 32-year-old's last-day record. Two years ago, with QPR needing to win against Palace on the final Sunday to survive, he conceded six at Loftus Road. It was his last appearance for the club.

"We're obviously hoping the lads do us a favour, but in a way one of our former players already has," added Kember. "Lee Bradbury came out in the press on Wednesday saying he was going to send us down. We pinned the article to the wall in our dressing room to wind them up. It worked."

Grimsby appeared safe after wins against Watford and West Bromwich Albion but three successive defeats have left them teetering on the brink again with a visit from the champions doing little for frayed nerves. While relegation scraps are nothing new for their manager Lennie Lawrence, last-day drama is an unknown quantity for Huddersfield's Lou Macari.

"We have been battling like hell for so long now," he said. "If anyone has got the jitters, they'd better stop right now because it won't do anyone any good. We just need to go out there and do it one more time; that's all I'll be asking of them."
