webTitle: Coventry braced for the end of a miracle

fields.headline: Coventry braced for the end of a miracle
fields.trailText: Coventry have made many implausible last-minute escapes from relegation over the last 34 years, but a mood of resignation has settled finally over Highfield Road. Even victory at Villa Park today and against Bradford in a fortnight may not be enough to save them.
fields.body:
Coventry have made so many implausible last-minute escapes from relegation that even when the flood threatened to engulf them a couple of months ago, they insisted they were merely paddling.

Even before home defeat by Liverpool a week ago, which swept away their hopes of being masters of their own destiny, City still claimed to be waving, not drowning. It is easy to see why. The 34 years they have spent in the top flight have been a series of near-misses surrounded by the odd period of calm.

Yet now, knowing that even victory at Villa Park today and against Bradford in a fortnight may not save them, a mood of resignation has settled finally over Highfield Road.

Indeed, if Coventry were to save themselves, or rather be saved by the collapse of others, they would become a Steve McQueen among the great escapees, topping their 10 other last-day reprieves.

And after such a remarkably long stay in the top division, a record bettered only by Arsenal, Everton and Liverpool, it is staggering that this seminal moment in Coventry's history seems to be passing without a whiff of insurrection or even indignation: no demonstrations and precious few calls for the manager Gordon Strachan or chairman Bryan Richardson to pay with their jobs.

"There is a sense of reality in the dressing room, a sense that we've had a poor season and that we're favourites to be relegated," Strachan explains.

After becoming player-manager early in the 1996-97 season, he was the architect of one of Coventry's most famous escapes, when a 2-1 win at Tottenham on the final day, combined with a Wimbledon win over Sunderland, sent the Wearside club down.

But for sheer drama and irony, nothing can match the rescue act under Bobby Gould in the 1983-84 season when Mick Ferguson, on loan from relegation rivals Birmingham, scored the opener in a 2-1 win over Norwich on final day that sent his own club down.

Gould says: "We needed a big man up front and Mick fitted the bill. We got him for the final seven games and he scored in each of our three wins. John Hartson has done a similar job but they got him too late."

Gould understands what Strachan has been going through this week. "It's on your mind day and night, even when you get up to go to the loo. But before that Norwich match, I bumped into Mick Channon, who wasn't playing, and we had a couple of drinks together. He had lagers and I had a couple of Southern Comforts, which helped the nerves."

Despite the endless worrying and wondering where it went wrong, Strachan is keeping things in perspective. "This is a crisis for me but not the biggest in my life," he says. "I've never been relegated and I don't want to be the one to take Coventry down, but I was in a crisis at Dundee when we lost 6-1 to Queen of the South and the manager was giving me dog's abuse. You wonder if you can be a player or whether you should drop down and play for Arbroath.

"It was a crisis point for me when I left Manchester United to join Leeds and everyone said, 'not a bad career but now it's over'. Do you believe that or go on playing for another 10 years, like I did? They're test ing points in your life and it's how you handle them."

When the inquests begin into Coventry's malaise, a central talking point will be their inability to replace Robbie Keane and Gary McAllister, who both left last year. The club were powerless to resist a £13m offer from Internazionale for Keane or prevent McAllister leaving on a free transfer to Liverpool, and Richardson hopes the blame for relegation does not fall at his feet.

"I think the fans have become more realistic," he says. "They know how difficult it is for clubs on our budget to sustain a Premiership place and realise that we've given it our best shot by spending a lot of money over the past few years."

Richardson is already looking on the bright side of relegation. "If you come off the wheel, sometimes it can give you a chance to have a breather and say, 'let's take a different approach, bring the younger players on in place of the more experienced players who don't want to play in the First Division'."

Knowing relegation will strip them of £15m annual income, he and Strachan have decided that one of their goalkeepers, Sweden's Marcus Hedman or Chris Kirkland, will go. But they will not be cashing in on John Hartson and Craig Bellamy. They know if they do not return in the two years when they are supported by Premiership parachute payments, they could be gone longer than Captain Oates.

In today's pre-game speech, Strachan said he would like to replicate the inspiring dressing-room oratory of Dustin Hoffman in the film, Any Given Sunday. But instead he will just give the players some words from the "Scottish philosopher" Rab C Nesbitt, who would understand that even when you are lying in the gutter, you can still be looking at the stars.

Coventry's last day escapes

1968 At the end of their first season in the top flight, Coventry had to match Sheffield United's result on the final day to stay up. They drew 0-0 with Southampton while United lost 2-1 at home to Chelsea and were relegated.

1969 Coventry's season ended with a home draw to Liverpool on April 22, but Leicester had five games in hand and could still catch them. The Foxes, however, could win only two and were relegated after a 3-2 defeat at Old Trafford.

1977 The final relegation spot lay between Coventry, Sunderland and Bristol City. Coventry faced Bristol City, with the start delayed by 15 minutes. Once Sunderland had lost, both sides needed only to avoid defeat. A 2-2 draw ensued.

1981 Despite a draw at Nottingham Forest, Coventry could have been relegated had teams below them won. Results went their way and they finished 16th.

1984 Coventry finished 19th, one place off relegation, after coming from behind to beat Norwich 2-1. Robert Rosario could have sent them down but headed against the bar 10 minutes from time.

1985 Eight points behind Norwich with three games to play, Coventry won all three - beating the league champions Everton on the final day - to send the Canaries down.

1986 John Sillett took over with three games to go and won two of them. Would have gone down but for last-day win over QPR.

1992 At half-time on the final day Coventry were down, but Luton lost a lead at Notts County and City survived.

1996 Manchester City could have sent Coventry down but, believing themselves to be safe, they played out a 2-2 home draw with Liverpool. Bad move.

1997 Overturned odds of 1-9 on them being relegated, winning at Spurs on the final day of the season to survive. Kick-off again delayed by 15 minutes, but City avoided conceding the equaliser that would have sent them down.

webTitle: What you'll get in a payout

fields.headline: What you'll get in a payout
fields.standfirst: A top mutual has unveiled its shares giveaway. Rupert Jones looks at members' likely questions
fields.trailText: A top mutual has unveiled its shares giveaway. Rupert Jones looks at members' likely questions.
fields.body:
Almost a year to the day after announcing plans to demutualise and pay windfalls to members, Friends Provident this week finally unveiled full details of precisely who's getting what and when.

The company, founded by Quakers and now one of Britain's biggest mutual life insurers, intends to float on the stock market on July 9, triggering a multi-billion pound summer shares giveaway.

It is proposing to give all its 1.7m qualifying members a fixed handout of 200 shares each, which based on its own figures would be worth around £500. Just over a million of these people hold with-profits policies and they will also get a variable allocation of shares which could in theory range from just one to several thousand shares. Windfalls of several thousand pounds won't be uncommon.

The company sent out information packs to members this week. Here we answer some of the likely questions:

So how much will I get?

The share allocation statement being sent out will tell you how many shares you're getting. It will depend on what sort of member you are. If you're an eligible member of Friends Provident Life Office (see later) but your policy is not with-profits, you will get a fixed handout of 200 shares. These are likely to be worth between 225p and 270p each when it floats, so 200 shares would have a value of £450-£540.

If you're one of the 1.1m members with a with-profits policy (such as a pension plan or endowment) you will also get a variable handout of shares. How many you get will depend on the size of the policy and how long you have held it. For example, a man with a with-profits pension who was 40 when he took it out and has paid in £50 a month over the past 15 years is likely to receive a total of 1,700 shares with an estimated value of around £4,207. An endowment policy-holder who was 30 when it was taken out and has paid in £50 a month for 20 years could expect 2,650 shares with an estimated value of £6,558.

When will I get my windfall?

When the company floats on the stock market on July 9, which will happen provided at least 75% of those members who vote say yes. The packs being mailed out include voting forms which must be returned by June 4. Or you can vote in person at the special meeting in London on June 6.

You mentioned this business about membership of Friends Provident Life Office. What's all that about?

To be a member, you must have a Friends Provident Life Office or UK Provident policy which you held on May 4 last year and which will still be in force on June 6 this year. UK Provident was a mutual insurer bought by Friends Provident in the mid-80s.

I'm a policyholder with London & Manchester, the insurer taken over by Friends Provident in 1998. Do I get a windfall?

Sorry, you get nothing.

I've bought a second-hand Friends Provident with- profits endowment policy. Do I get a windfall?

Yes, probably. Friends Provident is seeking to amend its rules so that the original policyholder (ie, the seller) will get the fixed handout of 200 shares while the person who acquired the policy would get the variable allocation of shares.

What are the tax implications?

You won't get taxed on the shares unless you sell them. If you do, then provided the value of the shares sold together with any other capital gains realised is within the annual CGT exemption (currently £7,500), you won't pay any tax. But if you receive a larger windfall - £10,000 worth of shares, say - and you sell them, you will take the tax hit.

Why is the company demutualising?

It says listing on the stock market will provide it with increased financial strength and flexibility.

Will it affect my policy?

The company says there will be no adverse impact on policies, and the terms and conditions will not be affected. The benefits provided by becoming a public company "should improve investment returns for with-profits policyholders over the long term".

Will I be able to sell my shares and take the cash instead?

Yes.

What do I have to do now?

Fill in and send back the voting form by the deadline. And you can confirm membership details by checking and signing the voting form.

What happens then?

Assuming the demutualisation is approved, a prospectus and "share election form" will be mailed out to members from June 12. The form will ask you whether you want to keep your shares (and apply to buy extra shares at a discount if you wish) or sell them, and must be sent back by July 3.

Where can I get more help?

Log on to Friends Provident or phone the helpline: 0845-070-1170.

Scottish Provident members in line for £3,400

Scottish Provident plans to distribute windfalls averaging £3,400 to members if they vote next month in favour of a sale to Abbey National. But payments are unlikely to be posted before the end of the year, the firm said this week.

More than 440,000 Scottish Provident members will receive a flat payment of £500. With-profits policyholders can expect to see this figure boosted depending on how long they have held their policies and how much the policies are worth.

The mutual insurer says members will be sent a circular next week with details of the formula needed to calculate their share of the £2.1bn Abbey National is proposing to pay for the group. Some 300,000 customers with protection policies such as critical illness insurance are not considered members and miss out on windfalls.

Despite worries that they are fearsomely complex, loan notes will be on offer instead of cash to policyholders with windfalls ex ceeding the annual capital gains tax limit of £7,500. Members with several longstanding policies will be in line for more than £100,000.

Joint policyholders, most of them with endowment policies linked to mortgages, will be sent a joint cheque which they must divide between themselves, the firm says.

Scottish Life will also hand out £500 to its 220,000 members, but variable payments will be returned to policyholders in the form of an additional bonus. The firm is proposing to accept a £1.1bn offer from Royal London, , a rival mutual insurer, rather than be taken over by a bank or float on the stock market, which would generate larger cash payouts.

Only 70,000 life members will receive both flat and variable windfalls because endowment policyholders - the bulk of the membership - have been told their mortgage lender holds the membership rights.
Phillip Inman
fields.bodyText: Almost a year to the day after announcing plans to demutualise and pay windfalls to members, Friends Provident this week finally unveiled full details of precisely who's getting what and when. The company, founded by Quakers and now one of Britain's biggest mutual life insurers, intends to float on the stock market on July 9, triggering a multi-billion pound summer shares giveaway. It is proposing to give all its 1.7m qualifying members a fixed handout of 200 shares each, which based on its own figures would be worth around £500. Just over a million of these people hold with-profits policies and they will also get a variable allocation of shares which could in theory range from just one to several thousand shares. Windfalls of several thousand pounds won't be uncommon. The company sent out information packs to members this week. Here we answer some of the likely questions: So how much will I get? The share allocation statement being sent out will tell you how many shares you're getting. It will depend on what sort of member you are. If you're an eligible member of Friends Provident Life Office (see later) but your policy is not with-profits, you will get a fixed handout of 200 shares. These are likely to be worth between 225p and 270p each when it floats, so 200 shares would have a value of £450-£540. If you're one of the 1.1m members with a with-profits policy (such as a pension plan or endowment) you will also get a variable handout of shares. How many you get will depend on the size of the policy and how long you have held it. For example, a man with a with-profits pension who was 40 when he took it out and has paid in £50 a month over the past 15 years is likely to receive a total of 1,700 shares with an estimated value of around £4,207. An endowment policy-holder who was 30 when it was taken out and has paid in £50 a month for 20 years could expect 2,650 shares with an estimated value of £6,558. When will I get my windfall? When the company floats on the stock market on July 9, which will happen provided at least 75% of those members who vote say yes. The packs being mailed out include voting forms which must be returned by June 4. Or you can vote in person at the special meeting in London on June 6. You mentioned this business about membership of Friends Provident Life Office. What's all that about? To be a member, you must have a Friends Provident Life Office or UK Provident policy which you held on May 4 last year and which will still be in force on June 6 this year. UK Provident was a mutual insurer bought by Friends Provident in the mid-80s. I'm a policyholder with London & Manchester, the insurer taken over by Friends Provident in 1998. Do I get a windfall? Sorry, you get nothing. I've bought a second-hand Friends Provident with- profits endowment policy. Do I get a windfall? Yes, probably. Friends Provident is seeking to amend its rules so that the original policyholder (ie, the seller) will get the fixed handout of 200 shares while the person who acquired the policy would get the variable allocation of shares. What are the tax implications? You won't get taxed on the shares unless you sell them. If you do, then provided the value of the shares sold together with any other capital gains realised is within the annual CGT exemption (currently £7,500), you won't pay any tax. But if you receive a larger windfall - £10,000 worth of shares, say - and you sell them, you will take the tax hit. Why is the company demutualising? It says listing on the stock market will provide it with increased financial strength and flexibility. Will it affect my policy? The company says there will be no adverse impact on policies, and the terms and conditions will not be affected. The benefits provided by becoming a public company "should improve investment returns for with-profits policyholders over the long term". Will I be able to sell my shares and take the cash instead? Yes. What do I have to do now? Fill in and send back the voting form by the deadline. And you can confirm membership details by checking and signing the voting form. What happens then? Assuming the demutualisation is approved, a prospectus and "share election form" will be mailed out to members from June 12. The form will ask you whether you want to keep your shares (and apply to buy extra shares at a discount if you wish) or sell them, and must be sent back by July 3. Where can I get more help? Log on to Friends Provident or phone the helpline: 0845-070-1170. fields.headline: Whimsical laughs from The Right Size
fields.standfirst:
Bewilderness
Lyric Hammersmith, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Bewilderness
Lyric Hammersmith, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
WS Gilbert once observed that an accepted wit has but to say "Pass the mustard" and simple folk will roar their ribs out. On the evidence of this show, the comedy duo The Right Size have now reached that stage. Around me people yelped and guffawed; clearly in a minority of one, I cracked the odd smile but kept thinking the show wasn't nearly as funny as the couple's locked-in-a-bathroom epic, Do You Come Here Often?

It starts promisingly with two old friends enjoying a rustic reunion after 20 years. Terry (Sean Foley) is an ice-cream salesman; Maurice (Hamish McColl) is a smug, solitary lawyer. Wrapped in layers of brown paper, both look like ambulatory parcels. After hearing cries of help from the back of the sofa, they are projected into a vertiginous wonderland where they meet an old man (Freddie Jones), an itinerant magician-musician (Chris Larner) and a number of floppy dummies. The sustaining joke is that Jones can take only one of them back to the real world, which leads to much conspiratorial bickering.

Given that the show is inspired by the Narnia novels, I had hoped for much more specific satire; golden opportunities to have a go at CS Lewis's bluff piety and middle-class chumminess go begging. What we get, in effect, is a series of extended sight-gags. Much the best, all pre-recorded and screened, shows Foley stalking off stage in a huff, taking a taxi to Heathrow and ending up in front of the Egyptian Pyramids. Some of the other gags, such as McColl apparently decapitating Foley whose head then pops up through a trapdoor, are ingenious but will not come as a shock to any devotee of music hall.

The problem here is that the wobbly narrative barely sustains 90 minutes. Foley and McColl are at their best in extended situations, such as a pub scene where they confess their unhappiness, rather than in telling a story. I also wish they would push their comic personae much further, that Foley would be goofier and McColl more bullying. Classic double-acts, from Laurel and Hardy to Jewel and Warriss, have a streak of sado-masochism that these two shy away from. And, while I'm carping, it's odd how sex barely features on their agenda: how much more interesting it would be if they met a female recluse in the forest rather than the amiably bearded Jones.

None of my comments will matter a jot to hardcore Right Size fans, who will obviously have a ball. But what disturbs me about this show is that it celebrates, rather than satirises, whimsical playfulness and appeals to a nostalgic infantilism that these days seems all the comic rage.

 Until June 2. Box office: 020-8741 2311.

webTitle: Halifax takeover: The figurehead and his fixers

fields.headline: The figurehead and his fixers
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Lord Stevenson
fields.body:
Lord Stevenson

The chairman of the Halifax, who is moving into the same role at the enlarged bank, is a business and political networker par excellence.

Edinburgh-born and Cambridge-educated, he is also chairman of the Pearson and headed the House of Lords appointments commission which recently named the first "people's peers".

He is a long-standing friend of Peter Mandelson and a Labour supporter, and describes himself as "a child of the liberal 1960s", but is a self-confessed intellectual snob. Before the last election he introduced Tony Blair to City movers and shakers. He was knighted and ennobled by Mr Blair, but is not a Labour peer.

More figurehead and big picture thinker than fine detail man, he was absent from yesterday's press conference saying it is his style to let his chief executives get on with their jobs.

James Crosby

A 45-year-old Yorkshireman, Crosby showed his fatigue yesterday by inadvertently renaming the Bank of Scotland as the Bank of England during yesterday's hastily arranged press conference.

This fast-talking sports enthusiast is accustomed to moving at breakneck speed. Colleagues describe his irrepressible energy. In little over two years as chief executive he has transformed Halifax from a lumbering former building society.

He is an actuary and father of four young daughters. He was almost unknown in the City two years ago. His ambition has landed him the job of running the 11th biggest company in the FTSE.

Peter Burt

The BoS chief executive was applauded for his audacious takeover attempt of NatWest. It failed. As did last year's talks with Abbey National.

It is third time lucky with Halifax, but few expected the plain-talking Scot rooted in the heart of the Scottish financial community not to take the chief executive job. He described the cultural fit between the two banks as follows: "A Yorkshireman is like a Scotsman with the generosity squeezed out."

fields.headline: Mixed feelings for shareholders
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The merger was yesterday hailed as a good deal for Halifax's 3.1m private shareholders - but not so clever for Bank of Scotland's 60,000 "proprietors", as they are called.
fields.body:
The merger was yesterday hailed as a good deal for Halifax's 3.1m private shareholders - but not so clever for Bank of Scotland's 60,000 "proprietors", as they are called.

If the tie-up gets the go-ahead, Halifax and Bank of Scotland shareholders will receive one share in the new combined entity, HBOS plc, for each of the Halifax or Bank of Scotland share they currently hold - a straight one-for-one swap with no windfalls and no money changing hands.

Shareholders need do noth ing for the moment. Next month they will receive an information pack with the terms and a voting form.

Voting will take place in July, and the deal must be approved by at least 75% of the shareholders who vote. If the merger is approved, it will be binding on all shareholders of both institutions.

The merger is expected to become effective by the end of September. New HBOS shares will be issued and the old ones cancelled at the same time, according to a Halifax spokeswoman.

Shareholders will automati cally be sent new share certificates within 14 days of the merger, and will not need to send their old ones back.

While the deal will mean individuals have a smaller share in a bigger organisation, this should not make any difference to the value of their shareholding assuming the share prices stay close to where they are, said Hilary Cook, director of investment strategy at Barclays Stockbrokers.

She said this was "a good acquisition" for the Halifax, which was not overpaying. "For Halifax shareholders this is a very good move. This is an industry which is consolidating, where scale brings advantages. This takes them up to number five [in the league of banks]."

But if the deal falls through Halifax's shares look expensive, so her company has them down as a sell.

Ms Cook said the deal could be perceived as a takeover of Bank of Scotland, yet the Scottish institution's shareholders are not getting anything financially tangible out of it. "This does not appear to be a tremendous deal for Bank of Scotland's shareholders."

fields.headline: Hallé/Elder
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The Dream of Gerontius is now 100 years old and may no longer count as the central masterpiece of Elgar's output - today the symphonies and the concertos are more often heard. It may be that its incense-laden Victorianism needs careful performance if it is to survive. So Mark Elder's performance characteristically swept away much of the inherited tradition. He kept the music moving wherever possible, avoiding the interruptions of the beat that have for so long been treated as central to a truly Elgarian style. And the chorus of demons was less threatening than one could imagine, the cackles of "Ha ha" sung to their precise written pitches.

What Elder substitutes is a marvellously clear architecture, one that gives full value to the astonishing orchestration and the rock-solid musical design of the work. The grand climaxes, with the combined choirs of the Hallé and the City of Birmingham Symphony Chorus, were of shattering splendour. And everything Elder did seemed to be stressing that the Dream was composed at the same time as that other great choral-orchestral masterpiece, Schoenberg's Gurrelieder. While neither composer can have known of the other's work, Elder's performance neatly underlined their similarities of conception.

The American tenor Anthony Dean Griffey stepped in at the last moment to sing Gerontius. He has a fine voice for the role and admirable precision, though it may be some time before he gets the full scope of the character. Willard White showed again that he has the ideal voice and manner for the bass solos. But the true marvel of the performance was Jane Irwin as the Angel: she has the most perfect stillness of voice and a simplicity that matches Elder's approach to the score. Of the many Angels I have heard, hers is by far the most moving.

fields.headline: Burt sacrifices himself
fields.standfirst:
The fifth force: Halifax and BoS agree 'no fudge' management in £30bn merger
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The fifth force: Halifax and BoS agree 'no fudge' management in £30bn merger.
fields.body:
A Sunday lunchtime decision by Peter Burt, the chief executive of Bank of Scotland, opened the door to a "no fudge" management structure in the £30bn merger with the Halifax, announced yesterday.

In the face of speculation that Mr Burt had been put under pressure by tough-talking Halifax negotiators to give up any ambitions to the top job, the 57-year-old Scot insisted it had been entirely his decision to accept the more hands-off post of executive deputy chairman.

This allowed James Crosby, the Halifax chief executive, to take the same role in the combined bank, launched as HBOS and a "fifth force" on the high street.

When details of the talks leaked last week, it appeared Mr Crosby would be groomed to succeed Mr Burt in two years. Yesterday Lord Stevenson, the Halifax chairman, retained his role while another executive of the former building society, Mike Ellis, became finance director.

Mr Crosby moved to counter any criticism that the "nil premium", all paper merger to create the 11th biggest company in the FTSE 100 might involve compromises that could upset a smooth merger process. "This is a merger that is worked out in quite a lot of detail. There is an enormous amount of clarity," he said.

The combination, with headquarters at the Bank of Scotland building at The Mound in Edinburgh, will require 2,000 job cuts from a staff of 60,000 to save at least £305m a year in costs.

The banks made their "very strong commitment" to maintaining headquarters in Edinburgh despite leading MPs arguing the merits of Halifax. The Yorkshire town will be the hub of the retail bank.

The banks, whose individual brand names will stay on the high street, expect to generate at least £300m a year in additional revenues. Even so, Mr Crosby said, a "war chest" has been set aside with enough ammunition to cause pain for the big four retail banks - Lloyds TSB, NatWest/Royal Bank of Scotland, HSBC and Barclays.

BoS shares rose by 35p to 846p while Halifax broke through its 774p flotation price to end 30.5p higher a 823.5p, which served to raise the value of the combined group from £28bn to £30bn.

The nil premium deal involves swap ping existing shares for those in the newly created HBOS, with no cash handed over.

fields.bodyText: A Sunday lunchtime decision by Peter Burt, the chief executive of Bank of Scotland, opened the door to a "no fudge" management structure in the £30bn merger with the Halifax, announced yesterday. In the face of speculation that Mr Burt had been put under pressure by tough-talking Halifax negotiators to give up any ambitions to the top job, the 57-year-old Scot insisted it had been entirely his decision to accept the more hands-off post of executive deputy chairman. This allowed James Crosby, the Halifax chief executive, to take the same role in the combined bank, launched as HBOS and a "fifth force" on the high street. When details of the talks leaked last week, it appeared Mr Crosby would be groomed to succeed Mr Burt in two years. Yesterday Lord Stevenson, the Halifax chairman, retained his role while another executive of the former building society, Mike Ellis, became finance director. Mr Crosby moved to counter any criticism that the "nil premium", all paper merger to create the 11th biggest company in the FTSE 100 might involve compromises that could upset a smooth merger process. "This is a merger that is worked out in quite a lot of detail. There is an enormous amount of clarity," he said. The banks, whose individual brand names will stay on the high street, expect to generate at least £300m a year in additional revenues. The nil premium deal involves swap ping existing shares for those in the newly created HBOS, with no cash handed over. Speculation that a rival - notably Barclays - could wade in with a spoiling bid was rubbished by Mr Crosby. While most City analysts described the merger as a good fit, Jon Kirk at investment bank Fox-Pitt, Kelton said he would have preferred Mr Burt to have been named chief executive. The combination is expected to allow Halifax to enter business banking in England and Wales to complement its strong retail presence, while Bank of Scotland will have more cash available to fund the corporate deals in which it specialises. Speculation is now likely to focus on the chances of long-term independence for Abbey, Alliance & Leicester, Bradford & Bingley and Northern Rock.

webTitle: The message: Be afraid, be very afraid

fields.headline: The message: Be afraid, be very afraid
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: HBOS's message for the big four - be scared.
fields.body:
First things first. The official pronunciation of HBOS - the ugly name for the new Halifax and Bank of Scotland creation - is H.B.O.S, just like rival HSBC. H-BoS or some other such short-hand will not be tolerated.

Of course, it could have been BOSH, which would have been fun, but then the H coming first certainly makes it clear that the Halifax camp is running this show at the top level - the chairman, chief executive and finance director all come from its ranks.

Even so, it was slaps on the back all round at the central London hotel yesterday where the £30bn bank was unveiled. Matey explanations, scripted by the spin doctors perhaps, pointed to the cultural similarities between Yorkshiremen and Scotsmen. The message was everyone works well together.

Spin of the day: the 2,000 job cuts to the 60,000 workforce will take three years and amount to the equivalent of a mere four months of natural wastage. Halifax might lose the head office, but, if all goes according to plan, new jobs will be created in the retail banking hub of HBOS.

There was also a message for the big four - be scared. This "fifth force" is ready to spend money letting everyone know that banking competition has just ratcheted higher.

Confusingly, perhaps, this is precisely what BoS was expected to create during the merger talks which were thrown away by Abbey National earlier this year.

For this reason, the City is now starting to believe that the competition commission will give Lloyds TSB the all-clear to take over Abbey National. James Crosby, the enthusiastic chief executive of HBOS, did nothing to quash this speculation with lots of fighting talk about his "war chest" to woo consumers.

By launching a competitive assault on the big four, HBOS is starting a battle for business on a high street dominated by the big four. A fight not just for retail customers but for business customers too.

It might be in Mr Crosby's interests to give Lloyds TSB a hand in getting clearance to take over Abbey National, since the distraction of having to effectively dismantle Abbey would make it easier to steal Lloyds' customers.

webTitle: And the rich shall inherit the lot

fields.headline: And the rich shall inherit the lot
fields.standfirst: You can't take it with you, but wealthy parents find it easy to stop the government getting its hands on their estate. Liz Stuart reports
fields.trailText: You can't take it with you, but wealthy parents find it easy to stop the government getting its hands on their estate.
fields.body:
Under its former name of death duty, it struck terror into the landed estates of the rich, but in recent decades inheritance tax has become one of the most widely avoided taxes.

The terror may be rising, though. If proposals from a think-tank close to Tony Blair get the go-ahead, a sharp increase in the tax may be on the agenda after the election.

The Performance and Innovation Unit, in a paper outlining measures to make Britain more meritocratic, last week suggested that inheritance tax be raised, and even went as far as suggesting that inheritance should be abolished.

At issue is the unfair head-start that inheritance gives to the sons and daughters of the rich. "Families throughout the world do all they can to help their children and to prevent downward social mobility in particular. Indeed, the dilemma for policymakers is that it is highly desirable in a civilised society that parents should do this, but the consequence may be to reinforce inequalities of opportunity," says the report.

Right-wing think tank the Adam Smith Institute proposes the exact opposite: it wants inheritance tax to be abolished. "According to our research, since the tax was brought in it has made a negative return as it is very expensive to collect and administer.

"It causes people to do utterly weird things to avoid paying it, such as putting money into offshore trusts instead of investing it in the UK," says Dr Madsen Pirie, president of the Institute.

Currently inheritance tax, levied at 40% on estates of more than £242,000, brings in around £2bn in revenue each year, against the estimated £100bn raised by income tax.

Reducing the impact of the tax to zero through the use of trust law is one of the favourite games played by financial advisers to the well-off; 10 of the favourite tricks are outlined below. This also means that only the better-off middle classes end up paying inheritance tax, with the rich using trusts to sidestep the tax altogether.

However, not all of the new rich believe that they should featherbed the future of their offspring. When Linda McCartney's will was published this week it showed that although she had left £4m to her four children (much of it in trust), access was made difficult to encourage them to pursue their own careers first.

Remarkably, Kate Turner, head of tax at Coutts, the private bank which targets clients with at least £500,000 in liquid assets, says that her clients often do not object to paying the tax. "Either they simply do not mind paying it, or they are unwilling to leave money to their children because they feel they do not want to give them such a large headstart in life," she says.

She adds that inheritance tax planning should start when the client is in their 40s, rather than leaving it until retirement age.

From play days to pay days

Some children would be big losers if inheritance was taxed at 100% or abolished.

Brooklyn Beckham can already lay claim to a high rolling lifestyle with an extensive designer wardrobe and upmarket toy collection. Posh and Becks' combined earnings of more than £20m will also fill up his bank account.

Lucas Jagger, initially disowned by his father Mick after he was born to the Brazilian model Luciana Morad, should be able to claim a stake of the Rolling Stone's fortune. Mick's assets are estimated to total £150m.

Elsewhere in the music industry, Lennon Gallagher should benefit financially from being the son of estranged parents Oasis star Liam Gallagher and actress Patsy Kensit. Oasis made £60m in the past three years.

Anais Gallagher is in the same boat, except the father is Noel Gallagher and the estranged wife is party organiser Meg Matthews.

Victoria Beckham's mate Scary Spice is also in the money. Her daughter Pheonix Chi Gulzar, is sole inheritor of the estimated £15m fortune.

Arthur Donald, the grandson of Paul MaCartney, could be a rich man. Grandad is worth £500m.

How they get away with it

Here are the top 10 tips the wealthy need to know to avoid paying inheritance tax:

1. The first £242,000 of any estate is free of inheritance tax (IHT).

2. Agricultural land and business assets, unlike residential houses, are completely free of IHT. Farms, estates and companies can therefore be passed down between generations of families without the taxman seeing a penny. However, stringent rules exist to prevent the elderly rich snapping up a company prior to death to avoid duties.

3. Potentially Exempt Transfers (Pets). Under the Pet rules, an individual can give assets away - such as cash, shares, antiques and oil paintings - which will not be counted for IHT as long as they are gifted seven years before the individual dies. Die within three years of the gift, however, and it will still be liable for IHT. If they meet their demise between three and seven years later, then a proportion of the amount counts.

4. Houses cannot be transferred under Pet rules if the former owner continues to receive a benefit from the house, such as continuing to live there. But one adviser, Speechly Bircham (020-7427-6400), has found a way round the rules through its Home Loan Plan, where the homeowner sells it to a trust in return for an IOU.

5. Transfers between spouses are completely free of IHT, before or at death.

6. Discretionary trusts allow a family double use of the £242,000 allowance. Put simply, a husband dies and his £1m estate is divided £758,000 to his wife and £242,000 to his children. No tax is paid. When his wife dies, the £242,000 allowance can then be used a second time.

7. Annual and regular gifts from income are treated as free of IHT liability. The gifts - a maximum of £3,000 per year - are not confined to family only and no matter when the person giving the gift dies, it will be exempt from IHT.

8. Grandchildren can be given £250 a year without any IHT liability. There is no maximum number of gifts to grandchildren.

9. When children marry, they can be given up to £5,000 without incurring IHT.

10. Donations to charities and political parties are free of IHT.

 Information supplied by Mazars Neville Russell, Speechly Bircham and Jobs & Money research

fields.headline: Buy-to-let misery for students' neighbours
fields.standfirst: Angry residents' groups in big university cities say they are being ruined by an influx of youngsters. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: Angry residents' groups in big university cities say they are being ruined by an influx of youngsters. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
Neighbours who party all night, streets littered with takeaway containers and trash, neglected, crumbling houses, rat-infested discarded mattresses in back gardens; university students are destroying neighbourhoods in Birmingham, Leeds, Cardiff, Nottingham, Southampton and even Canterbury, according to angry local residents.

Two weeks ago, Jobs & Money highlighted the savings which can be made by parents of students, if instead of paying rent, they buy properties in the big university cities with an easily available buy-to-let mortgage. Our article provoked a furious response from residents who say that student buy-to-lets are wrecking local communities.

In Birmingham's Selly Oak area the adult population is 19,000 - of which 8,000 are students. Scores of local letting agents regularly leaflet homes in the area, encouraging families to sell out to landlords.

Barry Toon of the local Tara neighbourhood forum says: "The number of students has doubled in the past five to 10 years. A normal terraced house rented out to five students produces an income of £10,000 a year, so landlords have moved in, pushing up prices to unaffordable levels for local people and pushing out families.

"The local infrastructure is collapsing, with schools under serious threat of closure because there are simply not enough children in the area, and shops replaced by take-aways. There's a lot of social disruption; young students are away from home for the first time and want to enjoy themselves and party. But the result is families who can't sleep at night, streets strewn with takeaway litter and the elderly increasingly isolated."

In Leeds, Bronwen Holden, spokeswoman for the Headingley Against Landlordism action group in Leeds, says: "Landlords are like locusts. The buy up house after house, spend nothing on maintaining them and allow them to fall into severe neglect. The area is eventually abandoned and they move on to a better area, leaving a trail of destruction.

"Student parents might like to reflect on our experience and think of the areas where they live before they contribute to the decline of communities in university areas. Resident groups here and elsewhere are now saying we've had enough."

Not everybody agrees, however, as revealed by the responses on BBC Leeds Online's bulletin board recently when it asked local residents for their views.

"I am not a student. I live in Headingley and I think it is great so many students live in the area. There are loads of interesting pubs, restaurants, plus the cinemas of course, which would all face terminal decline without the student population. Locals complaining about the students are being ridiculous! They make Headingley the most vibrant place to live in Leeds," said one.

Another non-student, Ruth Dalzell said: "There wouldn't be so many great little shops and cafes if it weren't for the student population."

In Birmingham, city councillor Andy Coulson, who represents Selly Oak, admits there is little local authorities can do without new legislation. Planning consent for student housing (Houses of Multiple Occupation or HMOs) is only required where there are six or more occupants. "I'm very disappointed that the government has backed away from earlier proposals for regulating rented housing," says Mr Coulson.

In April 2000, a green paper, Quality and Choice: A Decent Home For All, launched by housing minister Nick Raynsford, set out proposals for a limited licensing scheme for HMOs, where local authori ties would be given new discretionary powers over both bad landlords and bad tenants. However, the paper was only consultative and to date no action has been taken.

One positive development is the rekindling of student accommodation construction by universities, which may take pressure off local housing. But Ms Holden remains deeply concerned. "We are not anti-student; we chose to live in a mixed area. It just isn't mixed any more. The government talks about sustainable communities, but the forces to maintain sustainable communities seem so weak."

 Headingly Against Landlordism. Tara Neighbourhood Forum in Selly Oak, Birmingham is on 0121-472-6671.

The cost of cover

Houses in university areas are prime targets for burglars, writes Liz Stuart.

According to insurer Endsleigh, around 40% of students living in houses take out insurance for their personal possessions, although some will find that their valuables are covered by their parents' contents insurance policy.

Insurance rates vary markedly across Britain, with Leeds students charged almost double the rate paid by those in Birmingham.

Several insurers market products specially designed for students. Endsleigh, which is recommended by the National Union of Students, would charge £74 a year for a student in Selly Oak in Birmingham and £124 for Headingley in Leeds, for £3,000 of cover. This includes damage to landlord's property, personal injury insurance in the case of mugging to a maximum of £50,000, and cover for £5,000 for fees should a parent die by accident. To cover a computer which is kept in a room costs an additional £15.

Saxon Insurance charges £30 a year, plus a £3 policy fee for unlimited cover, although the maximum claimable on each item is £250 in both Birmingham and Leeds.

To cover more valuable items, it costs an extra £20 for a computer up to £500 (or £40 extra for £1,000 of cover), £40 for a laptop, £10 for a musical instrument and £50 for a pushbike.

Campus would charge the Birmingham student £41 for a year's cover of up to £3,000, with no maximum for any sin gle item. This includes cover for a computer of up to £500, or for an additional £9, this cover is extended to £1,000. Mobile phone cover costs an additional £40.

The Leeds student, meanwhile, would pay £93, with all the same conditions. Proof of forceable, violent entry must be provided.

fields.bodyText: Neighbours who party all night, streets littered with takeaway containers and trash, neglected, crumbling houses, rat-infested discarded mattresses in back gardens; university students are destroying neighbourhoods in Birmingham, Leeds, Cardiff, Nottingham, Southampton and even Canterbury, according to angry local residents. Two weeks ago, Jobs & Money highlighted the savings which can be made by parents of students, if instead of paying rent, they buy properties in the big university cities with an easily available buy-to-let mortgage. Our article provoked a furious response from residents who say that student buy-to-lets are wrecking local communities. In Birmingham's Selly Oak area the adult population is 19,000 - of which 8,000 are students. Scores of local letting agents regularly leaflet homes in the area, encouraging families to sell out to landlords. Barry Toon of the local Tara neighbourhood forum says: "The number of students has doubled in the past five to 10 years. A normal terraced house rented out to five students produces an income of £10,000 a year, so landlords have moved in, pushing up prices to unaffordable levels for local people and pushing out families. "The local infrastructure is collapsing, with schools under serious threat of closure because there are simply not enough children in the area, and shops replaced by take-aways. There's a lot of social disruption; young students are away from home for the first time and want to enjoy themselves and party. But the result is families who can't sleep at night, streets strewn with takeaway litter and the elderly increasingly isolated." In Leeds, Bronwen Holden, spokeswoman for the Headingley Against Landlordism action group in Leeds, says: "Landlords are like locusts. The buy up house after house, spend nothing on maintaining them and allow them to fall into severe neglect. The area is eventually abandoned and they move on to a better area, leaving a trail of destruction. "Student parents might like to reflect on our experience and think of the areas where they live before they contribute to the decline of communities in university areas. Resident groups here and elsewhere are now saying we've had enough." Not everybody agrees, however, as revealed by the responses on BBC Leeds Online's bulletin board recently when it asked local residents for their views. "I am not a student. I live in Headingley and I think it is great so many students live in the area. There are loads of interesting pubs, restaurants, plus the cinemas of course, which would all face terminal decline without the student population. Locals complaining about the students are being ridiculous! They make Headingley the most vibrant place to live in Leeds," said one. Another non-student, Ruth Dalzell said: "There wouldn't be so many great little shops and cafes if it weren't for the student population." In Birmingham, city councillor Andy Coulson, who represents Selly Oak, admits there is little local authorities can do without new legislation. Planning consent for student housing (Houses of Multiple Occupation or HMOs) is only required where there are six or more occupants. "I'm very disappointed that the government has backed away from earlier proposals for regulating rented housing," says Mr Coulson. In April 2000, a green paper, Quality and Choice: A Decent Home For All, launched by housing minister Nick Raynsford, set out proposals for a limited licensing scheme for HMOs, where local authori ties would be given new discretionary powers over both bad landlords and bad tenants. However, the paper was only consultative and to date no action has been taken. One positive development is the rekindling of student accommodation construction by universities, which may take pressure off local housing. But Ms Holden remains deeply concerned. "We are not anti-student; we chose to live in a mixed area. It just isn't mixed any more. The government talks about sustainable communities, but the forces to maintain sustainable communities seem so weak."  Headingly Against Landlordism. Tara Neighbourhood Forum in Selly Oak, Birmingham is on 0121-472-6671. The cost of cover Houses in university areas are prime targets for burglars, writes Liz Stuart. According to insurer Endsleigh, around 40% of students living in houses take out insurance for their personal possessions, although some will find that their valuables are covered by their parents' contents insurance policy. Insurance rates vary markedly across Britain, with Leeds students charged almost double the rate paid by those in Birmingham. Several insurers market products specially designed for students. Endsleigh, which is recommended by the National Union of Students, would charge £74 a year for a student in Selly Oak in Birmingham and £124 for Headingley in Leeds, for £3,000 of cover. This includes damage to landlord's property, personal injury insurance in the case of mugging to a maximum of £50,000, and cover for £5,000 for fees should a parent die by accident. To cover a computer which is kept in a room costs an additional £15. Saxon Insurance charges £30 a year, plus a £3 policy fee for unlimited cover, although the maximum claimable on each item is £250 in both Birmingham and Leeds. To cover more valuable items, it costs an extra £20 for a computer up to £500 (or £40 extra for £1,000 of cover), £40 for a laptop, £10 for a musical instrument and £50 for a pushbike. Campus would charge the Birmingham student £41 for a year's cover of up to £3,000, with no maximum for any sin gle item. This includes cover for a computer of up to £500, or for an additional £9, this cover is extended to £1,000. Mobile phone cover costs an additional £40. The Leeds student, meanwhile, would pay £93, with all the same conditions. Proof of forceable, violent entry must be provided.  Want to know more? fields.headline: A warrior woman dances in Leeds
fields.standfirst:
Yaa Asantewaa
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Yaa Asantewaa
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.body:
You will have heard of Joan of Arc and you will know all about Boudicca, but if you were educated in a British school you will probably know next to nothing about Yaa Asantewaa, a 20th-century woman warrior of Ghana's Asante people. In March 1900 she led her people, an army of thousands, against the British colonial forces in Ghana, who were intent on subjugating the Asante and seizing the Golden Stool, a symbol of Asante unity and sovereignty that legend claimed had miraculously descended from the heavens in the 17th century. The stool was considered the soul of the Asante nation and British attempts to take it were seen as sacrilege.

All this, plus Yaa Asantewaa's triumph, defeat and exile in the Seychelles, is told in this production that comes across as a hybrid of carnival and the Royal Tournament. The director is Geraldine Connor, whose Carnival Messiah, inspired by Handel's Messiah, was a huge success. But here she sets herself a stiffer task and the evening doesn't always balance the demands of storytelling, drama and spectacle.

With most of the narrative out of the way, the second half perks up considerably and both cast and audience have a good time. This is a show with rhythm, and the drumming, dancing and singing all raise the roof. There is some brilliant mask work, and Connor knows how to create vivid set-pieces: the scenes of exile in a Seychelles of golden palm trees are spectacular and send you out of the theatre on a high.

But the spectacle alone is not enough to carry an evening that promises something more. It needs a more incisive script, more shape and more moments of real drama like Yaa Asantewaa's betrayal, which is done as simply and beautifully as a photograph being taken. At the moment it feels like a fringe show writ large, albeit one that is performed with heart and soul by the cast, the Adzido Pan-African Dance Ensemble and the Pan-African Orchestra.

 Until May 19. Box office: 0113-213 7700.

webTitle: Fifth force goes to war on high street banks

fields.headline: Fifth force goes to war on high street banks
fields.standfirst:
Halifax and Bank of Scotland merger sets up fight with big four
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Halifax and Bank of Scotland merger sets up fight with big four.
fields.body:
The Bank of Scotland and Halifax merged yesterday to create a £30bn "fifth force" in British banking - which immediately declared war on its four main high street rivals.

The combined group, to be known as HBOS, pledged to use a multi-million pound warchest to woo new customers by undercutting its competitors.

The deal, which was welcomed by City investors and trade unions, was clinched at 6am yesterday after a week of accelerated negotiations.

The new bank will have 1,125 branches across Britain. While 2,000 job cuts from the combined workforce of 60,000 are on the cards, compulsory redundancies are to be kept to a minimum.

The top jobs have all gone to Halifax executives but the head office will be in Edinburgh.

Halifax's 3.1m private shareholders - a legacy from its conversion from a building society - will exchange their shares for those in the new combined bank.

The separate Bank of Scotland and Halifax brands will survive on the high street but the combined bank aims to be a stronger rival to the big four: Lloyds TSB, HSBC, Barclays and NatWest/Royal Bank of Scotland.

Coming at a time of unprecedented upheaval among the high street banks, HBOS yesterday portrayed its formation as different.

"For so long, bank acquisitions have been about shutting down competition. This is about opening up competition. This is the ultimate pro-competition merger," said James Crosby, the Halifax chief executive who is the surprise choice for chief executive of the combined bank.

The biggest assault is expected to be launched in current accounts, where the big four have a 70% share of a market. Customers have traditionally been reluctant to move their accounts.

Halifax has already started to attack this sector by launching a current account paying interest at 4%, and is expected to launch similar market-beating deals for the Bank of Scotland's customers.

While personal customers are being promised a better deal, the combined bank also plans to take on its rivals in the small business banking market. Building on the Bank of Scotland's strong position in Scotland, Halifax will start to offer business accounts for the first time from 100 of its branches.

"We are deliberately opening a Pandora's Box," Mr Crosby said.

He added: "We've put away a little warchest ... which we will use against the big four. Watch this space.

"Customers are looking for more and not willing to accept no [for an answer]," he said.

The merger comes at a time of unprecedented government scrutiny of the sector. There have even been calls for a windfall tax on bank profits, and two separate investigations are being conducted by the competition commission. The watchdog is examining small business banking as well as the implications of Lloyds TSB's hostile bid for Abbey National. It will not be known for two months whether Lloyds will succeed, but the City believes there are more banking mergers in the pipeline.

This is the third time the Bank of Scotland has tried to join the ranks of the big four. Its ambitious chief executive, Peter Burt, attempted to take over NatWest and merge with Abbey National before sealing the Halifax deal.

Under the terms announced yesterday, Mr Burt shocked the City by taking on the role of managing the integration of the two banks rather than be coming the head of the combined group.

The appointment of Lord Stevenson, the Halifax chairman, as chairman of the combined group led some commentators to describe the combination as a Halifax takeover of the Bank of Scotland.

The two banks were forced to speed up their talks after news of a possible merger leaked last week. While the City believes there is an outside chance that a predator might yet try to spoil their union, the rise in both banks' share prices yesterday was regarded as praise for their deal.

fields.headline: Behind the scenes is a real-life drama
fields.standfirst:
As normality returns to the Royal Opera House following the settlement of a high profile industrial dispute, the unions hope to press on and negotiate better pay and conditions for everyone working backstage. And, John Crace reports, they need all the help they can get

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: As normality returns to the Royal Opera House following the settlement of a high profile industrial dispute, the unions hope to press on and negotiate better pay and conditions for everyone working backstage. And, John Crace reports, they need all the help they can get.
fields.body:
There comes a moment in any televised awards ceremony when the cameras stop rolling and the assembled actors and directors head to the bar for a drink and a gossip.

It's the moment when the presenter announces the awards for technical achievement, and the only way viewers at home get to find out who has won - or that the awards even exist - is if they happen to listen very carefully to the voiceover listing "the winners in other categories" as the closing credits run.

There is precious little glamour for the technicians, designers, administrators, stage managers and box office staff who account for well over half of those working in live theatre, but the variety of their work means few would rather be employed anywhere else.

There are as many different types of jobs as there are theatres. At a small theatre outside London, a deputy stage manager (DSM) could find him or herself doing everything from putting up the lights to bolting the scenery together; in a large West End theatre a DSM's role will be much more strictly defined. Similarly, a small theatre may only have a small complement of permanent staff and will take on contract workers and volunteers as and when they are needed, whereas a large venue will have a large permanent staff and will only rarely use freelances.

Touring companies and houses, such as Glyndebourne, that are only open for six months of the year will tend to use more freelance and part-time staff. However, even armed with the relevant specialist training and qualifications getting the first job can still be an uphill struggle.

"I've been very lucky," says Sarah Alford-Smith, who is just coming to the end of her eight-month contract as DSM at the Worcester Swan Theatre. "I've been in work ever since I graduated from the Bristol Old Vic Theatre School four years ago. Most jobs are got through word of mouth and by recommendation; I think I got my first job because someone rang up my theatre school to see if there was anyone who could fill a vacancy for assistant stage manager. I've also got jobs since then from adverts in The Stage and from the Stage Management Association freelist that gets circulated to theatres and producers."

Many start their careers as a freelance, picking up contracts as and when they crop up. David Curl has been freelance for much of his 16 years in theatre, and is now stage manager for the musical Notre Dame de Paris at London's 2,000 seater Dominion Theatre.

"In this business you should budget for periods of unemployment, though I've worked solidly for the past six years or so," he says. "I've built up a good network of contacts, and I've been well supported and looked after by the people I have worked with."

Not every one may have such a smooth career path.

"These days there are more and more courses offering training qualifications for the theatre," says Mr Curl. "I can't help feeling that as greater numbers of students graduate, a good many are going to be disappointed. There are only a finite number of jobs, and I've already begun to notice bottlenecks emerging. How can everyone progress from ASM up to DSM if there aren't the vacancies?"

What the recent increase in training courses has done, though, is to level the playing field between the sexes. Cathy Joyce is now 40 and has a permanent job as senior lighting technician for the Royal National Theatre (RNT).

"When I first came into the profession it was rare to find a woman working backstage on the technical side," she says. "You had to go out of your way to be seen lifting the heaviest equipment to prove you could do the job. These days women are much more integrated into the industry."

For most of her career Ms Joyce chose to work freelance as the money was far better. Not that she was talking untold riches, mind. The theatre is not the destination for those who want to get rich quick.

An ASM on a big show might earn £350 per week, while a stage manager with 15 years' experience on the same show may only be on about £500. Box office staff may be on £15,000 while craft grades, such as costume designers, can expect to earn £20,000.

The good news is that the industry has well-organised unions, Bectu and Equity, which are hot on issues of pay and health and safety. Bectu, which has just ended a dispute with the Royal Opera House (ROH) over the suspension of one of its members, has individual agreements with the national houses, a collective agreement with the West End Theatre, and a minimum levels of pay and conditions of employment in the English repertory sector.

The less good news, though, is that many theatres are happy to stick to the minimum levels. And, says Willie Donaghy, Bectu's arts and entertainment supervising officer, he faces a constant battle with theatre owners that want to erode his members' rights. "The Society of London Theatres has recently introduced proposals for greater casualisation, compulsory Sunday working, having the workforce on call 24 hours a day and for the abolition of permanent staffing levels," he says.

Further pay cuts may be in the offing as the EU's 48-hour working week comes into force. "My basic contract is for a 40-hour week," says Cathy Joyce, "but I usually end up working at least 60 hours. The overtime pay is an important part of my salary, and as the directive is implemented I will be restricted in the hours I can work. The RNT management and the union are working hard to resolve this, but since the theatre will have to take on more staff to make up the deficit, it's hard to see how pay levels can stay the same."

Why it didn't end in tears for Dave

Dave Shea, 30, is a freelance technical manager working for several Scottish theatre companies. He is currently working on the restaging of Tron Theatre and the Royal National Theatre's collaborative production of Zinnie Harris' Further than the Furthest Thing at the Tricycle Theatre in London.

"When I started my A-level Theatre Studies course I was mainly interested in performing, but we had a particularly forceful teacher who was always trying to push us to the point of tears, and I wasn't prepared to go as far as he wanted. Added to this, most of the other students were women and it was usually left to me to put up the sets when we took a show into school, and I gradually came to realise I was happiest working on the other side of the lights.

"I took a two-year diploma in stage management at the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama in Glasgow, but I moved back to Manchester for family reasons after graduating.

"I had done a work placement at the Royal Exchange theatre in Manchester as part of my course, and they gave me my first proper job after putting me on their casual list. A show would finish on a Saturday night, and various crews would be brought in to work round the clock to make sure the next show could start on the Tuesday. I specialised in lighting and would strip out the old show, before setting up, focusing and programming the lights for the next.

"Regular work was hard to get at first and I did pub and factory work to make ends meet. I applied for the odd job out of the paper, but these jobs understandably tended to go to people who had more experience. Contacts are really important and in this industry it's who you know that tends to count when getting a job.

"I got my first full-time job in 1995 when my best friend from drama school was appointed technical manager at the Tron theatre in Glasgow and he asked me whether I would like to apply to become his deputy. The pay was not fantastic - about £13,000 with overtime - but it was great fun. I left about two and a half years later when the theatre was heading for a 12-month period of refurbishment, as I wanted to be working on a show rather than in a darkened theatre. I went back to working freelance as there are comparatively few full-time jobs in Scotland, as there aren't that many theatres.

"It's an exciting life, as you never quite know how a show is going to pan out, but not a very financially rewarding one - especially if you're working for theatre companies funded by the Scottish Arts Council. Pay scales are improving, but even so I reckon I still only make about £15,000."

Training courses

Administration City University in London offers a one-year diploma course in arts management.

Design There are many courses available ranging from three years to one year. For a full list contact Society of British Theatre Designers, 47 Bermondsey St, London SE1 3XT.

Costume Some costume making is incorporated into most stage design and some drama school courses. More practical courses are offered by London College of Fashion, 20 John Princes St, London W1 0BJ; Wimbledon School of Art, Merton Hall Rd, London SW19 3QA; Bristol Old Vic Theatre School, 2 Downside Rd, Clifton, Bristol BS8 2XF; City College, Canning Place, Liverpool L1 8BT.

Scenic Carpentry and Lighting All stage management courses cover scenic carpentry and lighting. Oldham College also offer a BTEC National Diploma in Entertainment Technology based at the college's professional theatre, the Grange Arts Centre. Oldham College, Rochdale Rd, Oldham OL9 6AA.

Sound All stage management courses cover sound. Oldham College (see above) also offers a BTEC course, and City of Westminster College, 25 Paddington Green, London W2 1NB offers a City & Guilds 1820 Sound Engineers course.

Stage Management There are at least 19 stage management courses. Further details can be obtained from Conference of Drama Schools, 1 Stanley Avenue, Thorpe, Norwich, NR7 0BE.

"I got my first full-time job in 1995 when my best friend from drama school was appointed technical manager at the Tron theatre in Glasgow and he asked me whether I would like to apply to become his deputy. I left about two and a half years later when the theatre was heading for a 12-month period of refurbishment, as I wanted to be working on a show rather than in a darkened theatre. fields.headline: The weight of expectation
fields.standfirst: Despite repeated promises, the days of 10% returns look to be over now that inflation is seemingly a thing of the past. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: Despite repeated promises, the days of 10% returns look to be over now that inflation is seemingly a thing of the past. Tony Levene reports
fields.body:
The financial sales lexicon has lots of magic words - growth, past performance, security and windfall are just some. They are all guaranteed to press the emotional buttons of prospective investors and shift product.

But three short words have the most powerful magic of all. They are "ten per cent". And with inflation seemingly moribund - if not actually dead - that return is harder than ever to conjure up.

This week, Money reveals how promises of about 10% income a year on financial products are unlikely to be achieved. It's as if the clock has been turned back to the Victorian era, when inflation was much more in line with today's sub-2% levels, and the most that was expected from investments was an income of 5% a year.

Two weeks ago, the Financial Services Authority warned that investors - and their financial advisers - could suffer if they stick to 10% expectations rather than accept reality. "Some do not understand the implications of low inflation for future returns," it says. "Advertising products that emphasise past returns achieved in periods of higher inflation may confuse people about prospective future returns."

But our investigation was prompted by private warnings from senior figures in the City that a raft of products launched in recent years offering double-digit returns may now be at severe risk, their sophisticated structures laid bare by the big fall in the stock market and technology shares in particular.

The products are not specialist schemes used just by high net-worth individuals; small investors have bought into the schemes, based on investment trusts, which were plastered on billboards over the past couple of years promising 8%-10% income a year. It is believed that more than £5bn of small investors' money is at stake, and some estimates say they involve more than 100,000 investors.

What investors were buying was a high-income promise from some of the biggest names in the investment industry. What many may not have understood was that they were entering into some of the most complex products - split capital investment trusts - on offer in the retail financial market.

But now an Edinburgh academic and a Scottish investment trust guru have teamed up to warn that these trusts both tread a dangerous road and have the potential to pull down the rest of the investment trust world, if not the market itself.

They believe that the trusts are an upside-down pyramid, with the same limited cash pool whirling around the funds thanks to managers buying stakes in each others' products.

Their fundamental criticism is of the fashion by fund managers in recent years of issuing complicated income-creating shares in investment areas which normally produce little in the way of dividends. The trusts tend to be invested in technology, Japanese equities or European companies.

These are known as "barbell trusts". Andy Adams and Robin Angus of the Centre for Financial Markets Research at Edinburgh University say these trusts are really two portfolios - about half goes into "capital" shares which yield little or nothing while the balance, the "income" shares, are invested in high-yield instruments. These may be "junk" bonds issued by secondary telecom companies or high-interest debt issued by governments in developing countries.

To ratchet the income even higher, the trusts may also "gear up" - borrowing money at, say, 6% to buy bonds yielding, perhaps, 12%.

But the sharp fall in bonds offered by debt-laden telecom companies, and the recent Argentinian government debt crisis, have exposed the fragility of some of the split-capital investment trusts.

Holding the two ends of the "split caps" together is the weakest link - the big bank borrowings which can be called in if either of the two weights fails.

"There has been a boom in these issues," says Mr Angus. "Up to £5.4bn of these shares were issued in 1999 and 2000 alone. They are designed to overcome low returns, to meet investor clamour for the high yields they have been used to for decades."

Two have already hit problems. The highly geared Framlington NetNet Income, which invests in internet stocks while promising a high income, had shrunk in value from £48m to £8m when its bankers pulled the plug following Nasdaq's plunge.

And Aberdeen's Technology and Income had to be restructured for similar reasons. Both these trusts were launched at the height of the tech stock bubble.

"In the past, investment trusts were structured for the long term so investors could ride out market setbacks," says fund manager Alastair Mundy at Investec.

"Now many of the returns depend on debt which can be recalled at short notice if either end of the barbell breaches bank covenants. When one end is highrisk, high-tech and the other is high-risk junk bonds, it is easy for something to go wrong. And even easier when many of the high income investments are shares in other investment trusts' income shares."

These crossholdings raise the spectre of a domino style collapse with contagion spreading - in the same way as foot and mouth - to previously healthy investments.

"It is difficult to work out who owns what. Worse is what the inter-related structure of cross holdings could lead to in a falling market," say Mr Adams and Mr Angus.

"Price declines might become a self-feeding downward spiral as the net asset values of other trust shares hold also decline. Once these unravel, confidence in all investment trusts could suffer," they add.

"It's all too easy for contagion to spread," says Legal & General fund manager David North. "Problems in Thailand four years ago spread as far as Brazil even though there were no links between the two. Once you get uncertainty, you get a ripple effect into other investments."

But there are many in the investment trust industry who do not share the gloom. Fund managers say that these high return shares are largely bought by professionals and they know what they are doing.

"A number of trusts are at or near levels where banks could pull the rug," says Nigel Sidebottom of investment trust specialists BFS Investments. "But trusts are getting better at renegotiating terms.

"Highly geared shares do suffer more than most in falling markets but they have more capacity for recovery. It is wrong to conclude that barbells and other income producing structures are wrong - there are some attractive investments out there."

fields.headline: Paradise Shostakovich
fields.standfirst:
Paradise Moscow
Grand Theatre, Leeds
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Paradise Moscow
Grand Theatre, Leeds
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Shostakovich consigned his only operetta, Moscow, Cheryomushki, to his personal B-list. The composer went so far as to beg his friends not to attend the premiere of a work which, in a dark moment, he described as "boring, feeble and stupid".

Those are not words that leap to mind after seeing Opera North's new production. Renamed Paradise Moscow, this is a reorchestrated, expanded version of the 1994 Pimlico Opera production arranged for small band by Gerard McBurney. It uses director David Pountney's sharp, incisive translation - a vast improvement on the rather stilted original. Add McBurney's keen instinct for theatre scoring, Craig Revel Horwood's inspired choreography and an outstanding cast, and you have one of Opera North's finest creations in years.

Paradise Moscow is not an operetta in the strict sense: it has a fast-moving dialogue and song-and-dance routines more reminiscent of vaudeville. Pountney has exploited this magnificently, especially with regard to his villains. Barabashkin (Campbell Morrison) oscillates between sounding like a deranged sergeant-major and a likable Bob Hoskins, while Vava (Margaret Preece), the boss's conniving girlfriend, has a wonderful cockney screech unnervingly reminiscent of Terry Jones in Life of Brian.

Moscow, Cheryomushki was the gentlest of satires on Soviet life, but Paradise Moscow is a fully blown send-up, with the cavorting figures of Lenin, Stalin and Marx making a memorable appearance. KGB men pop up repeatedly and irrelevantly, more ridiculous than sinister. The extent to which Pountney has revised the libretto is especially blatant when Masha and Sasha compare reactions to the sound of a doorbell: Masha's memories - innocent in the original - are of feet on the stairs, limousines in the streets and a suitcase kept packed by the door. It felt slightly overdone. But there can be little doubt that Shostakovich would have loved this production - he might even have added Paradise Moscow to his A-list.

 Until May 12. Box office: 0113-222 6222. Then at Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (020-7863 8000), from May 23.
