webTitle: Double digits that just don't add up

fields.headline: Double digits that just don't add up
fields.trailText: Millions of envelopes carrying the legend 10.25% in a typeface nearly two inches high are dropping through investors' letterboxes. And for the typical target - a retired person trying to stretch their income for a few more luxuries - that's all they need to know.
fields.body:
Millions of envelopes carrying the legend 10.25% in a typeface nearly two inches high are dropping through investors' letterboxes. And for the typical target - a retired person trying to stretch their income for a few more luxuries - that's all they need to know.

There's the magic double digit return - up to three times many building society accounts. And there is plenty of other persuasion for GE Life's High Income & Growth Plan. The bond has no initial or annual charge and is tax-free in an Isa. But there is no such thing as an investment free lunch. The annual income is guaranteed; the return of original capital is not. Investors could lose all their savings.

The GE Life bond depends on the performance of the Dow Jones Euro Stoxx 50. Investors receive a full return of capital if the index gains or falls by no more than 20% during the bond's three-year life. But they have to read thousands of words in tiny print to find out what happens if share prices fall further. Once the index drops below 20%, savers start to lose capital; their losses accelerate if there is a 30% fall, while a 50% final index drop wipes out initial investments.

Investors could end up with nothing more than £3,075 in income for each £10,000 invested. Mailshot financial consultants RJ Temple do not mention this total loss potential in their letter, although they do say "you should only invest if you can accept an element of risk to your capital."

Future Values Consultants, a specialist analyst, says a recent NDF high income bond offering 12% is even riskier. An 11% fall in the Euro Stoxx 50 wipes out the income. "It is a one-year bond which may not be long enough for equity markets to work. All money is lost if markets halve," FVC says.

And those who picked up on the massively marketed Scottish Widows Extra Income & Growth Plan late last year are already nursing losses. This relied on 30 individual UK shares rather than an index. At the last count, no fewer than 20 had fallen below the 20% safety zone although seven had recovered sufficiently to start to count again for investors. A £10,000 investment is currently worth £8,130 although all depends on the next two and a half years. Adding the income would give - if markets are stable - a 4% return, not the big print 10.25%.

webTitle: Scottish Provident members in line for £3,400

fields.headline: Scottish Provident members in line for £3,400
fields.trailText: Scottish Provident plans to distribute windfalls averaging £3,400 to members if they vote next month in favour of a sale to Abbey National. But payments are unlikely to be posted before the end of the year, the firm said this week.
fields.body:
Scottish Provident plans to distribute windfalls averaging £3,400 to members if they vote next month in favour of a sale to Abbey National. But payments are unlikely to be posted before the end of the year, the firm said this week.

More than 440,000 Scottish Provident members will receive a flat payment of £500. With-profits policyholders can expect to see this figure boosted depending on how long they have held their policies and how much the policies are worth.

The mutual insurer says members will be sent a circular next week with details of the formula needed to calculate their share of the £2.1bn Abbey National is proposing to pay for the group. Some 300,000 customers with protection policies such as critical illness insurance are not considered members and miss out on windfalls.

Despite worries that they are fearsomely complex, loan notes will be on offer instead of cash to policyholders with windfalls ex ceeding the annual capital gains tax limit of £7,500. Members with several longstanding policies will be in line for more than £100,000.

Joint policyholders, most of them with endowment policies linked to mortgages, will be sent a joint cheque which they must divide between themselves, the firm says.

Scottish Life will also hand out £500 to its 220,000 members, but variable payments will be returned to policyholders in the form of an additional bonus. The firm is proposing to accept a £1.1bn offer from Royal London, , a rival mutual insurer, rather than be taken over by a bank or float on the stock market, which would generate larger cash payouts.

Only 70,000 life members will receive both flat and variable windfalls because endowment policyholders - the bulk of the membership - have been told their mortgage lender holds the membership rights.

webTitle: Isa savers bear the brunt of rate cuts

fields.headline: Isa savers bear the brunt of rate cuts
fields.trailText: Barclays, Cheltenham & Gloucester, Halifax and Nationwide are among the leading players that have cut rates on some of their savings accounts by more than April's 0.25% bank base rate cut.
fields.body:
Barclays, Cheltenham & Gloucester, Halifax and Nationwide are among the leading players that have cut rates on some of their savings accounts by more than April's 0.25% bank base rate cut.

And in many cases it's cash Isa savers who have borne the brunt of their hacking and slashing.

Many savers will conclude that some institutions kept their Isa rates high early this year to lure in as many people as possible during the peak Isa-buying season - then, as soon as they could, they pushed the rates right down.

fields.headline: Stand up for yourself
fields.trailText: Arm yourself with as much information as you can about the types of deals (eg fixed, capped, discounted, cashback) and repayment methods available before you go for advice.
fields.body:
Arm yourself with as much information as you can about the types of deals (eg fixed, capped, discounted, cashback) and repayment methods available before you go for advice.

If you want advice, rather than just information, make sure you tell the adviser that you want a recommendation of what's best for you.

Ask the adviser to tell you about the deals they offer and to go through the pros and cons of each.

Think about your circumstances and future plans (eg do you want to pay extra off on your mortgage? Is your income likely to change dramat ically in the next few years?). Make sure you tell the advisers about them - don't wait to be asked - and get them to explain why the mortgage they've recommended is suitable for you.

Think about your attitude to risk. Do you want a guarantee that you will repay your mortgage by the end of the term? Or are you happy to go with a repayment method that doesn't give you that guarantee?

Be aware of the myths: You don't have to take a mortgage over 25 years. Ask the adviser to quote on a 20-year term or less as well as the standard 25-year term. And repayment mortgages aren't bad if you want to move.

fields.headline: England boys flunk class examination
fields.standfirst:
France quick off the mark to face Spain in Sunday's final
Le Tallec 2, 77; Pongolle 4, 72
fields.trailText: England's boys will have to settle for a third-place play-off with Croatia after they were subjected to a masterclass in technique and movement by France.
fields.byline: Harry Pearson at St James' Park
fields.body:
The former head of FA youth coaching John Cartwright once commented that every competitive game was an examination. Last night the brightest sparks of England's football academies faced their stiffest assessment so far.

They did not quite make the grade, going down 4-0 to a talented French side for whom Florent Sinama Pongolle and Anthony le Tallec gave a display of all-round attacking quality the like of which the locals among the 30,000 crowd have not seen for some time.

The duo, who both play for Le Havre, had scored seven between them in the four previous matches and they did not wait long to add to the tally. Whatever inspiring words Bobby Robson had uttered when he visited the English players before kick-off were still echoing around the dressing room when the lanky Le Tallec turned an innocuous-looking cross into the first goal with an acrobatic overhead kick worthy of the great Klaus Fischer.

Two minutes later his partner threw off his marker with a twinkletoed turn, advanced to the edge of the area and fired a low shot into the corner of Lenny Pidgeley's goal.

Two down inside four minutes, England did well not to capitulate. Yet despite the endeavour of Craig Westcarr on the right of midfield and the hard work of Cherno Samba upfront, they created little more than half-chances, the best of which, Westcarr's header from Kris Taylor's looping cross, flew narrowly wide.

A decade ago Cartwright's view was that the English system placed too much emphasis on passing exams and not enough on education. Since then youth coaching in this country, like the education system, has undergone a radical overhaul. The latest national curriculum is the brainchild of football's answer to Chris Woodhead, the FA's technical director Howard Wilkinson.

The new model has put the stress firmly on instruction. Unfortunately for the English, when it comes to cramming players full of knowledge France are currently the planet's most successful nation. They are the World, European and European Under-18 champions.

Jean-François Jodar's Under-16 team may yet prove to be his nation's best-educated set of players. Up until this encounter they had scored 13 goals and conceded none. For most of last night's game they gave the hosts a masterclass in technique and movement.

The French youngsters play to the same pattern as their senior 11. The defence is well organised, the strength and composure of the captain Jacques Faty noticeable enough to have attracted the attention of Sir Alex Ferguson, and the midfield combines strength with artistry.

One movement in the first half summed up their approach. An early ball in from Gael Maia found Mourad Menghi, who gives a passable imitation of Zinedine Zidane even down to the square, hunched shoulders and lolloping running style. The young No10 controlled the ball with his first touch, then rolled a pass with his studs into the path of the onrushing Pongolle. The striker dashed past Steven Schumacher and cut the ball back for Le Tallec, whose firmly struck shot rattled the bar.

The second half offered more of the same with Le Tallec and Pongolle both scoring again, the latter after running from the halfway line.

This was the first time England had reached the last four in this competition since a fresh-faced Tony Adams was marshalling the defence (on that occasion they were beaten by the USSR) and the coach Dick Bate had already acknowledged that his charges had exceeded expectation by beating Germany in a penalty shoot-out in the quarter-finals.

On Sunday they face Croatia for third place, 3-0 losers to Spain in the other semi-final. At this level demonstrating a good grasp of the game's techniques is ultimately more important than victory. France have clearly mastered a goodly few of them. For England more study is necessary.

France (4-4-2): Chaigneau ; Pietre , Colombo , Faty , Berthod ( Debris, 21); Maia , Menghi ( Drouin ,55), Yebda , Jacmot ; Le Tellec , Pongolle ( Grax, 74)

Referee : G Gilewski (Poland).

webTitle: Zola stays at Chelsea with title as the target

fields.headline: Zola stays at Chelsea with title as the target
fields.trailText: Gianfranco Zola has announced his intention to remain a player at Chelsea for two more years and to win the Premeirship within that time.
fields.body:
Gianfranco Zola yesterday delivered two messages that his adoring Stamford Bridge public wanted to hear: the charismatic Italian is staying, and the championship is within Chelsea's grasp in the next two years.

As Zola revealed he is extending his playing career with Chelsea for that time - at its end he will be almost 37 - and banished long-held fears that he would return to Italy this summer, he made clear he wanted the Premiership title to be his and Chelsea's crowning achievement.

"I am totally convinced the club will be challenging for trophies in the future," said Zola, who from 2003 has the option of staying a further two years with Chelsea as a coach. "I haven't won the Premiership and I'm looking forward to winning it. That would be fantastic, something that would really complete my career."

Although fans and team-mates lobbied Zola to stay, he was torn by family considerations. Fortunately for Chelsea his wife's fears that their two children would not be brought up speaking Italian if they stayed in England receded and she also appreciated how much her husband was wanted.

"It was up to my family to decide," said Zola. "But they are pleased to stay and I am delighted. There will be a few people teasing me when I say it was mostly down to my wife, Franca, but that's it. She was convinced this is the best thing for the children; we can't give them a better education anywhere else and we will keep on making sure they speak Italian.

"I had some wonderful years in Italy, and some clubs there were interested in me, but I didn't particularly want to leave England or this club."

fields.headline: Clubs gang up against Chesterfield
fields.trailText: A number of Third Division clubs are planning to go to court to get most of Chesterfield's results this season declared void.
fields.body:
A number of Third Division clubs are planning to go to court to get most of Chesterfield's results this season declared void.

The clubs are incensed at what they see as the lenient treatment of Chesterfield and are seeking to have them punished further.

Yesterday the Football League board ratified the decision, made by a three-man disciplinary panel, to dock Chesterfield nine points and fine them £20,000 for financial irregularities, some of which concerned the transfer of the striker Luke Beckett from Chester in August. The deduction leaves Chesterfield on 77 points, all but guaranteeing automatic promotion.

But, just when Chesterfield's place in the Second Division seemed assured, six clubs have agreed to support the team that finishes bottom of the table in seeking a judicial review of the fairness of Chesterfield's success on the pitch.

The aim would be to strip them of the points they have won when Beckett, their leading scorer, played. Currently that stands at 75 points, which would mean they would be relegated instead of the bottom club. It would play havoc at the top of the table too, affecting the third promotion place and the play-offs.

"It is unfair that 23 clubs in the Third Division should be expected to work according to the rules while one club allegedly played an illegally contracted player all season," said one club executive.

"If one of the teams is acting against the rules and gaining an advantage as a result, then that team really has to pay the price. Effectively nearly every game Chesterfield played could be deemed to be in breach of the rules.

"We think it's quite straightforward that they should lose the points they achieved while that player was on the field. Half a dozen clubs have agreed to support the team which eventually finishes bottom in seeking a judicial review. The feeling is that strong."

It was the Beckett transfer which prompted an exhaustive inquiry into Chesterfield's affairs after an FA tribunal ruled that the club should pay £150,000 for the striker in three instalments: £75,000 to be paid immediately, followed by two payments of £37,500. Only after representations by Chester City to the FA was the first instalment paid in November. They are still awaiting the second, due on November 14, as well as the third.

The six clubs point to the case of non-league Bath City, who were docked three points for fielding an ineligible player even though the reason was an innocent administrative error and the player came on as a substitute for about 40 seconds and did not touch the ball.

webTitle: Fans rebel at Wimbledon and QPR merger plans

fields.headline: Fans rebel as London clubs talk of merger
fields.trailText: Fans of QPR and Wimbledon have vowed to fight by any means possible to prevent a planned merger of the two clubs.
fields.body:
Wimbledon and Queens Park Rangers moved last night to defuse fan fury by pledging that a proposed merger of the clubs would not go ahead if supporters strongly object to the controversial plan.

The two London clubs admitted they have held talks about a merger as a way to overcome their problems: Wimbledon of the First Division have no ground and a small fan base while QPR, just relegated to the Second, are in administration with debts of £8m.

The plan was even discussed at a meeting of the Football League board, who gave it a provisional green light though they had not received any concrete submission from either club.

But supporter reaction was immediately hostile, with protests planned and vows made to "fight any merger to the end".

Although QPR initially approached Wimbledon with the plan, the Dons chairman Charles Koppel summed up their joint thinking when he said yesterday: "Both clubs have a unique set of problems and we have to ask, is there a way to resolve those problems? Are we stronger together than apart?

"We are committed to exploring all available options for strengthening the club on and off the pitch. Our initial view is that, in the current financial environment for football outside the Premier League, the idea could have merit and may be worth exploring further."

Both clubs had been hoping to persuade their fans of the practical and financial merits of a merger.

Despite 30 declarations of interest in buying out the current QPR owner Chris Wright, no firm offer has come in, even from a City consortium who came to light yesterday and are allegedly considering a £12m takeover.

The plan would see a new club emerge called Wimbledon and Queens Park Rangers - other names floated yesterday included Queens Park Dons and Wimbledon Rangers - playing at Loftus Road in the Second Division, depending on league approval.

Wimbledon's Terry Burton would be manager of the new club and the shirt colours would reflect those of both teams.

The two clubs set out on talks hoping the climate of supporter obstruction which saw stillbirths for two previous proposed mergers -Fulham Park Rangers and Thames Valley Royals (Reading and Oxford) - had changed. They also felt it would be easier in the case of teams that did not have a historic rivalry.

QPR, though accepting they would lose some fans, had even estimated that the new team would attract between 10,000 and 12,000 for the first game next season.

But the leak to a national newspaper caught both clubs by surprise and dented hopes of persuading fans of the financial and practical advantages. There was some suspicion that this was the motive behind the leak.

Libby Magrill, a spokeswoman for QPR 1st, the QPR Supporters Trust, insisted: "QPR fans will fight to retain the identity of our club. Any move to merge QPR with Wimbledon this year, or at any stage in the future, will be opposed by every possible means."

The Wimbledon Independent Supporters' Association declared that they "unequivocally oppose the merger of two separate identities, families, supporters and histories".

Wisa and QPR 1st plan to lobby the league while a protest by Wimbledon fans is scheduled for the final game, at home to Norwich on Sunday. At QPR supporters demonstrated outside Loftus Road yesterday.

QPR quickly issued a statement criticising the leak and insisted that before any final decision they had always intended to consult their supporters, via a questionnaire, in a "sensible and controlled manner", and will do so still if merger discussions continue.

Privately QPR went further. "It had always been decided this wouldn't go through without the blessing of the majority of the fans," insisted one source. "It just wouldn't have worked."

Koppel took a similar line. "It has to come down to whether or not the supporters feel that it is something they can buy into."

webTitle: Ron Atkinson: Gary McAllister was an absolute steal

fields.headline: Not so much a golden oldie, Gary was an absolute steal
fields.trailText: Gary McAllister looks an absolute steal on a Bosman free from Coventry. With more games behind him, he'd have given Teddy Sheringham a good run for his money as player of the year.
fields.body:
Before the season started I wrote in this column that I felt Gary McAllister was the signing of the summer, and his recent form for Liverpool suggests I was right. If he had played more games before Christmas he'd have given Manchester United's Teddy Sheringham a good run for his money as player of the year.

With five goals in his last five matches McAllister looks an absolute steal on a Bosman free from Coventry. His penalty winner against Barcelona and his quick-thinking free-kick at Everton have been particularly important, though his value to Liverpool goes much deeper.

There are plenty of good passing players in midfield at Anfield such as Dietmar Hamann and Steven Gerrard. But I don't think Liverpool have anyone better than Gary in terms of inventiveness and, just as important, know-how. Gary won the title at Leeds in 1992 and has 57 Scotland caps, so he's been there and done it.

He played under me at Coventry and I know how fit he'll be for a 36-year-old. He always trained terrifically hard and loved training, whether it was the hard physical stuff or the skill work and small-sided games. I remember as well how he would go out and practise after a session.

All the same it helps Gary that he doesn't have to play 60 games a season. It gives him a chance to rest, and, because he's competitive enough to want to be in the team most weeks, when he is selected he'll be determined to make it hard for Gérard Houllier to leave him out.

He's certainly managed that of late. He had an outstanding last season for Coventry and was instrumental in helping them to 14th place, but I feel he's learned to vary his passing more. At one time at Coventry I thought he looked to play a lot of long balls but he's showing the whole spectrum with Liverpool and has been devastating at set pieces.

He has scored with free-kicks at Everton, Coventry and Bradford in the past few weeks but a side of Gary's game that is never really highlighted is how useful he is in defending set plays. At 6ft 1in he's bigger than people might realise and can make life difficult in a wall or defend the near-post areas and get very solid headers away.

When I was in charge of Manchester United I monitored Gary's progress at Leicester. We had a number of good midfielders, so I never made a move for him, but apparently he'd been a United junior before I got to Old Trafford. I understand he'd been coming down regularly for trials at the time that the likes of Norman Whiteside were starting to come to the club.

Although I signed Gary for Coventry from Leeds in 1996, it was very much a Gordon Strachan-inspired idea to take him on board. Gordon was being groomed to take over, and he was a good friend of Gary from the Leeds and Scotland camps.

My feeling was that Gary was at a level we weren't ready for. I thought we lacked the quality to go with him, and I reckon that if he'd gone to Liverpool then they might have won the title that season, and had a lot more success in the past four years.

He'd have been a perfect replacement for John Barnes, who was still the playmaker but wasn't on top of his game, and would have been made to measure for Steve McManaman and Robbie Fowler. There was talk of Liverpool making a move, but whether the fee put them off I'm not sure.

I remember going to Anfield with Coventry near the end of the 1996-97 season. If Liverpool had won they would have gone top and Coventry would have gone bottom and might well have been relegated. But Coventry won 2-1 and Liverpool virtually fell apart after that. They needed someone like Gary to control the game.

He did settle in at Coventry after a few problems and in a funny way the serious knee injury he suffered there in 1997 seems to have put years on his career. The long time away enabled him to get some good body rest and I think he's come back with extra zest.

Sadly, Gary has had to overcome personal as well as injury problems. His wife was seriously ill with cancer earlier this season. Thankfully she has recovered and Gary is in a position where football must be an absolute pleasure to him day in and day out, particularly when he's chasing so many things so late in his career.

He's shown great character and looks the sort of player Liverpool could use in future as a third, spare, man at the back if they wanted. Gary's someone you don't begrudge big wages, and whatever Liverpool are paying they're getting their money's worth.

fields.headline: Tories pledge residential care reform
fields.trailText: The Conservatives have promised to reform the way residential care costs are met in an effort to address the problem of elderly people having to sell their homes to pay their bills.
fields.body:
The Conservatives have promised to reform the way residential care costs are met in an effort to address the problem of elderly people having to sell their homes to pay their bills.

The party's health spokesman, Dr Liam Fox, said people who make their own private provision to pay for residential care would be indemnified by the state if their stay in residential care proved to be more expensive than the average stay - currently £25,000-£30,000.

If the fund was not ultimately required - currently only one person in four requires long-term care - it would be inherited by the next generation.

The Conservatives also promised to match the government in providing free nursing care.

"What is the point of saving to be able to leave something for your children and grandchildren if the state confiscates almost all your savings - and your house too - to pay for care costs?" he said.

"I want to create a responsible society. I want to create a society in which people are rewarded for thinking ahead and are encouraged to save.

"I want to create a society in which people do not live under the threat of the government confiscating their life savings and their family homes."

The Tories argue that under the present system the state penalises people who have saved for old age, because it forces individuals with assets of over £18,500 to finance their own care.

A spokesman for Help the Aged said: "Neither the Conservatives, nor Labour, in England, have grasped the key point that long-term care is just as vital as life-saving hospital treatment.

"This new idea from the Conservatives effectively punishes a sufferer from Alzheimer's disease, requiring them to pay up to £25,000 for their bad luck."

fields.headline: Turbulent priest rocks Belgian church
fields.standfirst: A gay priest has stretched Belgium's ultra-conservative Catholic church to breaking point and enraged senior clerics by setting up a 'rent-a-priest' service, reports Andrew Osborn from Brussels.
fields.trailText: A gay priest has stretched Belgium's ultra-conservative Catholic church to breaking point and enraged senior clerics by setting up a 'rent-a-priest' service, reports Andrew Osborn from Brussels.
fields.body:
Meddlesome priests have come a long way since the twelfth century, when Thomas à Becket, the then Archbishop of Canterbury, pushed King Henry II too far and paid for his impertinence with his life - but they can still be a divisive force.

In Belgium, where the Catholic church is struggling to modernise itself, a young rebel priest is in open conflict with the primate of all Belgium, Cardinal Godfried Danneels, and the dispute is threatening to drag the church into chaos.

Rudy Borremans, 32, a spiky-haired, bespectacled Flemish priest - more Gary Rhodes than Thomas Becket - has enraged senior clerics by openly living with his gay lover and setting up an unorthodox "rent-a-priest" business.

The Dutch-speaking renegade is also challenging the church to lighten up and come to terms with what have traditionally been taboo issues; sex, euthanasia and abortion.

In an unprecedented move he will be forced to face down his accusers in an ecclesiastical court later this year.

If Borremans is found guilty of violating church laws, he could be ex-communicated and cast into a secular wilderness forever.

Needless to say he is not popular with the establishment. But it is not his homosexuality that the church reproaches him for, but rather his breaking of the vow of celibacy he took when he joined the priesthood.

Heterosexual priests are also forbidden from taking a sexual partner or a wife.

Observers estimate, however, that at least 50% of the country's priests have illicit sexual relations with men or women but are simply far more successful than Borremans at keeping it a secret.

But, to cap it all, Borremans is outspoken, and his rent-a-priest service, which hires out disgraced former clerics to administer at weddings, baptisms and funerals at rates which undercut the official Catholic church, has turned him into a bête noire.

He only asks that people pay "what they can afford" for such services, and is happy to cater for punters who are normally turned away by the established church; namely single mothers, divorcees and homosexuals.

"The problem is that the priests wear two hats at the same time," Danneels has complained. "One day, they officiate according to Catholic practice and the next day they administer at secular ceremonies."

The dispute has been bitter and now it shows every sign of escalating. Despite the fact that he was suspended from his duties as a cleric two years ago, Borremans has carried out at least 90 unofficial baptisms since then.

Nine face-to-face meetings with the Cardinal, aimed at settling the dispute, have failed and, incredibly, both sides claim to have received threatening phone calls and been intimidated by unidentified thugs.

Borremans has even threatened to take Danneels to court for defamation of character and, over Easter, he deliberately defied the increasingly tetchy Cardinal.

Banned from attending a special mass at Mechelen cathedral, near Brussels, at which priests repledge their allegiance to Danneels, the rebel cleric turned up with a small band of supporters. Church sources called the stunt 'the ultimate provocation'.

Last year, Borremans went on hunger strike to draw attention to what he called 'the church's abuses'.

He now lives, quite openly, with his gay lover Guy Vermeylen in an unremarkable apartment block in Leuven, the town famous for Stella Artois lager.

He remains convinced, however, that the church must reform if it is to survive.

"I still feel like a Catholic priest despite being suspended," he explains. "But I feel that there are certain issues which the church must take on board, such as the role of women, sexuality, euthanasia and abortion but they don't even allow debate!

"Anything which is illegal causes wounds which fill with puss which nobody heals. Not even the church."

Borremans claims to receive hundreds of letters from supporters who feel marginalised by the church, and feels that he has a mission to carry on his priestly duties because of his background.

"People have a huge need for rituals where symbols really mean something, be it from a text or from somebody who embodies religion."

Convinced of the justness of his cause, Borremans's self-confidence means he is unlikely to throw in the towel any time soon.

"In some ways I feel like an oracle. Someone a little prophetic," he muses.

fields.headline: Brutality gets an airing
fields.standfirst: Death penalty tapes put the US to shame
fields.trailText: There have been about half a million murders in the US since 1976 when the supreme court restored the death penalty.
fields.body:
There have been about half a million murders in the US since 1976 when the supreme court restored the death penalty. Since 1977, just over 700 people have been executed, more than 500 of them since 1993. Given that 19 of the 50 states did not impose the ultimate punishment in this period, these figures, compiled by Amnesty International, starkly demonstrate the random and arbitrary nature of judicial killing in America. A federal government study recently confirmed independent findings that racial and geographical factors have a big impact on death penalty application. In 80% of the 700 cases, the victims of the relevant crime were white. Conversely, African-Americans have been disproportionately targeted for execution. The US stands accused of flouting international standards by continuing to execute the mentally impaired, providing inadequate legal representation, executing people who were minors when they committed their crime, and keeping condemned prisoners lingering on Death Row for periods exceeding 10 years.

States such as Illinois have declared a moratorium on executions because of alarm over a number of miscarriages of justice. Liberal American opinion agrees with the consensus in European countries that the US position is morally untenable and increasingly out of line with global trends. Since the US restored the death penalty, 60 countries have abolished it. A condition of Turkey joining the EU, for example, is its renunciation of the death penalty. Nor can the US authorities show evidence that the death penalty works as a deterrent - the reason being that it does not. Since George Bush is an enthusiastic hangman, leadership on this issue will not come from the top. But the imminent execution of Oklahoma bomber Timothy McVeigh has forced the matter to the fore.

If entrenched US attitudes are to be changed, a massive public education effort is required. That is why the airing on public radio this week of grisly tapes of executions in Georgia's electric chair is so important. Listening to a killing, listening to the callous, gallows humour of the guards, listening to the murderous popping of enormous electrical surges, is very different from contemplating execution in the abstract. That most states now employ lethal injection makes no odds. The brutal result is the same. Perhaps, finally, America will listen up - and begin to awaken to its shame.

webTitle: QPR-Dons merger 'to be dead within 48 hours'

fields.headline: QPR-Dons merger 'to be dead within 48 hours'
fields.trailText: The proposed merger between Wimbledon and Queens Park Rangers is likely be called off within the next 48 hours after opposition from supporters groups.
fields.body:
The proposed merger between Wimbledon and Queens Park Rangers is likely be called off within the next 48 hours after opposition from supporters groups.

"The merger isn't going to happen," QPR 1st spokesperson Libby Magrill told Guardian Unlimited today. "We met with QPR chairman Chris Wright yesterday, and although he wasn't that keen on the idea anymore anyway, we helped to persuade him that it was an awful plan."

"QPR had planned to send a questionnaire about the merger to supporters, but I don't think they are going to do it anymore," she added. "What's the point? They know everyone is dead against the plan."

"The Wimbledon Supporters Association will meet with their chairman Charles Koppel on Sunday, but by then I think the deal be dead."

fields.headline: Money Channel puts faith in administrators
fields.trailText:
6.15pm: Adam Faith's Money Channel has called in the administrators in a last-ditch bid for survival, writes Dan Milmo.
02.05.2001: Money Channel founded by Adam Faith runs out of cash
fields.body:
Adam Faith's Money Channel has called in the administrators in a last-ditch bid for survival.

Accountancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers has been appointed to find a rescuer for the company, which was established by the popstar-turned-entrepreneur two years ago.

Michael Gercke, the PricewaterhouseCoopers administrator, said: "initial expressions of interest" had been made about bailing the company out.

Earlier this week, the Money Channel board asked for the company's AIM-listed shares to be suspended after a burn rate of around £750,000 per month left it with less than £1m in the bank.

Money Channel had pinned its hopes on an interactive advertising service, but its success with viewers had failed to entice advertisers.

fields.headline: Surfer girl
fields.standfirst: After three months in the city Milly finally bids farewell to Sydney and begins a top-speed tour of the coast. First stop is a small town called Bingara, where she discovers a completely novel way of surfing...
fields.trailText: Week 22: Sydney to Bingara After three months in the city Milly finally bids farewell to Sydney and begins a top-speed tour of the coast. First stop is a small town called Bingara, where she discovers a completely novel way of surfing...
fields.body:
Thursday April 26 was another big day for me - my last day ever at my hotel in Sydney. For the last time I dragged myself in too early, polished, cleaned, set, served, vacuumed... well, OK, I'm not really going to miss that but I'll certainly miss the social side and all the different people I've met. On the other hand I couldn't wait to be hitting the road again - there's a very big world just waiting for me to see it.

Friday night was my official work farewell night, so before that I attempted to get my life into order. I phoned the Oz Experience people whom I'm travelling with between Sydney and Cairns, and booked to leave on Tuesday. I'd already bought the ticket in England, now its just a little matter of phoning them every time I want to travel on - though sadly I've got to be in Cairns by May 20, so its going to be something of a whistle-stop tour. However, I've had lots of good advice so I'm going to try and fit in as much as possible. That night was a particularly mad one, but as it was the last time I would ever see the people from work it was nice to go with a bang!

On Saturday I somehow managed to rouse myself in time to go to the races. The night before my manager had been kind enough to give me some tickets he couldn't use (including entry into the members' stand) on the condition that I go along and dress up. There was no way I could turn down an offer like that. The race course was just a short bus-ride from my house which gave me time to hunt out my sole respectable outfit!

I've never been to the races before, but it was quite an experience. The men were all in suits and the women in various states of classy dress with the odd wonderful hat - although nothing on the Ascot scale. People-watching was probably the highlight of the day. I allocated myself a sum of money to waste - I had no illusions of ever seeing it again - and then realised I had no idea how to place a bet. After several failed attempts I enlisted the help of a nice lady, and finally succeeded in placing a small bet 'each way'. I watched from the stalls as the horses thundered towards the finish-line. Mine came in fourth. I asked an old couple if that meant I'd won anything, but sadly not.

There were eight races that day and I improved at the betting business enough that I was soon confidently requesting "five to win on number three in the fourth". It was definitely fun to watch the tiny jockeys race by, but it wasn't until the third race when my horse snatched it by a nose that I understood the rush of winning and why everybody jumps up from their seats and yells at the track. A dangerously addictive pass-time and an interesting afternoon - and I returned home with exactly the amount of money I'd left with, so I couldn't complain. I had my last big night out in Sydney with my flat-mates that evening, and in some ways I'm looking forward to pursuing a more relaxed lifestyle as I head up the coast (hopefully).

I had very little time left in Sydney and didn't want to waste any of it, so on Sunday I dragged my flat-mate to Sydney Aquarium, a tourist spot I had yet to visit. Besides, a perk of my job was that I got free entry, so it would have been silly to pass it up. I'd hardly describe myself as a fan of caged-creature exhibitions, but the Aquarium really surprised me - there was loads of fascinating marine life I'll just never have the opportunity to see in its natural habitat. We saw lazy seals and a sleeping (but still extremely menacing) crocodile, walked through glass tunnels where huge sharks and rays swam overhead (the former with far too many teeth for my liking), saw giant crabs and many, many types of fish. The names were as varied as the appearance, my personal favourite being the 'half and half goat-fish'.

On Monday morning my friend from home and east coast travelling-partner Gary arrived from Melbourne. Monday night was our last in Sydney and I intended to do so much, but then I met a work-mate for a last ridiculously large lunch where once again I had to endure eating oysters - I think I'm getting braver. Somehow lunch stretched into the evening, so I was a little disorganised.

Basically, Gary and I were booked through to Byron Bay on the Oz bus, but there are certain compulsory stops the bus makes so we had to make a day-by-day itinerary. I wasn't ecstatic about this as I'd prefer to take each day as it comes, but with just a 20-day trip, I do want to make the most of my time. So on Tuesday morning, early, we arrived at Sydney Central Station and I was finally on my way! A girl from work, Amanda, was on the same bus as us by coincidence - I was definitely no longer a lone traveller. We were bound for a sheep station in Nundle - eight hours north of Sydney on our big green bus - nothing could be further removed from my months in the city! Our bus and another going the opposite way on the south-bound route both arrived there on the same night, so there were nearly 100 of us crammed into 14-bed dormitories in converted sheep-barns, having a party out in the Australian countryside. It was a good night for getting to know our fellow travellers - most of whom we'll be with for the next three days through to Byron - and they certainly kept us entertained. At one point a padding-covered barrel on ropes descended from the ceiling. This was 'Curly', the wild sheep, and the idea is to ride it for as long as possible while the farm-hands swing the ropes to make it buck. I though I did alright - well, OK, I stayed on for a few seconds. After that the barn was converted into a disco and we boogied the night away well into the small hours.

The next morning everyone was woken by the soothing sounds of dogs being loosed into the dorm rooms. At least I was on a top bunk. A few groans later we pulled ourselves up and out, ready to head on to our next destination: the previously unheard-of town of Bingara, further north. The Oz bus is excellent at sorting your accommodation, helping with an itinerary and any trips you're interested in, but I did wish some of these stops weren't compulsory as our time was short enough.

As it turned out, Bingara was a fantastic stop. Our bus took over the local pub, then a group of about 40 of us headed down the road for a late afternoon's horse-riding. I was a bit nervous after my horse-trek in Queenstown, but figured the best thing was just to get back in the saddle. The riding ranch couldn't have been more brilliant, though, and I needn't have been nervous. Everyone was given horses to suit their ability and confidence and we were vaguely split into ability groups, so the better riders could really push themselves while we wandered behind. The leaders were absolutely fantastic - they took the time to come and see everybody individually and I felt like I'd learned loads over the afternoon - by the end, I'd got my confidence back so much that I was taken cantering. Gary had never ridden before in his life and I suddenly saw him come cantering past, so I can safely say this place will look after everybody. The scenery was fantastic - riding through bush and rivers as the sun set. We even saw wild kangaroos watching from the woods.

The absolute highlight came when we made a quick stop by a river and I got to go 'horse-surfing'. Both Amanda and I had neglected to bring our swimming-costumes but, after watching a handful of others, we borrowed shorts and went in fully clothed. Basically, the horse goes into the water up to its withers, then you grab its tail and cling on for dear life! One of the leaders then gets the horse to canter and you're dragged behind, flying on top of the water. It was such a funny experience - one of those bizarre activities you never imagine doing but will remember forever.

That night in the pub was pretty quiet and Bingara definitely isn't a party town, but I'd had such a good time riding that I almost regretted that we were heading on the next morning. Sadly, however, this is a very quick tour of the coast, and now I can't wait for tomorrow when I have my one night in Byron Bay - then move on...

Until next week (racing my way up the coast and loving it)

Milly
fields.bodyText: Thursday April 26 was another big day for me - my last day ever at my hotel in Sydney. For the last time I dragged myself in too early, polished, cleaned, set, served, vacuumed... well, OK, I'm not really going to miss that but I'll certainly miss the social side and all the different people I've met. On the other hand I couldn't wait to be hitting the road again - there's a very big world just waiting for me to see it. Friday night was my official work farewell night, so before that I attempted to get my life into order. I phoned the Oz Experience people whom I'm travelling with between Sydney and Cairns, and booked to leave on Tuesday. I'd already bought the ticket in England, now its just a little matter of phoning them every time I want to travel on - though sadly I've got to be in Cairns by May 20, so its going to be something of a whistle-stop tour. However, I've had lots of good advice so I'm going to try and fit in as much as possible. That night was a particularly mad one, but as it was the last time I would ever see the people from work it was nice to go with a bang! On Saturday I somehow managed to rouse myself in time to go to the races. The night before my manager had been kind enough to give me some tickets he couldn't use (including entry into the members' stand) on the condition that I go along and dress up. There was no way I could turn down an offer like that. The race course was just a short bus-ride from my house which gave me time to hunt out my sole respectable outfit! I've never been to the races before, but it was quite an experience. The men were all in suits and the women in various states of classy dress with the odd wonderful hat - although nothing on the Ascot scale. People-watching was probably the highlight of the day. I allocated myself a sum of money to waste - I had no illusions of ever seeing it again - and then realised I had no idea how to place a bet. After several failed attempts I enlisted the help of a nice lady, and finally succeeded in placing a small bet 'each way'. I watched from the stalls as the horses thundered towards the finish-line. Mine came in fourth. I asked an old couple if that meant I'd won anything, but sadly not. There were eight races that day and I improved at the betting business enough that I was soon confidently requesting "five to win on number three in the fourth". It was definitely fun to watch the tiny jockeys race by, but it wasn't until the third race when my horse snatched it by a nose that I understood the rush of winning and why everybody jumps up from their seats and yells at the track. webTitle: The Ken effect that never happened

fields.headline: The Ken effect that never happened
fields.standfirst:
It's one year since Ken Livingstone thwarted his former party to became mayor of London; but all still looks rosy for Tony. Will Woodward wonders what all the fuss was about

Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: It's one year since Ken Livingstone thwarted his former party to became mayor of London; but all still looks rosy for Tony.Will Woodwardwonders what all the fuss was about.
fields.body:
So, about Ken: what's your problem? Just over a year ago I spent three weeks asking figures in the Labour party and outside essentially that question.

The results ran for a few thousand words in the Guardian below the headline "The case against Ken Livingstone", and attempted to explain why so many apparently reasonable people had such a negative attitude towards the would-be mayor.

Accompanying the piece that day was a story that Mr Livingstone had been approaching high profile Londoners, including the academic Tony Travers and journalist Simon Jenkins, asking them to stand for the assembly as independents with a view to eventually supporting him.

This was important at the time because Mr Livingstone was insisting that "under no circumstances" would he stand as an independent for mayor. The revelation showed just how far had gone his plans to leave Labour if, as eventually happened, Millbank ensured that he did not win the party's nomination for mayor.

Those who thought he would run as an independent were right. One of the main lines of attack on Ken as an independent, at a time when he was trying to win the votes of Labour members, was that the 'drip, drip, drip' of anti-Labour slant ("really splash, splash, splash," according to Terry Ashton, former general secretary of the London party), would hurt the government.

As an independent, he has been his own man. But Labour's poll ratings have remained, save for a blip over fuel, serenely high. This might not have been the case had Ken been Labour's candidate. Ken has helped teach Blair - perhaps belately, some might say, following the fiasco in Wales when Alun Michael was imposed as first minister over Rhodri Morgan - to lighten up. However Tony Travers, a local government expert, writes in the new book The Blair Effect:

"It is impossible to know how much damage the Livingstone debacle did to Blair and his government. National opinion polls did not waver. But New Labour's image as a party of efficient and effective political fixers was dealt a major blow."

But has Ken been "an absolute answer to a prayer" for Tory papers, as Neil Kinnock claimed? Er, no. Can Labour voters "afford to mess about", as Kinnock doubted, by backing Ken? Er, yes. Look at the sky, which has clearly not fallen in.

However, the accusation that he would not work successfully with the government has been confirmed over Livingstone's number one policy concern - the tube. Ken - along with the public - opposes John Prescott's part-privatisation plan for London Underground. According to Bob Kiley, the man who transformed the New York subway and Ken's underground tsar, it is "unworkable and dangerous".

Kiley is the sort of man Blair would do business with - if he wasn't doing business with Ken. But Londoners will not exempt Ken from blame if, by the time he seeks re-election, there are no signs that the tube is getting better.

Some critics outside Downing Street claimed Livingstone's record as leader of the Greater London Council was poor and a sign of things to come. As then, he is spending heavily on advertising - £1m to plug a public consultation process for London's transport strategy, with posters and leaflets featuring Ken's phizog. Another £20m is being spent promoting congestion charges. But then the government spent £62m on advertising in the first quarter of the year alone. And council taxes are going up: a rise in the precept charged by the Greater London Authority is going up by £27.90 for a band D property, constituting about half the overall rise in council taxes.

So is Ken a grandstander, a wacky leftie? The "rainbow coalition" is not much in evidence. Ken backed the tube strikers, but he also supported the police over the May Day protest. Business and the city have been courted.

He is surrounded by a phalanx of cronies, including Socialist Action alumni John Ross who was once a leading light of Socialist Action and is now his chief economic adviser on £40,000. There is also Redmond O'Neill, now transport adviser on £29,500.

Leftwingers Lee Jasper, a prominent black activist, Diane Abbott and John McDonnell, former GLC deputy leader, are in Ken's cabinet. Dave Wetzel, once in charge of Mr Livingstone's "fares fair" transport policy, is the vice-chairman of Transport for London.

But Ken, a Blair-style big-tenter, is also working with former foes. From the right comes Steve Norris and Susan Kramer, Tory and Lib Dem candidates for mayor. They are both on the Transport for London board. From the left comes Glenda Jackson, a contender for the Labour nomination, who is in his cabinet. Everyone, it seems, can do business with Ken. Except the leaders of his former party, which, unfortunately for him, are the government.

webTitle: Analysis: Trains and shares and planes

fields.headline: Trains and shares and planes
fields.standfirst:
Since Hatfield, the case for public ownership of Railtrack has been strengthened; making it a non-profit trust should silence the doubters

Special report: transport in Britain
Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: Announcing a £4bn plan to increase the carriage of freight by rail, Alastair Morton of the Strategic Rail Authority yesterday said he was putting the railway "at the heart of the logistics chain". The industry, he added, must take advantage of the opportunities offered.
fields.body:
Announcing a £4bn plan to increase the carriage of freight by rail, Alastair Morton of the Strategic Rail Authority yesterday said he was putting the railway "at the heart of the logistics chain". The industry, he added, must take advantage of the opportunities offered.

But what, after Hatfield, is the rail "industry"? Public or private? Railtrack is undergoing a metamorphosis. In return for an advance of £1.5bn from the government, it agreed to focus on its "core business" operating, maintaining and renewing the existing network. It has undertaken to appoint a non-executive board member with a specific remit to defend passengers and the public interest and says that it plans to limit shareholder dividends over the next five years. Railtrack will also receive nearly £500m extra over this period in freight subsidies. These payments are in addition to nearly £5bn already promised in direct grants.

On major new enhancement projects, starting with the upgrading of the East Coast main line, its role has been downgraded. Other private sector partners, including the train operating companies, will be invited to take the lead. Railtrack has also been stripped of its role in building the second and final section of the high-speed Channel Tunnel Rail Link (CTRL), from Southfleet in Kent to London St Pancras. Instead it will take over the operation of CTRL once built by London & Continental Railways in a partnership with the engineering firm Bechtel.

Whether this is the end of the line or the start of a process of more fundamental reform depends on whether the problem with the railways turns out to be structural or managerial. At present, ministers tend towards the latter view. In particular, they argue that the renationalisation of Railtrack would cost too much and delay investment.

The first of these arguments is spurious. Renationalisation could save money, since shares are a more expensive form of finance than government borrowing in order to buy them back. The cost equation depends on whether you believe that Railtrack as a public monopoly will be more or less efficient than as a private monopoly. A parallel can be drawn with the Welsh water utility, Dwr Cymru. The water services regulator, Ofwat, has approved the acquisition of Dwr Cymru, a private company, by Glas Cymru, a non-profit company limited by guarantee. One of the arguments in favour is the potential for lower financing costs which would lead to lower bills.

Much of the force of the second argument has been blunted by the diminished role of Railtrack, which has been asked to concentrate on routine maintenance and renewal. Major investment projects will be taken forward as joint ventures involving the train operating companies and other private sector partners, with Railtrack owning and operating the new infrastructure on completion as part of an integrated network. This change itself could undermine the rail regulator's recent review of Railtrack's charges. Because the financial risks involved in these projects are higher, Railtrack is allowed to make bigger profits than would otherwise have been the case, an annual 8% return on its regulatory asset base.

All of this highlights Railtrack's multiple personalities as network operator, railway builder, profit-making company and public service provider. There is another reason to reconsider the ownership of Railtrack, which is to make it more accountable to passengers and train operators. Some train operating companies would like to operate their own track but most lines are used by more than one operator. Although it could work on some parts of the network, integration between track and train operations could fragment the network and add to the bureaucracy of contracts.

The trust option for Railtrack has attractions. Its board could include the different stakeholders, government and train operating companies but also passengers and workforce. Like Glas Cymru, it could be accountable to a representative membership. Without shareholders or profits, a potential conflict of interest would be removed. As a company at arm's length from government, it might borrow free from Treasury constraints. It could be financed by the issue of private bonds with or without government guarantees - such as those pro vided for the Channel tunnel link. A bonus could be simplification of the regulatory structure. With no danger of Railtrack exploiting its monopoly status for profit, the role of the rail regulator could be refashioned and even absorbed into the SRA.

An arrangement not dissimilar to a trust or public corporation has been arrived at for National Air Traffic Services (Nats). A consortium of UK airlines has been chosen for the public private partnership, which will hold 46% of shares in Nats. It has promised to operate on a not for profit basis, so no dividends will be paid to its shareholders. Some 49% of the shares will be owned by the government and the remaining 5% by the workforce.

In spite of the recent injections of cash, huge uncertainties remain over Railtrack's future. It has been unable to find a new chairman. The full extent of its financial trou bles will not be apparent until its accounts are published next month. The train operators are claiming more compensation for lost custom than Railtrack is willing to give. Its future costs continue to escalate, such as for the refurbishment of the West Coast Main Line, which is now estimated to cost £6.3bn, up from the estimate of £5.8bn last October and the original estimate of £2.3bn. Railtrack could also be the subject of charges of corporate manslaughter for the deaths at Hatfield.

In principle, the argument for public ownership of Railtrack is strong. Following the examples of Nats and the Welsh water utility, a new start for Railtrack as a non-profit trust is practically and politically a winning formula.

 Tony Grayling is at the Institute for Public Policy Research.

webTitle: Five years left for Sumatra forest

fields.headline: Five years left for Sumatra forest
fields.trailText: The richest forests on Earth - on the Sundra Shelf in Sumatra, Indonesia - will be totally destroyed in five years if the current "resource anarchy" in the country continues, say four world experts in today's edition of the magazine Science.
fields.body:
The richest forests on Earth - on the Sundra Shelf in Sumatra, Indonesia - will be totally destroyed in five years if the current "resource anarchy" in the country continues, say four world experts in today's edition of the magazine Science.

Key animal species such as the Sumatran rhinoceros, the Sumatran tiger and the Asian elephant are heading for extinction unless there is radical action to save them, they say.

The report says that the local districts charged with managing the forests cannot cope with illegal logging gangs.

During a visit to Indonesia in December, the authors saw the gangs acting freely, clearing and burning large tracts of forests for agriculture. They also saw extensive saw mill operations.

The report claims that Jakarta is unable, or unwilling, to stop such activity but that to avoid a "biological catastrophe" action cannot be delayed until the political climate settles.

Forests on the Kerinci lowlands will be destroyed in three years, the report says, while illegal logging vastly increases the risks of huge forest fires and could trigger widespread flooding due to the diminishing number of trees able to soak up rainwater.

The authors include Kathy MacKinnon, senior biodiversity expert at the World Bank, and Paul Jepson, an Indonesia conservation expert.

The authors suggest prosecuting illegal loggers, including top officials, and greater public exposure of wrongdoing. They also called for vigorous opposition at local level.

fields.headline: 'America teaches kids to ask questions'
fields.trailText: An American teacher writes that American children are more accustomed to offering their own opinions than their British counterparts, writes David Cohen in this week's press roundup.
fields.body:
Amid all of the chatter on the other side of the Atlantic these days of establishing rigorous national standards, amid all the stateside groaning and moaning about failed education and crumbling schools - few educators in the US, in the view of Amy Biancolli, in one of the more interesting opinion pieces to have appeared in the world press this past week, have given any credit to what American pedagogy actually does so much better than the British. "Namely," she believes, that it "teaches American kids to ask questions".

Ms Biancolli, a high school teacher, whose provocative views appeared in the Washington Post, offered her transatlantic grouse on the basis of the year she spent in the mid-80's working at a large private girls' school in Edinburgh. "It took months of badgering before I was able to get some of my Scottish teenagers to speak up in class," she recalls. "They simply weren't accustomed to asking questions or tossing around their own observations."

So desperate did she become to whip up her charges that she took to bringing a Trivial Pursuit board into school, complete with made-up questions about current events - all in the hope, alas unrealised, of kindling their interest in any subject not purely to do with national education tests. For American readers, then, her conclusion for 2001, offered with a near audible shiver, was simple: "Widespread standardised testing is an evil that the American educational system should avoid at all costs."

But not so dirty dancing. An editorial in the Philadelphia Inquirer didn't know whether to laugh or cry over the new craze, variously known as the Freak or Grinding, which at least one local school has recently banned, to the anguished howls of many teens and some of their parents. A brief description of the Freak's dance steps at issue follows (reader discretion advised): "A girl might be on all fours, with one boy's pelvis pressed into her face and another's pressed into her bottom. [School administrators] see boys on their backs with girls spreadeagled over them; girls bent forward with boys' hips thrust into their backsides." Sometimes, noted the editorial, "hands slip inside pants."

With such descriptions vividly in mind, administrators at a growing number of other American schools have taken to outlawing all sexual innuendo from the dance floor, leaving their charges, one assumes, to choose between the Charleston, the jitterbug, or ... well, what exactly? "Now everyone - students, administrators, parents - will be forced to teach one another some needed new steps," parried the editorial.

There was a faint whiff of sarcasm in an op-ed piece by Michael Freund in yesterday's Jerusalem Post that examined the purported links between a Zionist quest for world domination and the popularity of the schoolchildren's game of Pokemon. Commenting on the campaigns in a number of Arab nations to ban the game from schools, on account of it being a "Zionist and Jewish plot", the article noted that Pokemon has attracted the criticism because it promotes "theories of evolution, encourages gambling and, at its core, is part of a Jewish conspiracy aimed at turning children away from Islam." Mr Freund isn't of a mind to disagree. "I have discovered," he wrote, "that if one pronounces Pikachu (a popular Pokemon character) with a heavy Yiddish accent, it does sound strikingly similar to 'Pick a Jew', which could be interpreted as a covert Zionist plea for voters across the world to elect Jewish candidates. And there are various Pokemon characters that bear an extraordinary resemblance to former foreign minister David Levy on a bad-hair day."

Never mind that spot of diplomatic unpleasantness which followed the American Navy plane and a Chinese fighter colliding in indeterminate circumstances last month over the South China Sea, or even the by now periodic arrests of Western-trained academics whose work takes them too far into mainland China. Not in Taiwan, at any rate, where a major object of editorial fascination continues to be last month's dawn raid by police at National Chengkung University, in which dormitories were turned upside down and computers searched for MP3 files. At least 14 of the Chengkung students were found to be in possession of illegal music files, for which they are now being sued by the relevant music companies for intellectual property theft.

"We cannot remember the last time when the students of Taiwan were so united by a burning rage," said the Taipei Times, noting in its editorial that the raid appeared to have taken place without a search warrant or even the explicit consent of university authorities. Still, it added, "Everyone needs to realise that Taiwan is undergoing a transformation from intellectual property user to intellectual property creator [but] if we want others to respect our own intellectual property rights, we must first learn to respect the rights of others."

More sarcasm, this time in the Times of India, in a leader article on the nation's University Grants Commission's decision to offer diplomas, at both the graduate and post-graduate levels, for aspiring pandits.

"For far too long," sniffed the Times, "the pandit has remained a butt of jokes, due to his pigtail, his ghanta and the traditional rapid-fire style of uttering mantras. Regular courses of study and examination would eliminate the unsavoury comedy because no one will dare take a crack at a certificate-holding purohit." To the charge that such programmes might be a complete waste of scarce education resources on the subcontinent, the paper shook its head. "The number and frequency of religious ceremonies are steadily on the rise, the dotcom era has failed to wean the devotee away from his deity, and the pandit is becoming increasingly indispensable."

fields.headline: Peace overtures at BAE Systems
fields.trailText: BAE Systems has established a dedicated business unit with a "significant budget" aimed at harnessing its weapons technology for civilian use, in a stepping up of its efforts to turn swords into ploughshares.
fields.body:
BAE Systems has established a dedicated business unit with a "significant budget" aimed at harnessing its weapons technology for civilian use, in a stepping up of its efforts to turn swords into ploughshares.

The chairman, Sir Dick Evans, announced the move at yesterday's annual general meeting, which was dominated by protesters attacking the group's ethics.

Speaking at an acrimonious meeting from which half a dozen people were ejected, Sir Dick insisted the company was committed to shifting the balance of its operations towards "non-lethal" activities.

At the same time, he disclosed that BAE was hoping to gain contracts from President Bush's controversial "son of star wars" missile defence proposals which, critics say, could reignite the arms race.

Sir Dick pointed out that the company's ring laser equipment, used to stabilise fighter planes, could provide effective suspension in cars. BAE Systems had signed a deal with a Japanese motor manufacturer to exploit its use in mass-market vehicles.

Expertise in miniaturisation, derived from designing tiny instruments for planes and tanks, had led to the development of a tiny pump which could be used in surgery on patients with heart failure.

"We're putting a lot of effort into extracting this kind of technology and finding uses for it," said Sir Dick. "We've put a significant budget behind it and it's being done on a much more cohesive basis than in the past."

The dedicated unit is still at an embryonic stage but will be headed by Tony Rice, the managing director of BAE Ventures.

Sir Dick stopped short of putting a target on the proportion of revenue BAE Systems hoped to attract from civilian business and made clear he would not baulk at further controversial military contracts.

Asked about the US missile defence programme, which was condemned this week by Russia and China, Sir Dick appeared to welcome Mr Bush's renewed enthusiasm. "It does look as though the Republicans may be looking at this on a rather wider basis," he said. "That could open up some further opportunities."

Directors defended the company's work in the US, which has refused to sign the Ottawa convention banning the use of landmines. John Weston, the chief executive, said: "The US hasn't signed up to the Ottawa convention because it feels it needs an alternative before stopping using landmines."

BAE Systems was working on a system of sensors which would distinguish between vehicles and people, and would alert officers of movement rather than exploding indiscriminately.

The meeting saw the latest in a series of confrontations with groups such as the Campaign Against the Arms Trade, which object to BAE's supply of equipment to China, Morocco, South Africa and Indonesia.

Activists greeted shareholders outside the QE2 conference centre in London, and a group of women sang the peace anthem Stand Up Now. During the meeting, a man was ejected for walking around the room wearing a Pinocchio-style long nose while Sir Dick was in full flow.

One shareholder described a recent visit to Iraq, where he had encountered a young man named Amir, who had been crippled at the age of 12 by a missile attack on a fruit market, fired by a British aeroplane. Addressing Sir Dick, the investor asked: "What would you say to him about your role in making profits from his misery? Do you want world peace or are you praying for war?"

Sir Dick promised to consider a visit to Iraq to talk to such victims, adding that BAE Systems' defensive products could prevent war: "We have made and continue to make a very major contribution to world peace."

A refugee from the western Sahara urged the company not to arm the Moroccan authorities, who are accused of human rights atrocities in the area. Sir Dick said it was "highly unlikely" that BAE Systems would do such a thing.

After a series of criticisms, Sir Dick replied: "If you have that view, I find the fact that you've bought shares somewhat surprising."

fields.headline: John Allen
fields.standfirst: Pioneering physicist whose helium research aided astronomers mapping the evolution of the universe
fields.trailText: Pioneering physicist whose helium research aided astronomers mapping the evolution of the universe.
fields.body:
The physicist John Allen, who has died aged 92, pioneered research into the way some materials undergo extraordinary changes at very low temperatures near absolute zero. In particular, he was one of the discoverers of the extraordinary behaviour of helium, called superfluidity.

Instead of freezing solid when cooled to near absolute zero, liquid helium lost its viscosity. As if in defiance of gravity, it would drift up the wall of its container and over the rim; and Allen found it could leak through tiny holes more easily than any gas, even hydrogen.

This change to a superfluid state took place when helium was cooled below 2.17 Kelvin (-270.98C or -455.76F). The superfluid behaved so differently from helium at temperatures above 2.2K that it was given a separate name, helium II, to distinguish it from the more usual form, called helium I.

Helium II was also a superb conductor of heat, conducting it 800 times as rapidly as copper. So when heated gently to over 2.2K, a rapid thermal expansion forced the surface of the liquid to rise up in the form of a fountain. It was a spectacular effect that Allen used to good effect to ram home some tough physics in the lecture hall with a touch of showmanship.

The discovery had great implications for astronomers, assembling possible models of the evolution of the universe, to take into account some extraordinary physics. While superfluid helium was a rare laboratory creation on earth, it demonstrated a phenomenon that would have been all-pervasive throughout the early cosmos.

Allen was born in Winnipeg, Canada. He gained his first degree in 1928, at the University of Manitoba, where his father was professor of physics. Allen Sr thought his son needed a bit of experience before venturing on a further career - so, for the next year, the young man assisted in research in sensory perception through sound and vision, as part of a biophysics project.

In 1929, he won a three-year scholarship in the physics department at Toronto University, where Sir John McLennan had created a world-leading cryogenics research centre for conducting experiments at very low temperatures.

Allen took his PhD in superconductivity in 1933, and was then introduced by Don Misener to research into the phenomenon that was later called superfluid helium. While at Toronto, he designed and built the first portable cryostat, a glass apparatus for maintaining very low temperatures, which was taken to London for McLennan to give a public lecture on liquid helium and demonstrate superconductivity at the Royal Institution. The apparatus is still in the institution's museum.

In 1935, Allen moved to the Royal Society Mond Laboratory, Cambridge, where he had hoped to work with the Russian physicist Peter Kapitza, who was renowned for his work with extremely low temperatures of liquid helium. But, in 1934, after one of his annual visits to his mother in the Soviet Union, Kapitza was detained, and never returned to Cambridge.

So the two scientists worked independently, and, in January 1938, the science journal Nature published the results of their separate work.

Two single-page papers appeared side by side; one by Kapitza in Moscow, the other by Allen and Misener, both then at Cambridge. Both papers reported experiments showing that helium could flow through incredibly small channels with apparently zero viscosity - this was the discovery of superfluidity.

For reasons yet to be unravelled by science historians, most of the credit for the discovery was given to Kapitza, who won the 1978 Nobel physics prize for his work.

Allen continued research and teaching at Cambridge until 1947, when he was made professor of natural philosophy at St Andrews University. He was twice dean of the faculty of science, and responsible for major reforms. He had an important influence both in establishing the university's international reputation in pure and applied physics and astronomy, and in encouraging the development of science in Scotland.

Allen was elected a fellow of the Physical Society in 1945, of the Royal Society of Edinburgh and the American Physical Society in 1948, and of the Royal Society in 1949. He was chairman of the very-low temperature commission of the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics, and a member of the British National Committee for Physics.

His 1933 marriage to Elfriede Hiebert ended in divorce in 1951; they adopted a son, Hugh, who survives him.

 John Frank Allen, physicist, born May 6 1908; died April 22 2001

fields.headline: Lowry's gentle eye
fields.standfirst: Writer's collection goes on sale
fields.trailText: LS Lowry (1887-1976), immortaliser of the huddled masses and the smoking factory chimney, is not the first artist you might associate with Frederick Forsyth, Lady Thatcher's favourite thriller writer.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
LS Lowry (1887-1976), immortaliser of the huddled masses and the smoking factory chimney, is not the first artist you might associate with Frederick Forsyth, Lady Thatcher's favourite thriller writer.

However, it emerged yesterday that for 20 years Mr Forsyth, now a gentleman farmer and scourge of the euro-loving left, has been collecting Lowry's views of industrial streetscapes and spindly dogs.

Next month he will put up nine of his Lowry paintings at a Christie's auction. He is already a millionaire from his bestsellers, including The Day of the Jackal, The Odessa File and The Dogs of War, but the collection is expected to bring in at least another million.

Yesterday he referred back to Christie's all calls about his decision to sell. The auction house said he intended to launch into another area of collecting, but it did not know which one.

He said of Lowry's appeal: "There is something about the figures in his pictures that intrigues me; all seem to be locked in thought, some pressing forward upon a personal errand, some gazing melancholy into the distance, others about to say something to the figure next to them. They are alive with the concerns of every day, but caught and locked into perpetuity by Lowry's gentle eye."

Northern River Scene, 1959, regarded as the strongest of the collection, is estimated at up to £300,000. Lowry was commissioned to paint Lincoln but set a factory, instead of the cathedral, at the heart of the composition.

Industrial Scene was one of 16 works by contemporary artists reproduced to decorate Lyons tearooms.

Frederick Forsyth was born in Ashford, Kent, in 1938. He became a journalist, doing foreign correspondent work for Reuters and the BBC. When he returned to London in 1969 he expanded a short story he had written - about repeated attempts to assassinate Charles de Gaulle - into The Day of the Jackal.

He is now a radio and print political commentator, denouncing the Labour government on subjects including the farmer and the pound, which must be preserved, and the fox, which should be hunted.
