webTitle: London 'is safer than most EU capitals'

fields.headline: London 'is safer than most EU capitals'
fields.standfirst:
As violent crime rises by 20% in England and Wales, the capital's murder rate remains low

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: London is still one of the safer capital cities in the world to live in with a murder rate below the European average, according to international criminal justice statistics published yesterday.
fields.body:
London is still one of the safer capital cities in the world to live in with a murder rate below the European average, according to international criminal justice statistics published yesterday.

The Home Office figures show that overall recorded crime levels in England and Wales fell faster in the second half of the 1990s than in the average European country.

However, the chances of becoming a victim of a burglary or car crime in England and Wales remain among the highest in the European Union.

Although violent crime rose by 20% in England and Wales between 1995 and 1999, the years covered by the international comparison, the murder rate in London remains among the lowest of all European capitals with a killing rate of 2.36 per 100,000.

The homicide figures for Northern Ireland show that the murder rate in the province dropped 55% between 1998 and 1999 as the Good Friday agreement took effect. Northern Ireland recorded a murder rate in 1999 of 3.87 per 100,000; about the same as cities such as Copenhagen and Berne.

The murder capital of the world remains Washington DC (50.82), and other capitals struggling with crime are Pretoria in South Africa (27.47) and Moscow (18.20).

England and Wales however still retain their place near the top of the European imprisonment league with 125 inmates per 100,000 inhabitants compared with a European Union average of 87 prisoners per 100,000 population. Longer sentences in England and Wales was the main reason the prison population rose between 1995 and 1999.

Within Europe only Portugal has a more punitive culture, imprisoning 142 people for each 100,000 inhabitants. These imprisonment rates are relatively low compared with Russia, which jails 729 for each 100,000, and America which has an imprisonment rate of 682 per 100,000.

The overall recorded crime rate across Europe barely changed over the period 1995 - 1999 falling by about 1% in EU member states. The largest falls were in Ireland (21%), England and Wales (10%), Scotland (8%) and Denmark (8%). Some countries outside Europe enjoyed big falls in official crime rates with the US down 16% and Canada down by 11%.

Although violent crime rose sharply in England and Wales in the second half of the 1990s, the highest rises in Europe were seen in Italy (up 37%), the Netherlands (34%) and France (31%). Violent crime in Russia fell by 46% and in America by 20%.

The Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, said the figures were encouraging but more had to be done. "Comparing the recorded crime statistics of different countries is always difficult because of a wide variation in recording practices, counting rules and offence definitions," he said.

"What they do show, however, is that crime in England and Wales is far too high - and while crime continues to fall we are still recovering from the large increases in the late 1980s and early 1990s."

The international comparisons were published as the home secretary, Jack Straw, unveiled details of his plans to introduce "custody plus" sentences, which would mean that the period in prison would be followed by an enforced programme in the community designed to prevent reoffending.

webTitle: Objects moved by the power of light

fields.headline: Objects moved by the power of light
fields.trailText: Researchers in Scotland have come up with a laser device able to grip and twist objects at a distance. The device, invented by a team from the physics department at St Andrews University, is able to rotate microscopic objects, such as a tiny glass rod, twice the thickness of a human hair, with nothing more than the power of light.
fields.body:
Researchers in Scotland have come up with a laser device able to grip and twist objects at a distance. The device, invented by a team from the physics department at St Andrews University, is able to rotate microscopic objects, such as a tiny glass rod, twice the thickness of a human hair, with nothing more than the power of light.

"We've only just begun to realise the possibilities for what we might do with this technology," said Kishan Dholakia, one of the researchers who wrote a paper on the "tractor beam" in today's edition of the journal Science.

Particles of light have a tiny amount of mass and high velocity, meaning laser beams exert a slight force on objects they touch.

This property has already been used to create "laser tweezers", tightly focused beams which can trap microscopic objects and move them from place to place. But those lasers could not, like traditional tweezers in a human hand, turn most objects around.

By using two lasers together, the St Andrews team created an interference pattern in the form of a spiral of light which traps an object in the arms. Adjusting the beams causes the spiral to rotate, taking the object with it.

As well as the glass rod, which could be used to stir tiny amounts of liquid, the scientists have rotated a hamster chromosome, showing how their technique could be used to study the innermost workings of cells for medical research.

Another use for the "tractor beam" is in nanotechnology, the science of building microscopic machines from components not much larger than a few molecules.

"Our technique could be used to drive motors, mixers, centrifuges, and other rotating parts in cheap, tiny, automated technologies of the future," Dr Dholakia said.

Another member of the team, Michael McDonald, said it would not be practical to scale up the beam to move bigger objects. The power of the lasers used was very low, but that did not mean that a laser 100 times as powerful would be able to move an object 100 times as big.

webTitle: The Dear Leader's look (and how to get it)

fields.headline: The Dear Leader's look (and how to get it)
fields.standfirst: Jess Cartner-Morley reveals why North Korea's Kim Jong-il has his finger firmly on fashion's sleek, militaristic pulse
fields.trailText: Jess Cartner-Morley reveals why North Korea's Kim Jong-il has his finger firmly on fashion's sleek, militaristic pulse.
fields.body:
A few titbits of information, of varying plausibility, periodically emanate from the closely guarded world of Kim Jong-il. Stories range from the mild - the North Korean leader's taste for foreign cigarettes and French cognac - to lurid tales of excess, last days of the Roman Empire-style, involving bear fights and dancing girls. One story, however, has the unmistakable ring of truth. While his country remains distanced from the outside world, Kim Jong-il has installed satellite television for himself and is a keen viewer.

It is pretty clear from recent portraits that Kim Jong-il is an avid fan of MTV's House of Style. How else to explain the striking parallels between this outfit and the autumn/ winter 2001/2002 collections shown earlier this year? The blouson-style jacket, the neatly ironed trousers, the shiny shoes - he could have stepped straight off the Louis Vuitton catwalk.

What's even more impressive is that Kim Jong-il has been working this look for years. He has clearly long been aware of the growing military influence on menswear. In September 1998, when he was officially named head of state, he appeared in a dashing pale grey quilted flying jacket. Since then, his look has become increasingly pared-down, in line with the sleeker silhouette promoted on the menswear catwalks. Plainly, he foresaw the shift from long military coats to shorter blouson styles which was a feature of the recent collections. The ribbed hem of his jacket echoes the ribbed detailing shown by Ruffo in Milan and Cerruti in Paris, while the sharply pleated trousers and well-polished shoes are dead ringers for Neil Barrett's. The overall silhouette - boxy bomber jacket, smart loose trousers and shiny shoes - was a mainstay of the menswear collections at Jil Sander and Vuitton. The look has elements of military styling in its dull colour and utilitarian shape. The dumpy jacket, as favoured by minicab drivers worldwide, is clearly a sharp sartorial comment on the ethics of fashion appropriating the uniforms of the working man.

Granted, it's not a totally unique look. There are reportedly many similarly fashion-forward types on the streets of Pyongyang. But no one wears it with quite the flair that Kim Jong-il does. Look at him: he's loving the camera. He knows he looks hot.

Sadly, that blouson-shaped jacket does his portly physique few favours, while the boxy shapes of the outfit accentuate his short stature. The regularity with which he wheels out this outfit also points at a less than sparklingly inventive wardrobe. Nonetheless, in the fashion stakes, North Korea's leader gets our vote. Look out for the Kim look around Hoxton Square any day now.

fields.headline: Councillor investigated over regeneration funds
fields.trailText: Police are investigating the affairs of a Labour councillor who allegedly channelled thousands of pounds of regeneration funding into his own private company.
fields.body:
Police are investigating the affairs of a Labour councillor who allegedly channelled thousands of pounds of regeneration funding into his own private company.

Duncan McGregor is being investigated by fraud squad officers in Derbyshire over allegations that he used his position as head of a regeneration trust in a rundown mining area to line his own pocket.

He has already paid money back to a village parish council that uncovered his secret scheme to siphon money from the trust to his own firm - and which has now asked the police to investigate him. Until recently, Mr McGregor was head of the scrutiny panel at his local authority, Bolsover district council, but stood down from the chair when the parish council's allegations were made public.

The claims centre on Creswell regeneration trust, which Mr McGregor helped set up in 1996 to help breathe new life back into the former pit village.

Mr McGregor and Keith De Banke had been chairman and clerk, respectively, of Creswell parish council when it was decided the council should grant £10,000 a year to the trust to develop new sports facilities at the village miners' welfare building.

Both Mr McGregor and Mr De Banke were directors of the trust, a company limited by guarantee.

Between 1996 and 1998, the council gave £30,000 to the regeneration trust but became concerned when there was no sign of any new sports facilities at the miners' welfare, which had been refurbished by the trust with funding from numerous public bodies.

When Labour lost control of the parish council in 1999, the ruling independent group instigated an investigation and found that a private company of which Mr McGregor and Mr De Banke were both directors had bought the offices in which the regeneration trust was based and the trust was now paying rent to the firm.

A total of £13,000 of public money had been paid to their private company before the arrangement was revealed.

It is not known what difference, if any, there was in the amount of rent paid to Mr McGregor's company and that paid to the previous landlord.

In an out-of-court settlement, the two men agreed to pay £5,000 each and legal costs of £16,000 to Creswell parish council, which sued them for "recovery of personal gain" and whose case was due to be heard last month.

Further investigations revealed that on numerous occasions between 1997 and last year, Mr McGregor's separate expenses for representing Bolsover district council and the regeneration trust showed him to be in different parts of the country at the same time.

On the same day, Mr McGregor managed to be in Torquay on council business and in Worksop, North Nottinghamshire, on trust business.

Other examples show him to have been in Wigan and Hull; London and Matlock; and Glasgow and Lichfield.

Bolsover district council has said its dealings with the trust were all satisfactorily audited and Mr McGregor's expenses claims were legitimate.

Chairman of Cresswell parish council, Shaun Wass, said there should be strict rules governing councillors handling public funds but not making themselves publicly accountable.

He said: "It is an absolute disgrace that he has received personal benefit from public funding. The rules need to be tightened up to stop anything like this happening again."

He said the parish council had voted overwhelmingly in favour of Mr McGregor resigning his seat, but he had refused to go, claiming he had done nothing wrong.

Mr De Banke resigned as clerk and finance officer in 1999.

Derbyshire police confirmed they were investigating allegations made against Mr McGregor, who was unavailable for comment.

fields.headline: A hardline act to follow
fields.standfirst: According to the polls, Ariel Sharon has the support of the people despite the violence, writes Suzanne Goldenberg
fields.trailText: According to the polls, Ariel Sharon has the support of the people despite the violence, writes Suzanne Goldenberg
fields.body:
When the hardliner Ariel Sharon was swept to power as prime minister, his campaign managers claimed he was the one man who could bring peace and security for Israelis.

Two months on, Mr Sharon has not delivered on either promise. The Palestinian uprising ignited by the ageing warrior's morning jaunt to a Muslim holy site in Jerusalem has entered its eighth month, claiming nearly 500 lives, most of them Palestinian, and Islamist militant suicide bombers continue to strike inside the borders of their state.

And yet despite the impasse, a poll published today suggests Israelis remain extraordinarily satisfied with their prime minister.

The survey, which appears in Yediot Ahronoth, the country's largest circulation newspaper, found 70% of Israelis - and 78% of Jewish Israelis - say they trust Mr Sharon as prime minister.

That gives him the highest credibility rating of any Israeli prime minister, according to the poll for the Dahaf Institute.

Since his installation two months ago, Mr Sharon, true to his 50-year past, has focused on military efforts to snuff out the revolt against Israel's occupation.

He has turned the invasion of Palestinian-ruled territory into the Gaza Strip - a violation of the Oslo peace accords - into a regular exercise. That has blunted international criticism of the Israeli army's destruction of orange groves, olive trees, private homes, and police posts in areas that belong to Yasser Arafat's administration by making such abuses appear routine.

Mr Sharon has stepped up the assassination of Palestinian activists, and indicated this week that Israel would persist in such internationally condemned tactics.

But what has he accomplished? The Palestinian response to Mr Sharon has brought suicide bombings in the heart of the Jewish state, mortar attacks on Jewish settlements inside the Gaza Strip, and a revival of drive-by shooting attacks on Israeli motorists in the West Bank.

Rightwing Israelis, led by Jewish settlers, want Mr Sharon to strike back even harder against the Palestinians and to re-occupy tranches of Palestinian territory. However, a sharp US rebuke for just such an action in Gaza last month has set limits on Mr Sharon's efforts to snuff out the uprising.

So how solid is the support from Israeli civilians for Mr Sharon's hardline approach?

Despite his high overall approval rating, the poll suggests Israelis hope Mr Sharon will change. Some 62% of Israelis, and 58% of Israeli Jews, want Mr Sharon to accept the Jordanian-Egyptian ceasefire proposal now under consideration. That means they oppose Mr Sharon's refusal to accept a core plank of the initiative: a freeze on the illegal Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza.

The poll also found that Israelis differ with Mr Sharon on his refusal to negotiate with the Palestinians under fire. Some 52% of Israelis, including 49% Jewish Israelis, support negotiations; just 25% of Israelis want Mr Sharon to exert more military pressure on the Palestinians.

Although Mr Sharon enjoys the trust of his people now, "the great majority of Israelis adopt moderate positions," Yediot says.

"Positions that are not accepted by a good portion of Sharon's ministers, and often not by Sharon himself."

That means if Mr Sharon wants to stay in Israelis' good books, he will have to look far beyond the military operations that have defined his prime ministership so far.

fields.headline: Camelot chief to head marketing institute
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Camelot chief executive Dianne Thompson is to be the new president of the Chartered Institute of Marketing, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Camelot chief executive Dianne Thompson is to be the new president of the Chartered Institute of Marketing.

The appointment comes just one week after she was named businesswoman of the year and two weeks after she joined the advertising watchdog, the Advertising Standards Authority.

Ex-marketeer Ms Thompson will take over the presidency of the CIM in June from the current president Baroness O'Cathain.

The CIM is the world's professional body for marketeers and represents 60,000 members.

As president Ms Thompson will champion marketing as a key driver to competitive business.

She will also work with the institute to promote professionalism in marketing through qualifications, membership and chartered status.

Ms Thompson said: "I hope that having worked in a wide variety of industries during my career I can, as president, continue the invaluable work that Baroness O'Cathain has undertaken during the last three years to promote the cause of marketing."

The Camelot chief started her career as a marketing trainee at the Co-operative Wholesale Society and worked as marketer for companies including ICI Paints and the Signet Group.

She was also lecturer at Manchester Polytechnic for seven years during which time she ran her own advertising agency.

fields.headline: Weakest Link drives out ITV garage
fields.trailText: TV overnights: The return of the Weakest Link helped BBC1 to peaktime ratings victory, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The return of the Weakest Link helped BBC1 to a peaktime ratings victory last night, with the Anne Robinson-hosted quiz show beating ITV's Garages From Hell 3.

The Weakest Link was on between 8pm and 8.45pm last night; while ITV's look at the tricks of the second hand car trade ran for 60 minutes from 8pm.

The BBC1 quiz show had 7.6m viewers and a 36% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

Garages From Hell 3 could only muster 6.7m and a 31% share.

Other BBC1 winners included Mr Trebus's Life of Grime, a documentary between 9.20pm and 10pm updating the story of a Polish war veteran's epic battle with Haringey Council over his penchant for hoarding rubbish.

The Life of Grime special had 6.6m viewers and a 29% audience share.

The ITV opposition, medical drama A&E, had 6.2m.

Overall, BBC1 had a 34.4% share of viewing between 6pm and 10.30pm; while ITV had 28.5%.

fields.headline: Chinese and American hackers declare 'cyberwar'
fields.standfirst:
Chinese and American hackers have been escalating an online battle to deface each other's websites by replacing existing content with anti-US or anti-China rhetoric

More internet news
Related special report: China
fields.trailText: Chinese and American hackers have been escalating an online battle to deface each other's websites by replacing existing content with anti-US or anti-China rhetoric.
fields.body:
Chinese and American hackers have been escalating an online battle to deface each other's websites by replacing existing content with anti-US or anti-China rhetoric.

In the wake of the American spy plane incident, Chinese hackers vowed to attack US sites, which led hackers in the US to retaliate.

The US spy plane made an emergency landing on Chinese soil on April 1 after colliding with a Chinese fighter jet over the South China sea. The Chinese pilot was killed.

According to UK computer security firm Mi2g, the Honkers Union of China hacking group has defaced more than 80 web sites in the past month, while the Americans or their allies have attacked more than 100 sites.

Most of the attacks have been minor defacements. The website for China's remote sensing satellite ground station was overwritten with a picture of a mushroom cloud. Meanwhile the White House historical association site was plastered in Chinese flags.

US websites falling victim to the vandals included the National Institutes of Health, the navy, the department of labour, and the Californian department of energy, as well as many corporate sites.

A US hackers collective dubbed Project China left a message on one Chinese site reading: "Get ready to meet a strike force with strength the world has never seen before! We are going for all-out cyber warfare on your gov.cn boxes and every other box that you fucks haven't secured!"

Mi2g notes that this is not the first time we have seen a bitter 'cyberwar' between opposing national groups; Israelis and Palestinians also engage in defacement battles against each other's sites.

fields.headline: Captain Corelli's Mandolin
fields.standfirst: First there was the controversial book, then the musical and now the star-studded film. Here's our guide to the best sites on the phenomenon that is Captain Corelli's Mandolin
fields.trailText: First there was the controversial book, then the musical and now the star-studded film. Here's our guide to the best sites on the phenomenon that is Captain Corelli's Mandolin.
fields.body:
1. The film of the book, Captain Corelli's Mandolin, opens today. Produced by Working Title - the team behind Notting Hill and Bridget Jones's Diary - and starring Hollywood's favourite babe du jour Penelope Cruz and mega star Nicolas Cage, box office success seems assured for this oh-so-90s publishing phenomenon.

2. Louis de Bernières' novel has sold over 1.5m copies worldwide since its publication in 1994, and has recently made a reappearance in the UK's bestsellers chart.

3. Set on the beautiful Greek island of Cephalonia during the second world war, De Bernières' story tells of a love affair between the daughter of the island's doctor and a captain in Mussolini's army of occupation. Woven into the drama is a hostile account of the role of the Greek resistance fighters - portrayed as rapists, torturers and cowards.

4. Historians and veteran resistance fighters have attacked the book as a distortion and misrepresentation of the history of the Greek National Liberation Front (EAM), full of crude anti-communism, and De Bernières came under fire for an alleged right-wing bias in the depiction of the Greek communist partisans. The Morning Star called his novel "crude and brazen anti-communism''; De Bernières retaliated on the letters page: "How long are you people going to sit in the dark in an air-pocket, wanking each other off?"

5. Another of De Bernières' accusers was none other than the real Captain Corelli, who attacked the author for "pandering to racism" and portraying Greek partisans as "barbarians".

6. On his novel's translation into Greek, and following complaints from Cephalonia, De Bernières agreed to making a few key changes to his portrayal of the Greek communists. "I haven't actually changed my mind about what I think is the truth, but I had to bear in mind the possibility that I might be wrong," he told The Observer. "The story of the resistance is extremely complex", he said, with uncharacteristic understatement.

7. Nafsika Papanikolatos, writing for the Alternative Information Network, points out that "De Bernières' novel must ... not be read as a historical book ... He did not select images at random, but he opted for those that fit his conceptual understanding of reality and naturally he left others out. Reading the book as a historical treatise evidently leads to infinite debates and one can question several statements made in it about the anti-fascist front and about the Greek partisans." Most historians agree that the Greek communists did, in fact, play a key part in the resistance against the Nazis.

8. Director John Madden and writer Shawn Slovo have chosen to steer clear of the controversy, and have made wholesale changes in their screenplay, effectively eradicating and sanitising the novel's more controversial elements.

9. So, it is any good? Guardian critic Peter Bradshaw doesn't think so. "Droopy and disappointing ... with some of the unhappiest casting to be seen and dodgiest accents to be heard in the cinema," he writes.

10. Still can't get enough of Corelli? Well, there's a musical currently touring the UK, or you can visit Greece and even go in search of Captain Corelli. And finally, take the chance to impress your friends by telling them exactly what a mandolin is.

webTitle: Woman loses court bid to save sheep

fields.headline: Woman loses court bid to save sheep
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A woman today failed today in a bid to save her five pet sheep from being slaughtered as part of pre-emptive cull measures in light of  foot-and-mouth disease.
fields.body:
A woman today failed today in a bid to save her five pet sheep from being slaughtered as part of pre-emptive cull measures in light of foot-and-mouth disease.

Carolyn Hoffe had barricaded the five rare Dutch Zwartbles sheep in the living room of her home in Glasserton, near Whithorn, Dumfries and Galloway, to prevent Government officials from culling the animals.

She launched a legal challenge at the Court of Session in Edinburgh but following the three-hour hearing Lord Clarke said that he was not prepared to suspend the slaughter, which can now be carried out immediately.

Lord Clarke described the case of Mrs Hoffe's sheep as "a fast-moving situation".

He said he was not wholly convinced there was no merit in Mrs Hoffe's petition, but added "I'm not prepared to grant interim suspension of the Scottish ministers' decisions since on the basis of what has been submitted to me and the material placed before me, I am quite satisfied that the balance of convenience lies with the respondents."

Mr Moynihan then told the court that the Executive would be advised that the cull could take place straight away.

He said: "Advice will be given to the ministers that they are entirely free to proceed immediately."

The QC also denied that the Scottish Executive had been "rigid" in implementing its pre-emptive cull policy at Mrs Hoffe's property.

He said that unlike in the case of Mr Stokes's farm, Mrs Hoffe's sheep had been outdoors when foot-and-mouth was first confirmed in the area.

Mr Moynihan also said that despite Mrs Hoffe keeping the sheep in her house to prevent them becoming infected, her decision to allow a film crew into her home had proved she was not reliable.

He also pointed out that there had been repeated correspondence between Mrs Hoffe and the Executive, whose officials had re-investigated the case three times before deciding to proceed with the cull.

The QC said Mrs Hoffe's sheep must be slaughtered to prevent further spread of the disease.

He added: "Scottish ministers cannot take the risk of leaving five sheep at the very centre of that seat of infection because only one of those five sheep could itself cause western spread of this infection.

"If the ministers are correct in their suspicion and Mrs Hoffe's petition is granted, there is the risk of substantial damage to the national interest because of the dairy herds surrounding this area."

webTitle: Widening the role of the voluntary sector

fields.headline: Widening the role of the voluntary sector
fields.standfirst: The Treasury is about to inject more cash into the voluntary sector, particularly to boost the children's fund and mentoring, but does government funding curtail the sector's independence? Stuart Etherington examines the plans
fields.trailText: Stuart Etherington: The Treasury is about to inject more cash into the voluntary sector, particularly to boost the children's fund and mentoring, but does government funding curtail the sector's independence?
fields.body:
The government has announced another package of measures designed to support the voluntary sector and the work of volunteers. With particular emphasis on the children's fund and a new mentoring fund, it is yet more recognition of the sector as a vital partner in providing social care.

With the ever-increasing development of new partnerships between voluntary sector organisations and all levels of government the issues surrounding the level of support that can be expected from the state for the sector are fast becoming central to any disussion of the future of the sector's role in society.

What government policy in this area should be about is a long-term strategic approach to capacity building of the sector, enabling it to take on the further development of its social activities.

Community groups and voluntary organisations are ideally placed and have the right experience to help their local communities. By helping to build the resources of these organisations the government is simply allowing them to do the job they are so well designed for.

However, with each new injection of Treasury cash a debate rages over whether or not it is new money and how this government funding affects the independence of the sector. The underlying issue, however, is whether a series of individual measures can evolve into a far more long-term commitment to working with the voluntary sector.

Does the government realise the size of the job it has taken on? The sector needs a much more sustainable funding environment which can only come through a greater commitment from the next government to core funding.

We also need to be working as partners with a fuller understanding in Whitehall of the effects on the sector of all government policies. Hence our call for a civil service training program that will explain how the sector operates.

Even more vital if the government is serious about a strategic approach to working with the sector is the National Council of Voluntary Organisations' call for a cabinet minister with direct responsibility for the voluntary sector. Furthermore, it must be an equal partnership. One built around mutual benefit and understanding. Without the development of more local compacts between local authorities and their local voluntary and community groups this can not happen.

So we welcome the government's latest review of funding for local voluntary organisations. Let's hope that the sector can depend on these kind of measures being built upon by the next government with a long-term strategic approach to building the sector's capacity.

 Stuart Etherington is chief executive of National Council of Voluntary Organisations.

webTitle: MP in new outburst, a day after pledging to keep silent on race

fields.headline: MP in new outburst, a day after pledging to keep silent on race
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Full coverage of Election 2001
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: William Hague's hopes of closing down the Tory race row were blown apart last night when a rightwing MP reneged on a pledge to keep quiet on the issue.
fields.body:
William Hague's hopes of closing down the Tory race row were blown apart last night when a rightwing MP reneged on a pledge to keep quiet on the issue.

Laurence Robertson, the MP for Tewkesbury who had promised Mr Hague that he would not repeat his controversial views on race, reiterated his warning that Britain is a "crowded island" which is "struggling to come to terms with mass immigration".

His remarks, less than 24 hours after he signed an anti-racism pledge drawn up by the Tory whips, came in an article for the Gloucestershire Echo.

Mr Robertson, who promised not to speak out again on race "under any circumstances" after he was rebuked for praising the outspoken rightwing MP John Townend, insisted in the article that he was not a racist and boasted that he had recently met a senior diplomat from the Ethiopian embassy in London.

But then he added: "We are struggling to come to terms with the mass immigration into this country over the last 40 years and we are now having further problems with controlling the numbers of asylum seekers coming into the UK. Why does this matter? Well, this is a crowded island to start with and we see the effects of that every day.

"Also it is difficult to manage a society when there are great numbers of people belonging to different ethnic groups, all with different cultures, languages and religions, within it ... in order to create good race relations we need to limit the numbers of people coming into this country."

The Tory whips were last night furious with Mr Robertson. One Tory source said: "He is sailing very close to the wind."

The renewed pressure on Mr Hague came as a poll showed that voters believe that the prime minister is doing more to promote race equality than the Tory leader. The NOP poll, commissioned for ITN's Powerhouse programme, found that 43% of voters believed that Mr Blair had got the balance right on race.

Only 26% of voters believed that Mr Hague had achieved this.

webTitle: Straw bans NF rally after clashes

fields.headline: Straw bans NF rally after clashes
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: The home secretary has approved a ban of all political marches through a town blighted by racial tension, it was announced last night.
fields.body:
The home secretary has approved a ban of all political marches through a town blighted by racial tension, it was announced last night.

Police and council leaders in Oldham, Greater Manchester, turned to Jack Straw for support after the National Front planned to hold a rally on Saturday.

There have been claims in recent weeks by Asian youths that they have set up so-called no-go areas for white people.

Violence erupted last weekend when Stoke City football supporters clashed with local Asians before and after the match against Oldham Athletic.

Sixteen people were arrested on Saturday when bricks and other missiles were thrown at fans who had been chanting racist abuse.

Police have appealed for calm in the town but said they will be "out in force" on Saturday with special stop and search powers to enforce the prohibition order.

Chief Superintendent Eric Hewitt, of Greater Manchester police, said: "More than 500 police officers will be on duty in an unprecedented show of strength. There have been reports of National Front supporters from around the country descending on Oldham to demonstrate or cause trouble.

"My advice to them is to stay away. The police will be operating a zero tolerance policy when it comes to any acts of disorder, racial harassment or disturbance of the peace."

 A 15-year-old boy appeared in court yesterday accused of beating up a 76-year-old war veteran in an alleged racist attack in Oldham last month. His case was adjourned until today when he will appear before a youth court.
Press Association

webTitle: West London, West London, and West Merseyside (sort of)

fields.headline: West London, West London, and West Merseyside (sort of)
fields.trailText: ACTION TIME
fields.body:
ACTION TIME

Forget talk of Queens Park Dons and Shepherd's Bush Wombles. It ain't gonna happen. The proposed merger between QPR and Wimbledon is sinking faster than the crafty, crooked, corrupt and corpulent frame (yes, the thesaurus is out) of the late, fat Robert Maxwell - and it can't be long before the plan joins the sweaty schemer's attempt to merge Oxford and Reading on football's seabed.

"The merger isn't going to happen," QPR 1st spokesman Libby Magrill told the Fiver today. "We met with Chris Wright yesterday, and although he wasn't that keen on the idea anymore anyway, we helped to persuade him that it was an awful plan." Better still, Libby reckons the deal could be pronounced dead within 48 hours. "The Wimbledon Supporters Association will meeting with Charles Koppel on Sunday, and I think it'll be dead by then."

So make that 1-0 to direct action. But now another challenge awaits: getting ITV to show Leeds's Big Cup semi-final second-leg match against Valencia next Tuesday. Today the Fiver found out there's nothing in ITV's contract to stop them showing the game, providing obscure digital channel ONdigital allows them to do so. Seeing as ITV companies Granada and Carlton own ONdigital, that shouldn't be a problem. But guess what?

"This isn't the sort of thing that supporters like to hear, but the reason why companies spend a lot of money on rights is to encourage people to subscribe to our services," brayed blasé ONdigital spokesperson Andrew Marr today. And as we cowered, Marr - not to be confused with the BBC's political editor, who wouldn't hurt a fly - followed up his attack with the thundering: "We have paid a lot of money for these rights, so why should we give them away? If they want to see the game they can go to our website and find a pub showing the game." Indeed. Indeed. And you wonder why nobody watches your rubbish channel.

CANTONAESQUE

Six years ago, Eric Cantona jumped over the advertising hoardings at Selhurst Park and stuck his fist into the loud ignorant mouth of Matthew Simmonds. Echoes of that incident could be heard bouncing around the walls of Brentford's Griffin Park ground last night, as Luton defender Jude Stirling was arrested after allegedly attacking a Brentford fan who is said to have shouted racist abuse during a match.

The incident occurred with Stirling sitting in the dug-out watching his team play out a 2-2 draw with their hosts. Luton boss Joe Kinnear takes up the story: "The fan was throwing racial abuse at Liam George throughout the game. The guy came up with one hand in his pocket and walked up to Jude's face and said something highly offensive and disgraceful. Jude said he thought [the fan] might have had something in his pocket - maybe a knife or something like that - he didn't know what to do so he felt he was defending himself and gave him a right-hander."

Sure enough, it wasn't long before the police put a stop to the affair and took Stirling down to Chiswick nick, where they discussed the matter at some length with him before turfing him out at 3.30am. "A man has been bailed to return to police on June 5 pending further inquiries in connection with an alleged assault," said a Scotland Yard spokesman, who confirmed that a 33-year-old man had been injured but no charges had been brought. "We are looking at video footage from the ground." While Stirling must wait to find out his fate, Kinnear has promised to "do the best I can to support the kid", claiming: "One doesn't like to see any sort of violence at football matches but Jude reacted in the same manner that I would have done myself." That's nearly a Hegelian dialectic. Er, we think.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"One or two situations are progressing quite well regarding new signings" - Could this be a return to the situation situation for Tottenham manager Glenn Hoddle?

ELEMENTARY, IT'S WATSON

Never change a winning formula, that's what they say. Who they are we're not sure, and why we should trust them we don't know. But we do. As, indeed, do Tranmere Rovers, who having already enjoyed years of amazing success with an angry-looking shouty bloke who spent most of his life on Merseyside in charge, have gone and appointed another as their new manager. Step forward, former Everton defender and formidable frowning man Dave Watson, and become the latest man to make rash promises that will be regretted six months down the line.

"It's to be known straight away that the target is promotion," the 39-year-old began. "There's no time for consolidation because the squad of players that we have are well capable of challenging for promotion," he continued. "I've already seen quite a few Tranmere games this season. And a lot of what I have seen has been Tranmere have playing quite well but giving away silly goals or missing easy chances," he went on, almost making it sound as though he'd been doing nothing at all for the last year or so.

And although Watson comes fresh from Goodison Park where he's been coaching the players, nothing is probably exactly what he's been doing. Well, have you seen Everton play recently? Nevertheless, he's not totally without management experience, having been put in charge at Goodison for six weeks in 1997 during one of the club's very many crises. "I throughly enjoyed that and I'm looking forward to having the chance here," he reminisced. What price on him facing his old team in a league derby come season 2002/3, do you think?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Midas Soccer reckons that Sol Campbell won't be moving to Barcelona - yet. They claim "all the talk at the Lane is that Sol will sign a one-year deal and see what happens in Glenn Hoddle's first full season in charge." The website also reports that Hoddle is planning a £2m move for Quinton Fortune. Meanwhile, Teddy Sheringham has rejected United's offer of a one-year contract and a move to Fulham - and is set to sign a lucrative two-year deal with Spurs.

Liverpool are planning a £6m bid for Gareth Southgate.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Liverpool's Gary McAllister has won the Carling player of the month award for April. The manager of the month award went, for the second successive month, to Leeds manager David O'Leary.

Watford have confirmed that Ray Wilkins and Steve Coppell will move to Vicarage Road to join new manager Gianluca Vialli's backroom team.

Everton have unveiled a statue at Goodison in tribute to their greatest ever player Dixie Dean.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (3.10am)

There was loads of live Premiership football on last weekend. Of course, you had a full diary then, meaning you couldn't watch any of it.

Sky Sports 1: Premier League Preview (12midnight)

This weekend? Nothing planned. And what's on? Naff all.

Sky Sports 3: Hold The Back Page (11pm, 3am SS2)

Bah!

fields.headline: Banana skin: Camelot
fields.standfirst: Banana skin and top banana is a new must-read awards section courtesy of MediaGuardian.co.uk. Every week you can nominate your heroes and villains - those people or companies that have impressed or distressed you most with their PR or media performance. This week, step forward and collect your coveted banana skin trophy... Camelot
fields.trailText: Banana skin and top banana is a new must-read awards section courtesy of MediaGuardian.co.uk.
fields.body:
Name: Camelot
Age: 6.5 years
Description: lottery operator seemingly unwilling to ditch its fat cat label.
Not to be confused with: Ebeneezer Scrooge, Top Cat.
Banana skin
Martyn and Kay Tott win £3m on the National Lottery. They have lost their ticket but can prove they bought it. For months, Camelot keeps the couple on tenterhooks about whether they can or cannot receive the lucre. The final decision? Camelot keeps the £3m. Result
The distressed Totts turn to Max Clifford for help but miraculously receive a government boost to their claim - the culture, media and sport secretary, Chris Smith, says Camelot should cough up. Enter stage right, Sue Slipman, Camelot's head of external affairs
"If we were to set a precedent [by giving the money to the Totts] we would actually be putting the national lottery itself at risk. We cannot carry those kinds of liabilities," she says. Enter stage left, Max Clifford, PR guru to the wronged and wretched
"It just shows they are a very, very cruel organisation and they obviously don't care," he says. Enter centre stage, Chris Smith, in pre-election, "reflecting the mood of the people" mode
"There is no legal requirement on Camelot to [pay the Totts] but if I were them, I would...I hope they [Camelot] will actually see reason in this matter," he says. Possible outcome one
Camelot capitulates and gains a nice, warm, fluffy reputation for the first time. The £380m of unclaimed prize money - mainly a result of lost tickets - is claimed and bankrupts the operator. But Camelot is remembered fondly. Possible outcome two
Camelot holds out and confirms what everybody, apart from the Lottery Commission, always knew: once a fat cat, always a fat cat. Possible outcome three
The Totts, under the auspices of Mr Clifford, milk their 15 minutes of fame for all it's worth and try to generate £3m from public appearances dressed as Tiny Tim. Final thought
Sir Richard Branson would surely have given the Totts the dosh - and made a big PR show of his beneficence. Useful link
Read Camelot's full response on Camelotplc.com

 Do you know someone who deserves a banana skin or a top banana? Email Julia Day with your nominations at julia.day@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Schoenberg: Moses und Aron
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Schoenberg's Moses und Aron.
fields.body:
Of all the great unfinished operatic masterpieces of the 20th century, Moses und Aron is the most tantalising. Schoenberg composed only two of his projected three acts, and left almost no clues as to what the third would have contained musically; even the libretto is likely to have been heavily revised as he wrote the music. The immediate reasons for his failure to finish a work on which clearly he placed a great deal of importance were external: he was ill, and then with the coming to power of the Nazis in 1933 his teaching position in Berlin immediately became untenable. What is more puzzling is his inability to get down to the work in the last 17 years of his life when he was settled in Los Angeles.

Even the torso that does exist is curious, and it has been described as more akin to an oratorio than an opera, with the chorus playing a vital role in the drama. Yet in intelligent stagings - Peter Hall's celebrated production at Covent Garden in the 1960s, Peter Stein's in Amsterdam in 1995 - Moses und Aron packs a dramatic punch, even without its concluding act.

On disc the detail and expertise of Schoenberg's score are endlessly fascinating, and the care with which the drama is plotted - climaxing with the orgiastic worship of the golden calf in act two - easy to appreciate. All the available versions have considerable virtues. Michael Gielen (Philips) conducts a perceptive and pragmatic performance with a decent cast, while Georg Solti's (Decca) is typically hard-edged and rhythmically vital, and he has arguably the best of all Arons in Philip Langridge. Pierre Boulez has recorded it twice, with his first version (Sony, with Gunther Reich and Richard Cassilly in the title roles) now edged out of favour by the far better recorded and played version he made in conjunction with the Stein production in Amsterdam. David Pitman-Jennings is the later Moses and Chris Merritt an eloquently plausible Aron, while the playing of the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra is both stunningly accurate and remarkably beautiful.

Key Recording: Boulez (Deutsche Grammophon 449 174-2, two CDs)

webTitle: ITV in the dark over Richard and Judy defection

fields.headline: ITV in the dark over Richard and Judy defection
fields.trailText:
4.45pm: Richard and Judy kept ITV in the dark about their defection to Channel 4 until lunchtime today, writes Jason Deans.

04.05.2001: ITV grits teeth over departure
04.05.2001: Who will replace them?
04.05.2001: Richard and Judy in shock departure
04.05.2001: The Richard and Judy years
fields.body:
Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan kept ITV and Granada bosses in the dark about their defection to Channel 4 until lunchtime today.

Neither the ITV boss director of programming, David Liddiment, the head of Granada programming Grant Mansfield, nor head of the daytime programming at ITV, Maureen Duffy, were given any warning about the bombshell news.

The pair resigned just hours before appearing at a Channel 4 press conference to speak about their new contracts.

"No one at Granada knew anything about it until lunchtime today," said Madeley.

"We felt it was better to make a clean decision. We had another offer in from Granada but we never considered it. Money wasn't an issue," he added

Madleley said he and his wife took the decision to end their 13-year ITV career on Monday when they got the green light from Channel 4.

"This has all happened very quickly," he said.

Finnigan added: "Tim Gardam phoned us and said 'it's on'."

Contract negotiations continued until midnight last night.

The go-between was Amanda Ross, head of Cactus TV, a Chrysalis group company. She had worked with Richard and Judy for two years on the soap awards and when Channel 4 contacted the company for new ideas for daytime TV she approached the celebrity couple.

"It's sad to leave but we really needed to do something else. We'd just have got stale otherwise. We'd been in London for last five years and only expected to be here for two," said Finnigan.

But Madeley dismissed as "crap" press reports that they were unhappy with ITV.

He said: "I've got a lot of pride in the success of This Morning. There are 10 more weeks to run on the contract and we would hate to think that we were conniving in the downfall of the show," he said..

The pair promised not to "start acting all wacky" once they have moved to Channel 4.

"Our kids would be mortified. I'm not going to start talking in rap and Judy won't be dressed in full-length leather," said Madeley.

He said he felt "a bit schizophrenic" about leaving the show. "We're as passionate about This Morning as we always have been. But we'd done it for 13 years.

"We looked at this option and over the next couple of years it looked a more exciting gig."

Finnigan said Channel 4 was the channel the couple watched the most at home. "I've thought for some time that Channel 4 is the most entertaining and innovative channel," she said.

fields.headline: Ken's bedside manner
fields.standfirst: The air might not be any cleaner, and the queues for NHS treatment may not have decreased. But a year after his election as mayor, it appears that Ken Livingstone has in fact delivered on some of his manifesto promises to improve the health of Londoners. Our health specialist from our panel of public sector experts gives her verdict
fields.trailText: The air might not be any cleaner, and the queues for NHS treatment may not have decreased. But a year after his election as mayor, it appears that Ken Livingstone has in fact delivered on some of his manifesto promises to improve the health of Londoners. Our health specialist from our panel of public sector experts gives her verdict.
fields.body:
The manifesto promises to:

Ensure that improving the health of Londoners is a central objective of all the mayor and assembly's policies

Appoint a London commission with a broad and representative membership to advise the mayor and assembly on a health improvement programme for London

Set up arrangements for the London region of the NHS to report regularly to the mayor and assembly on progress in meeting targets for health improvement in London.

Anna Coote, director of public health at the King's Fund, London's leading health charity:

"Even though the mayor has very little statutory power over, or responsibility for, health in London, the issue has received an impressive amount of attention at the GLA.

There is a general understanding that the health of Londoners will not be improved merely by tinkering with the NHS but that it requires concerted action against poverty, unemployment and pollution, as well as for regeneration and the development of strong communities.

In the first year of the GLA, a reasonably constructive relationship appears to have developed between the mayor and the NHS in London. Initial concerns that there would be confrontation between the two bodies have not (yet) materialised.

One of the mayor's first actions after taking office was to set up the London health commission (LHC), a London-wide partnership charged with recommending ways of improving London's health.

An important early achievement of the LHC has been to conduct health impact assessments of the mayor's strategies (beginning with those for transport, economic development, biodiversity and air quality) and to propose ways in which they can be amended to promote better health and reduce risks.

The commission has considerable potential to drive London-wide action to tackle the causes of avoidable ill health. How far it can be sustained as an effective strategic partnership will depend on how much political muscle is behind it and whether it has adequate resources and administrative support."

webTitle: Welcome for government's care trusts climbdown

fields.headline: Welcome for government's care trusts climbdown
fields.trailText: Local government and social services welcomed the government's climbdown on the imposition of care trusts - but warned that they are still far from happy about the creation of the new bodies.
fields.body:
Local government and social services welcomed the government's climbdown on the imposition of care trusts - but warned that they are still far from happy about the creation of the new bodies.

John Beer, chairman of the association of directors of social services health and social inclusion committee, said the compulsion element had threatened to mar progress towards closer, voluntary working between health and local authorities.

He said: "Removing these clauses has long been the settled aim of the association and other organisations who were deeply perturbed at their presence within the bill."

"Welcome as this move is, there are still important issues to be reconciled over care trusts," he added.

"These will have to be considered when regulations concerning their composition and governance arrangements are addressed, the most important one being how we can create true partnerships which will be in the best interests of local people."

Unison social services national officer Owen Davies said: "We're pleased that the government has withdrawn the compulsion powers but we are still concerned that care trusts still don't really represent an equal partnership between the NHS and social services departments."

The climbdown on care trust imposition looks unlikely to heal the rift between Local Government Association (LGA) chairman Sir Jeremy Beecham and the LGA Lib Dem group leader Sir David Williams.

The government's original care trust proposals sparked a major row within the association, with the Liberal Democrats reportedly insisting the organisation should "go down in flames" before accepting the new arrangements.

Sir Jeremy took a softer line, claiming that the LGA had already won an important battle for the right of councils to appoint their own representatives to the new organisations.

"I'm very disappointed with the LGA about care trusts. We've got an acceptable package from government almost despite the LGA," said Sir David.

He added: "Generally, Beecham has stood up well to the government, and I have a lot of admiration for him. But the LGA did roll over too easily on this one."

John Beer, chairman of the association of directors of social services health and social inclusion committee, said the compulsion element had threatened to mar progress towards closer, voluntary working between health and local authorities. He said: "Removing these clauses has long been the settled aim of the association and other organisations who were deeply perturbed at their presence within the bill." "Welcome as this move is, there are still important issues to be reconciled over care trusts," he added. "These will have to be considered when regulations concerning their composition and governance arrangements are addressed, the most important one being how we can create true partnerships which will be in the best interests of local people." fields.headline: Pakistan's dictator seeks presidency
fields.standfirst: Pakistan's military leader has dropped hints that he will consolidate his power by appointing himself president, writes Rory McCarthy
fields.trailText: Pakistan's military leader has dropped hints that he will consolidate his power by appointing himself president, writes Rory McCarthy.
fields.body:
Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, has taken another step towards appointing himself president by reviving a key army position for one of his closest allies among the generals.

Gen Musharraf reopened the post of deputy army chief this week and gave the job to Lieutenant-General Muzaffar Hussain Usmani, a rightwinger in the army who was heavily involved in the coup 18 months ago. It is the first time the post has been opened up since the rule of the last military dictator, General Zia-ul Haq.

Lt-Gen Usmani is expected to take over day-to-day control of the army when he starts his new job later this month, leaving Gen Musharraf free to concentrate on running the country.

Gen Musharraf, Pakistan's self-styled "chief executive", who is currently on a visit to Burma and Vietnam, has already said he will not retire as army chief when his term ends in October this year and has hinted that he will make himself president.

Although the general has promised to hold elections by October next year, in line with a supreme court ruling, it now seems likely that he will increase presidential powers and remain as Pakistan's leader under a civilian government.

"This is a sign that elections, whenever they are held, will not mean a restoration to the people of undiluted sovereignty, but will involve significant military involvement," the Nation, a leading English-language newspaper, said in an editorial.

"In reality power will continue to rest with the establishment, despite its track record of not giving much confidence in its ability to solve the multifarious problems facing the country."

A large faction of the Pakistan Muslim League, the political party that was in power at the time of the coup, now appears ready to accept the general as president and indemnify him for everything done since the coup. It wants him to restore the parliament that was suspended on the day of the coup, October 12 1999.

Lt-Gen Usmani, who has trained at Britain's Royal College of Defence Studies, remains a three-star general and has not been promoted to four-star, full general status. He is due to retire from the army early next year but Gen Musharraf could easily keep him on as a deputy or vice-chief.

During the coup, Lt-Gen Usmani, who was the corps commander for Karachi, played a key role. Minutes after the then prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, announced that Gen Musharraf was sacked as army chief, Lt-Gen Usmani's men secured control of Karachi airport.

Gen Musharraf, who was at the time flying back to Pakistan after a visit to Sri Lanka, landed safely at Karachi and later that night arrested Sharif and took control of the country. The former prime minister was later convicted of hijacking Gen Musharraf's plane and in December was sent into exile in Saudi Arabia.

The general has since been scathing about his nation's politicians and has tried to stifle all political activity in the country. More than 2,000 political activists were rounded up last week to prevent a protest rally in Karachi on May Day.

"Those who are useless politicians should stay at home," Musharraf said this week. "They have played a useless innings and have been getting out on zero."

In an interview with a leading Pakistani news magazine published this month Gen Musharraf refused to rule out the possibility that he would take over as president. Asked if his presence was needed after the promised elections in October 2002, he said: "I really think that my role is required."

He added: "If any Pakistani thinks that the army should just confine itself to the barracks, to its training and think nothing of other activities in the nation that is not the reality on the ground."

webTitle: Why there's nothing to write home about - yet

fields.headline: Why there's nothing to write home about - yet
fields.standfirst: Ken Livingstone was elected as mayor a year ago today on a manifesto focusing on affordable housing in London. House prices are still rapidly increasing and the capital needs 28,000 new affordable homes every year in the next decade. So where are they? The housing specialist from our panel of public sector experts gives her verdict
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone was elected as mayor a year ago today on a manifesto focusing on affordable housing in London. House prices are still rapidly increasing and the capital needs 28,000 new affordable homes every year in the next decade. So where are they? The housing specialist from our panel of public sector experts gives her verdict
fields.body:
The manifesto promises to:

Use the mayor's development control powers to ensure all councils are making their contribution to meeting London's housing needs

Work with London's council, the empty homes agency, businesses and others to set a target of reclaiming up to 100,000 empty homes across London to help provide affordable, low-cost homes

Commission an immediate inquiry, to be complete within three months, of London's needs for new affordable, low-cost homes, to provide firm foundations for the housing policies in the spatial development strategy including targets across London for all types of affordable housing

Sue Ellenby, head of the London Housing Federation:

"In Ken Livingstone we have a mayor who understands that the availability of more affordable housing is essential to the capital's health and economy. This has been very welcome.

What is also very positive is that the mayor, along with senior GLA officers and the assembly members, view this issue as something that they can, and should, do something about.

We positively welcomed both the focus on homelessness from mayoral adviser Glenda Jackson, and the excellent report from the mayor's housing commission: Homes for a World City.

Taking into account the needs of those on moderate incomes who are being priced out of the housing market this report confirms that London needs 28,000 new affordable homes a year over the next 10 years.

It also shows that Mr Livingstone's planning powers are critical in trying to achieve this.

So we now wait optimistically for the spatial development strategy - the document that will set out the mayor's vision of how London should look in the future, which will include planning and house-building targets. We hope the strategy will include a target for half of new housing developments to be affordable.

So the verdict so far is 'very good'. The mayor's second year is key to taking the housing issue forward. If we get a positive planning framework and organisations can effectively work together through the new housing forum for London to attract more investment, then perhaps positive progress can be made to solve London's housing crisis."

webTitle: What the mayor has pulled out of his community chest

fields.headline: What the mayor has pulled out of his community chest
fields.standfirst: Ken Livingstone's election manifesto pledged to battle poverty and inequality. Tony Hillman, of regeneration charity Urban Forum, gives his verdict on the mayor's performance so far
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone election manifesto pledged to battle poverty and inequality. Tony Hillman, of regeneration charity Urban Forum, gives his verdict on the mayor's performance so far.
fields.body:
The manifesto promises to:

Ensure the London development agency (LDA) targets regeneration funds on areas of most need and that regeneration schemes are required to include clear outcomes for reducing poverty and inequality

Give priority to regeneration schemes that are drawn up and led by local communities themselves and increase the funding available for local capacity building and community development

Ensure that as part of its regeneration programme the London development agency establishes London-wide cooperation of support from business to schools.

Set a target for London to create 10,000 jobs in new green businesses by 2005

Tony Hillman, information officer at regeneration charity Urban Forum:

"Regeneration matters in the London area fall within the remit of the LDA. Although it has made a reasonable start, there is a concern over whether it has effectively got to grips with the capital's voluntary and community sector.

The economic development strategy for London produced by the LDA completed its consultation at the end of February and has to be approved by the new director of strategy, Greg Clark, who starts his job in June. Voluntary sector bodies in the capital have given it a cautious welcome.

We welcome the clear link between economic development and social exclusion that runs through the strategy document and the recognition of the need to improve London's deprived areas.

Some voluntary groups are suspicious of the drive to make London a 'world city' - something Ken Livingstone is keen on - because they fear the needs of ordinary Londoners will get left behind.

The GLA is slowly gearing up to its scrutiny role - indeed in the wake of the Damilola Taylor murder it has recently announced a 'major investigation' into whether regeneration schemes are helping deprived areas as they are supposed to.

It may be fairer to judge the mayor and assembly in a year's time when they have settled into their role."

webTitle: Policing Livingstone's law and order record

fields.headline: Policing Livingstone's law and order record
fields.standfirst: Ken Livingstone came to power a year ago promising a boost in police recruitment and investment in anti-crime technology.  Has he delivered? Metropolitan police federation vice-chairman David Rodgers offers his verdict
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone came to power a year ago promising a boost in police recruitment and investment in anti-crime technology. Has he delivered? Metropolitan police federation vice-chairman David Rodgers offers his verdict.
fields.body:
The manifesto promises to:

Agree with the commissioner a plan for restoring police numbers to the levels London needs - initially I [Ken Livingstone] believe a drive to recruit at least 2,000 more officers will be required

Agree a plan with the commissioner for increasing resources and investment in the latest anti-crime technology, particularly DNA testing and the new generation of CCTV cameras.

David Rodgers, vice-chairman, Metropolitan Police Federation:

"The Metropolitan police authority (MPA) has been on a learning curve for the past year. A lot of people in the MPA, through no fault of their own, had no idea how the metropolitan police worked.

We haven't really noticed any real great change as yet on the police side. We haven't noticed anything horrible they've done either.

Between them, the MPA and the Metropolitan police are trying to cut down on red tape, which is very good news, because we all know the police and the rest of the public sector can get bogged down with paperwork.

The MPA has set up many meetings. There's a lot of transparency, and I think that's a step in the right direction.

But we've got to get a grip on our staff retention problem. The problem is not getting recruits in at the bottom. They are leaving in the middle. Tackling that has got to be the number one priority.

If not we're going to lose a lot more officers in the next two to three years, because they joined in the 1970s and can retire now. We could lose up to a third of our workforce in the next four years.

If dealing with that means more pay, let's address it. If it means better working conditions, let's address that. Without that, the people of London will be short-changed on policing."

 Interview by Simon Parker

webTitle: Rugby union: Jones leads way out of Gloucester

fields.headline: Jones leads way out of Gloucester
fields.trailText: Gloucester's attempts to keep Ian Jones at Kingsholm for another season ended in failure yesterday when the former All Black lock announced he was retiring from professional rugby and would return to New Zealand with his family.
fields.body:
Gloucester's attempts to keep Ian Jones at Kingsholm for another season ended in failure yesterday when the former All Black lock announced he was retiring from professional rugby and would return to New Zealand with his family.

Jones, now 34 and capped 79 times, had been weighing up the offer of a new deal but, for reasons he insisted were "purely rugby orientated", has opted to leave the club he joined after the 1999 World Cup.

There will be those who link his decision to the dressing-room unrest earlier this year. Gloucester's director of rugby Philippe Saint-André, however, pronounced himself "very sad to see him go" and admitted he would struggle to find a replacement of similar calibre.

Jones intends to bow out after this month's Barbarians tour of Wales, Scotland and England, and Gloucester's forwards coach John Brain has also rejected an invitation to stay at Kingsholm to assist the former Brive coach Laurent Seigne, arriving this summer. Several other players, not least the former Wallaby centre Jason Little, are preparing to move on as Saint-André pursues fresh talent, much of it from France and Argentina.

London Irish's captain Conor O'Shea will be out until at least October because of complications arising from the ankle injury he sustained at Kingsholm in November.

The Scottish Rugby Union has announced that a third professional team, representing the Borders, will be formed from 2002-3 amid concerns about the depth of talent available to the national selectors. And the SRU chief executive Bill Watson said renewed efforts would be made to lure exiled Scots back. "The fact of the matter is that unless we provide opportunities for our best players they could be lost to Scottish rugby," he said.

If commercially viable, a fourth professional team representing Caledonia is envisaged within five years.

webTitle: Is London being taken for a ride?

fields.headline: Is London being taken for a ride?
fields.standfirst: Ken Livingstone was elected as mayor a year ago today on a manifesto that pledged a radical overhaul of transport in London. So why are the buses always late and the trains still overcrowded? Our transport specialist from our panel of public sector experts gives his verdict
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone was elected as mayor a year ago today on a manifesto that pledged a radical overhaul of transport in London. So why are the buses always late and the trains still overcrowded? Our transport specialist from our panel of public sector experts gives his verdict.
fields.body:
The manifesto promises to:

Freeze tube fares in real terms for four years

Freeze bus fares for four years and urgently investigate the feasibility of introducing a 70p flat rate bus fare throughout the capital

Join business and local communities in making the case for two new tube lines - Crossrail and the Chelsea-Hackney line

Work with the Strategic Rail Authority and the Rail Regulator to demand improvements in performance from the rail companies and agree increased service levels to reduce overcrowding

Fight to retain a unified underground system in the public domain

Argue that we should finance the investment needed to modernise the tube by the cheapest possible method, which the evidence indicates is raising bonds backed by a combination of fares and government grants

Draw up a programme to introduce new fast, high quality bus routes from outer to inner London along dedicated and well-policed bus lanes serviced by imaginative park and ride schemes

Ensure the rapid completion of a London-wide system of bus lanes

Provide positive incentives to leave cars at home by holding down fares, strictly enforcing bus lanes and investigating the feasibility of reducing bus fares

Consult widely about the best possible congestion charge scheme to discourage unnecessary car journeys in a small zone of central London, to commence during the middle of my term of office, with all monies devoted to improving transport

Aim to reduce road traffic by 15% by 2010

Nick Dolezal, chair of the Association of London Government transport and environment committee:

"Work on transport in the Greater London authority has been an anticlimax. The impression is more of talk than delivery. But big transport projects do take time to deliver.

Congestion charging is a mayoral priority, but still has not been agreed upon and will not be in place before 2003 even with a hurried timetable. Arguments over the future of the tube centre on improvements to be achieved between seven and 20 years' time.

The mayor's transport strategy has received much attention. It has put forward many proposals that have received large-scale support, and a few that have received large-scale opposition, including plans to make it easier to use cars in outer London.

There are several issues where there has been positive progress, and where the value of the mayor as a leader and coordinator has come through.

These include the development of a partnership with the boroughs to provide better bus priority, through more bus lanes, bus-only streets, and better traffic and bus priority enforcement.

Integration of the transport network remains the major challenge still to be addressed. Transport for London still operates as a separate entity, with conflicting internal policies.

Bob Kiley, the mayor's inspired choice as transport commissioner, will need to address this to get the most improvements for transport in London."

webTitle: Golf: Olazabal nods off to flying start

fields.headline: Olazabal nods off to flying start
fields.trailText: Laid-back Jose Maria Olazabal yesterday took full advantage of an extended rain delay here by catching 40 winks before going out to shoot 66, two behind the English pacemaker Daren Lee, in the weather-hit first round of the French Open.
fields.body:
Laid-back Jose Maria Olazabal yesterday took full advantage of an extended rain delay here by catching 40 winks before going out to shoot 66, two behind the English pacemaker Daren Lee, in the weather-hit first round of the French Open.

Scheduled for a breakfast-time start, the Spaniard had to kick his heels for two hours and then two hours more but simply found a quiet corner to nap while the greens staff squeegeed the fairways.

"You can't practise for four hours and it's tough to know what to do with yourself, but I managed to sleep for 45 minutes," he explained.

"They were trying very hard to play the course as near as possible to normal. In the end they had to reduce one par five to a par three. It happened once before in an Italian Open and it was no problem."

With par reduced from 72 to 70, Olazabal finished on four under but was making no predictions, saying: "I'll sit and wait and see what happens. There's a lot of danger out there from water and bushes and many bad things can happen."

He made four birdies and narrowly missed a fifth at the last after the cup was resited when his French playing partner Raphael Jacquelin's pitch took a lump out of the rim of the original hole.

Lee made his move with two early birdies: having holed from 18 feet at the short 4th he followed up with another from 12 feet at a 571yd 5th that had been reduced to a 177yd par three. He put his six-birdie effort down to adding three degrees of loft to his putter and not playing a practice round.

The 36-year-old Londoner, who avoided an eighth visit to the tour's qualifying school last year with a fifth place in the BMW event in Munich, explained: "Since my amateur days I've preferred to walk a course before a tournament, drawing diagrams of the holes and charting distances.

"A practice round can take 5 hours and you end up watching everybody else instead of doing what you want to do. I simply hit a lot of chips and putts and work out the lines.

"I was poor on the greens in missing the cut in Portugal last week and decided to give my putter a whack to increase the loft to five degrees, which gave me a lot more confidence."

fields.bodyText: Laid-back Jose Maria Olazabal yesterday took full advantage of an extended rain delay here by catching 40 winks before going out to shoot 66, two behind the English pacemaker Daren Lee, in the weather-hit first round of the French Open. Scheduled for a breakfast-time start, the Spaniard had to kick his heels for two hours and then two hours more but simply found a quiet corner to nap while the greens staff squeegeed the fairways. "You can't practise for four hours and it's tough to know what to do with yourself, but I managed to sleep for 45 minutes," he explained. "They were trying very hard to play the course as near as possible to normal. In the end they had to reduce one par five to a par three. It happened once before in an Italian Open and it was no problem." With par reduced from 72 to 70, Olazabal finished on four under but was making no predictions, saying: "I'll sit and wait and see what happens. There's a lot of danger out there from water and bushes and many bad things can happen." He made four birdies and narrowly missed a fifth at the last after the cup was resited when his French playing partner Raphael Jacquelin's pitch took a lump out of the rim of the original hole. Lee made his move with two early birdies: having holed from 18 feet at the short 4th he followed up with another from 12 feet at a 571yd 5th that had been reduced to a 177yd par three. He put his six-birdie effort down to adding three degrees of loft to his putter and not playing a practice round.
