fields.headline: O'Sullivan in champion form
fields.standfirst: Swail trails as favourite stays focused on place in final
fields.trailText: Ronnie O'Sullivan, not at his most dashing but determined, sound and assured, led Joe Swail 6-2 after the first of the four sessions of their best-of-33-frames semi-final of the Embassy World Championship at the Crucible.
fields.body:
Ronnie O'Sullivan, not at his most dashing but determined, sound and assured, led Joe Swail 6-2 after the first of the four sessions of their best-of-33-frames semi-final of the Embassy World Championship at the Crucible.

In this form and mood he hopes that today's two sessions will leave him little or nothing to do in tomorrow afternoon's final session, for he knows the value of conserving nervous energy in this uniquely testing marathon of the mind.

His frames tally of 36-14 from three matches here so far show how well he has maintained his concentration, and he was as focused in yesterday's more fragmentary frames as in those he settled with one break.

Swail's path to a second consecutive semi-final here could hardly have been more arduous. Only from two down with three to play did he register his 10-9 victory over Sean Storey, the world No99, in the opening round; he trailed Mark Williams 11-7 before eliminating the defending champion 13-12; and he was extended to 13-11 by Patrick Wallace, whose loser's cheque of £36,500 was only £8,000 less than he earned in his first six professional seasons.

Yet Swail, still the front runner for the £20,000 highest-break prize with 140 and pleased to be assured of £73,000 for reaching the semi-final, began with a carefree 107. O'Sullivan responded with 73 but, reaching over, fouled a red with his body in the third frame, which Northern Ireland's No1 took with a final-red-to-pink clearance.

Swail was to have no further success as O'Sullivan's runs of 62, 58 and 70 marked his progress to 5-2 before he added the last frame of the day with bits and pieces.

O'Sullivan has yet to win the world title and at 25 has about five peak years left. But no player has ever made top-quality performance look so easy. Making his first century break aged 10 and winning his first pro-am at 12, he looked as though he had been born with a cue in his hand. At an age when the diligent were doing their homework, he was playing here, there and everywhere. In essence he led an adult existence, and he was invariably accompanied by his father.

His was a fast, exciting life with no cares until nine years ago, just into his run of 72 wins out of 74 qualifying matches in his first professional season, when his father was sentenced to life imprisonment for a fatal stabbing in a nightclub brawl.

Young O'Sullivan's mood swings started soon after his enforced separation from a father he loves. On an upswing he won the Champions Cup and Scottish Masters in early season and, even on a downswing, retained the China Open just before Christmas.

In the early months of 2001 he was all over the place. "I don't know whether I've got the bottle for this game," he said after losing 5-4 to Swail in the Welsh Open.

His mind and game came together again about six weeks ago when he won his fourth title of the season, the Irish Masters. Unfocused, he was a first-round loser in the Scottish Open but at the Crucible he has been so good that the bookmakers, before a ball was struck in the semi-finals, made him the 11-10 favourite for the title.

There was more good news for him a few weeks back. Ronnie Snr has been recategorised from A to B, a first step on the way to home visits and possibly parole. Ronnie Jnr hopes to show him the trophy on his next visit.

fields.headline: Stopping the Clinton cringe
fields.standfirst: The Democrats are finally hitting back over son of star wars. Now the EU needs to follow its lead, says Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: The Democrats are finally hitting back over son of star wars. Now the EU needs to follow its lead, says Martin Kettle.
fields.body:
What a difference being in opposition makes. Two years ago, with Bill Clinton in the White House, Democrats overwhelmingly swallowed their doubts (if they had them) and went along with the president's tactical retreat on missile defences.

Now, with Republican George Bush installed as president, most of the Democratic party has sprung into action to oppose the administration's plans.

And what a difference being in government makes too. If the Labour party had been out of power in Britain, there is no question but that Tony Blair and Robin Cook would have been eloquent international critics of missile defences. Likewise Gerhard Schröder and - in particular - Joschka Fischer in Germany.

As it is, office holders all, they are tongue-tied in the face of Bush's latest plans.

The president's speech in Washington on Tuesday was a declaration of fixed intent and needs to be understood as such.

Bush is committed to building a missile defence shield. He is prepared to spend whatever it takes to do it. He is willing to discard the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty of 1972. Nothing that anyone else says or does will seriously deflect him. Not even, we can be certain, the absence of any proven, working interceptor technology with which to build the shield.

In his speech, Bush promised "real consultations" with Europe and Asia on his plans. Teams of US officials leave Washington to begin the talking process next week.

But it is simply an illusion - or a deception - to claim that these consultations can deflect the Americans from the decision they have already taken. As the Süddeutsche Zeitung said on Wednesday, the emissaries are coming to inform not to consult. The consultations will have only marginal effects, if they have any effects at all.

This issue ought to trigger one of the most important debates on international security that most of us will see in our lifetime. The words are those of Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader in the senate. And there have been some signs this week that such a debate is beginning to take place in America.

"This may be the central national security issue of our time," wrote Senator Joe Biden in an excellent article in the Wall Street Journal yesterday.

"The president's position is an invitation to an arms race. It would violate existing arms control treaties and ask us to defend our nation with a technology that some of our nation's best scientists do not believe is reliable," said Senator Dick Durbin, one of only three senators who voted against Clinton's plan in 1998.

Other senior Democrats, like Dick Gephardt, Carl Levin and Paul Wellstone, have all weighed in already too.

The questions are numerous and could hardly be bigger. Is the threat of new missile attacks against the US genuine? If so, are missile defences the most effective way of countering the threat?

Do America's enemies really favour missile attack over other weapons to such a degree that such a move is needed? Why is America's retaliatory power not already a deterrent? Does reliable technology exist to intercept a hostile missile?

And what about intercepting a cluster of missiles? Will deployment of missile defences, which is itself an act of missile proliferation, encourage still wider proliferation elsewhere? If the world's most powerful nation abrogates treaties, then why should others adhere to them?

And those are just some of the international questions. For Americans, there are other issues, which chiefly have to do with money.

Missile defences will not cost less than $100bn, probably much more, and, if they are extended to other nations, the cost will be many times that.

If defence spending lurches upwards on such a scale, then other government programmes will suffer, especially because the administration's tax cuts mean there is less federal money to play with.

There is a very real sense in which Bush is choosing guns over butter.

Self-evidently, America needs to debate these issues and, sadly, America has neglected this debate in the past. Clinton deserves his share of the responsibility for this neglect, cringing pre-emptively in the face of Republican missile defence fervour.

But Bush, his allies and his backers are the real missile defence zealots, and the real need for friend and foe to say what they think is now.

At least, belatedly, some voices are being raised in America. Not in Europe, however, or not enough. Europe's governments have adopted the pre-emptive cringe from Clinton.

The Europeans fear that they will lose credibility with America if they say what they think. They think they may win some marginal points if they reason with Washington.

Perhaps they may. But the essential truth is the opposite. Europe loses credibility not by its outspokenness but by its feebleness.

webTitle: Racing: Dunlop can strike with Millenary and Auntie Rose

fields.headline: Dunlop can strike with Millenary and Auntie Rose
fields.trailText: While it might be asking too much of him to match his tally of five winners at the Craven meeting last month, John Dunlop is sure to be a force to reckon with at this weekend's Newmarket Guineas fixture.
fields.body:
While it might be asking too much of him to match his tally of five winners at the Craven meeting last month, John Dunlop is sure to be a force to reckon with at this weekend's Newmarket Guineas fixture.

The vibes are certainly strong for Arundel's St Leger winner Millenary, who reappears in this afternoon's Sagitta Jockey Club Stakes.

Dunlop won last Sunday's Prix Ganay with Golden Snake and that was a timely boost for his gallops companion Millenary, who is reckoned to have improved.

On the book the Rainbow Quest colt has nothing in hand of St Leger runner-up Air Marshall, who is 2lb better off for a three-quarter length defeat at Doncaster. But Millenary had earlier given Sir Michael Stoute's runner weight and a beating in the Gordon Stakes at Goodwood and he should have the edge once again.

Millenary (3.10) might have more problems giving 5lb to Wellbeing, whose only defeat last season was when fifth in the Derby on the back of an interrupted preparation.

Wellbeing is the choice of Henry Cecil's stable jockey Richard Quinn, but judged on recent home work stablemate Sandmason should not be underestimated.

It remains to be seen whether Holding Court can recapture the sparkle of his French Derby victory, Boreas looks held by Wellbeing on last season's form and the drying ground is against Salford Express.

Dunlop could also land the Directa Parseal Dahlia Stakes with Aunty Rose (4.15). She had her problems after finishing third behind Petrushka in the Nell Gwyn Stakes last season, but the very fact that she has been kept in training is encouraging.

The Hblb Leicestershire Stakes, rescheduled from last Saturday's abandoned Leicester meeting, features Godolphin's first runner of the domestic season in Mahfooth. He disappointed in the Dubai Duty Free, run over a distance of nearly nine furlongs, last time but should go well over this shorter trip.

However, seven furlongs is also ideal for Warningford (4.50), for whom the booking of Kieren Fallon looks highly significant. James Fanshawe's seven-year-old has looked very sharp in his recent home work.

Nineteen runners will line up for tomorrow's Sagitta 2,000 Guineas, when in addition to favourite Tobougg and Rumpold, Godolphin also run Divine Task.

Kevin Darley has been booked for this Irish River colt, who split Rumpold and Tobougg in a trial race in Dubai.

From five possibles, Ballydoyle trainer Aidan O'Brien has confirmed Minardi, King's County and Darwin.

fields.headline: Newbury look to all-weather
fields.trailText: Newbury have applied for an all-weather track, to be built inside the current Flat and National Hunt turf courses and hope to have it ready within the next five years.
fields.body:
Newbury have applied for an all-weather track, to be built inside the current Flat and National Hunt turf courses and hope to have it ready within the next five years.

Managing director Mark Kershaw said: "It is very early days but the BHB and the Jockey Club have said they are interested in our application.

"It's something which has been considered in the past but which has not been followed through for various reasons.

"Once we saw the effect of our new grandstand we then looked at ways to utilise it even more."

fields.headline: Shortcuts
fields.trailText: Oversubscribed | Overexposed | Overheard
fields.body:
Oversubscribed

No logo clothes

Been there, got the T-shirt? May Day's savviest demonstrators returned with a rather fine sweatshirt. Which was, I hasten to add, being given away. If you missed out but would like to second the emotion, working along similar lines is Davina Bell, a final year fashion student at the University of Westminster, whose current collection is inspired by the belief that "fashion should be sold as an opinion, not as a brand". Inside each garment is printed a statement such as: "The consumerism of identity has caused a society in which the culture we breathe is predetermined by the conglomerate company." There is no designer label (though there is a price tag).
JCM

Overexposed

Geri

It's scary how committed to publicity this woman is. First she snogged Chris Evans, now she subsists on steamed veg, grilled chicken and the odd grain of rice. But the newly petite Geri's exploits haven't been for naught. Now she isdevoid of womanly curves, one can barely move without confronting the artist formerly known as Old Spice. Then there's the rumour, wheeled out so often it creaks, that she has sex with Robbie Williams. Result: she has propelled up the charts a song suitable only for drunken hen nights. It would be nice to imagine Geri is conducting a knowing post-modern experiment, designed to make us reflect on our obsession with thinness and famous people having sex. But it seems unlikely.
Hadley Freeman

Overheard

"Being a Benetton"

Someone or something universally considered bland, yet inexplicably ubiquitous. For example: "Victoria Hervey is the Benetton of It girls"

fields.headline: Harrison primed for first payday
fields.standfirst: Olympic champion to face Florida journeyman on Wembley bill
fields.trailText: After a cloak-and-dagger build-up that would have done credit to Oscars night, the identity of Audley Harrison's first professional opponent was announced yesterday in the shadow of Bodmin Moor.
fields.body:
After a cloak-and-dagger build-up that would have done credit to Oscars night, the identity of Audley Harrison's first professional opponent was announced yesterday in the shadow of Bodmin Moor.

Barely a fortnight before the Olympic super-heavyweight champion tops the bill at Wembley Arena on May 19, the name of Michael Middleton, a 32-year-old from Florida, was revealed.

Less the Beast of Bodmin than Joe Frazier on stilts, the personable Harrison is the man around whom the BBC is building its return to televised pugilism.

For the past two months he has been training for the six-round bout in seclusion at Hustyns, a "luxury lifestyle retreat" owned by Terry Johnson, a Cornish meat packager and supplier who proffered the same hospitality to Chris Eubank two years ago. Contrary to supposition, asserted the promoter Jess Harding, the bout has long been in the can.

Harrison's decision to employ the former world featherweight champion Colin McMillan as a nominal manager, resisting heavyweight representation in the interests of dictating his own course, had prompted fears that the scruple-free might seek to queer his pitch, hence the secrecy. Nor did the hush-hushing stop there. The Londoner, we were told, had been working with four sparring partners, all in the British top 10, none of whose names could possibly be revealed.

In basing himself in Cornwall, birthplace of Britain's first world heavyweight champion, Bob Fitzsimmons, Harrison's command of boxing lore was probably less of a factor than the rigorous security.

Finding the right opponent was always going to be complex. Gone are the days when Mickey Duff could wheel out "the Mexican heavyweight champion" as Frank Bruno's maiden obstacle. One reporter checked Middleton's record on the internet and hoisted a thumb to signal all was well. Although Harrison's maiden assignment cannot be too taxing, he must have some credibility, for the BBC's sake as much as his own. Hence Middleton, who has a record of eight wins and nine defeats.

"I left the video-watching to Colin," said Harrison. "He's a strong guy, durable." Stressing that Middleton had won his last fight, McMillan rammed the point home: "It's not going to be a one-round job." That said, he would not be disappointed if it were. "After what happened to Naseem [Hamed] and Lennox [Lewis], you've got to put your opponent away as quick as you can."

Unlike Bruno and Lewis, who began their professional lives on the undercard, Harrison is plunging in at the deep end. At 18st 5lb, almost 2st up on his Olympic weight - McMillan reckons he will shed 3lb before Wembley - making a splash should not be difficult. Harrison does not intend to drop down the bill in ensuing engagements, of which there may be up to six this year. "He likes that pressure," insisted McMillan.

Having visited the New York specialist consulted by Lewis and Hamed, Harrison claimed the hand he broke prior to the Sydney final was close to full potency. "I'm feeling 70-75%," he said. "I took three months off and I've been training for 11 weeks. I'm in good shape. Yeah, it's all looking rosy."

Asked if, at 29, it might be a trifle late to embark on this new road, he gave a broad, wry smile. He had no intention of elaborating, leaving that to his trainer Thell Torrance. "Age is only a number," said Torrance, whose mentor was the legendary Eddie Futch. "Look at George Foreman, look at Rocky Marciano. Audley is an athlete. Where he is right now, I'm satisfied. He's so dedicated it makes my job easy."

The promotion did not get off to the best of starts. Flyposters plastered around Wembley had to be withdrawn when it was pointed out that images of the Olympic rings were an infringement of copyright. The transition from amateur to professional promises several more rude awakenings, however long reality takes to bite.

fields.bodyText: After a cloak-and-dagger build-up that would have done credit to Oscars night, the identity of Audley Harrison's first professional opponent was announced yesterday in the shadow of Bodmin Moor. Barely a fortnight before the Olympic super-heavyweight champion tops the bill at Wembley Arena on May 19, the name of Michael Middleton, a 32-year-old from Florida, was revealed. Less the Beast of Bodmin than Joe Frazier on stilts, the personable Harrison is the man around whom the BBC is building its return to televised pugilism. For the past two months he has been training for the six-round bout in seclusion at Hustyns, a "luxury lifestyle retreat" owned by Terry Johnson, a Cornish meat packager and supplier who proffered the same hospitality to Chris Eubank two years ago. Contrary to supposition, asserted the promoter Jess Harding, the bout has long been in the can. Harrison's decision to employ the former world featherweight champion Colin McMillan as a nominal manager, resisting heavyweight representation in the interests of dictating his own course, had prompted fears that the scruple-free might seek to queer his pitch, hence the secrecy. Nor did the hush-hushing stop there. The Londoner, we were told, had been working with four sparring partners, all in the British top 10, none of whose names could possibly be revealed. In basing himself in Cornwall, birthplace of Britain's first world heavyweight champion, Bob Fitzsimmons, Harrison's command of boxing lore was probably less of a factor than the rigorous security. Finding the right opponent was always going to be complex. Gone are the days when Mickey Duff could wheel out "the Mexican heavyweight champion" as Frank Bruno's maiden obstacle. One reporter checked Middleton's record on the internet and hoisted a thumb to signal all was well. Although Harrison's maiden assignment cannot be too taxing, he must have some credibility, for the BBC's sake as much as his own. Hence Middleton, who has a record of eight wins and nine defeats. "I left the video-watching to Colin," said Harrison. "He's a strong guy, durable." Stressing that Middleton had won his last fight, McMillan rammed the point home: "It's not going to be a one-round job." That said, he would not be disappointed if it were. "After what happened to Naseem [Hamed] and Lennox [Lewis], you've got to put your opponent away as quick as you can." Unlike Bruno and Lewis, who began their professional lives on the undercard, Harrison is plunging in at the deep end. At 18st 5lb, almost 2st up on his Olympic weight - McMillan reckons he will shed 3lb before Wembley - making a splash should not be difficult. Harrison does not intend to drop down the bill in ensuing engagements, of which there may be up to six this year. "He likes that pressure," insisted McMillan. Having visited the New York specialist consulted by Lewis and Hamed, Harrison claimed the hand he broke prior to the Sydney final was close to full potency. "I'm feeling 70-75%," he said. "I took three months off and I've been training for 11 weeks. I'm in good shape. Yeah, it's all looking rosy." Asked if, at 29, it might be a trifle late to embark on this new road, he gave a broad, wry smile. He had no intention of elaborating, leaving that to his trainer Thell Torrance. "Age is only a number," said Torrance, whose mentor was the legendary Eddie Futch. "Look at George Foreman, look at Rocky Marciano. Audley is an athlete. Where he is right now, I'm satisfied. He's so dedicated it makes my job easy." The promotion did not get off to the best of starts. fields.headline: Ormond pains Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Leicestershire 224-8 Yorkshire 210 - Leicestershire won by 14 runs
fields.body:
Leicestershire 224-8 Yorkshire 210 - Leicestershire won by 14 runs

Yorkshiremen seldom admit to enjoying anything entirely without reservation. With an eminently attainable target and Michael Vaughan in full flow, it must have been tempting for the knot of visiting supporters for this Benson & Hedges Cup fixture to revel in the show as the England Test player rattled off 15 fours and made the game look ridiculously easy. Judgment was reserved, however, wisely so.

The fall of Vaughan's wicket on 92 to a brilliant catch by Daniel Marsh, son of Rodney, should have been no more than a setback. But having looked helpless in the face of his onslaught, Leicestershire regrouped. Their captain Vince Wells threw the ball to James Ormond and through some fine bowling and a slice of luck they pegged Yorkshire back and won a game that should have been beyond them.

Ormond on his day is one of the best pacemen on the county scene. Unfortunately such days are few and far between, mainly because he is often injured. Sure enough, he pulled up in his first over and limped off clutching his hamstring, leading to acerbic comment from Grace Road regulars.

But after an hour with the physio Ormond returned. His first wicket was a fluke; Darren Lehmann swung contemptuously at a leg-side delivery and it appeared to catch the back of the bat before looping gently to Neil Burns behind the stumps.

Michael Lumb was next, edging a bouncing delivery to Burns, and, when Anthony McGrath got a leading edge to one that also bounced unexpectedly high, Yorkshire were under real pressure. This was evident when Richard Blakey was run out after a mix-up with Gary Fellows.

Wells chipped in with the wickets of James Middlebrook and Chris Silverwood before Ormond produced another lifter to induce Fellows to chop on to his wicket. Another run-out ended the match.

This outcome had looked unlikely after Leicestershire failed to build on a promising foundation laid by Wells and Ben Smith, who added 119 runs for the second wicket. Vaughan, bowling his off-spin accurately and obtaining a modicum of turn, picked up four wickets to underline his potential all-round value to England.

Yorkshire's only consolation is being permitted to select Craig White and Darren Gough, two more centrally contracted England players, for Sunday's must-win game with Lancashire. Finding adequate cover for international call-ups is already beyond the White Rose county.

 A man was stabbed to death at the Recreation Ground in Antigua after the one-day international between West Indies and South Africa. Police said Craig Caesar Edwards, 27, had argued with another man who was arrested and is expected to be charged with murder.

fields.headline: Keegan has the final throw
fields.standfirst:
Middlesex 146-9 Kent 145-9
Middlesex won by one run
fields.trailText: After five abandoned games the sun finally shone on the South group of the Benson & Hedges Cup yesterday morning and though, by the time the outfield was fit for play, an unrelenting gloom had descended, there was a dramatic finish in which Middlesex won on a last-ball run-out as Kent's batsmen scampered a second run that would have given them the victory.
fields.body:
After five abandoned games the sun finally shone on the South group of the Benson & Hedges Cup yesterday morning and though, by the time the outfield was fit for play, an unrelenting gloom had descended, there was a dramatic finish in which Middlesex won on a last-ball run-out as Kent's batsmen scampered a second run that would have given them the victory.

If the start had been delayed by three hours, reducing the match to 31 overs per side, the end was compelling. Kent needed 14 off the last two overs with six wickets in hand and two batsmen going well when Matthew Walker inexplicably decided the best tactic was to slog the off-spin of Paul Weekes. He missed and was bowled.

Martin McCague hit the next delivery, a full toss, back to the bowler and the descent into chaos gathered pace when James Hockley was stumped off a wide after failing to score from his first ball.

Nine were required from the final over - eight if Kent lost fewer than nine wickets in all - and initially everything went well. James Golding worked Angus Fraser away on the leg-side for a pair of twos and managed a single from the third ball.

Fraser, whose first six overs had yielded only six runs, looked to be losing his line when it mattered most. But there is nothing like experience in these situations. The next ball yorked Paul Nixon.

Amjad Khan, a 20-year-old Danish bowler playing his first innings for Kent, scrambled a leg-bye, so two were needed from the final ball. Golding again worked the ball away on the leg-side but Chad Keegan's throw to the wicketkeeper David Nash was accurate enough to give Middlesex their unlikely success.

Kent had enough chances to compensate for the opener Robert Key's unfortunate afternoon. Not only did he struggle to get the ball off the square; he ran out Daryll Cullinan, also playing his first innings for the county.

Owais Shah's sprint in from cover and direct hit accounted for Cullinan before he had got going. It might have been better for Key - and Kent - if Stephen Fleming had held on to a slip catch when the opener had made two. His 27 runs used up 62 precious balls.

Middlesex's total had seemed at least 20 runs short of a challenging total. After the impressive Andrew Strauss and Shah had put on 74 for the third wicket, Middlesex managed only 51 from the last 10 overs.

Golding dismissed Strauss with his first ball of the season and Matthew Fleming put the seal on a disciplined Kent bowling performance with three wickets from four deliveries in the final over. If only the Kent batsmen had followed their bowlers' example.

webTitle: Cricket: We're all pals now says Waqar

fields.headline: Forget those feuds, we're all pals now says Waqar
fields.standfirst: Pakistan go public: Olive branches for today's tour opener against the Universities
fields.trailText: Pakistan have barely been in England 24 hours but already they have come up with the perfect solution to their years of internecine strife: they have banned all mention of it.
fields.body:
Pakistan have barely been in England 24 hours but already they have come up with the perfect solution to their years of internecine strife: they have banned all mention of it.

From this point forward, history is bunk, the past is forgotten, the future is now. The Pakistan tourists vowed yesterday to draw a line under the most destructive period in their cricket history, and all that has to be remarked is that it had better be a very strong line. If it holds throughout the series, then George Bush might consider it as a replacement for Star Wars.

Yawar Saeed, Pakistan's team manager, and once an all-rounder for Somerset, is fast winning respect here and his pronouncement at the end of an introductory media conference at Trent Bridge yesterday had to be admired for its idealistic attempt to impose order where for too long there has been chaos.

"We intend playing cricket in the very best traditions of the game," he said. "We will play hard but we hope we will win friends. I promise you will see everyone giving 100%. We would be grateful if you could judge us from today onwards. History is something we would like to forget."

With Waqar Younis, unexpectedly appointed as captain late in his career, also forcing an agreement at the first team meeting "not to talk about the past", pages of Wisdens could yet be expunged at a stroke. A late-night stroll down memory lane could finish with a one-way flight to Karachi.

The first examination of Pakistan's brave new world will be Yawar's assertion that Shoaib Akhtar, whose arrival has been delayed, will rock up early next week. Conspiracy theories would be disproved, suggested Yawar, and there was not even a replacement in mind. In Pakistan, though, one finds there are generally half a dozen replacements in mind.

"Shoaib's delay is a procedural thing," he said. "When we were leaving, the doctor said he needed a few more medical tests. He is expected to complete those within the next 24 hours."

In New Pakistan, Waqar and Wasim Akram are no longer fast-bowling adversaries, conspiring against each other. In New Pakistan, unity is strength, as Waqar was at pains to stress. "Everybody is friends," he said. "It is a game of cricket. Of course we want Wasim in the side. He is a key man."

If you regard some of this with a deal of scepticism then perhaps you are suffering from a western perspective. Richard Pybus will tell you so. Pybus, 36, once a journeyman Suffolk medium-pacer and still a coach with Border in South Africa, was reinstalled for his second term as Pakistan coach, in place of Javed Miandad, only a few days ago. He has possibly the unique claim of being supported by both Waqar and Wasim.

Pybus presented team spirit as "everything" and said his priority was "creating an environment and organisation in which Waqar, as captain, can flourish". He added: "These guys are professionals and work hard. You look at what goes on with a western perspective. I know the players, I know the culture, and I came back because there is now a good management team."

Pybus has suffered personally from Pakistan political machinations. He was joint coach with Mushtaq Mohammad when they reached the World Cup final in England two years ago but, after a military coup, cricket administrations came and went and, 18 months ago after a disastrous tour of Australia, he was replaced.

"Then the guys were not up to speed, they weren't fit and lacked preparation," he said. "This time they are in really good shape."

fields.headline: The Richard and Judy years
fields.trailText: Jessica Hodgson looks back on the Richard and Judy years
fields.body:
April 5 2001
Richard is forced to apologise after saying that Bob Godfrey, the creator of Roobarb and Custard, must have been on drugs. Mr Godffrey, a veteran TV animator, said: "Drawing a green dog and pink cat doesn't mean I was on drugs. I'm incensed."

March 11 2001
The Sunday People claims staff cannot stand working for "Ditchard and Judy", because they are so demanding. "Insiders" claim that they have been changed by fame.

February 27 2001
The Daily Mail reports that anarchists broke into the Granada studios minutes before the pair were due to go on air, chanting ecology"slogans.

February 14 2001
Richard and Judy host the first-ever televised gay wedding on This Morning, marrying Mark Jinks and Neil Morris from Manchester.

February 5 2001
The Daily Express reveals that the couple plan to reveal details of Judy's health problems and Richard's shoplifting in a joint autobiography, for which they will be paid half a million.

February 11 2001
It is claimed that Richard and Judy plan to leave the series after falling out with new ITV boss Maureen Duffy.

January 17 2001
The show hits controversy as it emerges that Mitchell Quy, who killed his wife then appeared on the show, was jailed for life.

October 15 2000
Judy makes the headlines as she bares her "golden globes" at the National Television Awards, having to be rescued by John Lesley.

July 7 2000
Judy says "shit" on air after spilling hot fat from a kebab on her hand.

June 21 2000
Richard does a toe-curlingly embarrassing impression of Ali G.

February 1999
Richard and Judy, along with other daytime shows, have their wrists slapped by the ITC for relying too much on sex and nudity.

February 1999
Tony Blair appears on the show to discuss the next football manager of England and where he goes on holiday, setting a precedent for politicians using the tabloid media for big announcements.

February 1999
Victoria Beckham rings the show to tell Richard and Judy that a David Beckham lookalike on the programme "is not bad".

September 1998
Richard and Judy are slammed by the Impotency Association after they persuade three couples to "road test" Viagra on the show.

1998
Judy reveals on television that she feels "better and sexier" than ever after having hormone replacement therapy.

webTitle: Dando suspect had 'exaggerated interest' in TV stars

fields.headline: Dando suspect had 'exaggerated interest' in TV stars
fields.standfirst: Special report: Jill Dando
fields.trailText: The man accused of killing Jill Dando had "an exaggerated interest" in television stars and guns, the Old Bailey heard today.
fields.body:
The man accused of killing Jill Dando had "an exaggerated interest" in television stars and guns, the Old Bailey heard today.

The jury heard how Miss Dando, 37, was killed by a single bullet through her head as she crouched outside the front door of her home in Gowan Avenue, Fulham, south-west London, at around 11.30am on April 26 1999.

Mr George, who is unemployed, denies murder.

"Nobody witnessed the attack. Within a short time a number of people saw her slumped and bleeding in the porchway," said Orlando Pownall, prosecuting.

He told the court that Mr George had obsessive personality traits, including an exaggerated interest in well-known figures, whose success he aspired to emulate, the army, weapons and the media.

"Each of these aspects to his character is significant and relevant to this case," said Mr Pownall.

Mr George had allegedly changed his name a number of times and adopted the names or original surnames of some of those whom he most admired.

Over the years, the court was told, he had called himself Steve Majors, which was derived from Lee Majors, who starred as a stuntman and in a series known as the Bionic Man and Steve Austin whose part he played.

"He also knew himself as Thomas Palmer, after one of the SAS soldiers who achieved fame when he was involved in the Iranian Embassy siege.

"More recently the defendant claimed that he was Freddie Mercury's cousin and chose to be known as Barry Bulsara, after the original surname of Mercury, the former lead singer of Queen who died in November, 1991."

Mr George was born in Hammersmith and lived for 10 years in a ground-floor flat about 500 yards from Gowan Avenue.

Before the case was opened Mr Justice Gage told the jury of seven women and five men that Mr George would sit with a helper, as he suffered from bouts of epilepsy.

Also in court was Miss Dando's former fiancé, Alan Farthing, her brother, Nigel, her fellow presenter, Nick Ross, and Mr George's sister, Michelle Diskin.

Mr Pownall said that the defendant "retained an unusual interest in the BBC" after working there as messenger for five months in 1976.

Mr George also bought copies of the Radio Times, while documents seized from his flat contained references to telephone numbers at the BBC.

Police developed films found at the address and discovered that there were photographs of the television when there were presenters and newscasters appearing, Mr Pownall said.

The QC went on: "In interview he suggested that he had not heard of Jill Dando before her death and did not know what she looked like.

"Such a suggestion was patently false."

"When arrested he claimed that he would not have recognised her if he had seen her in the street and yet after the shooting he told a woman that he knew somebody famous in Gowan Avenue, 'a very special lady'," Mr Pownall said.

He told another woman that he disliked the BBC because of the way that it treated the Queen singer, the jury was told.

The case continues.

webTitle: Tory moderates admit defeat in manifesto fight

fields.headline: Tory moderates admit defeat in manifesto fight
fields.standfirst:
Full coverage of Election 2001
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Tory moderates have lost their fight to influence the party's manifesto and are preparing a post-election assault on party policy.
fields.body:
Tory moderates have lost their fight to influence the party's manifesto and are preparing a post-election assault on party policy.

One leading moderate declared yesterday: "On June 8, the party's soul is up for grabs."

The party leader William Hague, who took personal control of the drafting process to toughen up the party programme, told staff in a pre-campaign pep talk at Conservative central office yesterday that it would be "the most radical and far-reaching programme for a generation". But moderates believe it will send out a reactionary and exclusive message.

"It is aimed at the party strategists' mums," one said despairingly, "and it will do nothing to shore up our support in metropolitan areas where we look like doing even worse than last time."

Moderates are dismayed that the manifesto, which was finalised by the shadow cabinet yesterday, will include a specific commitment to section 28, the legislation banning local authorities from promoting homosexuality in schools, which Labour is committed to repeal.

The ban has long been a focus of discontent on the left of the party, who fear it can be taken as a symbol of the party's narrow, homophobic outlook and it was specifically attacked by Shaun Woodward when he defected to Labour.

The moderates believe that in cities, especially London where the Tories lost 24 seats to Labour - including Michael Portillo's - the race row will have already damaged the party's chances of regaining marginals, and a perceived anti-gay bias will only worsen the situation.

Mr Hague confirmed that the future of the pound will dominate the Tory campaign.

After prolonged debate among strategists over how the euro issue should be played, it emerged yesterday that the most sceptical approach has won.

The plan now is to devote two thirds of days left before polling day to the issue. Mr Hague told party workers: "The decision to scrap the pound has already been taken by Labour and their Liberal allies. I say the Conservatives will keep the pound and this may be your last chance to save it."

He also highlighted tax cuts, education and law and order as likely battlegrounds and tried to boost morale by reminding workers that the Tories won the European elections in 1999 with a 36% share of the vote, even though polls showed them with only 17.5%. Local election results since then showed the party was still outperforming its opinion poll standing, while Labour's share of the vote, at 32%, was well below its poll rating.

In another sign of the battle lines in the aftermath of a Tory defeat, the leading Conservative pro-European, Ian Taylor, is to chair the European Movement.

The group will be the main all-party platform for a Yes vote in a referendum on the euro, which could be within months of the election.

fields.headline: Blair clears decks for poll
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is poised to trigger a general election campaign next Wednesday with parliament dissolving two days later in time for the June 7 poll.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is poised to trigger a general election campaign next Wednesday with parliament dissolving two days later in time for the June 7 poll.

The prime ministerial battle bus will then immediately take to the campaign trail while the Labour manifesto - focusing on economic stability and new ways to deliver public services - will be launched in the middle of the following week.

The Conservatives, needing every minute to claw back Labour's poll lead, may launch their document earlier. In a bid to raise morale, William Hague summoned 150 Central Office staff yesterday to tell them: "We have never been as prepared for battle as we are now. We will start this campaign faster and finish it more strongly than any previous election."

Gearing up for the election, Mr Blair held a press conference to declare the war against foot and mouth effectively won, before telephoning the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, to say he was pulling out of a summit of European socialists in Berlin on Monday.

Mr Blair also saw a stream of senior newspaper figures including Rebekah Wade, editor of the News of the World, and Charles Moore, editor of the Daily Telegraph. Rupert Murdoch, owner of News International, was also seen emerging from No 11, the residence of the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

Mr Blair clearly implied yesterday that the foot and mouth crisis was over and that there was no reason now not to proceed with the election. He said the backlog of slaughtered animal carcasses was cleared - 2.4m have been killed - and the last animal pyre lit.

"What we have had to do in terms of slaughter is a ghastly business, but we wanted to save British food production and there was no alternative.

He added: "Foot and mouth is not beaten yet. We have more to do. But we are on the home straight."

The number of new cases a day was halving every two weeks, as had been predicted. On current trends it would be down to four a day in two weeks and one a day on average by June 6.

fields.headline: Presenters line up for This Morning
fields.trailText: Fern Britton, John Leslie and Kaye Adams have been tipped as possible replacements for Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan on ITV's daytime show, This Morning.
fields.body:
Fern Britton, John Leslie and Kaye Adams have been tipped as possible replacements for Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan on ITV's daytime show, This Morning.

The three are being touted by ITV insiders as the leading contenders to replace the duo, who are heading for Channel 4.

Britton and Leslie already present This Morning on Fridays, when Madeley and Finnigan take a break.

Adams is also an established face of ITV daytime TV as co-presents the afternoon show, Live Talk, with Nadia Sawalha.

A decision on who will replace Madeley and Finnigan is expected to be taken before the current run of This Morning ends in July.

fields.headline: Outbreak threatens 250,000 jobs
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The English tourism council has warned that as many as 250,000 jobs are at risk because of the foot and mouth outbreak.
fields.body:
The English tourism council has warned that as many as 250,000 jobs are at risk because of the foot and mouth outbreak.

Without special aid, English tourism was likely to lose £5bn this year, £2.5bn next year and £1bn in 2003, the council said. It added that only 14% of Britons intended to take a short break holiday in the countryside during May.

Without additional public investment, 150,000 direct tourist jobs were at risk and "potentially 250,000 jobs may be affected", the council said.

The ETC added: "While the foot and mouth outbreak appears to be over the worst, many countryside tourism businesses are still facing financial ruin.

"Most countryside businesses depend upon British visitors for their income. As many as 90% of countryside visits are made by people who holiday at home. Nearly £4 out of every £5 spent on tourism in England comes from people who live here."

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, moved to support tourism today by urging local authorities to think "very hard" about reopening footpaths in areas where there had been no foot and mouth cases.

His call came the day after Tony Blair declared that the battle against the disease was in the "home straight", clearing the way for an expected general election on June 7. Ministers are now anxious to see the countryside start returning to normal before the election.

Mr Brown said that decisions would have to be made on a case-by-case basis, but that where whole counties have not had a single case, local authorities should look very hard at reopening the footpaths.

He added that the risk of spreading the disease is not coming primarily from footpaths, but that the major disease risks are the movements of vehicles, the movements of people and the unlicensed movements of livestock.

Mr Brown's pleas came as four paths leading to the summit of Mount Snowdon were being officially reopened today after the foot and mouth crisis forced their closure. The chief executive of the Snowdonia national park authority, Iwan Huws, was marking the occasion by walking to the top of the 1,085-metre peak - the highest in England and Wales. The Snowdon massif, in the heart of north Wales, was closed to the public on February 27 and was a designated infected area until April 18. Following the reopening, walkers will still be obliged to disinfect footwear at the start and end of their excursion.

Ramblers' Association spokesperson Jacquetta Fewster welcomed the move.

She said: "It's great that more of the countryside is being reopened, particularly in such a beautiful area. But there are still thousands of miles of footpaths that remain needlessly closed. The Ramblers' Association urges all local authorities to encourage the public back into the countryside by opening up paths in line with recent government advice."

webTitle: British film actors threaten to strike

fields.headline: British film actors threaten to strike
fields.standfirst: UK could follow Hollywood's lead in dispute over profit sharing deal -  Harry Potter movie faces disruption
fields.trailText: The UK could follow Hollywood's lead in dispute over profit sharing deal - Harry Potter movie faces disruption, write Fiachra Gibbons and Lucy Barrick.
fields.body:
A strike by British actors demanding profit sharing deals like those of their US counterparts became a possibility yesterday after talks with film producers reached an impasse.

Although the news sent a shudder through an industry already braced for a much more damaging American stoppage next month over the same thorny issue of "residuals", both sides say they do not want a strike.

British actors are paid a flat fee in advance for these residuals: video and DVD sales and TV broadcasts of films they appear in. The payment on broadcast or use of the film starts from £22 a day, depending on how many days they worked on a shot.

American actors, however, get an extra cut of the profits if a film is successful.

The actors' union, Equity, said last night it was unhappy with the way that talks with Pact, the producers' alliance, had reached a deadlock and said the gap between US and British pay rates was unacceptable.

Equity's assistant general secretary, Andy Prodger, said it was unfair that American actors working in the UK on predominately British productions received residual payments while British actors did not. On Mission Impossible "$1.8m [£1.3m] has been paid to the small number of American actors who appeared in the film, but not a penny has gone to any of the the British artists".

Even if talks break down altogether, it could be six months before any industrial action is taken. The sequel to the first of the Harry Potter films could be hit.

Mr Prodger, however, conceded that very few of those British films lucky enough to get a distributor broke into profit quickly, if ever.

Bertrand Moullier, of Pact, said he was confident the dispute could be resolved within the six-month deadline. "There is no need for people to get nervous. Negotiations are ongoing, and we are hopeful we can reach a sensible settlement to this."

But Mr Prodger said: "We're hoping to get a positive response before the end of the six months, but if it doesn't happen we would have to advise our members not to accept contracts.

"We don't want to strike, but we are very serious about getting a fair share of the profits."

The threatened Screen Actors Guild strike in Hollywood has effectively halted new projects there. It had been hoped that British studios could take advantage of the actors' strike and also the American screen writers' strike, due begin next week, by tempting producers to move lock, stock and barrel across the Atlantic. But the prospect of a British strike, however slight, would not encourage this.

In any case, the exodus from Hollywood has so far failed to materialise.

The worst case would be if the American actors' dispute were to spill over into Britain. Equity has indicated that its members would go out in sympathy if the studios tried to relocate films that were already set up to be shot in the US.

But industry analysts think there is little danger of this kind of escalation, as the studios do not want to be caught in a double whammy between antagonised actors and writers, never mind opening a fresh front with another union across the Atlantic.

fields.headline: Sunday Mirror wins lookalike libel case
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: A woman has failed to sue the paper over a picture publicising an adult website, reports Ashley Davies.
25.04.2001: PCC backs claim against Sunday Mirror
fields.body:
A woman who tried to sue the Sunday Mirror over a lookalike picture has lost her case.

Londoner Kerry O'Shea, 24, had brought a claim for libel over an advertisement for an adults-only website.

The advert appeared in the Sunday Mirror on five occasions last summer and used pictures of several women.

Ms O'Shea alleged one woman, shown holding a telephone receiver to her ear, looked almost identical to her.

Mr Justice Morland said if the photograph in question had been a true photograph of Ms O'Shea, whom he described as a "respectable young woman", she would undoubtedly have won her case.

But he dismissed her claim saying it would place an "impossible burden" on the media if they were forced to look out for such cases in the future.

Ms O'Shea claimed the ad suggested she "was appearing or performing on a highly pornographic website containing material of an explicit, indecent and lewd nature and had shamelessly agreed to promote this website and her own appearance on it in a national newspaper".

The judge was told the picture was of a well-known glamour model, known as "Miss E", who allowed her photo to appear in sex industry adverts.

Ms O'Shea's action against Mirror Group Newspapers and Free4Internet.Net was the first libel case involving lookalikes in English law.

webTitle: Shooting to kill can be dangerous

fields.headline: Shooting to kill can be dangerous
fields.standfirst:
The European Court of Human Rights has ruled that the rights of armed IRA men were infringed. The responses have been predictable, writes Derek Brown.
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The European Court of Human Rights has ruled that the rights of armed IRA men were infringed. The responses have been predictable, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The European Court of Human Rights has a long and distinguished record of safeguarding the citizens of Western Europe against excesses of government. That is why our rulers don't always approve of the body they created in the aftermath of the second world war.

The court has already been criticised harshly for its latest clutch of findings that the human rights of armed IRA men were infringed when they were shot and killed by security forces.

David Trimble, the Northern Ireland first minister, has called the ruling perverse and astonishing. Andrew McKay, the shadow spokesman on Northern Ireland, was even more blunt.

"There can be no justification whatever to suggest that in any of these cases excessive force was used. Anybody who cares for the rule of law owes the RUC and the Army a tremendous debt of gratitude for their dedication and sacrifice in defending democracy in our country," he said.

Two bits of mythology should be removed from the complex picture. One is that the European Court of Human Rights is part of the EU structure. It isn't. It is older and quite separate.

Another modern myth is that the Court is always anti-government in general, and anti-British government in particular. That too is blatant nonsense. Britain is a founder member of the Council of Europe, the parent body of the Court. There was a British judge on the panel which unanimously issued the latest ruling.

The essence of the ruling is that the government of the day, and the security forces, infringed basic human rights by operating a shoot-to-kill policy.

The most graphic case before the court related to the eight IRA men killed after a 1987 attack on the much-battered rural police station in Loughgall, County Armagh. That the eight were in the IRA and took part in the attack, is not in dispute. But the central fact is that they were not killed during the attack, but after it.

As they moved away from the scene, they were ambushed by an SAS unit and cut down without warning, along with an innocent passer-by.

Many people will say that the IRA men had it coming. After all, they knew what they were getting into when they joined an illegal organisation conducting an armed insurrection.

Civil libertarians, however, argue that while governments are entitled to take defensive action against such groups, they should never have the right to carry out what amounts to summary executions.

In Northern Ireland, the issue is of course clouded by partisan passions. Families of victims - notably those who belong to Relatives for Justice - call for prosecution of soldiers, policemen, and ministers, and speak of Britain as a terrorist state. Unionist politicians rail about all the victims of the IRA. In this, as in so many aspects of the conflict, visceral reaction does little to address the central cause of human rights.

The government too is doing little to clarify the situation. Northern Ireland secretary John Reid has withdrawn behind a verbal smokescreen, declaring that the Court did not talk about unlawful killings or specifically about a shoot-to-kill policy.

Indeed it didn't, but that should not divert attention from the essence of the Court's verdict, that the security forces took lives without justification. The Strasbourg judges have ordered £10,000 compensation to be paid to the families of 10 IRA dead IRA men.

It is likely that the government will appeal, and even more likely that bereaved families will go to law for more compensation, and for some kind of criminal prosecution.

The litigation will go drearily on, but none of it is likely to produce a finding as clear and important as that laid down by the European court.

fields.bodyText: The European Court of Human Rights has a long and distinguished record of safeguarding the citizens of Western Europe against excesses of government. That is why our rulers don't always approve of the body they created in the aftermath of the second world war. The court has already been criticised harshly for its latest clutch of findings that the human rights of armed IRA men were infringed when they were shot and killed by security forces. David Trimble, the Northern Ireland first minister, has called the ruling perverse and astonishing. Andrew McKay, the shadow spokesman on Northern Ireland, was even more blunt. "There can be no justification whatever to suggest that in any of these cases excessive force was used. Anybody who cares for the rule of law owes the RUC and the Army a tremendous debt of gratitude for their dedication and sacrifice in defending democracy in our country," he said. Two bits of mythology should be removed from the complex picture. One is that the European Court of Human Rights is part of the EU structure. It isn't. It is older and quite separate. Another modern myth is that the Court is always anti-government in general, and anti-British government in particular. That too is blatant nonsense. Britain is a founder member of the Council of Europe, the parent body of the Court. There was a British judge on the panel which unanimously issued the latest ruling. The essence of the ruling is that the government of the day, and the security forces, infringed basic human rights by operating a shoot-to-kill policy. The most graphic case before the court related to the eight IRA men killed after a 1987 attack on the much-battered rural police station in Loughgall, County Armagh. webTitle: Luton defender on bail after attack on 'racist' fan

fields.headline: Luton defender on bail after attack on 'racist' fan
fields.trailText: Luton Town defender Jude Stirling was on police bail today after allegedly attacking a fan who is said to have shouted racist abuse during a match.
fields.body:
Luton Town defender Jude Stirling was on police bail today after allegedly attacking a fan who is said to have shouted racist abuse during a match.

Stirling was arrested at last night's 2-2 draw with Division Two rivals Brentford.

The 18-year-old was not playing but watching the match from the Luton dug-out at Brentford's ground, Griffin Park, west London.

Witnesses said a Brentford supporter was yelling racist abuse at black players on the pitch when Stirling allegedly intervened.

Luton manager Joe Kinnear said: "The fan was throwing racial abuse at Liam George throughout the game - the guy came up with one hand in his pocket and walked up to Jude's face and said something highly offensive and disgraceful.

"Jude said he thought he (the fan) might have had something in his pocket - maybe a knife or something like that - he didn't know what to do so he felt he was defending himself and gave him a right-hander.

"There was the most severe provocation.

"I can't see how the fan was allowed to get to the players' dug-out. I don't know if there was that many stewards around there or not.

"This fellow had been throwing abuse at Ron Noades all night - he turned his abuse onto Liam George and then onto Stirling so he was obviously out looking for aggravation.

"One doesn't like to see any sort of violence at football matches but Jude reacted in the same manner that I would have done myself."

Kinnear said that Stirling - considered a rising star at the club - was taken to Chiswick police station, where he was released at 3.30am today.

"I shall be doing the best I can to support the kid and we will now wait and see what comes back from the police, and indeed the FA," he added.

Scotland Yard said a 33-year-old man had been injured but no charges had been brought.

"A man has been bailed to return to police on June 5 pending further inquiries in connection with an alleged assault," said a spokesman.

"We are looking at video footage from the ground."

fields.headline: ITV grits teeth over daytime defection
fields.trailText:
3pm update: ITV said it was 'business as usual' after the shock departure of daytime TV stars Richard and Judy to Channel 4, writes Lisa O'Carroll.

04.05.2001: Richard and Judy in shock departure
fields.body:
ITV bosses were today glossing over the loss of Richard and Judy and insisting This Morning would continue, following the couple's bombshell decision to quit the show after 13 years.

They said it was business as usual for daytime television and the priority was to find two new presenters.

ITV's head of daytime TV, Maureen Duffy, said: "Richard and Judy have made a terrific contribution to ITV over the past 13 years and we wish them well in the future."

Making her feelings felt about the future of the show, she added: "They leave This Morning, Britain's most popular daytime TV show, in great shape."

The departure of Richard and Judy will leave a gaping hole in ITV's armour.

Together they kept the show alive - they were notorious for maintaining control of the content of the show, making producers' lives difficult, but kept the show topical and attractive to viewers.

Over the past 13 years the couple has been invincible in the ratings, seeing off all rivals including the BBC's Anne Diamond with a regular audience of 2m.

Richard and Judy told few people of their decision to leave, although reports that they were unhappy at ITV surfaced as far back as February.

It is believed that the Granada programming boss, Grant Mansfield, was made aware of their decision only recently.

Others on the show, including the producers, co-presenters and publicity officers, were kept out of the loop until the deal was announced this morning.

"I know people always say it wasn't a question of money, but genuinely this time it was," said one source.

"It is a bit of a bombshell all round."

It is believed just three people at Channel 4 knew of the negotiations - Jo McGrath, the commissioning editor of daytime TV; the programme director, Tim Gardam; and the chief executive, Michael Jackson, who will have sanctioned the multimillion pound payout for the stars.

Ms McGrath was talking to independent producers about ideas for late afternoon when Amanda Ross, the head of Cactus TV - a subsidiary of Chrysalis - suggested an approach for Richard and Judy.

It only became clear at 8pm last night that a deal was going to be signed this morning.

Channel 4 executives are delighted with their scoop - the station has been flagging in the ratings ever since Anne Robinson's Weakest Link on BBC2 took off.

The BBC quiz show was pulling in up to 5m viewers - 2m more than Countdown on occasions.

fields.headline: DoomWatch
fields.standfirst: Talk of recession has now permeated every sector of the media. The slump is no longer the preserve of the internet and advertising industries. Each week, our new DoomWatch service will keep you up to date with the changes in the media economy, complete with expert opinions from the US and UK
fields.trailText: Positive results from US media heavyweights have failed to dispel fears of a recession in the world's largest economy. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Positive results over the past few weeks from US media heavyweights such as AOL Time Warner and Echostar have failed to dispel fears of a recession in the world's largest economy.

US investors have cashed in on the brief burst of optimism, with a flurry of profit-taking bringing down the tech-heavy Nasdaq list in New York.

Their decision to cash in while the going is good seemed to pay off, as US Labour Department figures showed further weakening in the jobs market.

The media market in the US is also faltering, with newspaper stocks continuing to revise down their advertising estimates, and cable systems companies apparently the only stocks in the sector putting up a fight.

"Everyone was expecting advertising revenue to come back, but the news is getting worse and it has been augmented by the unemployment figures.

"There has been some optimism over the last few weeks, but it has fizzled out," said Martin Clarke, fund manager at UBS Asset Management in New York.

The UK is far from immune, with the Bank of England governor, Sir Eddie George, admitting his surprise at the slowdown in the country's economic growth since the beginning of the year.

Recession roulette - who's winning and who's losing

 British Telecom shaved £4.8bn off its £30bn debt burden with sale of its stakes in Japan Telecom, J-Phone and Spanish mobile phone operator Airtel to UK rival Vodafone.
02.05.2001: BT raises £4.8bn in sales

 Mobile phone giant Vodafone hinted at a revival in the telecoms sector with an oversubscribed £3.5bn share issue to pay for the BT acquisitions.
02.05.2001: Vodafone upstages BT

 T-Online, Europe's largest Internet service provider, said advertising and e-commerce revenues had fallen by 36% to £19.4m in the first three months of the year.
03.05.2001: T-Online fails to impress

 Mobile phone operator Orange released first-quarter earnings figures which boosted its reputation as a fast-growing company, with revenues soaring 33% to £2.1bn compared to the same period last year.
03.05.2001: Telecoms boost with Orange up 33%

 Rupert Murdoch took a significant step closer to securing the £42bn merger of his Sky Global Networks TV stations with US satellite broadcaster DirecTV, after parent company General Motors agreed to hold official talks. A successful deal will form the world's largest satellite TV company.
02.05.2001: Murdoch in DirecTV merger talks

 Internet incubator Bright Station announced it was in dire straits, and unveiled a last-ditch rescue package with investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston. Sceptical investors gave the announcement short shrift, and the company has nearly run out of money.
30.04.2001: Bright Station rescue plan fails to impress

 Internet service provider WorldCom lays off 832 employees.
03.05.2001: WorldCom wields axe in Europe

 IPC pulled the plug on its Nova lifestyle magazine as the shrinking magazine market began to hurt major publishers.
03.05.2001: Nova magazine to close for second time

 Financial information broadcaster Money Channel admitted it was running out of cash, as advertisers were put off by its small viewing figures.
02.05.2001: Money Channel founded by Adam Faith runs out of cash

fields.headline: Captain Mainwaring's Mouth Organ
fields.standfirst: Exclusive: Guardian Unlimited has obtained explosive details of a government strategy to save British tourism from foot and mouth - which owes more than a little to a certain romantic film drama...
fields.trailText: Exclusive: Guardian Unlimited has obtained explosive details of a government strategy to save British tourism from foot and mouth - which owes more than a little to a certain romantic film drama...
fields.body:
To: "Smith, Chris" (smithy@culture.gov.uk)
Cc: "handouts" (handouts@lotterycommission.co.uk), "Brown, Nick" (nick@maff.gov.uk) stevie (spielberg@dreamworks.com)
Subject: Captain Mainwaring's Mouth Organ

Dear Chris

Regarding our discussion about boosting Britain's tourist industry, I've put my head together with Melvyn and the boys at the BFI and we've come up with something of an original idea for a film. It's a long shot, but it might just sell foot and mouth to the Americans...

Captain Mainwaring's Mouth Organ: love in the time of foot and mouth

It's 2001. On a small, green island in the North sea, peasant farmers are living under a brutal regime of occupation by the white-suited men from Maff. No one can move without hostile interrogation. Prohibition signs bar ancient rights of way. Disease is rife. Some of the locals are down to their last Range Rover.

In one village, a beautiful maiden lives. Fiery, pure, this woman embodies the essence of English sexuality. [I'm thinking Penelope Keith here, Chris - can you swing this for us?] Her husband, a horny-handed son of the soil from six generations of farmers, is a leader of the local resistance. He will defend his land to the last, and frequently takes pot shots at local ramblers.

Although solidly behind her husband against the Maff intruders, Keith is worried that his meetings with shadowy figures from the Countryside Alliance are making him increasingly brutal. Her wise father [what we'd give for a Gielgud here] gives her a 12-bore and tells her she shouldn't be afraid to use it.

And then she sees him: the man from Maff, a townie, but different from the rest. Captain Mainwaring: he's cultured, debonair. If we can get him, it's Nicholas Parsons. [Memo to casting director: can Nicholas do accents?]

One starry evening, Keith is wandering through the fields in a soft, silken Barbour jacket. A sweet sound permeates the constant gunfire - it's a song, a song that takes her back to the time when her own parents would sing to her: it's I've Got A Brand New Combine Harvester, a rousing patriotic anthem. In the faint half-light of a smouldering pyre, she sees its source: Parsons, proud and erect in disinfected leather wellies, blowing and sucking gently on his harmonica. Their eyes meet. Cattle low. The smoke clears.

[I think you're getting the picture, Chris - romantic but NOT TACKY]

It's forbidden love. She wants him yet distrusts him; she can't ignore Parsons' charms but can't quite forget what his cohorts did to the family goat.

[Note from Melvyn: would a bodice-ripping scene on a muddy country lane work here?]

Then Parsons is sent off to cull in counties far and wide. Months pass. But he never forgets. Finally he returns. He tiptoes over the cattle grid to Keith's farm and spies his love in the distance. The old flames start to burn again - it's another disease-ridden sheep being laid to rest. But Parsons sees, next to his love, another man, dressed in white overalls.

Keith turns and walks into the cowshed. The man in overalls follows. Parsons thinks it can only mean one thing: weeping, he walks away - though he will never forget.

Cut to cowshed. Shots ring out. An embittered Keith has slaughtered the man in overalls. It has all been a tragic misunderstanding. The credits roll.

NB Melvyn thinks this might be a little too downbeat for an American audience, and has come up with an alternative ending:

Keith spots Parsons in the distance. Jumping on her prize stud bull, she gallops towards him. Parsons leaps on behind and, his hair flowing in the wind, they ride out, ignoring the no entry signs on footpaths. As they ride, they notice a new breed of strong and healthy cows coming over the hill. Men from Maff lay down their overalls. Farmers embrace. The theme from Last of the Summer Wine plays. Love has triumphed, and the countryside is safe once more.

webTitle: Shell tarred with 'lust for profit' tag

fields.headline: Shell tarred with 'lust for profit' tag
fields.trailText: Royal Dutch/Shell reported record profits yesterday, angering fuel protesters and prompting renewed calls for a windfall tax on the oil industry.
fields.body:
Royal Dutch/Shell reported record profits yesterday, angering fuel protesters and prompting renewed calls for a windfall tax on the oil industry.

The Anglo-Dutch group made a net profit of $3.85bn (£2.69bn) in the first three months of the year - its fifth successive quarterly record and a 23% increase on the same period last year.

News of the scale of Shell's profits, which came amid reports of another round of fuel protests planned for next week, sparked a wave of anger.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, said: "It is as if they are playing their own game of 'Who wants to be a billionaire?' at the expense of the motorist and the taxpayer. If they are not prepared to voluntarily curb their own lust for profit, the only solution is the introduction of a windfall tax."

Garry Russell, organiser of the Dump the Pump campaign, was outraged. "What this calls for is for more windfall taxes directed at the oil giants," he said. "They are profiteering hugely."

Shell, which has 1,100 petrol stations in Britain and led the recent round of price increases, argued that it did not make a profit at the pump. "Over the last three years we have not made any money from petrol retailing," said a spokesman. "It is a very, very competitive market."

Shell was a good corporate citizen, contributing significantly to the economy in terms of employment, investment and taxation, he added.

The group said the rise in profits was due to higher oil and gas prices, backed by its campaign of cutting costs.

Sir Mark Moody-Stuart, the chairman, said: "We have come a long way over the last few years. We have continued to search for new opportunities for profitable growth, some of which you have seen come to fruition in the last few months."

Sir Mark expressed disappointment that the company's plans for the acquisition of Woodside in Australia had been blocked, but balanced that against acquisition of New Zealand's Fletcher Challenge Energy and the position Shell had built up in China.

The group has a number of deals in the pipeline: a bid for Barrett Resources in the United States, a joint retail venture in Germany and the acquisition of the stakes in Equilon and Motiva held by a joint-venture partner, Texaco.

However, Sir Mark rejected any suggestion that Shell was embarking on a profits-driven spending spree. "What we will not do is pursue targets purely in the interests of making a deal, nor will we lose sight of the underlying economics of our business."

Although fuel protesters were angered by the scale of the group's profits, the City was less impressed. Shares in Shell Transport & Trading, the British half of the Anglo-Dutch group, fell 23p to 560p.

Mark Redway, an oil analyst at Teather & Greenwood, said: "It's perverse, but it's a case of this might just be as good as it gets."

If they are not prepared to voluntarily curb their own lust for profit, the only solution is the introduction of a windfall tax." Garry Russell, organiser of the Dump the Pump campaign, was outraged. "What this calls for is for more windfall taxes directed at the oil giants," he said. "They are profiteering hugely." Shell, which has 1,100 petrol stations in Britain and led the recent round of price increases, argued that it did not make a profit at the pump. "Over the last three years we have not made any money from petrol retailing," said a spokesman. "It is a very, very competitive market." Shell was a good corporate citizen, contributing significantly to the economy in terms of employment, investment and taxation, he added. The group said the rise in profits was due to higher oil and gas prices, backed by its campaign of cutting costs. Sir Mark Moody-Stuart, the chairman, said: "We have come a long way over the last few years. We have continued to search for new opportunities for profitable growth, some of which you have seen come to fruition in the last few months." Sir Mark expressed disappointment that the company's plans for the acquisition of Woodside in Australia had been blocked, but balanced that against acquisition of New Zealand's Fletcher Challenge Energy and the position Shell had built up in China. The group has a number of deals in the pipeline: a bid for Barrett Resources in the United States, a joint retail venture in Germany and the acquisition of the stakes in Equilon and Motiva held by a joint-venture partner, Texaco. However, Sir Mark rejected any suggestion that Shell was embarking on a profits-driven spending spree. "What we will not do is pursue targets purely in the interests of making a deal, nor will we lose sight of the underlying economics of our business." Although fuel protesters were angered by the scale of the group's profits, the City was less impressed. Shares in Shell Transport & Trading, the British half of the Anglo-Dutch group, fell 23p to 560p. Mark Redway, an oil analyst at Teather & Greenwood, said: "It's perverse, but it's a case of this might just be as good as it gets."

webTitle: Killing of IRA men was 'human rights violation'

fields.headline: Killing of IRA men was 'human rights violation'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The government was today ordered to pay £10,000 to each of the families of 10 IRA men shot dead by police and troops in Northern Ireland after judges in Europe ruled the terrorists' human rights had been violated.
fields.body:
The government was today ordered to pay £10,000 to each of the families of 10 IRA men shot dead by police and troops in Northern Ireland after judges in Europe ruled the terrorists' human rights had been violated.

They include relatives of eight heavily-armed Provisionals ambushed by the SAS as they retreated from a gun and bomb attack which destroyed a police station.

In four separate cases considered by the European court of human rights - involving the deaths of 10 IRA men, a Sinn Fein member and a civilian - seven judges ruled unanimously that Article 2 of the Human Rights Convention guaranteeing a right to life had been violated.

Lawyers claimed excessive force was used and that a so-called shoot to kill policy had been sanctioned by the government and security chiefs.

As jubilant relatives immediately demanded the RUC officers and soldiers involved be charged with murder, one of the legal representatives said: "It is a reminder to the government, even in the midst of conflict, they cannot step outside the rule of law."

Outraged Unionist hardliners denounced the ruling and urged the government not to pay up.

Ulster Unionist leader and Northern Ireland first minister, David Trimble, said the ruling was astonishing and perverse.

But it is a huge victory for the families who claimed the way was now clear for relatives of other people shot dead by the security forces in disputed circumstances to take the same action.

Eight of the IRA men were shot dead in an undercover operation at Loughgall, Co Armagh in l987, when a civilian passer-by also died.

Two other IRA men were gunned down by police in separate shootings in Belfast and near Lurgan, Co Armagh, in l982 and l992.

The 12th victim, a member of Sinn Fein, was shot dead by loyalist paramilitary gunmen in Co Tyrone in l991.

Mairead Kelly, whose brother Patrick was among the IRA men killed by the SAS at Loughgall, said the government had been indicted in front of the rest of the world.

She said: "It is time the British got off the high moral ground and stopped lecturing people about human rights.

"The British have now been found guilty in front of the world and seen to be one of the biggest violators of all."

A spokesman for Tony Blair said the government may appeal against the judgment, but wanted time to study it.

He said there was no finding of unlawful killing, which meant the court had not found evidence of a "shoot to kill" policy.
