fields.headline: BBC Experience gets the chop
fields.trailText:
1pm: The BBC has been forced to write off £9m after admitting it has failed in its bid to create a visitor attraction to rival Madame Tussaud in London, writes Julia Day.
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The BBC has been forced to write off £9m after admitting it has failed in its bid to create a visitor attraction to rival Madame Tussaud in London.

It announced today that the BBC Experience, set up by the then director general John Birt, was getting the chop as part of a cost-cutting exercise.

Greg Dyke, the current BBC director-general decided the centre, which was built in the basement of BBC Broadcasting House, was not cost effective.

The BBC is instead considering the roll-out of educational centres in its local radio offices and will only consider a full-blown visitor attraction again as a commerical venture with a partner.

BBC Experience allows people to try their hand at directing EastEnders, presenting the weather forecast or reading the news.

But despite its popularity and increasing visitor numbers - more than 300,000 people have visited since it opened in 1997 - the BBC Experience has been deemed too expensive to keep open.

Even with a £7.95 entrance fee, the attraction has never broken even. There were 100,000 visitors last year but double that number were needed to break even.

Its closure will save the corporation £500,000 a year which will be ploughed in to programme-making.

Staff are to be told of the closure plan today. Around five full-time and 20 part-time workers stand to lose their jobs. Some may be redeployed as guides for the BBC Television Centre tours.

BBC Experience cost £5m to develop and £1m a year to run. But only half of the money was recouped in admission charges and corporate hospitality fees.

The decision to close was made after the BBC was faced with an expensive refurbishment to update the Experience with new technology.

A BBC spokesman said: "Like all visitor attractions you have to keep updating them, which is a big investment. It made us look at the Experience and think we didn't want to do it."

He said a pilot project at the BBC Open Centre in Blackburn may be rolled out as a means of letting the public experience what goes on at the BBC.

The project is a venture between BBC local radio, BBC education and the local authority. It allows people into the local station to use the facilities and take internet education classes.

"The other area we are interested in is if a suitable partner comes along for a visitor attraction. But it would have to be a commercial venture," says the BBC spokesman.

Special report
The BBC

webTitle: Richard and Judy in shock defection

fields.headline: Richard and Judy in shock defection
fields.trailText: 1pm: Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan, the king and queen of daytime television, have quit ITV after 13 years, writes Jessica Hodgson .
fields.body:
Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan, the king and queen of daytime television, have sensationally quit ITV after a run of almost 13 years.

They have shocked bosses at ITV by announcing they are to present a new evening show on Channel 4.

The married couple, who have come to epitomise daytime TV, have become part of the ITV furniture over the past decade with a cult following among housewives and students alike for their This Morning show.

It is understood they told virtually no one at ITV or Granada of their decision until recently.

In a statement, Madeley said: "Judy and I have enjoyed 13 wonderful series of This Morning and we will be incredibly sad to say goodbye to all our colleagues at Granada and ITV."

Finnigan denied there had been a "tug of war" for the couple.

She added: "We have just decided that we want to try something different and Channel 4 represents a brilliant opportunity to explore a new direction."

The show, with its mix of lifestyle hints, sofa chat and therapy, has become cult viewing and Madeley and Finnigan have been daily tabloid fodder for years.

And audiences seem to love them all the more for their numerous gaffes.

Last year Finnigan made the front page of all the national newspapers when she revealed her ample bosom to the world's media at the National Television Awards.

Last month Madeley was forced to issue an on-air apology after claiming that Roobarb and Custard creator Bob Godfrey "had to be on drugs".

Their popularity has made them a constant subject of attention - the highest point of their tabloid career was the revelation that Madeley had been arrested for shoplifting wine from a supermarket.

Their fanbase runs to millions and they have recently been paid the ultimate accolade with an impersonation by the BBC's Alistair McGowan.

And there have been repeated questions about Judy's health.

Channel 4's raid has caught everybody by surprise because Madeley and Finnigan, who have long been associated with the daytime heartlands of ITV.

But Channel 4 has tended to stray from such mass fodder.

The Channel 4 director of programmes, Tim Gardam, said the deal "will reinforce Channel 4's market leader status in afternoon and early evening television".

fields.headline: BBC2 presenters branded 'stiff and stuffy'
fields.trailText: 2pm: BBC2 presenters have been branded too stiff, stuffy, plain or smug by the corporation's own audience research, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
BBC2's specialist presenters have been branded too stiff, stuffy, plain or smug by the broadcaster's own audience research.

A focus group brought together to discuss the channel's academics and specialists seemed more concerned with how the stars looked and sounded than with what they had to say.

The research also revealed that for many viewers BBC2 is more likely to be identified with comedy and leisure than serious programmes.

A BBC spokeswoman dismissed the relevance of the research, pointing out that it was commissioned in April 1998, before the arrival of BBC2 controller Jane Root.

"Broadcasters do this sort of thing all the time, but we don't do that much focus group research," she said.

What they said about...

Lucinda Lampton, who fronts American history series Old New World
"Too posh, patronising and too wacky". Some said she was like a "mad auntie" who "left some men cold".

Simon Schama, presenter of A History of Britain
Looks like an unmade bed. Although viewers found him "sincere and erudite" they did not like his beard and hand gestures.

Stephen Fry, comedian and participant in documentary Laughter and Loathing
"Elitist and verbose" and gave older male viewers a "flavour of distaste". Although people found him witty and intelligent, they though he was nervous and unable to resist sending things up.

David Aaronovitch, journalist and presenter of On Air, a series about television
The findings were more hurtful than most. He was said to be "aggressive and slippery" and "a bit manic". However, his tough interviewing and political astuteness were also note and appreciated.

Terry Jones, former Monty Python and presenter of Gladiators: the Brutal Truth
Some viewers could not take him seriously in documentaries but felt affectionate towards his "zany" enthusiasm. Older male viewers were put off by his humour, which "took things too far", and his weak "r" worked against him.

Sister Wendy Beckett, art critic, nun and presenter of Grand Tour
Her mannerisms were found irritating and she was perceived as being unprofessional and "not authoritative". Some felt her novelty value had worn off but others saw her as an "endearing riveting amateur".

Andrew Graham Dixon, presenter of Colour: Art that Shook The World
Some viewers said he sounded too much like a politician or a provincial reporter. He was said to "alienate" viewers and was unlikely to bring new people in. But he worked well for serious art lovers.

Michael Wood, historian and presenter of Conquistadors: the Fall of the Aztecs
Described as "fluent, charming, authoritative" and "born for TV". Women in particular liked him but his only weakness was his William Hague-like voice, the research said.

Robert Hughes, Australian author and presenter of Beyond the Fatal Shore
Went down well with men but women found him unattractive and smug. Some were put off by his accent and his "too dry" tone.

MediaGuardian.co.uk special report
The BBC

webTitle: Government backs down over health and social care bill

fields.headline: Government backs down over health and social care bill
fields.trailText: The government has made key concessions over two of the most controversial parts of its health and social care bill in order to ease its passage through parliament before the general election.
fields.body:
The government has made key concessions over two of the most controversial parts of its health and social care bill in order to ease its passage through parliament before the general election.

Ministers last night caved in to pressure from local authorities and withdrew plans which would give them the power to force failing social services and community services providers into care trusts.

In the face of pressure from Conservative peers, they also scrapped a proposal to control the use of anonymised patient data by pharmaceutical companies.

But they refused to give way on plans to give the health secretary powers to sanction the use of confidential patient information without patient consent where it is in the "public interest," such as for use by cancer research bodies.

The concessions follow a government defeat in the Lords last month over its plans to abolish community health councils (CHCs) - although ministers said they will reverse this defeat in the Commons.

Health minister Lord Hunt told the House of Lords last night that the government had "thought again" about making care trusts compulsory in the light of peers' concerns.

"We have concluded that the best way to respond to those concerns is to withdraw the proposals for compulsory care trusts," he said.

Local authorities have been doggedly opposed to care trusts because of fears that they will effectively fold social services into an NHS-dominated management structure.

Although they have failed to prevent the creation of care trusts, the concession over plans to impose them will be welcomed by local government as a significant compromise by ministers.

The change means that local authorities and NHS bodies will not be dragooned into care trusts where local services have failed and cannot be improved within existing arrangements.

But Lord Hunt added that the government would not shirk from taking corrective action against failing services.

"Although we agree that compulsory care trusts may not be the right approach, the amendments that I propose leave intact the powers to require the use of the health act partnership in response to service failure."

The government had sought to control the use of anonymised patient data by drugs companies because of concerns that their use of the information to market their products to GPs would lead to unneccessarily high prescribing bills.

Lord Hunt made it clear that the government was reluctantly prepared to back down over the clause because it had received assurances from the pharmaceutical industry that it would use the data "responsibly".

He said: "We will not hesitate to take action, including legislation should that prove neccessary in the future to protect the NHS and its clinicians from unacceptable commercial pressures."

Lord Hunt rejected opposition arguments that proposals to give the health secretary power to sanction use of confidential patient information in the public interest would drive a "coach and horses" through the "established order of medical ethics".

But he outlined plans to set up a statutory advisory committee to strengthen the safeguards against potential abuse of the powers.

fields.headline: Ryanair sued over 'misleading' adverts
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: The Belgian airline, Sabena, is suing Ryanair over advertisements it claims are misleading, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
The Belgian airline, Sabena, is suing Ryanair over advertisements it claims are misleading.

Sabena has alleged an advert in a Belgian newspaper unfairly compared Ryanair's ticket prices with its own.

Dublin-based Ryanair set up its continental European service to Brussels earlier this year.

Its advert last week used the words: "Sick to death over Sabena's high fares? Low fares are coming to Belgium."

But Sabena said Ryanair had compared the price of its one-way economy tickets with Sabena's business class tickets.

Sabena does not offer a one-way economy price fare.

A Sabena spokesman said: "For us it is not the fact Ryanair engaged in actual comparisons... but the fact that they use slogans in their recent ads which are not real comparisons and which are at the same time offensive."

Ryanair denied wrongdoing. The case will be heard in a Brussels court next Wednesday.

fields.headline: La Bête
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: watching this complete version is like dying and going to smut heaven
fields.body:
Here is a film I first saw, like many other people, as a sixth-former in the 1970s in its cut version - passed in that form with a special X certificate by Sir Horace Cutler's Greater London Council - and it was to be viewed in that well-known temple of arthouse cinema, the now- defunct Moulin cinema in London's Soho.

La Bête (The Beast) has now been passed uncut by the BBFC and watching this complete version is like dying and going to smut heaven. It is surely Borowczyk's masterpiece: a delirious, preposterous, bizarre gothic romance about Mathurin (Pierre Benedetti), the boorish son of the sinister Marquis de l'Espérance, played by Guy Tréjan. Mathurin is about to be married to the beautiful American heiress Lucy Broadhurst, but he has a terrible secret, connected to dark rumours about a "beast" haunting the ancestral home.

Borowczyk begins the movie with some crunchingly candid close-ups of equine coupling: hard horse porn, as it were. And then, through various modulations and longueurs, builds up to a showstopping fantasy sequence based on Beauty and the Beast: a young woman enjoying congress with someone dressed up in a big hairy beast costume. It is notable for many things, not least its elegant solution to the problem of not being allowed to show the erect male member: make it an imaginary beast's erect male member!

This is the most purely absurd film you will ever see in your life, and yet there is something magnificent in its absurdity: it is weirdly serious, and yet has an enigmatic playfulness. As an haute porn classic it lacks the glacial poise of Ai No Corrida, and is closer to the naff Euro school of decadent chateaux and execrable dubbing such as The Story of O and Emmanuelle - the fourth sequel to which Borowczyk was tragically reduced to directing. And yet there is something more ambitious in The Beast. George Steiner has an essay about pornography in which he says that it is composed in the "deeper earnest of jest", and that has to be the spirit in which Borowczyk wrote, directed and edited The Beast. It's ridiculous; it's tacky; it's pretentious - but it's touched with something comically sublime.

It is notable for many things, not least its elegant solution to the problem of not being allowed to show the erect male member: make it an imaginary beast's erect male member! This is the most purely absurd film you will ever see in your life, and yet there is something magnificent in its absurdity: it is weirdly serious, and yet has an enigmatic playfulness. As an haute porn classic it lacks the glacial poise of Ai No Corrida, and is closer to the naff Euro school of decadent chateaux and execrable dubbing such as The Story of O and Emmanuelle - the fourth sequel to which Borowczyk was tragically reduced to directing. And yet there is something more ambitious in The Beast. George Steiner has an essay about pornography in which he says that it is composed in the "deeper earnest of jest", and that has to be the spirit in which Borowczyk wrote, directed and edited The Beast. It's ridiculous; it's tacky; it's pretentious - but it's touched with something comically sublime.

webTitle: ITV refuse to show Leeds semi live

fields.headline: ITV refuse to show Leeds semi live
fields.standfirst:
ONdigital spokesperson urges people to go to the pub instead
Follow the game with Guardian Unlimited Football
fields.trailText: ITV are refusing to show live coverage of the Champions League semi-final second-leg match between Leeds and Valencia next Tuesday - even though they have the power to do so.
fields.body:
ITV are refusing to show live coverage of the Champions League semi-final second-leg match between Leeds and Valencia next Tuesday - even though they have the power to do so.

The news has provoked outrage from Leeds fans and the Football Supporters Association, who have demanded the channel show the club's biggest game in 26 years.

The match will go out live on ONdigital - with ITV showing highlights later on in the evening. However, Guardian Unlimited has learned there is nothing in ITV's contract with Uefa that stops them showing the game.

Uefa spokesman Thomas Giordano said: "Under our contract with ITV, they are allowed to show the Valencia v Leeds match live, providing they also show Wednesday's game and get the agreement of ONdigital."

As two ITV companies - Granada and Carlton - own ONdigital, this shouldn't be a problem. However, both Granada and Carlton have refused to intervene. They say ONdigital is a completely separate entity and will be keeping the rights to show the game for themselves.

FSA chairman Malcolm Clarke told Guardian Unlimited he was "amazed" at the news.

"This is a huge European match which football fans across the country want to watch," he added. "Instead it's been shoved away on a minor channel.

"Our view is that everyone should be able to see the game - not just the few with access to ONdigital."

Leeds fan Andy Summer agreed. "I bet if it was Manchester United, ITV would be showing the game live," he said.

ONdigital have responded to the criticism by telling irate fans to subscribe - or watch the game in the pub.

Spokesman Andrew Marr said: "This isn't the sort of thing that supporters like to hear - but the reason why companies spend a lot of money on rights is to encourage people to subscribe to our services.

"We have paid a lot of money for these rights, so why should we give them away? If they want to see the game they can go to our website and find a pub showing the game."

Meanwhile, ITV spokesman Paul Tyrell insisted that the FSA - and those Leeds fans angry at not being able to see the game - should remember the positive aspects of the TV deal.

"I know a lot of fans will be disappointed not seeing the game," he admitted. "But without the additional coverage on the digital and satellite companies the clubs wouldn't be receiving such a cash windfall from the Champions League.

"And without that extra money, it's debatable whether Leeds could have afforded £18m for Rio Ferdinand and £12m for Robbie Keane," he added.

fields.headline: Week 36
fields.standfirst: Things to bet on. Punters. Blue Square. A heady mix, we're sure you'll agree
fields.trailText: Things to bet on. Punters. Blue Square. A heady mix, we're sure you'll agree.
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial #100 kitties):

Scott Murray = £143.04

The Prince of Punts (aka Paul MacInnes) = £45

The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £23.46

Sean Ingle = £13.32

Scott Murray: Arsenal v Leeds - draw £10 @ 9/4

Now let me ask our resident Blue Square expert one thing: what the hell has happened to the "number of bookings" bet you could make earlier in the season? I used to like that one, paid out regularly that did. Actually, I think I may have answered my own question.

I'd have backed a few bookings in this one. Arsenal and Leeds have a history of wanton violence, and by Christ it's fun to watch. Doubt this will be any different.

But sadly my hands are tied, so I've plumped for the draw instead. Not too much value in that on the face of things, but consider: can you see Arsenal beating in-form Leeds? Or Leeds repeating their Anfield smash and grab and winning another away game at Champions League rivals? No, thought not, and as I reckon that'd happen at least every other time, 9/4 will do for me.

The Prince of Punts (aka Paul MacInnes): Leicester v Spurs - no goalscorer £5 @ 8/1

The Prince once knew a man - Was it a man? It may have been a mandrill - who advised that betting on a 0-0 draw was a game devised by, and intended purely for, mugs. "Don't do that," he said, "it's stupid. Bet instead on there being no goalscorer in the same game. It's the same bet, but you also win if the game's decided by an own goal." Top hole, thought the Prince, and then forgot all about it.

The advice came to mind again this week, after the Prince had decided to bet on there being no goalscorer in the match between Leicester and Tottenham. "That's interesting," thought the Prince, "I've just done exactly what that man - or was it mandrill? - told me to do."

And quite right too. Because Leicester must bring an end to their impressive run of defeats sometime (alas it wasn't last week), but with their woefully thin attacking options perhaps it won't be with a 4-0 thumping. Meanwhile, Spurs are still rubbish under Glenda, but have a reasonably good defensive record of late. Chuck the return of Tim Flowers in the Leicester goal into the mix, and you have value. Or was it valium?

Tom Clarke of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Leicester v Spurs - Leicester to win £5 @ 11/8

Spurs are my team, and past experience has taught me to always bet against them so I get financial compensation if they lose. If they win it hits my wallet, but it's worth it.

As Spurs are away and have virtually no fit players, they won't win. Leicester are going through a bad patch, to put it mildly, but then that has to end sometime. And these runs usually end against us.

Sean Ingle: Arsenal v Leeds - Leeds to win at 11/4 and Vicenza v Reggina - Reggina to win @ 3/1 - £4 double

Yes, it's a double. But I'm so far behind in the standings I might as well go for broke.

Leeds have the second best away record in the Premiership, Arsenal have the second best home record. The match could go either way, but I think Leeds - who, don't forget, have won six on the spin in the league - are overpriced at 11/4.

Ditto Reggina. In recent weeks Massimo Taibi's team have been on something on a roll, thrashing Verona 3-0 and whipping Napoli 3-1. So at 3/1 they represent great value to beat fellow relegation-scrappers Vicenza, who have only won one in their last five.

webTitle: Your last news fix of the week

fields.headline: Your last news fix of the week
fields.trailText: Welcome to SocietyGuardian's daily email briefing. We've a busy day of news, comment and analysis; read on for a special offer to all subscribers.
fields.body:
Welcome to SocietyGuardian's daily email briefing. We've a busy day of news, comment and analysis; read on for a special offer to all subscribers.

Today is the first anniversary of Ken Livingstone's election as London mayor.

To mark the occasion, we ask experts to assess his track record. For the full package of news and features, log on to our new Big issue

Also making news today:

NHS staff: Influx of foreign nurses helps NHS

A huge influx of foreign nurses is about to rescue the NHS from staff shortages that were threatening to undermine the government's plans to expand hospitals.

Health: Checks on doctors 'insufficient'

Patient safety may be at risk because hospitals have inadequate systems for rooting out incompetent doctors, according to the health service inspectorate.

Poverty: Grant boost for anti-poverty drive

Voluntary organisations are to get a £130m package for community anti-poverty initiatives.

Prisons: 'Brave' choice of prisons inspector praised

A leading human rights expert, Anne Owers, has been named by home secretary Jack Straw as the surprise successor to Sir David Ramsbotham as chief inspector of prisons.

Also on the site:

Regeneration: If we build it, they will come

Norman Foster's new Wembley should be built not only as a monument to the nation's favourite sport, but to regenerate one of the most deprived areas in the country, argues Sir Stuart Lipton, chairman of the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment.

Practice: Addiction prevention through audience participation

Actors usually don't like having their performance interrupted by the audience. But for a theatre company made up of recovering alcoholics and drug addicts, that's the whole point. Martin McNamara reports on an innovative project.

Social care: Protecting children from the web of deceit

The internet opens up huge opportunities for children. But it also provides paedophiles with new routes to abuse. Time to educate the educators in the use of the web so children can be protected, says John Carr.

Don't forget to catch up with the trade press, try out the SocietyGuardian quiz and keep logging on for regular news updates at:

Addresses must be received by Friday, May 18.

fields.headline: BoS and Halifax agree merger
fields.standfirst: Halifax and Bank of Scotland have merged to create HBOS, challenging the power base of the existing "big four" high street banks.  Lisa Bachelor reports
fields.trailText: Halifax and Bank of Scotland have merged to create HBOS, challenging the power base of the existing "big four" high street banks. Lisa Bachelor reports.
fields.body:
Halifax and Bank of Scotland announced this morning that they have agreed terms over their £28bn merger.

With a name that sounds more like an aftershave than a bank, the new holding will be known as HBOS with the headquarters based in Edinburgh, where the Bank of Scotland head office is located. The merger will mean around 2,000 job losses from both banks over the next three years as part of a cost-saving strategy.

HBOS will be set up to compete with the current "big four" high-street banks: Barclays, HSBC, Lloyds TSB and Royal Bank of Scotland/NatWest. The new bank will offer a diverse range of products: much of Bank of Scotland's expertise lies in business; while Halifax is the UK's largest mortgage lender.

Under the terms of the merger, Halifax shareholders and Bank of Scotland proprietors will receive one share in HBOS for each Halifax share or Bank of Scotland stock unit they now hold. Due to the larger number of Halifax shares, Halifax shareholders will own about 63% of HBOS, while bank of Scotland shareholders will own about 37%.

The HBOS board of directors will be drawn equally from the boards of Halifax and Bank of Scotland, but, in an unexpected move, the top job will be taken by a Halifax employee. James Crosby, group chief executive of Halifax, will become chief executive of the new bank. Peter Burt, group chief executive of the Bank of Scotland, who was widely expected to take the role, will become deputy chairman of HBOS. With only 18 months to go until his retirement, Mr Burt says that by taking the position he would have caused more upheaval in the long term.

Commenting on the merger, Stuart Cliffe, chief execurive of the National Association of Bank and Insurance Customers said: "Generally speaking mergers are not a good thing as historically they result in a loss of jobs and local branches. However, this morning's announcement sees two of the second division banks merging and moving to the top slot. This will mean a new player to rival the major high-street banks which should be a good thing for customers."

fields.headline: Blair promises tighter immigration controls
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Asylum seekers who try to abuse the system have to be processed and removed more quickly, Tony Blair said today.
fields.body:
Asylum seekers who try to abuse the system have to be processed and removed more quickly, Tony Blair said today.

The prime minister used an article in the Times to counter Tory accusations that the government is soft on the issue, further fuelling speculation that he is within days of calling a June 7 general election.

Mr Blair signalled that, if re-elected, Labour would press for a tighter regime for processing people seeking to settle in Britain but insisted that he remained committed to helping those genuinely fleeing persecution.

He also noted that some economic immigration in skills shortage areas was necessary. He argued that other economic migrants who seek to abuse the system have to be processed and removed more quickly.

Mr Blair suggested that the 1951 UN Convention on Refugees needed to be modernised.

"The UK is taking the lead in arguing for reform, not of the Convention's values, but of how it operates," he wrote. "This includes improving the ways in which genuine refugees can be helped, for example by applications from abroad and an EU-wide resettlement programme.

"It means offering more help to the regions from which many of these refugees come. But it also means ensuring that those who are not entitled to benefit from the provisions of the 1951 Convention are dealt with swiftly, through quick decisions and an effective system for returns.

"This must be a priority should we win the next election."

The focus on asylum appeared to be an attempt to regain ground on the issue, which polling consistently suggests is one of Labour's weakest areas.

The prime minister's article appeared as Downing Street announced that he had pulled out of a trip to Germany planned for Monday. Mr Blair had been due to attend a conference of European socialist leaders in Berlin, but the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will take his place.

Mr Blair had already effectively cleared the decks for an election date announcement - possibly next Wednesday - by declaring that Britain was on the "home straight" in the battle against foot and mouth.

webTitle: Bland dilemma over BT licence fee bid

fields.headline: Bland dilemma over BT licence fee bid
fields.trailText:
10am: Sir Christopher Bland is set for his first conflict of interests with the BBC after BT emerged as a bidder for licence fee collection. By Dan Milmo.

02.05.2001: BBC rethinks BT links
Special report: the BBC
Special report: BT in crisis
fields.body:
Sir Christopher Bland, the newly installed chairman of British Telecom, is set for his first clash of interests with the BBC after the telecoms group emerged as a potential bidder for the licence fee collection contract.

Sir Christopher sparked controversy earlier this week when he assumed control of BT without resigning from his post as chairman of the publicly funded broadcaster.

Critics of the move claimed that having the same person in charge of two of the UK's most powerful communications companies was bound to create a conflict of interest.

The news that the BBC is to approach private sector companies with a £500m contract to gather the licence fee will add fuel to the debate, as BT is understood to have sounded out the corporation about the contract.

A BBC spokeswoman confirmed the corporation had been contacted about the contract by several interested parties, but refused to confirm if BT was one of the potential bidders.

"People have registered their interests, and a large number of different organisations have contacted us. It would be unfair to single out any of the parties involved," she said.

A decision on the contract is expected to be reached in September.

The BBC is revamping the way it collects the licence fee in a bid to cut costs and boost revenues from a levy that raises £2.3bn a year.

The corporation has used the Post Office - now known as Consignia - as the cornerstone of the collection process for the past 75 years. But it has grown frustrated with the £120m lost to licence fee evasion each year.

The BBC decided to approach the private sector after the contract ended with Consignia and its partner, advertising giant WP.

Greg Dyke, the director general of the BBC, hopes a private firm will crack down on evasion and carry out the collection at a lower cost, saving £60m a year.

This will go some way to meeting Mr Dyke's target of finding an extra £200m per year until 2006 as part of the government's funding shake-up.

Other likely bidders include the utility group Centrica and more than a dozen advertising companies.

BT refused to comment on the news.

webTitle: Finding a way to rebuke the US

fields.headline: Finding a way to rebuke the US
fields.standfirst:
The UN move to not reelect America to its human rights body indicates just how much the world has been outraged by George Bush's early decisions, explains Mark Tran
George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The UN move to not reelect America to its human rights body indicates just how much the world has been outraged by George Bush's early decisions, explains Mark Tran.
fields.body:
The US has just received an unmistakable sign that its high-handedness carries a political price.

For the first time, the US will be absent from the UN human rights commission that it helped to create in 1947, after failing to win enough votes for membership.

The humiliation was a genuine stunner. Singapore's ambassador to the UN, Kishore Mahbubani, said that he 2couldn't believe it" when he heard the news.

The unexpected move, which came in a secret vote, apparently won backing from some friends of the US. It certainly failed to persuade some European countries to withdraw from the race for the three seats reserved for Western countries.

The Bush White House may try to play down the significance of the event. In the grand scheme of things, the commission's work goes by largely unheralded. The commission lacks real power and its main function is to serve as a bully pulpit for nations to focus attention to egregious abuses around the world.

Now the US will be deprived of the opportunity to use a forum to criticise the likes of Cuba and China for human rights violations.

It must also rankle a nation that traditionally has prided itself on putting human rights on the foreign policy agenda. Every year, the US state department assembles a comprehensive report on human rights in countries around the world; it is a treasure trove of information.

Critics may dismiss the American preoccupation with human rights as merely gesture politics. Advocates of realpolitik, such as Henry Kissinger, show little patience for the US concern with human rights, but even he acknowledges that this preoccupation lies deep within the American political tradition, going back to the idealism, albeit flawed, of President Woodrow Wilson in the 1920s.

So it does matter that the US has been banished from an arena that says a lot about American political ideals.

The rebuff has led to an absurd situation where countries like Sudan and Pakistan, hardly paragons of virtue when it comes to human rights, are members, when the US is not. Amnesty International has expressed alarm at America's exclusion, knowing that the body has lost a crucial voice.

But the situation is of America's own making. President George Bush has show scant regard for the interests of others. He has turned his back on the Kyoto accord on global warming, writing off in one fell swoop a treaty that took years to assemble.

Now he is pressing ahead with a costly and dodgy missile defence system that threatens to trigger a new arms race and that will render the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty obsolete.

The US also treats the UN with scant regard. The administration has yet to formally nominate its choice for UN ambassador, John Negroponte, and the House of Representatives has been tardy in authorising authorise the payment of $582m in US arrears to the UN.

It should come as little surprise then, that the world can occasionally cock a snook at America.

webTitle: What to do while waiting for an election

fields.headline: What to do while waiting for an election
fields.standfirst: Constituency candidates across the country were geared up for war more than four weeks ago - but Mr Blair postponed the election. David Cameron, the Conservative candidate for Witney in Oxfordshire, explains how he passed the time
fields.trailText: Constituency candidates across the country were geared up for war more than four weeks ago - but Mr Blair postponed the election. David Cameron, the Conservative candidate for Witney in Oxfordshire, explains how he passed the time.
fields.body:
"That's the pub where the police arrested Oswald Mosley in 1940." The retired foreign office mandarin was leaning over his garden fence and pointing at The Shaven Crown in Shipton-under-Wychwood. "Apparently Shaun Woodward drinks there now." I made some cheap crack about "the police not bothering to arrest traitors these days" and went on my way.

This snippet was just one of the useful pieces of information I have gleaned in the past week. Others include the fact that West Oxfordshire has its own vineyard and the constituency is stuffed full of cats' homes, including the superbly named Paws with Inn.

What on earth has this Tory candidate been doing? Far from wandering the byways of Oxfordshire grinning inanely at potential voters, I have been engaged in what Jack Straw would probably call "purposeful activity."

The "phoney election" period caused by Blair's entirely correct (but belated) decision to postpone the general election left a gaping hole in many candidates' diaries.

There is only so much time that can be spent buffing the campaign bus and polishing the opening press release, so I made the rash decision to jump on a bicycle and undertake a sponsored bicycle ride to all 85 parishes in the Witney constituency.

5 days, 220 miles, 85 rain-soaked villages, 2 aching limbs and 1 muddy bike later I have finished and £4,000 will be finding its way to a politically balanced list of good causes including one of the farmers' benevolent funds, an animal charity, a local school and the Macmillan Cancer Nurses.

My local Conservative agent is still chuckling. He applauded my determination, but worries about my naivety: not knowing that "bike" is slang for prostitute, my press release announcing this caper opened with the quote: "I haven't been on a bike for years." Looking back, I can see his point.

But there is a serious side to this. What did I learn apart from the fact that Jack Straw actually lives in Minster Lovell, hundreds of miles from his Burnley constituency, and that the Cotswolds are full of painfully steep hills?

In short, this: Tony Blair has taken a big risk in announcing that foot and mouth is "over" and the countryside is "open". My experience was very different.

Oxfordshire has only suffered two cases of foot and mouth, but farmers, rural business and the local councils have taken every precaution to stop the disease spreading.

As long as there are fresh cases breaking out anywhere in the UK, they will rightly remain nervous. On my ride I saw just a handful of footpaths re-opened; most were firmly closed.

Parts of some villages are actually behind a foot and mouth no-go sign. Entire roads in two villages I visited were closed to all traffic and pedestrians.

The anger also remains. Every publican I spoke to was still spitting blood about the mishandling of the crisis and said their takings were between 20 and 30% down on last year.

Of course we all want foot and mouth to be over, footpaths to be open and the countryside to return to normal. But farmers who are still laying disinfected straw at their gates may be forgiven for being cautious.

Was the timing of Blair's press conference determined by epidemiology or the need to get on with the election? You don't have to be a hard-bitten Tory cynic to think spin doctors rather than vets have been calling the shots this week in Downing Street.

· David Cameron is the Conservative candidate for Witney in Oxfordshire

webTitle: BBC falls victim to spoof site

fields.headline: BBC falls victim to spoof site
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The BBC is investigating after a fake version of its news site appeared on the net, reports Amy Vickers.

Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The BBC is investigating a possible breach of copyright after a fake version of its news website appeared on the internet.

The spoof site, which appeared on Wednesday, carried a false story announcing the suicide of the Hear'Say member, Suzanne Shaw.

It said she had been found dead in her North London home following recent revelations she had appeared in a home-made porn video.

In fact, Ms Shaw was on holiday.

"We're taking this matter very seriously as it was a complete breach of copyright," said a spokesman for the BBC. "We have to protect our copyright and integrity."

The spokesman refuted press reports that the culprits had hacked into the BBC's site.

fields.headline: 'Bomber' storms Granada TV Centre
fields.trailText: 12pm: Police have been called to Granada's London Television Centre after a man stormed into the building claiming he had a bomb.
fields.body:
Police have been called to Granada's London Television Centre after a "highly aggressive" man stormed into reception claiming to be carrying a bomb.

Police surrounded the South Bank complex and began evacuating staff shortly after 10.30am, according to sources in the building.

Suzie Norton, a GMTV producer, said the man told security guards at the building he was carrying a bomb and a gun.

"Someone who saw him said he had a big bag with him, so if he has got one it must be in there," Ms Norton said.

Staff were first moved into the bar at the back of the second floor away from any potential danger, she added.

Police then herded them into a paved area outside the 22-storey building.

"The police have told us we could be here for a long time. There is an element of tension but people are staying reasonably relaxed," Ms Norton added.

The Granada-owned TV centre is the home of GMTV, London Weekend Television and London News Network.

Scotland Yard declined to discuss the incident.

webTitle: Top Tory at centre of sanctions busting claims

fields.headline: Top Tory at centre of sanctions busting claims
fields.standfirst:
Tory at centre of sanctions claims

Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: The Tory trade and industry spokesman, Alan Duncan, was under pressure last night to explain his alleged involvement in an elaborate operation to bust UN oil sanctions against apartheid South Africa. The claims come from two fellow oil traders who claim to have personal knowledge of his career before he entered parliament.
fields.body:
The Tory trade and industry spokesman, Alan Duncan, was under pressure last night to explain his alleged involvement in an elaborate operation to bust UN oil sanctions against apartheid South Africa. The claims come from two fellow oil traders who claim to have personal knowledge of his career before he entered parliament.

Documents seen by the Guardian lend weight to the traders' claims that Mr Duncan was involved in managing covert shipments from Brunei to Durban in the breach of international embargos. He claims they were wrongly copied to him.

Mr Duncan refused to comment on the detailed charges this week. But last night he issued a statement saying: "These are malicious and false allegations against me, long since disproved. This is a pathetic attempt to smear, which is just what anyone would expect on the eve of an election."

Interest in Mr Duncan's business career resurfaced recently in the wake of President Bill Clinton's controversial decision to pardon his for mer boss, the fugitive broker Marc Rich. Mr Duncan worked for Mr Rich's commodity empire between 1982 and 1988.

Last night political opponents urged William Hague to investigate the role played in the Rich group by his trade and industry spokesman.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrats' defence and foreign affairs spokesman, said: "If there are prima facie allegations of this kind which suggest a breach of a UN embargo one would expect a member of any party to put the record straight as to whether the accusations are accurate.

"There was a great deal of ambiguity about the Thatcher government's policy towards apartheid and economic sanctions. It would clearly be right to clear that ambiguity up.

"The obligation to be candid would obviously be greater in the case of someone with a responsibility for trade and industry."

Labour MP Fraser Kemp, a member of Labour's election team, said: "There is a public duty on William Hague to investigate the serious allegations made against a member of his trade and industry team, and a public responsibility on Alan Duncan to answer all the points raised. "These are not issues that can be swept under the carpet when the Tories will be asking people to vote for them at the election in the hope of forming a government."

The Labour peer Lord Hughes of Woodside, who as Labour MP Bob Hughes was chairman of the Anti-Apartheid Movement, said: "It seems to me pretty clear that if he has nothing to hide and his record is quite clean, he should be perfectly happy to answer straight forward questions.

"So near to a general election people need to know exactly where the leader of the party stands and it should be looked at very closely by Mr Hague."

Mr Rich was the main supplier of oil to South Africa between 1979 and 1993 from a number of countries; a Brunei contract, from 1982 to 1986 involved his company shipping more than 50 tankers of crude to the Shell refinery in Durban, worth hundreds of millions of dollars. This was in defiance of the UN embargo and the explicit wishes of all major oil exporting countries, including Brunei, which did not want the oil ending up in South Africa.

The Tory trade and industry spokesman, who is worth sev eral million pounds, hosted Mr Hague's successful campaign in 1997 and John Major's successful tilt at the Tory leadership in the Westminster home Mr Duncan bought after returning from Singapore. At that time, he described himself to the head of a Gulf oil company as "the person primarily responsible for our crude oil business in the Middle East and Far East".

He earned an estimated £100,000 a year by delivering to South Africa about 15% of its oil imports, which were supposed to be destined for other countries.

A colleague who also worked for Mr Rich in Singapore told the Guardian this week: "That [the Brunei contract] was one of the crude oil deals he was definitely involved in. Duncan was the only Rich crude oil trader in Singapore, and that was where Middle East and Far East oil was traded from."

As the pre-eminent supplier to South Africa throughout the 1980s, Mr Rich helped to keep the apartheid economy afloat for more than 10 years, in defiance of the UN voluntary oil embargo and the stricter sanctions imposed by the major oil exporting states.

Mr Rich, pardoned in January by Mr Clinton during the president's final days in the White House, fled Manhattan's Fifth Avenue for Zug in Switzerland in 1983 to escape charges ranging from tax evasion and racketeering to trading with the enemy in the form of Iran during the hostage crisis. His companies pleaded guilty to the charges in 1984 and paid $200m in fines.

Mr Duncan joined Mr Rich's London office in Wigmore Street in 1982 and, despite Mr Rich's growing notoriety, stayed with him for six years. In 1984 he was assigned to the Singapore office, which was at the hub of the firm's activities in the Middle East and Far East until 1986. South African opposition MPs in May 1984 named Mr Rich as one of apartheid's main oil suppliers.

Mr Duncan is named as a recipient of urgent telexes from a Japanese corporation caught up in the trade. It asked for copies of certificates show ing where the oil ended up. Forged documents were routinely issued by the Rich organisation to disguise South Africa as the destination, substituting countries such as France and Italy. Mr Duncan claims that the telexes were wrongly copied to him and he knew nothing about the shipments.

Nelson Mandela, who is currently enjoying rapturous receptions across Britain, supported sanctions and in a message smuggled out of prison and published in London during 1977 declared: "Every effort to isolate South Africa adds strength to our struggle."

Mike Terry, secretary of the Anti-Apartheid Movement for 20 years to 1995, said: "If these allegations are true they make a mockery of William Hague's anti-racist stance. There is a public duty on him as leader of the Tory party to find out what, if any, role people in his team played in breaking sanctions against South Africa and sustaining apartheid."

fields.headline: What we asked him
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: The Guardian tried on a number of occasions to put allegations to Alan Duncan. We wished to verify publicly the information we had been given and to seek Mr Duncan's comments. We were aware that he might have information others did not possess or had not disclosed. It was our intention to include Mr Duncan's responses as part of our coverage.
fields.body:
The Guardian tried on a number of occasions to put allegations to Alan Duncan. We wished to verify publicly the information we had been given and to seek Mr Duncan's comments. We were aware that he might have information others did not possess or had not disclosed. It was our intention to include Mr Duncan's responses as part of our coverage. Mr Duncan declined to make any detailed comment.

On Tuesday we faxed Mr Duncan a number of questions, the gist of which are given here. Again Mr Duncan declined to make any comment. The questions concentrate solely on Marc Rich's involvement in the oil trade and do not involve any matters for which Marc Rich was indicted.

The allegations to which we invited response included

1 That you remained working for Marc Rich for five years after he was indicted by a grand jury in 1983 of wire fraud, racketeering, trading with the enemy and $48m in income tax evasion. You carried on working for him even when he fled the USA becoming one of the six most wanted international fugitives.

2 That you continued to work for Marc Rich for four years after his companies pleaded guilty in 1984 of engaging in a criminal scheme to conceal in excess of $100m in taxable income; and paid $200m in back taxes, interest, fines and foregone tax deductions.

3 That you knew from at least 1984, when the story received massive international publicity, that Marc Rich & Co were supplying large quantities of oil to apartheid South Africa in contravention of the voluntary UN oil embargo and the embargos imposed by Opec and Oapec states; and that you continued to work for him in that knowledge.

4 That you were involved in a special business deal for the supply of Brunei oil to South Africa, via a Japanese corporation, while you were based at the Singapore office of the company between 1984 and 1986.

We also asked about how Mr Duncan had subsequently represented his role.

fields.headline: 'The Mercury prize? Oh God, that would be great. I deserve something'
fields.standfirst: Singing sensation Alison Goldfrapp tells Dave Simpson why her time has come
fields.trailText: Singing sensation Alison Goldfrapp tells Dave Simpson why her time has come
fields.body:
Doing battle with Alison Goldfrapp is not something to be undertaken lightly. Take her recent run-in with a photographer. Goldfrapp, as the band she founded with Will Gregory are called, were on a stage "about four inches high" and a photographer was irritating the vocalist and obstructing the crowd's view. Alison, who regards photographers as an occupational hazard in the same way that hardened criminals regard judges, totally lost it. "I told him to piss off, which was probably very comical. But then something just took over and I tried to lamp the bastard!"

Goldfrapp, incidentally, is all of 5ft 2in tall. She is tough and complex but also insecure - and very funny. When we're introduced, in a French restaurant as dark and decadent as her music, she blanks me completely, barking down her mobile about some other offending lensman: "He's made me look like a fucking puffy Humpty Dumpty!" When we finally sit down, she orders two bottles of wine, one each, and advises against eating.

Mercifully, she grants me permission to visit the toilet, and winces when I mention her recent photograph in Vogue. "A classic scenario," she sighs. "You'd think you could rely on Vogue to make you look drop-dead gorgeous. I looked like a fucking drag queen!" Thus begins a memorable evening with the suddenly very sought-after elfin hurricane, who looks rather more like a mischievous European actress than a drag queen.

Last September, Goldfrapp released their debut album, Felt Mountain, to general praise. Critics adored its blend of Weimar Republic cabaret, French pop, lush orchestration and cinematic scope. In a landscape of pop fodder, here was something unusual and different. Now the public is catching on.

Slowly but surely, following the pattern set by Moby, their labelmate on Mute, the album has sold 25,000 - a real feat without a hit single (although Utopia, re-released next month, should change that). Marketing has been carried out via press, word of mouth and the odd free track on cover-mounted CDs. In the meantime, the story across Europe has been one of sold-out tours, upgraded venues and general pandemonium - deservedly. Felt Mountain is the early favourite to take this year's Mercury music prize.

"I'm delighted with the attention, but I really don't think we're as commercial as Moby," she frets. "It's been very natural, though, and I like that. I didn't think people would get it in England because we're a bit arty. The Mercury? Oh God, that would be great. I mean, I'm no spring chicken, so recently I've started to think, 'Yeah, I deserve something.' I've been slogging at this for quite a long time. I've had a very weird . . . apprenticeship!" She laughs, and the untouched mineral water topples from the table.

Now in her early 30s, Goldfrapp grew up in Alton, Hampshire, one of those small towns where "you want to get out. There isn't anything else to do, so you take lots of drugs and get beaten up on a Saturday night." She was the "posh girl who lived in the nice street". Her father worked for the Arts Council and the Spastics Society, and her mother was a nurse. "All the mental people would come and see my mum," she recalls, "and usually end up staying."

The family were considered bohemian and eccentric. Mr Goldfrapp (the name is German: "Frapp means hit," she enjoys telling me) would inflict classical music and opera upon his daughter, conducting from the dinner table. At the time, she says, she preferred David Cassidy. Alison went to convent school and still gets misty-eyed about the endless corridors, austere, black-clad nuns, and stone floors flecked with what looked like glitter. "I thought I was in a film," she says.

She says that after being deemed "academically retarded" she was forced to leave the convent and was devastated to have to attend the local comp, where she was vilified as the "snobby little girl from the convent". Lots of "horrible things" happened there, which she doesn't want to expand on. In short, she went seriously off the rails. There were incidents involving borstal boys, glue-sniffing and car theft. Soon afterwards, she departed for London's squats, and her life continued to spiral out of control.

If convent school taught her anything, it was that everyone, no matter how stupid they seemed, was good at something. But what? Goldfrapp was interested in music, art, and drama, but combining any of those with temping jobs in telesales was difficult. She spent four years "living in bedsits and answering ads in Melody Maker". Because she was young and cute and could sing a bit, friends suggested she could be the next Kylie Minogue. Instead, she went to study art at Middlesex College. "That was crucial," she says. "They taught me that it doesn't matter whether you have any money - 'the idea' is everything. Also, that I could do music, and that it didn't have to be pop."

Fired up with a new enthusiasm, she accepted a job singing in Antwerp, Belgium, for a contemporary dance company run by Andy Goldberg, who introduced her to the music of 1950s multi-octave singer Yma Sumac. Goldfrapp was seduced by the "decadence" of all things European. Eventually, though, she tired of the "anal discipline" involved and sought musical freedom. At the same time, her father died and she split up with a long-term boyfriend.

Weirdly enough, everything appears to have taken off for Goldfrapp when she milked a cow, while yodelling ("I've always liked that Swiss kitsch thing"). She was exploring performance art at a party, and among the guests were Orbital, who recruited her to sing - not yodel - on their 1994 Snivilisation album. Still grateful, she subsequently worked with Tricky, singing on 1995's seminal Maxinquaye album and touring with him for two years. If her previous experiences were character toughening, this one gave her steel. It was, she insists, "brilliant", but left her mentally shattered.

"It took two years for me to get my head back to what I wanted," she sighs. "Things were complex because I was good friends with Martina [Tricky's then partner-vocalist], who I effectively replaced. It was highly acrimonious between those two and I was in the middle. I mean, I like Tricky. As much as he's a fucking nightmare. Offensive? He's totally offensive! But I can give it back." Undaunted, she watched Tricky intensely, learning the importance of economy and impulse. "His best stuff was done in his living room," she says. "I'd be standing in the hallway with one working headphone while he went out for chips. When he came back, the track was done."

The importance of working instinc tively was underlined when she provided studio backing vocals for Bryan Ferry, "a perfect gentleman", but who was prone to indecision and "endless tweaking" until eventually nothing was released. However, by now Goldfrapp knew roughly what she wanted. Enter Will Gregory, a composer of film scores best known for ID - the football hooligan film. Gregory came across a tape of Goldfrapp singing Human, which became one of the standout tracks on Felt Mountain.

Mailing tapes of their favourite music (Her: Françoise Hardy. Him: Ennio Morricone) to each other, the pair clicked. Oddly, Goldfrapp insists they both think visually: "What is the scenario behind this song? What are the emotions?" She like beats, but bossa nova rather than bpm. "I've been in things where all these guys talked about was fucking bpm!" she shrieks. "You know, instead of smoking their eighth spliff in their anorak, I want to hear a tune! Will's exactly the same."

Turned down by major labels, the pair secured a contract with Mute in August 1999. Finally a label had recognised Goldfrapp's unique vision and her untrained, operatic-sounding voice. At this point, one of the barmier episodes took place. Fuelled by her post-Ferry hatred of studios, she and Will recorded for six months, from September 1999, in a cottage on a Wiltshire hillside, where Alison often found herself alone.

"It was mad and I wouldn't do it again," she says. "My social and private life collapsed. Because it was a bungalow, it felt really vulnerable. Big windows. Mice in the roof. I like extremes but, at the end of that six months, I really did feel I was going bonkers. I remember spending three days in a raincoat, scrubbing the side of the bungalow because there were all these spiders hatching. I became obsessive about the wildlife I thought was taking over the bungalow. It was disgusting, moths everywhere. You could hear the mice scuttling across the roof."

Mad, but it worked. Felt Mountain has an eerie widescreen, cinematic feel to it. This is partly because it was recorded outside, under the stars, and partly because the feeling of "total loneliness where something horrible is happening" reignited fears from her childhood. In fact, her childhood appears all over the album: twitching curtains, slaughter in the countryside, hints of disturbance. "It's sort of beautifully macabre," she muses. "I love all that David Lynch, Midwich Cuckoos thing. But it isn't cinema. It's real."

Goldfrapp the band occupy unique territory between mischief and danger, blurring fantasy and reality, though their "coffee-table" appeal is undeniable. Alison's lyrics are mostly abstract obsessional tales, using cut-up surrealist techniques. With Will's blessing, she designs their artwork - spooky little birds and limbs in the grass. Felt Mountain's sleeve depicts her head doubled, like a freak show, but also a vagina ("a computer accident, honestly, but I kept it"). She confesses to an "unhealthy" inter est in voyeurism but insists that the notorious publicity photo of her playing piano in her undergarments (taken, importantly, by her friend Anna) was partly triggered by poverty. "After six months in the bungalow, I didn't have any nice clothes. My trousers looked like shit. So I took them off!"

She is aware of her sexuality but is amused and uneasy about reviewers dubbing her a "dominatrix". She insists that, at heart, she is shy and vulnerable, and comes over as a warm, funny, immensely likeable young woman, who can't watch herself on television, worries about seeming a "gibbering twit" in interviews and has endless traumas about her appearance.

"When I was young," she says, "I used to change my appearance three times every day, which drove my mother mad. When I did that Vogue thing, I think I felt that's how I should look. I thought I'd look really sophisticated in a black dress, lots of make-up and fishnet tights. And then I just realised, 'Fucking hell, no!' But I am trying to have fun with it, with all of it."

Throughout her life, it seems, Goldfrapp has been striving to escape something, to create a parallel fantasy world. And if she does become a big star? "I don't crave it," she insists, before adding words which will alarm photographers everywhere: "But I'm sure it would be jolly good fun!"

Goldfrapp play London Union Chapel on May 17 and 18 (020-7734 8932) and tour in May and June. Utopia is released by Mute on June 4.

fields.headline: TV watchdogs curb on-air promotions
fields.trailText: 12pm: The ITC is planning to limit the amount of airtime given over to on-air promotions on ITV, C4 and C5, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Independent Television Commission is planning to limit the amount of airtime given over to on-air promotions on ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5.

The watchdog plans to limit plugs for the broadcasters' own programmes and services to 90 seconds per hour in peaktime.

The ITC said it wanted to "address viewer concerns about promotional and advertising clutter".

The commercial terrestrial broadcasters are likely to resist any moves to limit on-air promotion of their own shows and services.

As multi-channel competition for audiences increases, on-air trailers are becoming an ever more important weapon in the battle to hold onto viewers.

As part of the review the regulator is asking broadcasters for their views on this issue and plans to allow ITV more freedom to cross-promote its digital channels and services.

This could lead to ITV promoting Carlton/Granada-owned pay-TV platform ONdigital, which is to be renamed ITV Digital, and ITV.co.uk - set to be rebranded ITV.com - on its main terrestrial channel.

ITV2 and the soon-to-launch ITV Sport Channel would also benefit.

"Such promotions should be factual and non-discriminatory. Generic promotions for digital television would be encouraged," the ITC said.

The ITC is also proposing to tighten guidelines on undue prominence for products within programmes.

In addition, it is planning to review whether digital broadcasters with interactive services should supply a feed clear of the interactive icon to channels that cannot offer interactivity.

An ITV spokesman said promotions and cross-promotions were an "increasingly important way of informing viewers about programmes and services available in the multi-channel world".

"However, broadcasters need to strike the right balance between informing viewers and protecting the quality of the viewing experience," he added.

Advertisers warned that a relaxation of rules governing on-air trailers could "reduce the impact of paid-for spot advertising".

"Research suggests that increasing levels of cross-promotion may often be perceived by viewers as increasing levels of spot advertising," the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers said.

Useful site
www.itc.org.uk

webTitle: Shadow minister accused of supplying apartheid regime

fields.headline: Shadow minister accused of supplying apartheid regime
fields.standfirst:
Oil executives and documents suggest Hague confidant coordinated South Africa special deal

Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Alan Duncan has been uncharacteristically reluctant to discuss his six years as an oil trader in the worldwide empire created by the commodity broker Marc Rich which, quite literally, fuelled South Africa's apartheid regime.
fields.body:
Alan Duncan has been uncharacteristically reluctant to discuss his six years as an oil trader in the worldwide empire created by the commodity broker Marc Rich which, quite literally, fuelled South Africa's apartheid regime.

Mr Duncan says he was employed in a very junior role within the company created and dominated by America's number one white-collar fugitive, and in the 1980s had no involvement in the secretive operation that helped sustain white rule.

Documents obtained by the Guardian and the allegations of two fellow oil traders, one of whom was employed by Marc Rich & Co while the other worked for the firm on a casual basis, raise fresh questions about the part played by a current member of the Conservative trade and industry team.

Mr Rich, controversially pardoned in January by Bill Clinton during the president's final days in the White House, fled Manhattan's Fifth Avenue for Zug in Switzerland in 1983 to escape a series of criminal charges ranging from tax evasion and racketeering to trading with the enemy during Iranian hostage crisis.

Mr Duncan, whose Westminster home in Gayfere Street was the base for John Major and William Hague's successful tilts at the Tory leadership, was a firm believer in the Tory maxim that it was best to make money before entering Westminster. He made an early start after his time at Oxford, where he cut his political teeth by becoming president of the union.

After a year as a trainee at Shell, he moved to Mr Rich's London office in Wigmore Street in 1982, joining what was later to become one of the most notorious, if successful, trading companies in the business. In 1984, as his boss became an international pariah, he moved up a notch in the Rich empire, assigned to Singapore, which was at the hub of the firm's lucrative activities in the Middle East and Far East. But he never considered Mr Rich a crook, believing charges levelled against him in the US were politically motivated.

Lifeblood

Opposition MPs in the South African parliament in May 1984 named Mr Rich as one of apartheid's major oil suppliers, breaching voluntary international embargos and contractual obligations imposed by Opec producers.

Despite repeated and overwhelming votes for a mandatory oil embargo in the UN's general assembly and a vigorous international campaign throughout the 1980s, individual traders like Mr Rich and companies like Shell continued to supply the apartheid regime with its lifeblood.

It has been estimated that about 15m tonnes of crude oil reached there every year. Its value was $3bn but South Africa paid an extra premium - as much as 80% above market price - as a bonus to companies willing to carry on the secret trade.

Although all the major exporting countries had a policy of not selling oil to South Africa, Britain under Margaret Thatcher took the lead in resisting any stronger action in the UN security council and in the Commonwealth, which included Brunei.

Mrs Thatcher considered Nelson Mandela, then incarcerated on Robben Island, a terrorist and Young Conservatives campaigned for the future president of South Africa to be hanged.

In its report of June 1984, the anti-apartheid Amsterdam Shipping Research Bureau said Brunei, which became independent on January 1 that year, had given it assurances that its crude should not be sold the South Africa and "that this policy is stipulated in the oil sale contracts."

Between February 1982 and November 1986, the Rich empire shipped more than 50 tanker cargos of Brunei champion crude to the Shell/BP refinery at Durban. Spotters on beaches and clifftops noted their names and in a report to the South African truth and reconciliation commission, four years after the last consignment, the former director of the Amsterdam Shipping Research Bureau described Mr Rich as the "No 1 embargo buster".

Mr Duncan has consistently played down his involvement with the US broker, maintaining he was too junior in the operation to be closely involved with him.

His insistence that he was a very small cog in the Rich operation is undermined by a telex, obtained by the Guardian, in which Mr Duncan boasted of his position.

Dated May 30, 1986, and sent by Mr Duncan to Khalef al Oteiba, managing director of the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, the main producer in the United Arab Emirates, the trader wrote: "For some time now we in Marc Rich & Co have been considering approaching you to purchase crude oil on a regular basis. We understand you are already acquainted with our organisation and the extent of our marketing and refinery network worldwide.

"As the person primarily responsible for our crude oil business in the Middle East and the Far East, I would much appreciate the opportunity to meet you to discuss our requirements for the remainder of 1986, which include all the grade you produce."

Mr Duncan said recently: "I worked for Marc Rich's company from 1982 until 1988. However, since leaving, I have neither seen Rich nor spoken with him at any time. I was never senior enough to be on those kind of terms with him anyway."

According to trader Gary Smith, Mr Duncan was given a rather important job for the group in Singapore. It was, according to Mr Smith, to manage a "special deal" with the sultanate of Brunei and ensure that the covert supplies of oil to South Africa were uninterrupted.

Mr Smith claims that Mr Duncan was "the crude oil coordinator of this particular special deal. All the major oil-exporting countries, including Brunei, had agreed to prevent diversion to South Africa, and individual contracts required a discharge certificate from the port of unloading.

Those who have monitored the trade claim that shippers would routinely use forged documents to disguise the true destination. Mr Smith does not suggest that Mr Duncan had any involvement in this sort of activity. He says he spoke to Mr Duncan specifically about South Africa.

"He [Mr Duncan] said 'Let's be grateful we have the SA business. That's good bread and butter.' Of course he knew about it. He was coordinating it," said Mr Smith, who attended meetings in Singapore and Switzerland with Mr Duncan.

At the quarterly meetings in Zurich of senior executives, which Mr Duncan attended, Mr Smith said all of Mr Rich's dealings were analysed, with South Africa being given the code word "Udo."

Mr Smith, who says he worked extensively for Mr Rich for three years from 1984 and visited Brunei in 1987 on the company's behalf, also met Mr Duncan in Singapore. "When I arrived in Singapore Duncan briefed me heavily and explained the deal at length," he said.

The Tory has repeatedly denied any knowledge of the deal other than that he picked up in newspapers and heard from gossip, insisting that during his spell in Singapore, which ended in the summer of 1986, he was responsible for other areas, including Korea and Malaysia, suggesting that the South Africa business was run from the Rich outfit's Tokyo office.

The South African operation, said Mr Duncan, had "nothing to do with me". He believes that Mr Smith, who twice tried to be selected as a Labour prospective parliamentary candidate, is politically motivated.

On June 30 1986 a telex from a Japanese corporation's London office, a copy of which has been obtained by the Guardian, was sent to a Rich & Co executive, Urs Reader, in Zug and copied to Mr Duncan in London and a Rich trader in Tokyo.

The Japanese mistakenly spelt his surname "Dankan" and the document, headed "Discharge certificates for Brunei crude oil", went on: "Our supplier has requested discharge certificates following cargos so please arrange the certificates as soon as possible."

There follows a list of nine tankers and the dates they left Brunei on 14 occasions between November 1982 and October 1984, carrying cargos ranging from 150,000 to 1.2m barrels.

Mistake

Another telex from the Japanese firm five days later, sent to Zug and copied to Mr Duncan (again spelt Dankan), asks for "prompt attention" in providing discharge certificates for four tankers. Three are from the earlier list; the fourth, Neptune Bravo, also ended up in South Africa after loading in Brunei.

Mr Duncan claims it was a mistake that the memos were copied to him, and he knew nothing of any of these shipments when he was in London or Singapore.

Mr Duncan said in a statement last night: "These are malicious and false allegations against me, long since disproved. This is a pathetic attempt to smear me, which is just what anyone would expect on the eve of an election."

Mr Duncan parted company with Mr Rich in 1988 to pursue his parliamentary ambitions, winning Rutland and Melton in 1992. By that time he was a wealthy man and through his private oil trading company, Harcourt Consultants, he made even more, he says, through supplying Pakistan during the Gulf war. "My wealth is exaggerated. But if I die, it's worth others picking up," he once explained.

fields.headline: Curious case of Marc Rich's pardon
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Marc Rich was pardoned in January by the outgoing President Bill Clinton in an act which provoked puzzlement and anger.
fields.body:
Marc Rich was pardoned in January by the outgoing President Bill Clinton in an act which provoked puzzlement and anger.

In Washington, the House of Representatives committee on government reform is investigating whether the pardon had anything to do with the fact that Mr Rich's ex-wife Denise, a New York socialite, had given $450,000 (£314,000) to the Clinton Library and $1.2m in donations to Democratic party campaigns, including Hillary Clinton's bid for the Senate.

Dan Burton, the committee's Republican chairman, said: "Mr Rich was publicly reported to have traded with just about every enemy the US has had over the last 20 years."

Mr Rich's 18-year battle with the US authorities became public knowledge in October 1982, when the existence of a grand jury investigation into his tax affairs was leaked. The allegation was that he was involved in a "classic criminal fraud" - a view the justice department still holds.

By summer 1983 the net was closing in and Mr Rich fled to Switzerland. In September, the grand jury handed down a 51-count indictment against him and his main business partner, Pincus Green, of wire fraud, racketeering, trading with the enemy during the 1980 Iranian hostage crisis, and tax evasion.

It charged them with violating federal controls on oil prices through a complex daisy chain of transactions. Profits from a $100m income were moved off-shore, evading $48m in taxes. If convicted on all counts, Mr Rich faced up to 300 years in prison.

It has been suggested that he also supplied weapons and spare parts to the Iranian regime of Ayatollah Khomeini. Hours before his pardon, an FBI criminal background check was sent to the White House indicating that he was involved in "arms dealing".

After lengthy negotiations, his US companies pleaded guilty in 1984 to tax evasion and making false statements, and paid fines of $200m.

With a $750,000 price on his head, Mr Rich was said to travel with an armed escort of former Israeli soldiers. Yet he was nearly captured by accident in July 1986 in an anti-terrorist clampdown at Heathrow airport.

Having flown into Britain on a Swissair flight, he panicked when he spotted the tightened security as he walked towards the departure gate to return to Zurich. Afraid of arousing suspicions, he abandoned three cheques totalling $1.6m in the pages of a phone directory at a public telephone booth.

His luck held shortly afterwards when, with police waiting for his private Gulfstream jet after a tip-off, a pea-soup of a fog covered Biggin Hill airfield, Kent, and the flight returned to Switzerland.

Now 66 and pondering whether to return to the US and face civil proceedings, he has made another lucrative killing by selling his trading arm, Marc Rich Investment, to a Russian conglomerate for $100m.

ABC news in America reported this week that US authorities had seized the £3.6m bank account he is using to pay his legal team.

New York state has filed a tax warrant, claiming that he owes £19m in state and personal income taxes, and £80m in penalties and interest.
