fields.headline: Captain Corelli's Mandolin
fields.standfirst: Nicolas Cage is disastrously miscast in a dreary, drooping adaptation of the Louis de Bernières novel
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Nicolas Cage is disastrously miscast in a dreary, drooping adaptation of the Louis de Bernières novel
fields.body:
Just two years ago, we left Hugh Grant lounging in a Notting Hill square, with a pregnant Julia Roberts snuggling up to him, and, like millions of others, he was reading a paperback with that unmistakable Mediterranean-blue jacket design. It was a cute bit of advance product placement for production company Working Title's next project: Captain Corelli's Mandolin, the story of a lovely young Greek woman and her affair, during the second world war, with a captain from the occupying Italian forces.

The gestation period is over, and the movie is here - but in the meantime, of course, its reputation as a "property" has developed unhelpfully. The author Louis de Bernières became testily defensive about his alleged right-wing bias in the depiction of the Greek communist partisans, and, indeed, about his alleged disapproval of the film itself, which excises the difficult sex and politics and turns it into a holiday romance with silly voices on the beautiful sun-kissed island of Cephallonia.

What a droopy, disappointing film this is. It has some of the unhappiest casting to be seen and dodgiest accents to be heard in the cinema, the worst offender being the barrel-chested, horse-faced Nicolas Cage as a captain in the Italian army (the comically incompetent innocents of fascism, apparently) who charms the socks, and indeed the pants, off the gorgeous Pelagia (Penelope Cruz). This he achieves with his sensitive love of music and that famous mandolin, which he has nestling pertly in his knapsack in lieu of a field marshal's baton. He and his adorable comrades want nothing more than to hang out on the beach, running in and out of the surf like the Monkees, singing and snogging their imported ladies of ill repute. "We are-a Italian-a!" explains Mr Cage, with a twinkle in his eye, "famous-a for-a singing-a! Eating-a! And making-a leeeeeeeurrrve!"

When he gets his mandolin out and starts twanging away, everyone swoons, but the idea of music transcending the divisive brutality of war and nationalism is completely lost. The music in the film is dire: Cage's singing is groan-inducing (I'm pretty sure it's not supposed to be that bad) and Corelli's composition, Pelagia's Theme, sounds sugary and bland. Frankly, no one could look more ill-at-ease or unconvincing with a musical instrument, and with so much broad comedy in his performance it would not be very surprising if Cage tried blowing into it.

So much for the American playing the Italian. Cruz is Spanish playing a Greek speaking in English in a kind of non-specific European voice; and David Morrissey (a generally excellent actor here forced into the role of uptight German officer) appears to be history's only recorded Scouse Nazi. The only actor really at home seems to be John Hurt as Dr Iannis, Pelagia's father - his face lizardly, impassive and sunburned, the corners of his mouth turned uncompromisingly down. He has the film's one really disturbing and powerful moment, when, as war is declared, he gives Pelagia a revolver - an oddly new-looking and well-maintained weapon - and tells her that she must not hesitate to use it on herself if necessary.

What tears at Pelagia's heart is that before war came, with its inappropriate and unpatriotic longings, she was betrothed to Mandras (Christian Bale), a stout-hearted local fisherman who enlists and then returns to join the communist partisans following an unequal military struggle against the Italians and Germans. These are not the villainous brutes of the novel, but Mandras is nevertheless shown turning a blind eye as a local woman is lynched for consorting with a German officer. (Perhaps it should be said that De Bernières' demonisation of the Greek communists is arguably in a distinctive British tradition inherited from Churchill, who boasted of saving post-war Greece from Stalin and was openly contemptuous of the partisans' struggle against the Nazis.)

But Mandras redeems himself at the end, and in any case, when Mussolini surrenders to the Allies, the Italians inherit the Greeks' victim status, and the movie shows them appearing to make a kind of chaotic, muddled common cause with Greece against the Third Reich.

John Madden's picture looks splendid - how could it not? - and the battle scenes in the final reel are managed with elan. But all the vitally emotional warfare is muted. So much emphasis is placed on the picturesque innocence of Pelagia's love in this Eden-like setting, and a miraculously equivalent innocence on the part of an Italian army officer, that the harsh realities of war, violence and betrayal seem weirdly pallid and inconsequential.

In the end, Cage's Corelli and Cruz's Pelagia seem more like children than much else: babes in the dark wood of 20th-century history - and perhaps that is part of the story's popularity. But you long for the film to grow up and give us a story about plausible adults.

fields.headline: BMXs and brainboxes
fields.standfirst: This is the week for unabashed pop - David Byrne's songs sound like showtunes, Moldy Peaches have made being brash kids into an artform, and even Michael Franti has gone disco...
fields.trailText: This is the week for unabashed pop - David Byrne's songs sound like showtunes, Moldy Peaches have made being brash kids into an artform, and even Michael Franti has gone disco...
fields.byline: Reviews by Alexis Petridis, Betty Clarke, Adam Sweeting, Robin Denselow, Caroline Sullivan and Paul Lester
fields.body:
David Byrne Look Into the Eyeball
(Virgin/Luaka Bop) ****
£14.99

These days, pop stars are available in only three varieties: Manufactured, Neanderthal and Boring Bloke. In the early 1980s, however, a different genus existed. Art school-educated and influenced by glam eggheads David Bowie and Roxy Music, the Brainy pop star made the top 10 shoehorning cleverclogs stuff about art and sociology into quirkily commercial singles. Britain had David Sylvian and Scritti Politti's Green Gartside, while America had Talking Heads frontman David Byrne. Most Brainy pop stars eventually traded hits for highbrow pursuits: Byrne has spent the decade since Talking Heads split scoring ballets and exploring world music. Stimulating for him, perhaps, but less fun for the listener, a state of affairs highlighted by Look Into the Eyeball's return to unabashed pop. The Great Intoxication and the lovely Philly soul pastiche Neighborhood marshal Byrne's arch lyrics and scholarly musical enthusiasms - Brazilian rhythms, bursts of atonal jazz and electronica, knowing mimicry - behind careening, carefree melodies that recall the naive romance of 1940s showtunes. The result is Byrne's best since 1985's Little Creatures: sumptuously orchestrated, effortlessly droll and - of course - as brainy as they come. (AP)

Michael Franti and Spearhead Stay Human
(Parlophone) ***
£14.99

Rapper and vocalist Michael Franti has always been an anomalous figure in hip-hop. In the early 1990s, when gangster rap's funk samples and trigger-happy lyrics ruled supreme, Franti's Disposable Heroes of HipHoprisy sampled livid industrial noise and wrote Noam Chomsky-influenced raps about mass media's destructive influence on individual thought. While Franti's words remain committed as ever, his current band Spearhead back his sung-spoken musings on government corruption and racism with jazzy funk and, on Thank You, even disco. Curiously, however, as Franti has moved from rap into Gil Scott-Heron territory, he has fallen prey to one of hip-hop's most pernicious evils: the "skit". Stay Human features nine of these irritating spoken-word interludes; telling an initially provocative tale about death row and starring Woody Harrelson as an unrepentant state governor, they quickly become irksome, interrupting the album's flow. Judicious use of the fast-forward button becomes a must if Stay Human is to get the repeated listening it deserves. (AP)

Moldy Peaches Moldy Peaches
(Rough Trade)****
£9.99

While the naive wisdom of childhood is eroded in most of us by responsibility and respectability, Adam Green and Kimya Dawson have not only clung to the surreal images and outspoken brashness of youth but distilled it into an artform. Using Sesame Street singalongs as a template, Moldy Peaches sing about the bare essentials and fleeting emotions of life with New York cool and laughter in their voices. Nothing Came Out has Dawson trying to tell a boy she likes him in words of heartfelt innocence. "You're probably holding hands with some pretty skinny girl who likes to talk about bands," she sings, yearning to watch cartoons with the object of her affection. All the motifs of childhood are here, from Converse trainers and Duran Duran to MP3s, BMXs and rollerskates. In many of the songs Green and Dawson handle a line each, punk poets disguised as Nancy Sinatra and Dean Martin against a background of guitars and hiss. The recording is deliberately crude, the impression one of two cynical, introspective kids with heads full of ideas, let loose with a tape recorder. While the duo rock out on the fantastic NYC's Like a Graveyard and Who's Got the Crack, it's the fragile melodies and honesty that linger. Anyone Else But You, which describes the central relationship as "part-time lover and a full-time friend" is the highlight of an album that is sweetly crazy and completely memorable. (BC)

The Black Crowes Lions
(V2) **
£13.99

The Black Crowes, stalwarts of good-time rock'n'roll, are cool. A recent secret show was stuffed to the rafters with the London showbiz elite; soon they'll be touring the US, co-headlining with Oasis - it's the latest thing to be down with their long hair, meandering guitar solos and outbursts of "Awwhhhhh!" Lions is the band's sixth album and although the keyboards are a little bit more inventive, it's still the traditional spit and sawdust, late night Black Crowes sound. Here women lay their men down. A lot. In fact, the Black Crowes may be the least pro-active bunch in rock. But the lyrics aren't what counts, it's the laid-back, blues-influenced vibe that's important. When it's there, it's good. Lay It All on Me tames Chris Robinson's shrieky vocals with a melancholy mood of subtle riffs and sleazy piano, and Losin' My Mind is a ballsy ballad spoilt only by the way each track runs abruptly into the next. But much of Lions is tiring, the sound of the maudlin rather than the cocksure drunk in the corner. It's in stadiums, not bedrooms that the Black Crowes belong. Come On's pomp and stomp will please the faithful but, despite what the cool kids say, the Faces did it better. (BC)

Paul McCartney Wingspan - Hits and History
(Parlophone, 2 CDs) ****
£16.99

Faced with the challenge of developing a post-Beatles career, Paul McCartney devised Wings as a kind of surrogate family, bringing his wife Linda along for moral support. The group always felt vaguely insubstantial and somehow unserious, but as this double-disc anthology demonstrates, the Wings years (1971-80) produced an impressive streak of hits: Band on the Run, Jet, Live and Let Die, My Love... and Mull of Kintyre. It isn't all Wings material here, though, since there are also extracts from Sir Fab's solo albums, not least Maybe I'm Amazed and Take It Away. Meanwhile, the CDs fit into a grand strategic plan that also includes a two-hour TV documentary tracing the inside story of Wings. Yes, there was life after the Moptops. (AS)

Eric Bibb Painting Signs
(Manhaton Records) ****
£13.99

It's hard work digging new life out of the much-shovelled earth of da bloooze, but Eric Bibb does it better than most. Blessed with a light, flexible voice that can plumb growling depths when required, Bibb interprets his remit as broadly as possible. Delia's Gone is a nifty specimen of nimble vocals and sprightly guitar-pickin', while both the sound and the sentiment of Hope in a Hopeless World owe more than a passing debt to Marvin Gaye in his "social justice" mode. Among the funkiness and slides guitars, Bibb boldly reworks the Hendrix warhorse Angel, using just voice and piano. Eminently consumable. (AS)

Vocal Sampling Cambio de Tiempo
(Decca) ***
£13.99

Vocal Sampling are a novelty band who are too good to be considered a mere novelty - Paul Simon called them "the best thing I've heard in 10 years". They are a six-man a cappella group from Cuba who use no backing tracks or instruments, but manage to sound like a full Latin orchestra. Other singers may mimic the sounds of particular instruments - it's a gimmick that has been used by anyone from Bobby McFerrin to Jose Alberto - but this group imitate everything from double bass and percussion through to strings, guitar and brass. They're so good at it that you almost forget you are listening only to vocalists. Their sense of rhythm is impeccable, and so are their elaborate arrangements, which switch between salsa, jazz and do-wop, often within the same song. Their dance pieces actually swing, their revival of that well-worn standard Guantanamera is inspired, thanks to what sounds like a slick, big-band brass arrangement, and they even take a spine-tingling stab at the Richard Strauss epic known in Havana as Asi Hablaba Zarathustra. (RD)

Shed Seven Truth Be Told
(Artful) ***
£14.99

Britpop swaggers afresh in the shape of Shed Seven, who have acquired a new guitarist, keyboardist and label since 1999's platinum-selling Greatest Hits. Undaunted by their perennial second-banana status, the York fivesome have a can-do spirit that lifts this album above the everyday. Even if they are essentially just adding a new coat of paint to the same retro structure, they do it with a certain panache. If The Music Don't Move Yer makes up for its yokelish title by deploying the guitar riff from Anarchy in the UK - not the most original move, but it virtually explodes out of the speakers. The dribbly sentiment of Love Equals may be the inevitable consequence of the Sheds hitting their 30s, but singer Rick Witter invests it with youthful yearning. To the Wind also passes pleasantly, pairing feathery guitar with Witter's Paul McCartney impression. (CS)

To Rococo Rot and I-Sound Music Is a Hungry Ghost
(City Slang) ****
£12.99

Based in Berlin and Dusseldorf, brothers Ronald and Robert Lippok together with Stefan Schneider are very much in the contemporary German electronica mould. On this, their fourth album (and first in tandem with New York DJ Craig Willingham, alias I-Sound), To Rococo Rot use computers and live instruments to create a series of ambient songs that function either as background sound-decor or, cranked up higher, as concise instrumental pop. The inner sleeve dedication to Mute Records label boss Daniel Miller points to a fascination with old school experimental electro-pop, echoes of which can be heard on The Trance of Travel and Along the Route. With its glitch rhythms, Mazda in the Mist betrays TRR's history on Germany's avant-garde circuit, while the pretty From Dream to Daylight features the violin playing of Alexander Balanescu of Balanescu Quartet fame. (PL)

webTitle: CD of the week: Elbow: Asleep in the Back

fields.headline: Howling at the moon
fields.standfirst: Take a walk on the dark side with Elbow, says  John Aizlewood  - it's heart-wrenching
fields.trailText: Take a walk on the dark side with Elbow, says John Aizlewood - it's heart-wrenching
fields.body:
Elbow Asleep in the Back
(V2) ****
£9.99

For a band who suddenly find themselves flavour of the month as the British record industry tumbles over itself to find the next Coldplay (who, of, course, were once the next Radiohead), Elbow have done their shifts at the coal face. The Bury men actually began work on this debut album in 1998 upon signing to Island Records. Marooned by Island's subsequent implosion, Elbow retrenched, released a brace of independent-label EPs, played low-key concerts, tinkered with personnel and waited for the curious osmosis that is word of mouth to take its course.

In October last year, with Elbow's thoughtful intricacy very much in fashion and a settled five-piece line-up, opportunity knocked once more in the shape of V2. As if they had thrice clicked their red shoes, Asleep in the Back was garnering accolades months ahead of its release.

Its provenance, as with so much of what is vaguely called New British Prog, is Mark Hollis's career backflip of 1985. Hollis's band Talk Talk released no records that year, but he spent it transforming them from pretty pop pin-ups who supported fellow new romantics Duran Duran into a meandering but beautiful beast. Talk Talk's 1986 album, The Colour of Spring, sought and found kinship with the lyrical and musical complexities of Nick Drake, John Coltrane and an irony-free Steely Dan.

Elbow stick to Hollis's template more rigidly than Radiohead, Coldplay or The Blue Nile, who have all - consciously, or by our friend osmosis - followed this particular route. Like Hollis, singer and lyricist Guy Garvey has a cusp-of-quiet-desperation catch in his voice as he floats across Little Beast, a portrait of smalltown, small-time ennui and violence, and wearily lists his own failings in death- rattle fashion on the even more etiolated Can't Stop. Hollis, however, would never have allowed himself the almighty cathartic howl that Garvey hollers towards the end of Powder Blue.

But Garvey is not just yet another woe-is-me lyricist who never saw the shards of humour in Leonard Cohen. By any yardstick, whether observing others or unveiling enticing globules of himself, Garvey's is a fertile mind. For every moment of lyrical indulgence, there are many that are magical and he is a master of the arresting image, be it "the girl's a priest (to me at least)" of Little Beast, or what turns out to be the lovelorn notion that "I'll be the corpse in your bathtub" on Newborn.

Intriguingly, the characters in Garvey's less than benign world share little but their dissatisfaction: a yearning to escape, mixed with a harkening to better times. He stumbles occasionally - Red's cliched tale of someone else's drug addiction simply doesn't ring true - but for the most part he strides boldly, and Newborn's tale of young lovers plotting their old age together ("You'll spend the end of your days smiling gently, like a newborn") is desperately moving and atypically optimistic.

He flees a grim smalltown (unsurprisingly, Elbow have already raised the heckles of Bury council, unroused since they erected a plaque to their other famous son, Robert Whitehead, inventor of the torpedo) on Any Day Now; watches another couple's relationship collapse on Powder Blue; has a friend whose girlfriend falls pregnant on Presuming Ed (Rest Easy) - "you need to chill your fucking bones," he advises, sagely - and elegiacally trawls through his childhood on Scattered Black & Whites.

Musically, Elbow do enough to distance themselves from the herd. None of these 11 songs is hurried through and they correctly understand that a freeform approach need not necessar ily mean eschewing melody. Rather, it gives them the freedom to do as they please without losing sight of the song. Like Nelson Mandela, they use their freedom wisely.

Thus, angular guitar solos meet tom-tom percussion - drummer Richard Jupp is Elbow's busiest bee - and layered vocals on Bitten by the Tailfly. Scattered Black & Whites teasingly begins as Talk Talk homage before almost breaking into U2's Where the Streets Have No Name. What sounds like a Star Wars wookie roars through Coming Second and the harmonic epiphany during Presuming Ed (Rest Easy) is so complex and uplifting it could have been a Todd Rundgren vocal arrangement. And that's before the nods to classical, avant-garde, pop and the Joy Division-style breaking glass that closes Powder Blue.

Although rarely inaccessible, Elbow are hardly easy listening and Coming Second is genuinely harrowing. Moreover, although they do nothing new, they have a bigger melting pot and less fear of using it than their peers. However, in an era where music for squaddies may yet take over and the return of a band as vacuous as Stereo MC's is seen as some kind of British cultural renaissance, Elbow fly a tattered flag for grumpy intelligence with a heart-wrenching streak.

webTitle: Classical CD of the week: Vaughan Williams

fields.headline: Capital gains
fields.standfirst: The original 1913 version of Vaughan Williams's A London Symphony, severely cut by the composer, is a rediscovered treasure, says  Andrew Clements
fields.trailText: The original 1913 version of Vaughan Williams's A London Symphony, severely cut by the composer, is a rediscovered treasure, says Andrew Clements
fields.body:
Vaughan Williams: A London Symphony (1913 version); Butterworth: The Banks of Green Willow
London Symphony/Hickox
(Chandos) ****
£14.99

A London Symphony was apparently Vaughan Williams' favourite of his nine symphonies, yet it took more than 20 years to reach the form in which we know it today. It was George Butterworth who in 1910 convinced Vaughan Williams that he was ready to compose a purely orchestral symphony to follow the choral work that was his first essay in symphonic form, the Sea Symphony. The score of the new work was completed by the end of 1913 - a portrait of London life that was initially inspired by HG Wells's novel Tono-Bungay. The first performance took place the following March.

Soon after that, the manuscript of the full score was lost somewhere in Germany and for another performance in 1915 the work had to be reconstructed from the orchestral parts, with Butterworth himself lending a hand; a year later the young, hugely talented composer was killed at the Somme, and Vaughan Williams dedicated the London Symphony to Butterworth's memory. fields.headline: Jazz CD releases
fields.standfirst: Randy Brecker: Hangin' in the City | Steve Lodder: Bout Time 2
fields.trailText: Randy Brecker: Hangin' in the City | Steve Lodder: Bout Time 2
fields.body:
Randy Brecker Hangin' in the City
(ESC Records) **
£14.99

Randy Brecker, brother of sax-star Michael and one of the more distinctive and independent of the post-Miles Davis trumpeters, has always had one foot squarely planted in a music world where the cash tills are supposed to be ticking over pretty quickly. He shared the billing on one of the most successful of all jazz-funk bands with his brother, and his jaunty, muted trumpet here - like a more upfront, broad-grin version of Miles's playing over fusion grooves in the late 1980s - continues to show how effectively he got inside Davis's conception of shrewdly paced swing and the expressiveness of the muted trumpet.

On Wayne Out, a fast shuffle turning from funk to a kind of Afro-beat (with Chris Minh Doky on bass and David Binney's guitar partner Adam Rogers), Brecker's trumpet boils and bubbles; and his agility and ingenuity on quick runs is up to any of his most effective soloing of recent times. Michael Brecker turns up on several tracks, and on the title the brothers drop in a sampled reminder of their key role in the pioneering of jazz-funk, with a loop from their highly regarded Dreams band of 1970. As a piece of deftly played, sleazily effective, only faintly-dated jazz-funk, this set has something going for it. But the leader's vocals (of which there's a hell of a lot), his ill-advised wrangling with rap, not to mention his dodgy posings with various cheesily smiling It Girls on the cover, might turn out to be market-repositioning turn-offs even for his long-time fans.

Steve Lodder Bout Time 2
(MacTwo) ***
£14.99

A regular collaborator with Andy Sheppard, and a highly valued sideman with innumerable local and international ensembles, pianist Steve Lodder has been confirming that he's a class act for such a long time now that, as with David Binney, this set under his own leadership seems to have been unaccountably delayed. Lodder is both an improvisor of originality and a musical thinker of erudition and depth, and he brings an influential extra dimension to almost every band he plays in. But, as Michael Brecker found before his long-postponed shift into leadership, the big question for a player that has been such a constant sideman is which musical identity to pursue out of innumerable alternatives encouraged by others.

Lodder has ambitiously sought to bring many contemporary elements together here - percussive and rhythmic ideas drawn from the dance and club world, relaxed inflections from Latin music, episodes of mildly tongue-in-cheek remakes of old idioms reminiscent of Carla Bley's approach, Miles Davis-style electronic funk, vocal tangos with Charlie Parker themes for a countermelody, and rhapsodies that suggest atmospheric movie scores (Clarissa Lost and Found) that shift dramatically into their keyboard solo space rather in the way a Pat Metheny piece develops.

All the soloing is excellent, and Lodder's own playing has rarely been heard to better effect on disc. But the material, despite its idiomatic variety, holds the attention less firmly, and several of the pieces travel hopefully in search of an essence. Clarissa Lost and Found is a beauty though, and the eccentrically funky flamenco of Pere David's Stomp also suggests very promising possibilities for Lodder's growing independence.

webTitle: Jazz CD of the week: David Binney: South

fields.headline: Playing second to none
fields.standfirst: David Binney has helped plenty of bands with his flexible talent, but does he shine so brightly with his own material?  John Fordham  finds out
fields.trailText: David Binney has helped plenty of bands with his flexible talent, but does he shine so brightly with his own material? John Fordham finds out
fields.body:
David Binney South
(ACT) ****

David Binney, the 39- year-old Florida-born alto and soprano saxophonist, is one of the brighter talents to have appeared on the international scene in recent years. The same can be said of Chris Potter, who joins him on tenor on this set.

If it seems with Binney (and Potter) that his age raises a query as to why his reputation has been a long time coming, the saxophonist's secure place as an embellisher of the work of others is the answer. He has been a first-call sideman for years, performing with the Gil Evans band, with Maria Schneider, Bobby Previte and Uri Caine, and with Medeski, Martin and Wood. The CV gives some idea of how flexible Binney's skills are, and of the unsectarian nature of his outlook.

If you were going only on Dave Binney's appearance with Jim Hall's quartet in the UK this week, however, it may have seemed likely that a Binney's debut disc would belong closer to the mainstream of the jazz tradition. He's a fluent and agile post-bop improviser with (at times) absorbing suggestions of both the late Art Pepper's heartfelt cry and David Sanborn's mellow soulfulness. Binney's soloing was a constant source of surprise and variety in the quartet's Queen Elizabeth Hall show in London - from crowded and tumbling semi-free forays of a spiky percussive nature (occasionally suggestive of Eric Dolphy) through long-note meditations of a stately, violin-like purity, to a punchy funkiness.

But the set on this disc depends far less on the orthodox shapes of tunes. Rather than proceeding like songs, the tracks often develop through thoughtful explorations of harmonic movement alone. Some pieces just sound like chord patterns, some are reveries of minimal movement, and Binney's smoky sound against Adam Rogers's guitar resembles a darker, more fraught equivalent of the oblique lyricism of Andy Sheppard's playing alongside John Parricelli. There are also distant connections to Wayne Shorter's provocative sense of form. But though there's plenty of lateral (and rather Euro-jazzy) contemplation and some pretty hard-edged free-improvisation here, Binney in a full up-tempo post-bop spate is quite something.

Despite the fact that there is plenty of sharp and probing soloing, this is primarily ensemble music - a spacious, multi-stranded repertoire that successfully balances the patient layering of harmonies and detailed examination of textures against funkiness, open swing and bursts of explosive improvisation.

It might feel a bit unforgiving for some, but it's certainly promising, and the presence of Potter, Uri Caine, Brian Blade and Jim Black (the latter adding his unremittingly unruly energies to two of the tracks here) give some indication of the regard the leader is held in.

fields.headline: AntiTrust
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: As well as being the cleverest computer nerd in the land, Ryan Phillippe is obviously the most gorgeous. It's as if Silicon Valley has been re-located to Dawson's Creek
fields.body:
This is like a wackily far-fetched, paranoid version of Douglas Coupland's Microserfs, or perhaps just a hi-tech version of the John Grisham thriller The Firm. Tom Cruise, you remember, joined the chi-chi corporate world of a top law firm only to discover it's run by the Mob; here, Ryan Phillippe is Milo, the brilliant young computer geek seduced away from his homely start-up venture to join a big corporation called NURV (Never Underestimate Radical Vision), run by the greying, bespectacled software mogul Gary Winston (Tim Robbins). Milo gets totally creeped-out by all the fanatical suppression of competition and sinister global domination plans. When he visits Gary's magnificent beachfront pad, he sees weird computer-generated pictures which change to suit the mood of whoever's in the room. "Doesn't Bill Gates have something like that?" asks Milo pointedly - at which point, presumably, Bill Gates is supposed to call off his attack-dog team of lawyers since the Gary figure isn't supposed to be him.

Peter Howitt's film is entertaining in an implausible sort of way. And as with all films targeted at the teen market, Hollywood's Good Looks Apartheid applies pretty stringently here. As well as being the cleverest computer nerd in the land, Ryan Phillippe is obviously the most gorgeous. It's as if Silicon Valley has been re-located to Dawson's Creek. (All we need now is a biopic of Alan Turing starring Joshua Jackson.) The real butt-uglies are the goateed losers in NURV's tech division, among whom the mysterious and beautiful Lisa (Rachael Leigh Cook) naturally stands out. "Hey man, Lisa smiled at you!" says one techie to Milo wonderingly. "She never lets anyone near her!" Could this be, I wonder, because she and Milo have the unearthly good looks of supermodels, and everyone else is a fat ugly dork?

fields.headline: Classical CD releases
fields.trailText: Ligeti | Keiser | Scelsi | Bartok | Beethoven
fields.body:
Ligeti: Melodien; Chamber Concerto; Piano Concerto; Mysteries of the Macabre
Aimard/Masseurs/ Schoenberg & Asko Ensembles/De Leeuw (Teldec) ****
£14.99

After eight releases, Sony Classical's complete Ligeti edition has come to a premature end with all the orchestral works still to be issued, and the project has been taken up by Teldec. This first instalment suggests that standards will be just as high under Reinbert de Leeuw as they were under Esa-Pekka Salonen for Sony. All the works have been released on disc before, even though Teldec claim Mysteries of the Macabre, a trumpet and ensemble spin-off from the opera Le Grand Macabre, as a premiere recording. Pierre-Laurent Aimard's earlier account of the Piano Concerto, conducted by Boulez on Deutsche Grammophon, is arguably more convincing, more sharply defined, than this one, but de Leeuw's accounts of Melodien and the Chamber Concerto, two of the finest ensemble works of the 1970s, are models of clarity and unfussy virtuosity.

Keiser: Der Geliebte Adonis
Zumbult/Popken/Spogis/ Ryden/Capella Orlandi Bremen/Ihlenfeldt
(CPO, three CDs) **
£26.99

One of the unexpected highlights of last year's CD releases was Reinhard Keiser's Croesus, in a performance conducted by Rene Jacobs for Harmonia Mundi. The power and inventiveness of this opera suggested that Keiser (1674-1739) was much more than just an historically important figure in the development of opera - he was the leading German practitioner of his day, and a precursor of Handel. He was also an original composer in his own right whose works fully deserved further exploration today. Der Geliebte Adonis, first performed in 1697 and based on the story of Venus and Adonis, is the earliest of Keiser's surviving stage works, and contains some telling numbers, but in general the level of originality is far below that of his later scores. In a first-rate performance it might seem more worthwhile but this concert performance from Bremen is simply not distinguished enough, vocally or instrumentally to make it convincing.

Scelsi: Hymnos; Hurqualia; Konx- Om-Pax; Canti del Capricorno
Vaillancourt/Ahlstedt/ Carnegie Mellon Philharmonic & Concert Choir/Izquierdo
(Mode) ***
£13.99

"The history of the second half of the 20th century is unthinkable without Giacinto Scelsi", claims the sleeve note for this second volume in Mode's series devoted to the orchestral works of this elusive composer. While there's no doubt that his music, with its intense concentration on the minutiae of sounds and monolithic sense of form is thoroughly individual, whether it is really significant is another matter altogether. The three big pieces here, interspersed with a selection of the solo vocal Canti di Capricorno, date from the 1960s. Both Hurqualia, for large orchestra, and Hymnos, for organ and two orchestras, nag away at single pitches, creating clouds of microtones around them, while Konx-Om Pax is a huge assemblage of sound involving a large chorus. The general contour of the three works is much the same, a remorseless progression to a gigantic climax and then an ebbing away; for Scelsi, the details of the musical journey mattered more than the point of arrival.

Bartok: Concerto for Orchestra; Dance Suite; Miraculous Mandarin Suite
London Symphony/Solti
(Decca) *****
£8.99

Since it first appeared in 1965, Georg Solti's electrifying account of the Concerto for Orchestra has only occasionally been matched on disc and never superseded. One of the finest recordings that Solti ever made, his propulsiveness and rhythmic precision are ideal for a work that can so easily sound glib and four-square. With top-class playing from the LSO it acquires real freshness and sense of dramatic purpose. Solti is equally successful in energising the Dance Suite, pungently characterising each folk tune, and making sure that the orchestral colours come through with total immediacy. For the reissue in the Legends series, this original coupling has been augmented by a 1963 version of The Miraculous Mandarin, equally driven and theatrical, though it is in the unsatisfactory suite form rather than the full ballet.

Beethoven: Diabelli Variations
Piotr Anderszewski
(Virgin Classics) *****
£14.99

The Polish-born Anderszewski first attracted attention at the Leeds piano competition in 1990, when he abandoned his semi-final recital in mid-performance because he was dissatisfied with his own playing. It did him no harm: since then his reputation has steadily burgeoned. But though he has made two discs with the violinist Viktoria Mullova, he is only now really being taken up by the recording industry, and this compelling version of the Diabelli is a wonderful and auspicious start. Anderszewski's performance takes 63 minutes - most versions come in around 55 - yet the presence and magnetism of his playing are such that it never seems a moment too long, with every variation deeply considered and presented in a sometimes startling new light. This is piano playing of the highest class.

fields.headline: Along Came a Spider
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Freeman is a class act and his rumbling bass voice always means he can carry off a scene with a certain style, however absurdly written
fields.body:
A kidnapping thriller that stars Morgan Freeman, explicitly reprising his role as - the criminal profiler Alex Cross - who first appeared in 1997 in Kiss the Girls with Ashley Judd - and, implicitly, his persona from movies like Seven. He is the wise, fatherly cop schooled in the mentality of the wackos, called in when a mysterious predator Gary Soneji (Michael Wincott) snatches the pre-teen daughter of a senator from her fancy private school. Cross is helped out by the feisty-yet-vulnerable secret service agent Jezzie Flannigan who was supposed to be looking out for the little girl in the first place, so she's got something to prove. Flannigan is played by Monica Potter, a star with china-doll-like beauty and acting ability.

Until approximately halfway through, the drama proceeds on familiar lines, with the kidnapper taunting and playing "mind games" with his pursuers on the phone, leaving weirdo clues through websites, and occasionally treating himself to a Malkovich-flavoured tantrum. But then the plot is up-ended by an enormous and unexpected twist, a great big Chubby Checker-sized hip-swivelling twist - which utterly cancels out the dramatic import of everything that has been accumulating over the previous hour. Basically, a new kidnapping plot begins here, a kidnapping plot which is all about money and not psycho stuff, and this plot is not really melded into the first in any satisfactory way.

Freeman is a class act, though, and his rumbling bass voice always means he can carry off a scene with a certain style, however absurdly written. Eventually, though, for a psycho thriller to work, the psycho in question has to be fascinating and scary - and this one is just tiresome.

He is the wise, fatherly cop schooled in the mentality of the wackos, called in when a mysterious predator Gary Soneji (Michael Wincott) snatches the pre-teen daughter of a senator from her fancy private school. fields.headline: MPs rebuke former heritage chairman
fields.trailText: Sir Jocelyn Stevens, the former chairman of English Heritage, was yesterday censured by MPs for hiring out Kenwood House at a cut-price rate for the society wedding of the daughter of King Constantine of Greece.
fields.body:
Sir Jocelyn Stevens, the former chairman of English Heritage, was yesterday censured by MPs for hiring out Kenwood House at a cut-price rate for the society wedding of the daughter of King Constantine of Greece.

The Commons public accounts committee said arrangements for the wedding which was attended by the Queen and the Prince of Wales and featured in Hello! magazine "fell below the standards to be expected from public servants". They condemned the £34,000 fee agreed to hold the wedding there as an insufficient return.

King Constantine - an acquaintance of Sir Jocelyn - had been expected to give an additional donation.

Instead Sir Jocelyn himself wrote a cheque for £5,000 two months after he had left his job with English Heritage, and days before his successor was due to appear before parliament to answer questions about it.

The MPs' report said that the use of Kenwood House "fell below the standards to be expected from public servants".

David Davis, Tory chairman of the committee, said yesterday that the hiring had not been open and transparent, and the tactic "of witholding key information about this from my committee is an object lesson in how not to handle parliamentary inquiries".

English Heritage said Sir Jocelyn has been reimbursed by King Constantine and it denied intending to deliberately withold information from MPs.

fields.headline: Go Racing on course to acquire TV rights
fields.trailText:
10.15am: The consortium has signed up 32 racecourses, enough to trigger its media rights deal, writes Jessica Hodgson.
27.04.2001: TV horseracing bid imminent
27.04.2001: GG Media launches advertising campaign
fields.body:
The Go Racing consortium has signed a deal that will enable it to control the TV rights to British horseracing.

The consortium, which includes Arena Leisure, BSkyB and Channel 4, said it had signed up 32 racecourses, enough to trigger its deal to acquire the media rights.

The Go Racing deal represents 71% of British betting turnover, according to the consortium.

Go Racing's chief executive, Christopher Stoddart, said he was: "delighted [to have received] such a good level of acceptances so quickly from the racecourses".

"We hope to be able to welcome most of the remaining racecourses by May 11 to ensure we deliver the best solution for racing."

Earlier in the week, a rival consortium, GG Media, claimed smaller racecourses had been intimidated by larger racing bodies into signing up to the Go Racing deal.

GG Media has offered courses until midnight on Wednesday to sign up to its proposal.

Related story

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: credit unions and loan sharks

fields.headline: There must be banks for the poor as well as the rich
fields.standfirst: The failure of credit unions plays straight into the hands of loan sharks
fields.trailText: The failure of credit unions plays straight into the hands of loan sharks.
fields.body:
A small tragedy is unfolding that could and should be prevented. A credit union held up as a famous model of self-help in one of the poorest places is about to crash. Some 3,000 people stand to loose every penny of their very hard-earned life savings.

At conferences on social exclusion, the Camberwell Credit Union has been presented as the exemplar, with its members testifying movingly to how it saved them from loan shark penury and above all, how it gave them pride in their local community as they banded together to create something for themselves. Credit unions have been extolled time and again by Labour ministers. But now its members face a shattering loss.

It was mainly West Indians who founded the union some 20 years ago when they were denied ordinary bank accounts. So they set up their own community bank on the North Peckham estate, (where Damilola Taylor was murdered), drawing in people from every background paying in some £5 a week.

They include the student single mother who scraped together £220 for her son's future, the Irish widow on benefits with two children who will lose £350, the 67-year-old West Indian chef who will lose £3,500 for his old age and the elderly woman whose son put £5,000 into her account as she had no savings; 24 people had £800 each put into their accounts by Southwark council for new furnishings when they were decanted while the estate is rebuilt.

They have all been told that due to bad debts, they will only get 50p in the pound back: if it is forced to close, the liquidators fees will take the rest.

The Financial Services Authority (FSA) discovered a shortfall of £200,000 and ordered the books to be frozen as an insolvent organisation. It was not fraud but over-lenient lending that destroyed them, as has happened before with these small, amateur run banks.

The very thing that makes credit unions so attractive to urban regenerators, encouraging social enterprise with deep community roots, is also what makes them perilously vulnerable. If Camberwell goes under it will send a frightening message to all the other 450 community credit unions. Expect a run on them by vulnerable people who simply cannot afford to take any risks. It could spell the end for many small community unions.

A rescue is being attempted by Harriet Harman together with Tessa Jowell, whose constituents are among the losers. The FSA is doing what it can to help. Southwark council has put in £20,000. The necessary £200,000 is not a large sum for the Treasury and big banks to stump up between them. But the Treasury has so far refused, claiming it would set a precedent for bailing others out.

However, as from July 2002 an excellent new law designed to strengthen credit unions will bring their members under the same umbrella as banks, protecting savers from any future collapse. So a Treasury rescue only risks a minor precedent for another year.

The British Banking Association has been asked for help too, but so far not a penny has been forthcoming. Banks have no interest in picking up 3,000 poor customers who cost more than they bring in. The only hope is that some might see this good cause will bring them better publicity than they could ever buy with a mere £200,000 of advertising. Particularly as the money would only be needed as a long-term guarantee and they would probably get it back.

"Financial exclusion" has much exercised this government - a big phrase for not having any money. With puritan fervour this chancellor is trying to create a savings culture to help the feckless poor who save too little.

There have been brainstorming seminars inside Number 11 and much research commissioned to delve into the savings habits of the poor. (Most were found to be "jamjarring".) Imaginative new schemes have been devised, such as baby bonds to give poor children a capital start in life. Or the new "savings gateway" where the government will match pound for pound any money the poor manage to save.

The other hope was the promised Universal Bank, to be set up within the post office. It should have been unveiled with a flourish yesterday, but at the last fence the deeply antagonistic banks balked again: so far not one of the 11 have signed the Memorandum of Understanding to bring it into being.

They have dragged their heels and succeeded in yet again trouncing the government, offering the minimum while contributing a minimal sum. The DTI has been frustrated in its negotiations by the Treasury forbidding them from threatening the banks with any hint of compulsion or punishment. "It would have been handy to have more cards in our hand," said one DTI negotiator ruefully.

Banks never wanted poor customers cluttering up their queues, paying in and out piffling sums at more cost than they were worth. Banks rarely lend sums under £1,000, so the poor needing small loans have only the loan sharks charging anything up to 150%, from whom they never escape. Now it emerges that the Universal Bank has partly stalled because all the commercial banks are arguing amongst each other, not competing for this new custom but each fighting to take on as little as possible.

When the Universal Bank was first announced, ministers talked boldly of the banks' "moral obligation" to compensate society for with drawing from rural and poor urban areas. Now it will probably be a puny thing, primarily a cheaper way for the government to pay out benefits and a support for post offices - no use at all in helping the poor avoid crippling loan shark debt.

Benefits will be paid into post office "card accounts", that do nothing else. Post offices will then urge people to go into banks and open basic accounts which offer almost nothing - and certainly no loans, though they can at least be accessed thereafter over post office counters. This is barely better than the jam jar: government claims that people can get discounts from paying utility bills by direct debit cut no ice with all those who can never afford to pay bills all at once.

Credit unions which require people to accumulate some savings before they qualify for small loans are a model of Brown prudence. However this admirable but pathetically small movement with just 100,000 community members and very shaky financial viability, usually only open for half a day a week, is not the answer for millions of people who need safe savings and loans with good financial advice.

Credit unions need to be professionalised, with government help. As for the Universal Bank, if Mrs Thatcher could windfall commercial banks, the chancellor could at least threaten it, unless they provide a decent savings and loan service for rich and poor alike.

webTitle: Halifax and Bank of Scotland agree merger

fields.headline: Halifax and Bank of Scotland agree merger
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Halifax and Bank of Scotland heralded "a new force in UK banking" today, after agreeing a £28bn merger. The two banks joined forces to create the fifth largest bank in the country after just a week of talks and vowed to take the fight to the big four.
fields.body:
Halifax and Bank of Scotland heralded "a new force in UK banking" today, after agreeing a £28bn merger. The two banks joined forces to create the fifth largest bank in the country after just a week of talks and vowed to take the fight to the big four.

More than 2,000 jobs are expected to be lost over the next three years as the banks integrate their operations, but few compulsory redundancies are forecast.

The two banks will operate under a new holding company, HBOS plc, but will continue to trade under their current brand names.

The merger represents third time lucky for Bank of Scotland, which has been spurned by potential partners on two previous occasions, most recently, by the Abbey National.

BoS chief executive Peter Burt said that the merger was "one of the most exciting deals of the financial industry for a very long time".

He added: "We are creating a new force in UK banking. Together, we believe we will be able to increase the rate of growth and produce a much better service to our customers.

"It is a merger of equals. We have had to make some tough decisions but the results is a very clear focus and an attractive strategy."

Halifax chief executive James Crosby, said the merger meant the banks would now be able "to broaden our attack" on Lloyds TSB, Barclays, HSBC and Royal Bank of Scotland, which owns NatWest.

"Our aim is to make life difficult for them," he said, adding that both banks would look to expand their services to small and medium-sized business.

"That is the last part of the major clearing banks' heartland," Mr Crosby said.

The merger still has to gain regulatory clearance, but Jim Wood-Smith, banking analyst at City stockbroker Gerrard, said that he did not envisage any problems.

"The regulators cleared the proposed merger between Bank of Scotland and Abbey National so there should not be any trouble getting this one through."

Finance union UNIFI said that, with a total workforce of more than 60,000, the 2,000 job losses should easily be covered by natural wastage.

Unions said that they had not been made aware that any branches will close as a result of the merger.

Halifax Labour MP Alice Mahon hit out at the merger, saying she felt "betrayed" by the plan to site the new company's headquarters in Scotland, but the move was welcomed by Scottish Tory leader David McLetchie.

fields.headline: Livingstone's good start
fields.standfirst: But he must win the battle for the tube
fields.trailText: Londoners with a taste for drama may feel a tad disappointed. After all, did not the prime minister and half the cabinet warn that victory for Ken Livingstone would be a "disaster for London"?
fields.body:
Londoners with a taste for drama may feel a tad disappointed. After all, did not the prime minister and half the cabinet warn that victory for Ken Livingstone would be a "disaster for London"? Did they not predict a cataclysmic return to the dark days of the 80s? Yet what has happened? Mr Livingstone's first year in office, which he marks today, has not been one of chaos and civic breakdown - but an almost anticlimactic period of quiet. The mayor has arrived and the sky has not fallen in; things have carried on much as they were.

For some this is a let-down. They liked the Ken of old, with his knack for controversy and attention-grabbing stunts. They find it hard to get used to a once Red Ken who works to get more money for the police and supports their clampdown on this week's May Day protests. But the mayor himself, as he explains in the interview we publish today, sees all this as vindication. He is grateful for the verdict of LSE local government expert, Tony Travers, who declares the first few months of the Greater London assembly "a miracle of competent administration". If Londoners are finding things quiet, that is fine by him. His first objective was to prove Mr Blair wrong - to get the new, devolved machinery up and running and to show that a Livingstone mayoralty was no "disaster".

Beyond that, what is the record? The mayor has some small achievements he can be proud of. He is beginning to get conductors back on buses, the proper policing of bus lanes will begin soon and his initiative for free travel for school trips has captured Londoners' imagination. He has not lost his touch for the symbolic gesture either. His planned pedestrianisation of Trafalgar Square is popular (even if his war on the pigeons is more divisive). Last Sunday's concert for Nelson Mandela was, he says, the first of many in the square. Meanwhile, his denial of planning permission for a luxury apartment block sought by Mohammed Al Fayed - on the grounds that it did not include enough affordable accommodation - has won plaudits.

If these feel like admirable, but small triumphs that is partly because of the limited authority granted to the mayoralty. But that record also omits the chief area of Mr Livingstone's activity: the battle to prevent the partial privatisation of the underground. This was the central plank of his winning platform and he has stuck doggedly to it. He is right to name as his most significant achievement the hiring of Bob Kiley as his transport boss. Mr Kiley's experience rescuing subway systems in the US has made the Livingstone case impossible to sweep aside: put simply, Mr Kiley has more credibility on this topic than either John Prescott or Gordon Brown.

These facts about the last year dictate the shape of the next three. They show that the mayor's most crucial task is to win the battle for the tube. As we argued earlier this week, the government's plan for the underground is wrongheaded and its pursuit is fast becoming dogmatic. Mr Livingstone is right to take his case to court and we hope he wins - unless Labour sees sense and cuts a deal.

But the parallel challenge of the rest of the term is to win the greater powers the mayor and assembly need to do their jobs properly. There are many odds and ends - arts and housing, for example - which ought to come under London's strategic authority. We wish Mr Livingstone well, less for his sake than for the devolution project itself. For if he can show it works in London, then Labour may be encouraged to devolve yet more power to the cities and regions of Britain.

webTitle: Influx of foreign nurses helps NHS

fields.headline: Influx of foreign nurses helps NHS
fields.trailText: A huge influx of foreign nurses is about to rescue the NHS from staff shortages that were threatening to undermine the government's plans to expand hospitals.
fields.body:
A huge influx of foreign nurses is about to rescue the NHS from staff shortages that were threatening to undermine the government's plans to expand hospitals.

Figures released yesterday by the UK Central Council for Nursing, Midwifery and Health Visiting showed a 71.1% increase in overseas-trained nurses applying to get on the UK register during the 12 months to the end of March.

They included 13,750 from the Philippines, 2,459 from India, 2,065 from Nigeria,and 2,056 from South Africa - where health authorities have expressed concern about a drain of scarce skilled staff being tempted into Britain.

There is usually no guarantee that applications from overseas to join the UK register will convert into extra nurses on the wards. But the UKCC said most of the 29,119 overseas-trained applicants in 2000/01 were on "adaptation courses" lasting from six to nine months to prepare them for work in British hospitals.

"This means that 2001/02 will see a very large increase in overseas registrations," the council said.

Last year the number of overseas-trained nurses reaching the register rose by 4.1% to 7,705.

The influx is likely to come in the nick of time for health ministers, who saw the shortage of staff as the main obstacle to their plans to improve the NHS.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, committed the government to increase the number of nurses by 20,000 by 2004, GPs by 2,500 and consultants by 7,500.

Last year ministers told NHS trusts they should not recruit nurses from developing places where they were in short sup ply, such as South Africa and the West Indies. Last month John Denham, the health minister, extended the instruction to cover employment agencies.

He said they would be blacklisted by the NHS if they failed to honour a revised code of practice banning poaching from countries that were battling to raise health standards.

But the government has not interfered with the freedom of movement of individual nurses coming to Britain of their own accord to seek jobs in the NHS.

The number applying to get on the UK register from the Philippines - where there is a surplus of trained nurses - more than doubled from 5,643 in 1999/2000 to 13,750 in 2000/01.

Over the same period applications from India nearly trebled from 880 to 2,459. Other big exporters last year included Australia with 1,330 applications and Zimbabwe with 1,201.

The council also announced the first increase for seven years in numbers of "homegrown" nurses and midwives who came on to the register after training in Britain. The total rose by 10% to 15,433.

But those increases were outweighed by increasing numbers of nurses in their 50s who were retiring. This led to a 0.4% decline in the number of nurses and midwives on the register, falling from 634,529 to 632,050.

The Department of Health said: "We are expanding the workforce and have increased the number of training places, but international recruitment helps stabilise the nursing workforce and reduces the shortfall in the short to medium term."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: The appeal of the extremely rightwing Tory defence spokesman Iain Duncan Smith knows few bounds. Not content with being backed in from 25-1 outsider to 2-1 second favourite to succeed Mr Hague, the former Guardsman (he shared barracks once with the boulevardier Andrew Neil) has been bragging at being asked to pose in the nude for a Cosmopolitan centrefold.
fields.body:
The appeal of the extremely rightwing Tory defence spokesman Iain Duncan Smith knows few bounds. Not content with being backed in from 25-1 outsider to 2-1 second favourite to succeed Mr Hague, the former Guardsman (he shared barracks once with the boulevardier Andrew Neil) has been bragging at being asked to pose in the nude for a Cosmopolitan centrefold.

Once Libby at Cosmo confirms that he (along with Polly Portillo, Ken Livingstone and others) has indeed been asked, my colleague Marina Hyde rings for a chat. "I don't really want to discuss that," begins Iain, haughtily. "I don't think it's a matter for discussion."

That's odd, says Marina, because people have reported you making rather pleased-with-yourself jokes about it. "Well that's what they are - just jokes."

And why didn't you consider it seriously? "Look, this isn't something worth talking about. It was something bizarre, and not part of the parliamentary process." Right. So it wasn't worry about the size of your, er... ?

A very, very long pause ensues. "Don't be daft," says Iain finally. "What a silly question. And printing anything on this is just silly. Really!" Click, brrrr ... alas, before Marina can put the vital supplementary she had planned.

 In another vintage Spectator (the smut in Taki-George's column has to be read to be believed: thank God you can rely on us as your sanctuary from genital humour), I am distressed by an attack on Paul Johnson's reputation for accuracy.

The novelist and interviewer Nigel Farndale writes about Paul Johnson's claim last week that "playwrights do not bring farting on to the stage". Oh no, what sort of howler has my sane and rational friend committed now?

"Samuel Beckett has one of his tramps fart in Waiting for Godot (and the other one complains bitterly about it)," Mr Farndale points out. Still, not as bad as translating JFK's " ich bin ein Berliner " as "I am a hamburger".

 Turncoat of Turncoats voting is suspended while we investigate the 10 votes cast from nowhere yesterday for rank long shot Reg Race, one-time leading loony leftie turned arch Blairite sycophant. We will examine these votes over the weekend before deciding whether to count them or not.

 Young teenagers planning a terrorist attack on No 10 be warned. You may think you're a ringer for Euan, Nicholas or Kathryn Blair, but it won't be enough. Mustard keen, the Met has already posted pictures of the elder Blair offspring (Leo goes up the day he takes his first step) in the policeman's sentry box outside the house. They really don't miss a trick.

 In the Mail, Simon Heffer reports that the Suzanna Ffiennes portrait to mark his 40th birthday (40, eh? who would believe it?), mentioned here in January, is complete. When Marina rings, he repeats his claim that his wife forced him into it. But you do seem rather prone to being pressurised like this. "Well, the last one was 10 years ago, and Gail Lilley pressed me into that, so it's hardly a habit."

Not at all. Still, two in a decade ... "You mustn't say it's a habit. I mean, galleries aren't exactly queueing up to buy Heffer pictures." Nonsense. If you've got it, flaunt it. Any day the Brera gallery in Milan, where Simon is still feted as a catwalk model, will be bullying him for a third.

 After yesterday's report on David Montgomery's internet problems, we balance the scales by showing the net at its quickfire best. Serena, from qm4.com, has emailed me, the subject box declaring: "your quote request has been answered!" Tremendous. This will be about the car insurance inquiry I made last October. "We are happy to inform you that CT O'Brien General Insurance has responded with the following quote:" Ah well, early days. "We hope you are pleased with our service, and that we have saved you time and money."

webTitle: Livingstone: the verdict on the mayor's 1st year

fields.headline: And the verdict is...
fields.standfirst:
How the mayor has performed in three main policy areas

Special report: Livingstone's London
Live chat: Jonathan Freedland discusses Ken Livingstone's first year
fields.trailText: How the mayor has performed in three main policy areas.
fields.body:
Transport

Mayor Livingstone will mark today's anniversary by posing for photographers with some newly recruited Routemaster bus drivers, a symbol of one of his campaign pledges. Tube and bus fares have been frozen in real terms. There is a transport strategy and much consultation.

But London's roads are not noticeably less congested by cars or commercial vehicles, and improvements to bus lanes and reliability are painfully slow. Its trains - tube and suburban - remain notoriously unreliable.

Voters do not blame the mayor - not yet. For much of the year Mr Livingstone has been engaged in a very public battle with John Prescott and (behind the scenes) Gordon Brown over the financing and management of the tube's modernisation.

Most independent experts, the City and voters side with Mr Livingstone. But the mayor's trump card has been his appointment of Bob Kiley, the smooth-talking moderniser of New York and Boston's creaking subway systems, as his transport commissioner.

Mr Kiley's flair and expertise impresses most people (Tony Blair is yet to meet him), as does his claim that Labour's public-private partnership will replicate the worst of rail privatisation.

Mesmerised by their fear and dislike of Mr Livingstone, ministers keep digging themselves into a deeper hole as the mayor seeks a judicial review. A compromise should be possible. Meanwhile the tube - a vital artery for 1m travellers in the biggest chunk of Britain's economy - goes from bad to worse.

Congestion charging, the mayor's other big idea, is more or less on track for introduction at £5 a day in 2003-04 inside an inner zone from Marylebone Road to the Elephant and Castle via Tower and Vauxhall bridges. The technology to make it work, a video-based monitoring system, is said to be "better than expected". Consultation is under way.

The mayor wants to see new bus lanes, better contracts with the bus operators and improved key routes. There are more conductors. Taxis and minicabs are also being encouraged to provide better services at night. Free public transport for school trips has been restored.

Mr Livingstone backs new tube and cross-rail systems to ease congestion, and one - the Paddington to Liverpool Street link - got the go-ahead yesterday. It may be working by 2010.

The mayor's team is full of good ideas. "But they lack a hard edge. Many come from a legislative background, not a delivery background," said one close observer.

Verdict: Still gridlocked.

Crime

Whitehall circumscribed the mayor's powers, but he and his appointees do have real power over the new Metropolitan police authority with its £2bn budget. Typically of Mr Livingstone's new inclusive approach he gave Lord Harris, a veteran London politician, the chairman's job.

His big achievement has been to use the first London budget, negotiated down by the cross-party GLA, to find the money for 1,050 extra police - though, with retirement still running high, that will mean recruiting 2,500 officers.

The government's admission that pay and housing are a London police problem means an extra £6,000 a year for recruits. Falling numbers are finally being reversed.

Pressure to recruit ethnic officers (25% is London's target) and to improve relations with minority groups extends far beyond the mayor's office, as does the debate about stop and search.

The mayor's anti-crime agenda addresses fear of crime, especially among women and older people on the street at night. A consultation paper is looking at ways to protect women from domestic violence.

The mayor and the police seem determined not to fall out. Livingstone Mark II was equivocal about the tube strike, but backed the police against what his media machine called "anarchist violence by May Day Monopoly protesters" this week.

Verdict: Good ideas.

Jobs and the environment

The City is pleased with Mr Livingstone because he now backs tall office blocks. But his housing powers are limited. On Tuesday he will launch his "spatial development strategy". His team has plans for better air quality, a cycle network by 2004 and better recycling of rubbish - though progress so far has been disappointing.

On the jobs front the mayor has set up a London development agency headed by Mike Ward, an old GLC ally from the 80s, but with heavy-hitting outsiders (including Judith Mayhew from the City) on board. The buoyant London economy has helped him, though the coming City shake-out looks likely to hurt the capital.

Verdict: So far so good.

webTitle: Smear tests which failed to save lives

fields.headline: Smear tests which failed to save lives
fields.trailText: More than 3m women went to their GP for a smear test last year. The majority - 83.7% - of all women aged between 25 and 64 have been screened in the past five years. Most will have had a negative result and will think there is no chance they will develop cervical cancer.
fields.body:
More than 3m women went to their GP for a smear test last year. The majority - 83.7% - of all women aged between 25 and 64 have been screened in the past five years. Most will have had a negative result and will think there is no chance they will develop cervical cancer.

The Leicester exercise demonstrates that they are wrong. Cervical screening saves lives, but it does not save every life.

We have been told for a few years that a small number of cancers will inevitably be missed. If Leicester is typical of the rest of the country then that number may be larger than imagined. A third of the cervical cancers in Leicester over an eight year period were either missed or their severity was under- estimated, and 14 women died.

The sobering point about the Leicester audit is that it was not triggered by one of the regular scandals that break over cervical smear tests. It was not a damage limitation exercise, but a cool-headed audit by clinicians who are considered to run a good quality screening service.

They will not be making more errors than anyone else.

When a woman has a smear test, a sample of cells from the neck of the cervix is removed, smeared on to a slide, fixed with preservative and sent to the cytology laboratory to be examined.

But the slides are not always easy to read for the trained cytoscreeners employed in laboratories in hospitals around the UK. Sometimes abnormal cells can be missed among thousands of healthy ones and sometimes they are obscured. Adenocarcinoma, a form of cervical cancer that is increasing among young women, is particularly hard to spot. The task is a laborious and poorly remunerated one and some hospitals find it hard to recruit screeners.

If there is any doubt about a slide, the screener is supposed to refer it on to the consultant pathologist. But even where the procedures are correctly followed, some abnormalities will be missed.

The argument that has raged in courts after women have died is over what constitutes an acceptable miss. There are huge variations around the country in the proportion of slides reported as abnormal. Where women have sued, it is not unusual for both sides to bring in pathologists who disagree over whether the pre-cancerous cells are visible on the slide or not.

The biggest cervical cancer scandal of recent times broke at the Kent and Canterbury hospital in 1996 when the smear tests of 91,000 women were recalled, eight women died and 30 had hysterectomies. More than 50 compensation cases have been settled.

While the laboratory at the hospital was not up to standard, it does not follow that every missed cancer was down to poor practice. Faced with the anxieties of women around the country and the huge litigation bill, the Department of Health realised there was a need to change the perception of screening.

In December 1998, the then health minister, Lady Hayman, warned women that the smear test was like a seatbelt; it was not guaranteed to prevent you from dying but might help save your life or limit the damage in a car crash. Since the programme was set up in 1988, the coordinators said it had saved more than 8,250 lives. The incidence of cervical cancer dropped by 42% between 1988 and 1997 in England and Wales. Each year, they said, 1,300 women had cancer diagnosed and treated who without screening would have died. Women were called for screening every three to five years. In the US they are screened every year, but statistics show the increased cancer detection rate was only 2%.

Improvements in the detection rate will come about only through improved technology. The government last year launched a pilot scheme for liquid based cytology, a different way of preparing the slide which should make it easier to read.

It will also pilot screening for human papilloma virus which is sexually transmitted and present in 95% of cancer cases.

Cervical screening saves lives, but it does not save every life. We have been told for a few years that a small number of cancers will inevitably be missed. If Leicester is typical of the rest of the country then that number may be larger than imagined. A third of the cervical cancers in Leicester over an eight year period were either missed or their severity was under- estimated, and 14 women died. The sobering point about the Leicester audit is that it was not triggered by one of the regular scandals that break over cervical smear tests. It was not a damage limitation exercise, but a cool-headed audit by clinicians who are considered to run a good quality screening service. They will not be making more errors than anyone else. When a woman has a smear test, a sample of cells from the neck of the cervix is removed, smeared on to a slide, fixed with preservative and sent to the cytology laboratory to be examined. But the slides are not always easy to read for the trained cytoscreeners employed in laboratories in hospitals around the UK. Sometimes abnormal cells can be missed among thousands of healthy ones and sometimes they are obscured. Adenocarcinoma, a form of cervical cancer that is increasing among young women, is particularly hard to spot. The task is a laborious and poorly remunerated one and some hospitals find it hard to recruit screeners. If there is any doubt about a slide, the screener is supposed to refer it on to the consultant pathologist. But even where the procedures are correctly followed, some abnormalities will be missed. The argument that has raged in courts after women have died is over what constitutes an acceptable miss. There are huge variations around the country in the proportion of slides reported as abnormal. Where women have sued, it is not unusual for both sides to bring in pathologists who disagree over whether the pre-cancerous cells are visible on the slide or not. The biggest cervical cancer scandal of recent times broke at the Kent and Canterbury hospital in 1996 when the smear tests of 91,000 women were recalled, eight women died and 30 had hysterectomies. More than 50 compensation cases have been settled. While the laboratory at the hospital was not up to standard, it does not follow that every missed cancer was down to poor practice. Faced with the anxieties of women around the country and the huge litigation bill, the Department of Health realised there was a need to change the perception of screening. In December 1998, the then health minister, Lady Hayman, warned women that the smear test was like a seatbelt; it was not guaranteed to prevent you from dying but might help save your life or limit the damage in a car crash. Since the programme was set up in 1988, the coordinators said it had saved more than 8,250 lives. The incidence of cervical cancer dropped by 42% between 1988 and 1997 in England and Wales. Each year, they said, 1,300 women had cancer diagnosed and treated who without screening would have died. Women were called for screening every three to five years. In the US they are screened every year, but statistics show the increased cancer detection rate was only 2%. Improvements in the detection rate will come about only through improved technology. The government last year launched a pilot scheme for liquid based cytology, a different way of preparing the slide which should make it easier to read. It will also pilot screening for human papilloma virus which is sexually transmitted and present in 95% of cancer cases.

fields.headline: Ken's capital success
fields.standfirst: Ken Livingstone has had a busy week; what with the Mandela concert, anti-capitalist protests and the threat of industrial action on the tube. But after a year in office, how the first-ever London mayor governs the metropolis will still be judged on whether he can make the trains run on time, says Tony Travers
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has had a busy week; what with the Mandela concert, anti-capitalist protests and the threat of industrial action on the tube. But after a year in office, how the first-ever London mayor governs the metropolis will still be judged on whether he can make the trains run on time, says Tony Travers.
fields.body:
It has been a busy week in the capital. On Sunday night there was the Mandela concert in Trafalgar Square. Tuesday saw the Metropolitan Police confronting the anti-capitalist march in the West End.

Yesterday, yet another one-day tube strike was called off at the 11th hour. Tomorrow is the anniversary of the elections that brought Ken Livingstone back to power in London. Inevitably, the mayor's first year in office has proved an opportunity for reflection.

Media coverage has tended to sum up the mayor's first year by damning it with faint praise. The press probably feel cheated because Mr Livingstone has not lived up to his image as a left-wing circulation-booster.

True, some of the old instincts remain: he denounced as "the scum of capitalism" a number of the companies bidding to take over the underground's infrastructure. He has continued to support the striking tube workers even though the TUC has, in effect, abandoned them. He remains, very obviously, a politician of the left.

Yet he has also copied the politics of "inclusiveness" straight from the New Labour handbook. His advisory cabinet has been shaped by a desire to represent a wide range of views. He appointed his Tory and Liberal Democrat rivals to the board of Transport for London, business has fallen in love with his growth-with-compassion approach to planning, and his oft-expressed interest in tall buildings has soothed developers while aggravating the heritage lobby.

Most shocking for old-style Ken-watchers was the mayor's recent hard line against the threat of May Day rioters. Mr Livingstone threw his considerable political weight behind the police in their tactics to avoid a repeat of last year's chaos in London. New York's tough-guy mayor Rudy Giuliani would have been proud of the Livingstone approach. The city and its economy came first, while concerns about possible civil liberties infringements were brushed aside.

There can be no doubt that post-2000, Ken Livingstone is different from his GLC incarnation. Becoming the sole, elected, executive of the Greater London Authority has required political gravitas from a man who previously enjoyed his reputation as a gadfly and, often, a trouble-maker. In his dealings with the police, transport, planning and economic development he has emerged as an almost moderate figure.

His battle over the public-private partnership for the tube has pitted him against the government, though on an issue where much of the public and virtually all informed opinion is on his side. Congestion charging, which is likely to be the major innovation of his four-year term, also has a wide measure of support.

London cannot be said to have changed radically in the past year. But to be fair to the mayor and assembly, they have had to put together a new government system from scratch. In Scotland and Wales, a fully developed civil service already existed to operate the new machinery of government. In London, there was a small "transition team". The first year of the GLA has proved hard for the mayor and his office.

The rest of the country will look to the London model for lessons about regional government and/or mayors. The very least that can be said of the post-2000 London arrangements is that they have not failed. Londoners appear broadly content with their mayor, whether or not they fully understand what he is doing.

However, by this time next year they will surely expect some results from this experiment in devolved democracy. Coping with riots, strikes, celebrations and anniversaries is one thing. Getting the buses to run on time will surely prove more difficult.

 Tony Travers is head of the Greater London Group at the London School of Economics.
