fields.headline: Cancer test errors shock
fields.standfirst: Audit reveals one-third of cases may be missed
fields.trailText: The true scale of errors in the NHS cervical screening programme became clear yesterday as a routine audit showed that up to a third of women who go to their GP for regular smear tests may have cancers missed.
fields.body:
The true scale of errors in the NHS cervical screening programme became clear yesterday as a routine audit showed that up to a third of women who go to their GP for regular smear tests may have cancers missed.

The audit was carried out by Leicester Royal Infirmary, where standards of screening are as high as anywhere in the country. Yet a study of 324 women who developed cervical cancer despite regular screening found that 122 had been given at least one - and in some cases more than one - smear test result which was either negative or suggested a milder level of disease than was the case.

Fourteen women died and 64 had to have a radical hysterectomy because the nature of their cancer was not recognised.

Yesterday the national cancer director, Professor Mike Richards, acknowledged that what had happened in Leicester could be the pattern elsewhere."We can assume that around the rest of the country, there will be other cases where abnormalities on the same sort of scale were not picked up," he said.

But he and the cancer charities urged women not to boycott the programme, which saves around 1,300 lives a year. "It is a very successful programme in that there has been a marked decrease in deaths," he said. He praised Leicester for its honesty and openness, which he hoped other areas would imitate.

It was impossible, he said, to pick up 100% of cervical cancers through screening, which looks for pre-cancerous changes under the microscope in a sample of cells from the neck of the cervix. But without screening, more patients would have died and a lot more would have required radical treatment," he said.

The women in Leicester who had undergone avoidable hysterectomies and the relatives of those who died were told yesterday that their previous smear tests had been wrongly reported as negative. Julietta Patnick, co-ordinator of the national screening programme, said every woman who developed cervical cancer would in future be told if she had been the victim of a wrongly-read smear test, potentially opening the floodgates to more litigation.

Prof Richards said the deaths had been tragic, but Leicester's cervical screening service was not failing. "It performs well on all qualitative assurance measures, and death rates from cervical cancer are falling in line with national trends.

Ms Patnick said that audits like that in Leicester, which she hoped to see repeated round the country, could help scientists work out why cancers were being missed: "What we need to do is find out why these women who have had an adequate smear history go on to develop cervical cancer."

The audit studied 403 women who developed cervical cancer between 1993 and last year. Of those, 79 had not been for regular smears, and in 122 cases there had been an error in the way the screeners had reported the slide results. In 44 of the 122, there had been no adverse consequences - the cancer had been diagnosed soon afterwards. But the other 78 suffered a worsening of their condition before it was diagnosed, and 14 died.

The Imperial Cancer Research Fund and the Cancer Research Campaign urged women to continue to go for screening. "Though cervical screening may not be perfect, it is preventing many thousands of cancers," said Dr Peter Sasieni of the ICRF.

webTitle: Parliament cracks EU secrecy, but new access rules have big catches

fields.headline: Parliament cracks EU secrecy, but new access rules have big catches
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Citizens won the right to unprecedented access to EU documents yesterday after the European parliament ended years of argument by ratifying new rules on openness.
fields.body:
Citizens won the right to unprecedented access to EU documents yesterday after the European parliament ended years of argument by ratifying new rules on openness.

MEPs voted by a resounding 400 to 85 to back a bitterly fought - and still controversial - compromise between the union's 15 governments, the supranational European commission, and the parliament. The rules are now legally binding on EU institutions.

The British government, which had campaigned for greater access, gave its blessing: "This is a real step forward in making the EU more open and accountable," a spokesman said.

It was a well deserved victory for the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, Sweden, with its strong tradition of transparency, and a defeat for secretive France and Germany, which had resisted change.

"It creates a new right for the citizens of Europe," said a delighted Britta Lejon, the Swedish minister for democratic issues. "Citizens have a right confirmed by treaty to access these documents."

Freedom of information lobbyists complained that the agreement contained too many exemptions and should not have been negotiated behind closed doors.

"The call from civil society for an open, accountable and democratic Europe may have been ignored on this occasion but its case is stands unanswerered," said Tony Bunyan, of the London-based civil liberties group Statewatch. The European Federation of Journalists also opposed the measure in its present form.

In Brussels, the sheer complexity of issues is usually a bigger problem than secrecy, but even so, the agreement should usher in real change.

On this issue, said a commission insider, "the French and their cronies have been fighting a losing battle".

EU citizens were promised greater transparency in the 1997 Amsterdam treaty as a reaction to mounting popular frustration at opaque government and bureaucracy, especially in the policy-making council of ministers, where governments cooperate.

In 1995, the Guardian correspondent John Carvel spurred the process when he successfully sued the council in the European Court of Justice for breaking its own rules on access.

The new rules cover all categories of documents, including foreign policy and defence documents - a sensitive point as the EU seeks to reassure Nato that its new defence initiative will not compromise jealously guarded alliance secrets.

Under the rules, the institutions can block the release of documents if they are judged to violate secrecy rules, based on the principle that release could be "harmful". Secrecy can be invoked only to protect commercial interests, cases before a court or, more controversially, "to protect internal working material".

Documents can be kept secret for a maximum of 30 years.

If a document is only partly covered by a restriction, the rest of it must be released. Requests must be answered within 15 working days - faster than before. An appeal can be made to the EU ombudsman or the European court of justice if a request is refused. Non-EU citizens have the same rights regarding requests.

Heidi Hautala, leader of the Greens, who opposed the deal, said: "Members did not seize the opportunity to fill in the loopholes in the compromise, which still allow for considerable restrictions" by classifying documents as sensitive.

In general, all EU papers are to be entered into a register, including defence documents unless - a potentially significant catch - the register information is itself classified secret. All institutions must report annually to parliament.

Even so, "This is the beginning of a new era of openness and transparency in the EU," said Michael Cashman, the British Labour MEP who launched the legislation.

"This code turns a spotlight on Europe's institutions and opens them up to public scrutiny."

webTitle: Kim turns on the charm for EU team

fields.headline: Kim turns on the charm for EU team
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: North Korean's leader, Kim Jong-il, kept the process of detente alive yesterday by wooing the first European Union delegation to his country with a promise to maintain the country's moratorium on missile launches until 2003.
fields.body:
North Korean's leader, Kim Jong-il, kept the process of detente alive yesterday by wooing the first European Union delegation to his country with a promise to maintain the country's moratorium on missile launches until 2003.

He made enough positive noises in five hours of negotiations with the EU team to offset the gloom caused by the tougher stance towards Pyongyang recently taken by the US president, George Bush.

According to the Swedish prime minister, Goran Persson, Mr Kim reaffirmed his intention to take part in a return North-South summit in Seoul, which was meant to take place in March but has been delayed. He did not suggest a new date for the summit.

In keeping with his "pro-active" diplomacy first demonstrated at the North-South summit in Pyongyang last year, Mr Kim spent the morning in"frank and friendly", discussions which continued at a lunch banquet.

Wearing his characteristic beige jump-suit, he clinked huge glasses of French red wine with Mr Persson with characteristic gusto.

Mr Kim made it clear that the delay in the summit had been caused by unhappiness at the Bush administration's dislike of the dialogue started by Mr Clinton with Pyongyang. It was not, he said, due to any cooling of relations with Seoul.

Pyongyang is eager to take part in the summit, Mr Persson said, but is wary of the timing because the US is reviewing its policy.

EU officials were also pleased by the restatement of the 2003 missile moratorium date for the first time since Mr Bush took office; the US president's decision on missile defence earlier this week leans heavily on the alleged threat from North Korea and other "states of concern".

Mr Persson was given an oral message from Mr Kim to Mr Bush which he said shows "a willingness to continue the dialogue" with the US, but he warned that not too much should be read into it.

Entering new ground, the EU commissioner for external relations, Chris Patten, persuaded Mr Kim to agree to discussions on opening a dialogue on human rights with the EU. But there was no response to the suggestion that Pyongyang should accept a visit by the UN special rapporteur on human rights.

"This is going to be a long process," Mr Patten said. "But the important thing is to start the journey."

With North Korea still an almost completely closed society, any move to allow on-the-spot inquiries into human rights abuses seems very remote. Its officials are extremely wary of any foreign scrutiny but their heavy-handed tactics often encourage the "negative reports" about which they complain.

For instance, journalists accompanying the EU delegation on the second day of its visit were stopped from leaving their hotel to walk in the streets of Pyongyang. An attempt by one to keep an appointment at the office of the International Committee of the Red Cross was frustrated.

The EU visit was originally suggested to Sweden, the holders of the EU presidency, by South Korea's president, Kim Dae-jung, anxious that the peace process which he had initiated was grinding to a halt.

All but one of the EU's members already recognise North Korea or are in the process of doing so: an EU decision on its recognition is expected to be a formality.

However, officials in Pyongyang appear in no doubt that in the end it is the US which carries the most political and economic weight, and the EU mission has been at pains to deny that it is mediating between the two.

fields.headline: BSkyB to shut Open
fields.trailText: 8.30am: BSkyB is expected to announce next week the closure of its interactive shopping service, Open, amid mounting losses. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BSkyB is expected to announce next week that it will close its interactive shopping service, Open, amid mounting losses.

Open, which was set up to help subsidise BSkyB's digital equipment giveaway, is believed to have lost £116m in the six months to December 31.

In February, only 650,000 retail orders had been received through Open, a figure considered to be too small to generate viable revenues.

BSkyB will merge the company with its own new media interests. John Swingewood, the director of new media at BSkyB, is expected to leave the company.

The Open managing director, Jon Florsheim, is tipped to take over the running of the merged businesses.

Open was set up in 1998 by British Interactive Broadcasting, a consortium comprising BSkyB, BT, HSBC and Matsushita.

Last year BSkyB bought out HSBC and Matsushita.

BT, the only other remaining shareholder, is expected to exercise its right to take compensation for the holding in BSkyB shares.

webTitle: 27% of new HIV patients may be resistant to drugs

fields.headline: 27% of new HIV patients may be resistant to drugs
fields.trailText: More than a quarter of patients newly infected with HIV in Britain may be resistant to at least one of the powerful drugs used to fight the virus and Aids.
fields.body:
More than a quarter of patients newly infected with HIV in Britain may be resistant to at least one of the powerful drugs used to fight the virus and Aids.

A study of 69 patients diagnosed between 1994 and last autumn suggested that 14% of them possessed a mutation associated with drug resistance and the figure rose to 27% among those infected last year.

Although the incidence of Aids and death from HIV infection have declined rapidly in the UK since the introduction of anti-retroviral drugs in 1996, 3,000 people each year are still infected by the HIV virus. About 30,000 people in all are infected and there is concern at the apparent rise in high-risk sexual behaviour among homosexual men.

The study, reported in today's British Medical Journal, showed that 10 of the patients had a mutation of the virus indicating resistance to one of the three anti-retrovirals used in "last resort" cases and two appeared resistant to two drugs. Because they were new cases, none had started therapy.

Nine were men infected through sex between men and the other was a woman who was infected while injecting herself. The authors, members of a group monitoring transmission of HIV drug resistance, said no conclusions should be drawn from this. But as unprotected sex among those at highest risk continues, the likelihood of being infected by a patient who has taken anti-retrovirals increases.

webTitle: No one seems to love this government

fields.headline: No one seems to love this government
fields.standfirst: Returning from New Zealand, I look wonderingly at my old party
fields.trailText: Since I left British politics and the Labour shadow cabinet seven years ago I have applauded the election of a Labour government. Returning to Britain in the run-up to the coming election, however, is to confront a political mystery.
fields.body:
I left British politics and the Labour shadow cabinet seven years ago to return to my native New Zealand. Since then, I have applauded from afar the election of a Labour government and its achievements in office.

Returning to Britain in the run-up to the coming election, however, is to confront a political mystery. Everyone tells me that Labour will be re-elected by a wide margin, but - and here's the mystery - I can find virtually no one who likes the government, and that's just as true of traditional Labour supporters as it is of the Tory press.

How come a government that no one loves is such a sure fire winner? The answer to the puzzle is, I think, quite simple. There is a black hole in British politics - just where the Tory party used to be. Labour will win the election not because it is loved, but because there is no one else to vote for.

So Labour's hold on Number 10 seems secure for another five years. But think back to that heady night in 1997. Is re-election by default the best that we thought could be achieved with that massive majority? Wasn't Labour going to change the world - and Britain's place in it? And if it had done, wouldn't celebration rather than apathy be the prevailing mood?

So, how to restore enthusiasm for a re-elected Labour government? For a start, let's hear no more of New Labour. "New Labour" may have been touted by its now discredited architects as the essential deliverer of election victory in 1997, but they have found it more difficult to convince the country and the party about it in government.

For most people, "New Labour" remains an artificial construct, an ad man's slogan whose substance is difficult to grasp. Confused people do not have strong motivations to vote or to sustain a government with enthusiasm.

This time, let's have a Labour victory and a Labour government - one that is true to Labour values and that does not find it necessary to make obeisance to the citadels of power. Tony Blair and his cabinet should realise that, while the world has moved on inexorably, it has left behind not only what they choose to call old Labour but the free-market excesses with which they seem to have been preoccupied. It is no longer necessary - if it ever was - to look over the government's shoulder to the legacy of the long-gone days of Thatcherism.

The time has surely come to strike a new balance between public and private, commerce and community, the individual and society. It is time for Labour to recover its intellectual self-confidence - there is, after all, no longer any case for an inferiority complex in respect of a rightwing which is now intellectually bankrupt. Labour should approach the electorate with the confidence that its vision of society will be shared - as a matter of self-interest - by the majority of the voters.

Labour must recognise that politics is about hard choices. We would not have politics if interests did not conflict and competing claims were not made on limited resources. Every decision made by government will be contested by someone. It is not possible to make effective decisions without upsetting some people. The attempt to take the politics out of politics has failed.

Tony Blair must fight the election on the basis of the changes which the interests of the country demand. Some people - including some powerful interests - may not welcome those changes. He must make it clear that his second government will pursue his vision, and the interests of ordinary people, even if it means offending the powerful.

The impulse to compromise is not an ignoble one. Consensus rather than conflict is a proper goal of political action. But Labour (neither old nor New, but drawing on its traditional values and adapting them continuously to new and ever-changing circumstances) should fight the coming election and then govern on the basis that it will change the country for good.

And what about a government that has confidence in the British people for a change? One that trusts them enough to say that being British does matter and that the British - with all their glorious diversity - have a future which lies within their own hands and which they can build for themselves if they choose.

The task of government is not just to govern competently - we should be able to take that for granted. The real function of political leadership is to uplift and inspire the nation. In that respect, the British ruling class has failed the British people over a long period. A post-war leadership which lost confidence in itself transmitted that loss of confidence to the people as a whole. The last election gave Labour MPs the opportunity to change that. They didn't take it. It is their good fortune that they will get a second chance.

Bryan Gould's filmed report will be shown on Sunday's Channel 4 News at 7.10pm

fields.headline: Fixed-line fall rocks France Télécom
fields.trailText: France Télécom found itself out of favour with investors yesterday over concerns about the traditional fixed-line business, writes Mark Milner.
fields.body:
France Télécom found itself out of favour with investors yesterday - but over concerns about the traditional fixed-line business rather than mobile phones which have dogged the sector recently.

First-quarter sales figures showed the group's Orange mobile business powering ahead, and the consumer internet operation - including Britain's Freeserve - adding customers at a rapid rate.

However, fixed-line revenues have been hit by price cuts on national and international calls and by competitors continuing to nibble away at the group's market share.

Commenting on the figures, Michel Bon, the chairman and chief executive, said: "As expected, our expansion is being driven by our two primary growth engines - wireless and the consumer internet."

The market was less impressed. France Télécom shares fell more than 5% over the course of yesterday's trading. "The figures were less positive than we first thought," said one Paris trader. "It's because of the like-for-like fall in the fixed-line business and a change in accounting methods."

Overall, France Télécom's operating revenues soared 36.5% to €10bn (£6.21bn) compared with a year ago, helped by the acquisition of Orange in the UK last autumn. Revenues from the group's mobile phone operation in France, which was folded into Orange, were also up sharply - as were Orange operations outside France and the UK.

Orange France increased its number of customers by 38% to 15m, with just under 50% of the mobile-phone market, while Orange in the UK saw its customer base soar from 6m to 11m, but that was only sufficient to boost its market share from 24.5% to 25.4%.

The internet business brought in €290m over the quarter as Wanadoo in France increased its customer base by almost 70% compared with a year ago. With the addition of Freeserve, France Télécom's internet arm had some 4.94m active customers. Page traffic increased from 528m pages at the end of December to just over one billion in March.

The group said fixed-line, voice and data services in France increased 5.2% to €5bn but, after taking account of the way in which calls from fixed lines to mobiles were charged, revenues were down by 1.8% on a like-for-like basis.

"This slight decline was primarily due to revenues from fixed-line telephony, which decreased 7.3% on a comparable basis following the rate cuts for both domestic and international calls introduced last year," said the company.

One analyst at a French brokerage said: "Most of the rise [in revenues] is from Orange UK; organic growth is only 7.5% versus 8.1% a year earlier. A slowdown in fixed-line was expected and it doesn't change the outlook, but the market got a little nervous, having initially bought the shares on what looked like strong figures."

 Shares in Europe's largest internet service provider, T-Online, fell sharply yesterday after the company reported a first-quarter fall in revenue from its key advertising and e-commerce business.

T-Online, a subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom, said that revenue from such activities fell to €31.3m in the first quarter from €49m in the previous three months.

"I think that's disappointing. We had hoped for a little bit more," said Morten Andersen, an analyst with Deutsche Bank, which had forecast advertising and e-commerce revenues of €38m.

webTitle: SurfControl offers to rescue submerged options

fields.headline: SurfControl offers to rescue submerged options
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Employees at internet company SurfControl are being given the option to cash in worthless share options, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Hundreds of employees at internet company SurfControl are being given the option to cash in worthless share options and replace them with fewer, cheaper options which might stand a chance of showing a profit.

SurfControl, whose products monitor workplace web surfing, issued 4.2m share options to 350 workers and almost all of them are under water. The shares have fallen from £38.62 last year to 725p now.

The options are designed to motivate and retain staff.

SurfControl said staff could surrender their options and they would be reissued with an exercise price 20% above today's middle market closing price. Employees would receive 20% fewer new options.

"The people within SurfControl and the business as a whole have consistently exceeded expectations, but the worldwide decline in valuations of technology stocks has resulted in almost 85% of the options issued to employees having an exercise price significantly above the current market price," said Steve Purdham, chief executive officer.

Analysts welcomed the move, which was agreed with shareholders and will include existing performance targets.

"The company has exceeded every forecast but has suffered due to a derating of the sector. The scheme seems fair for shareholders and employees," one analyst said.

Last month the Cheshire-based company reported better than expected third quarter results.

fields.headline: BBC questions quality of 9pm programming
fields.trailText: Debate is growing within the BBC about the quality of programming replacing the old Nine O'Clock News. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The editor of the BBC's Ten O'Clock News has added to the growing debate within the corporation about of the quality of programming replacing the old Nine O'Clock News.

Jonathan Baker, who leaves his position after the election, told the BBC's staff magazine that the scheduling preceding the programme needed more consistency.

"At the moment the programmes leading into the news are not consistently there," he said.

Newsreader Peter Sissons and the BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, have admitted the channel will not see the real "magic" in programming until the autumn.

Mr Baker, who will become world news editor after the expected June general election, said he expected the BBC's controversial switch to the 10pm slot to be vindicated as soon as the corporation's strategy "comes good."

A BBC spokesman said the new BBC1 programme schedule under the channel's controller, Lorraine Heggessey, will boost the bulletin's viewing figures.

"We assume that when the schedule strengthens, it will have a positive result for the bulletin," he said.

The 9pm window is seen as a key factor in the BBC's ongoing battle with ITV over the 10pm news slot, which the independent network is currently winning.

The BBC bulletin has averaged 5.1m viewers from its debut in October last year, while ITV has averaged 6m with its News at Ten programme.

However, the BBC has shown signs of improvement in the all-important 9pm slot, with its audience share rising from 23.7% to 26.3% over the past 12 months.

But the good news has been tempered by the end of big hits such as One Foot in the Grave and the Royle Family, and ITV has seen its dominance of the slot increase to a 35% share.

fields.headline: Labour to challenge 'fatcat' barristers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Labour will move against "fatcat" lawyers in a second term, it emerged last night, with plans being drawn up to implement recommendations from a report by the office of fair trading which criticised barristers' anti-competitive practices.
fields.body:
Labour will move against "fatcat" lawyers in a second term, it emerged last night, with plans being drawn up to implement recommendations from a report by the office of fair trading which criticised barristers' anti-competitive practices.

Ministers are said to want to encourage firms to employ both barristers and solicitors, and to introduce more criminal justice reform. One was quoted as describing lawyers as "the last bastion of restrictive practices".

Tony Blair, whose wife Cherie Booth is a QC, is said to be personally committed to reform.

The government has already introduced extensive legal reforms and figures released by the Lord Chancellor's Department yesterday showed that the cost of civil legal aid had fallen from £1.3bn in 1998-99 to a forecast £1bn this year. The growth in criminal legal aid spending is also slowing.

The barristers' trade union, the Bar Council, is retaliating against the cuts in legal aid by changing its rules. Barristers, who have formerly been obliged to take any case in their area of expertise unless there was a conflict of interest, are now allowed to refuse cases if the fee is deemed unreasonable.

This gives the green light in areas like family law for senior lawyers to refuse to accept legal aid cases where the fees do not reflect their experience, and many predict a two-tier service developing with only junior lawyers taking legal aid cases.

webTitle: BBC Today programme, a hotbed of Euroscepticism

fields.headline: BBC Today programme, a hotbed of Euroscepticism
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: The Tories may delight in criticising Radio 4's Today programme as a hotbed of radicalism, but a poll of the programme's staff has revealed a majority support the party's "keep the pound" message.
fields.body:
The Tories may delight in criticising Radio 4's Today programme as a hotbed of radicalism, but a poll of the programme's staff has revealed a majority support the party's "keep the pound" message.

In an attempt to rebut the claims by the Tory party chairman, Michael Ancram, that the BBC is "empty of people who hold Conservative views", Today's editor, Rod Liddle, questioned staff about their political persuasions.

The results show that 35.7% of those polled supported Labour, which Mr Liddle said was about 10 points down on their national poll standing.

Mr Liddle conducted the poll in response to a letter written by Mr Ancram to the BBC, in which he complained that the corporation was broadly biased against the Tories.

According to the results, 50% of Today staff approved of "lower taxes", 66% were in favour of "smaller government", while 60% believed in "saving the pound". Mr Liddle conceded in an article for the Spectator that the poll was "more than vulnerable to editorial gerrymandering".

Mr Liddle admitted several mistakes: that the Eurosceptic cause was underplayed at the time of the last elections to the European parliament; that the programme was too ready to use the expression "strong pound" instead of "weak euro" when reporting problems faced by the British manufacturing sector; and that it occasionally followed the agenda set by newspapers.

fields.headline: A cut above
fields.standfirst: Lord Stevenson says hairdressers shouldn't be made people's peers as they might not feel 'comfortable' in the House of Lords.  Ros Coward  took celebrity snipper Nicky Clarke along to test out the theory
fields.trailText: Lord Stevenson says hairdressers shouldn't be made people's peers as they might not feel 'comfortable' in the House of Lords.  Ros Coward  took celebrity snipper Nicky Clarke along to test out the theory.
fields.body:
Another New Labour attempt at populism has gone awry. Criticised for the predictably safe, middle-class list of people's peers, Lord Stevenson compounded the crime by saying that they could not select people, like hairdressers, who would be uncomfortable in the Lords. Roy Hattersley, suitably appalled, responded in Monday's Guardian. The people's peers ought to be real people like hairdressers, he said, and gallantly offered to acclimatise a couple.

Nicky Clarke, celebrity hairdresser and business man, was recognised instantly when I went with him to the house of Lords yesterday. "Come to do someone's hair?" a security man asked. Policemen recognised him. The public asked for his autograph. Tony Blair would hardly have got a more deferential reaction. Clarke laughs at the idea of being acclimatised. "I don't claim to be au fait with the day-to-day workings of the House of Lords, but I am their social equal. I don't need acclimatising. Quite a few politicians are my customers. I've been a fair few times to No 10 and No 11. I've got aristocrats and royalty for customers."

His glamorous lifestyle, regularly documented on the pages of Hello!, his A-list clientele, his extensive business interests and his Mayfair salon shout loud and clear that in new Britain, hairdressing ain't what it used to be.

Politicians on both sides have grasped enough of these changes to seek out a celebrity hairdresser when it comes to personal preening. "At one time," says Clarke, "I was styling for both Margaret Thatcher and John Smith's wife." But when it comes to social geography, the old snobbery prevails. "They think that if you have your hand on the outside of someone else's head, you've got nothing in your own."

Historically, those who service other people's bodies are viewed with contempt. "I'm not surprised by the snobbery," says Clarke. "I've heard it all before. My answer is that hairdressing requires a lot of skill, not just the talent for cutting but also social skills, and skills to run a successful business."

Among professionals such as Lord Stevenson, this has not sunk in. Most would react as, I confess, I did the other day when my daughter said she wanted to be a hairdresser - I vowed silently that it would be over my dead body. Hairdressing is still seen as a dead end job. "As in all cliches, there's some truth," says Clarke. "A lot of girls still do go in for it because they can't think of anything else to do. It still has a camp side, with gay men who think this is the only place to express a more creative, feminine side. But there have been great changes. There are lots of business opportunities now; teaching, lecturing, doing hair for films or staging demonstrations which are like putting on theatre shows. Not to mention the opportunities for your own product business. It's far from dead end."

Clarke is living proof of a social earthquake that has happened apparently off the radar of the people's peers appointment committee. A business man with a multimillion pound turn-over, a friend and confidant of popstars, politicians and royalty, he was brought up in Elephant & Castle (one of six children) by an English father and a Greek mother. "I come from a relatively simple south London council estate background. But we all went to grammar schools and were all pushed into trying to do well. I'm not ashamed of my background at all. In fact I'm proud of it, but it doesn't mean that you don't want to achieve more ".

If the Lords are tempted to mobilise another stereotype about a workingclass boy making good, they should look at his high-achieving siblings. His brother Michael van Clarke is another celebrity hairdresser with a similarly grand client list. Their sister, Norma Clarke, a feminist historian, has just written Johnson's Women, an erudite and well-received book on the 18th century. Both Michael and Nicky are selling the book in their salons. The Clarke clan holding court at the book launch at Dr Johnson's house, provided an uncanny echo of the 18th-century world of male display, Nicky's bouffant hair a modern equivalent of the powdered wig.

Members of the Lords, such as Stevenson, appear to have no grasp of the economic transformation of lower-order servicing into serious business. It is not surprising. Looking down from the public gallery yesterday, Clarke whispered: "I like all this, the sense of tradition and ritual. It's unique. But, let's face it, most of the members look as if they are from the shires. My world just isn't represented and in a democracy its only right and fair that it should be."

Would he have anything to contribute on the subjects up for discussion yesterday: the sale of the dome and private financing of the tube? "Sure. With the Wembley fiasco, I'd like them to look seriously at developing the dome as a sports venue. All the infrastructure's there. With the tube, for safety reasons, they should leave it in public ownership. We need good public transport. It's London's lifeblood."

Increasingly, MPs come from a narrow range of professions - Tories mainly from law and management, Labour from unions and teaching. Many of Blair's new MPs were effectively professional politicians, fresh from student politics or party activism, hardly representing modern Britain's diversity.

People's peers and the reformed House of Lords were meant to provide a check and balance to the commons, and this required a different kind of membership: people from the new service industries, people with different social connections, people with a different perspective on modern life. Instead the people's peer initiative brought in exactly the sort of people you would find in the New Year's honours list. Surely it is long overdue for their lordships to find "one's tailor" or "one's hairdresser" speaking as an equal in debates?

fields.headline: Arch rivals who cannot get away from each other
fields.standfirst:
Radical steals New Labour clothes to prove point

Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Darth Vader and Obi Wan-Kenobi may be sworn enemies - but both were once disciples of the same faith. And so it is with Ken Livingstone and Tony Blair.
fields.body:
In the world of comic books and super-heroes, the champion of good and his evil arch-rival should be more similar than either likes to realise. Darth Vader and Obi Wan-Kenobi may be sworn enemies - but both were once disciples of the same faith.

And so it is with Ken Livingstone and Tony Blair. Several critics have already noticed the echoes of New Labour resonating from the man who became London's first elected mayor one year ago today. Mr Livingstone uses PR consultants, flatters business and boasts of his zero tolerance of crime (including the "hooligans" who staged this week's May Day protests) - just like Mr Blair.

But, as an interview soon proves, Mr Livingstone has not forgotten the second half of the comic book convention. He may share some of New Labour's traits - but he remains their adversary.

Start with the biggest similarity of all. The mayor has used his first year the way Mr Blair has used his first term: to prove he can be competent in office. During his long, wilderness years on the backbenches, Mr Livingstone would tell anyone who would listen that what he really likes is running things. He missed the executive life snatched from him by Margaret Thatcher's abolition of the Greater London Council. For 14 years, he pined for something to be in charge of. And now he has it.

"Anything done here is my responsibility," he says proudly, surveying the vast office he occupies just a short walk from the Commons. This is not the pokey cubby hole of the rebel MP, but the lair of a chief executive - complete with state of the art ergonomic office chairs and blondwood desk.

He may ride the tube into work, but he commands a substantial bureaucracy - which suits him just fine. And, if you have not heard much from Ken for the last 12 months, that is because he has been getting the machine started. His goal has been not to cock things up.

"In all these assessments of the first year, no one's assessed all the things that didn't go wrong that could have," he said.

He noted that London did not repeat the crisis that once struck Los Angeles, when the mayor and police commissioner refused to talk to each other. He reckoned the Met was nervous about working with an elected mayor - but that both sides now had "confidence and trust" in each other. He had done his bit, not only by supporting the police tactics to quell the May Day protests but also by using the extra amount he is allowed to add to Londoners' council tax to pay for 1,050 new officers.

These are the things Livingstone boasts about: the evidence that he, whose mayoralty Mr Blair warned would be a "disaster for London," is quietly getting on with the job. But is this not a little humdrum? Can competence be the goal of Red Ken, the radical who once seemed determined to change the world? Is that the best the left can hope for these days, to be competent managers?

Lost generation

Do not knock it, said Livingstone. "It's why we lost for a generation, because the left weren't trusted to run things. We'd become arrogant and wasteful and we always preferred to raise people's taxes rather than make difficult choices. In the end they trusted Thatcher and Reagan to spend their money more than us."

But that, too, sounds suspiciously New Labour. Plenty in Gordon Brown's Treasury said the same thing - that they had to be prudent to restore public trust in government. Is not this the same?

Not quite. For Livingstone's plan is not to rehabilitate the reputation of New Labour, but the reputation of the left. This, said his allies, was what so scared Downing Street: not that he would fail London, but that he might succeed. If he proved that a left alternative could not only win elections but govern successfully and be re-elected, then he would have undermined the entire Blairite project -premised on the belief that only by moving rightward could Labour ever flourish.

Of course the conflict takes more obvious forms: the war for the tube. Mr Livingstone cited his appointment of Bob Kiley, credited with rescuing the New York subway and the Boston T, as the proudest achievement of his first year "because he gives Londoners hope of having a decent Tube system".

Mr Kiley is also the mayor's most potent weapon in his campaign to halt the government's plans for public/private partnership or PPP. "In appointing Kiley I've got someone who knows what he's talking about and who can see through all the cobblers."

Just as transport defined his campaign, Mr Livingstone became more animated on this than any other subject. Put to him a summary version of Brown's argument for PPP - that Labour's plan would force the private contractors, not the taxpayer, to foot the bill if their costs overrun - and he was ready with a fusillade."Nothing like the underground will ever see risk wholly transferred to the private sector. They can always walk away - but the public sector has to make it work."

Mr Livingstone reckoned guarantees from private companies were worthless: they would cover themselves by charging more up front. "The sticking point is safety. You're taking a maintenance staff of 7,000 and splitting it into four separate groups - with bizarre divisions."

But what can Mr Livingstone do? If he loses his court action against the government, will he resign? "Nahhhh. You'd do your best to make it work," just like he did when he stayed running the GLC, even after Mrs Thatcher had abolished it. But, he predicted, PPP would not work. "It will be down to luck. How long before someone dies? And if it's 20 or 30 people then there'll be something like the Scott inquiry and it will declare that this system is wrong."

He had some other strategies. He had heard the talk that the Labour manifesto would promise a renaissance of local government: "I want to be player in that debate." He imagined a new act of parliament, establishing regional assemblies for England - and he would like a few amendments giving him more powers in London. He would like housing and the arts to come under him - and, eventually, the right to raise his own revenue. He said he was determined to leave the job with more powers than when he started.

And what of his own future? He said he was focused only on doing the job well, but Ken Livingstone is all politics. Mid-conversation he asked his secretary to print some private polling he commissioned from Mori. He is a point up from his landslide last year. He is chuffed that support for his congestion charge plan increased by 16 points when voters heard that it was "Ken's scheme."

And what about the Labour party? "I'm told that divorce is more painful after one month than it is after 13 months." In other words, he is getting over it. "I'd like to be back in - and I really miss my constituency." Did he think Labour would have him back in time to seek re-election as the Labour candidate for mayor? "If in 18 months I've still got the poll ratings I've got now, they'll have me back again. If I haven't, they'll ask 'Who should we run against the sod'?"

What of his own ambitions? "Perhaps Tony will want me to do something else - it's purely a decision for Tony." In other words, Livingstone saw his career hanging on the largesse of the prime minister. What can he be thinking of? He cannot be brought into the cabinet easily, not now he is giving up his parliamentary seat.

It all seems so fanciful, not least because the Livingstone camp once used to speak of the London mayoralty as the foundation for a new left movement, a potential rival to New Labour in England much as the SNP or Plaid Cymru are in Scotland and Wales. That talk seems to have vanished. Now "it's purely a decision for Tony." Like comic book rivals, these two just cannot get away from each other.

This is not the pokey cubby hole of the rebel MP, but the lair of a chief executive - complete with state of the art ergonomic office chairs and blondwood desk. He may ride the tube into work, but he commands a substantial bureaucracy - which suits him just fine. And, if you have not heard much from Ken for the last 12 months, that is because he has been getting the machine started. His goal has been not to cock things up. "In all these assessments of the first year, no one's assessed all the things that didn't go wrong that could have," he said. He noted that London did not repeat the crisis that once struck Los Angeles, when the mayor and police commissioner refused to talk to each other. He reckoned the Met was nervous about working with an elected mayor - but that both sides now had "confidence and trust" in each other. He had done his bit, not only by supporting the police tactics to quell the May Day protests but also by using the extra amount he is allowed to add to Londoners' council tax to pay for 1,050 new officers. These are the things Livingstone boasts about: the evidence that he, whose mayoralty Mr Blair warned would be a "disaster for London," is quietly getting on with the job. But is this not a little humdrum? Can competence be the goal of Red Ken, the radical who once seemed determined to change the world? Is that the best the left can hope for these days, to be competent managers? Lost generation Do not knock it, said Livingstone. "It's why we lost for a generation, because the left weren't trusted to run things. We'd become arrogant and wasteful and we always preferred to raise people's taxes rather than make difficult choices. In the end they trusted Thatcher and Reagan to spend their money more than us." But that, too, sounds suspiciously New Labour. Plenty in Gordon Brown's Treasury said the same thing - that they had to be prudent to restore public trust in government. Is not this the same? Not quite. For Livingstone's plan is not to rehabilitate the reputation of New Labour, but the reputation of the left. This, said his allies, was what so scared Downing Street: not that he would fail London, but that he might succeed. If he proved that a left alternative could not only win elections but govern successfully and be re-elected, then he would have undermined the entire Blairite project -premised on the belief that only by moving rightward could Labour ever flourish. Of course the conflict takes more obvious forms: the war for the tube. Mr Livingstone cited his appointment of Bob Kiley, credited with rescuing the New York subway and the Boston T, as the proudest achievement of his first year "because he gives Londoners hope of having a decent Tube system". Mr Kiley is also the mayor's most potent weapon in his campaign to halt the government's plans for public/private partnership or PPP. "In appointing Kiley I've got someone who knows what he's talking about and who can see through all the cobblers." Just as transport defined his campaign, Mr Livingstone became more animated on this than any other subject. Put to him a summary version of Brown's argument for PPP - that Labour's plan would force the private contractors, not the taxpayer, to foot the bill if their costs overrun - and he was ready with a fusillade."Nothing like the underground will ever see risk wholly transferred to the private sector. They can always walk away - but the public sector has to make it work." Mr Livingstone reckoned guarantees from private companies were worthless: they would cover themselves by charging more up front. "The sticking point is safety. You're taking a maintenance staff of 7,000 and splitting it into four separate groups - with bizarre divisions." But what can Mr Livingstone do? If he loses his court action against the government, will he resign? "Nahhhh. You'd do your best to make it work," just like he did when he stayed running the GLC, even after Mrs Thatcher had abolished it. But, he predicted, PPP would not work. "It will be down to luck. How long before someone dies? And if it's 20 or 30 people then there'll be something like the Scott inquiry and it will declare that this system is wrong." He had some other strategies. He had heard the talk that the Labour manifesto would promise a renaissance of local government: "I want to be player in that debate." He imagined a new act of parliament, establishing regional assemblies for England - and he would like a few amendments giving him more powers in London. He would like housing and the arts to come under him - and, eventually, the right to raise his own revenue. He said he was determined to leave the job with more powers than when he started. And what of his own future? He said he was focused only on doing the job well, but Ken Livingstone is all politics. Mid-conversation he asked his secretary to print some private polling he commissioned from Mori. He is a point up from his landslide last year. He is chuffed that support for his congestion charge plan increased by 16 points when voters heard that it was "Ken's scheme." And what about the Labour party? "I'm told that divorce is more painful after one month than it is after 13 months." In other words, he is getting over it. "I'd like to be back in - and I really miss my constituency." Did he think Labour would have him back in time to seek re-election as the Labour candidate for mayor? "If in 18 months I've still got the poll ratings I've got now, they'll have me back again. If I haven't, they'll ask 'Who should we run against the sod'?" What of his own ambitions? "Perhaps Tony will want me to do something else - it's purely a decision for Tony." In other words, Livingstone saw his career hanging on the largesse of the prime minister. What can he be thinking of? He cannot be brought into the cabinet easily, not now he is giving up his parliamentary seat. It all seems so fanciful, not least because the Livingstone camp once used to speak of the London mayoralty as the foundation for a new left movement, a potential rival to New Labour in England much as the SNP or Plaid Cymru are in Scotland and Wales. That talk seems to have vanished. Now "it's purely a decision for Tony." Like comic book rivals, these two just cannot get away from each other.

fields.headline: Livingstone's good start
fields.standfirst:
But he must win the battle for the tube

Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Londoners with a taste for drama may feel a tad disappointed. After all, did not the prime minister and half the cabinet warn that victory for Ken Livingstone would be a "disaster for London"?
fields.body:
Londoners with a taste for drama may feel a tad disappointed. After all, did not the prime minister and half the cabinet warn that victory for Ken Livingstone would be a "disaster for London"? Did they not predict a cataclysmic return to the dark days of the 80s? Yet what has happened? Mr Livingstone's first year in office, which he marks today, has not been one of chaos and civic breakdown - but an almost anticlimactic period of quiet. The mayor has arrived and the sky has not fallen in; things have carried on much as they were.

For some this is a let-down. They liked the Ken of old, with his knack for controversy and attention-grabbing stunts. They find it hard to get used to a once Red Ken who works to get more money for the police and supports their clampdown on this week's May Day protests. But the mayor himself, as he explains in the interview we publish today, sees all this as vindication. He is grateful for the verdict of LSE local government expert, Tony Travers, who declares the first few months of the Greater London assembly "a miracle of competent administration". If Londoners are finding things quiet, that is fine by him. His first objective was to prove Mr Blair wrong - to get the new, devolved machinery up and running and to show that a Livingstone mayoralty was no "disaster".

Beyond that, what is the record? The mayor has some small achievements he can be proud of. He is beginning to get conductors back on buses, the proper policing of bus lanes will begin soon and his initiative for free travel for school trips has captured Londoners' imagination. He has not lost his touch for the symbolic gesture either. His planned pedestrianisation of Trafalgar Square is popular (even if his war on the pigeons is more divisive). Last Sunday's concert for Nelson Mandela was, he says, the first of many in the square. Meanwhile, his denial of planning permission for a luxury apartment block sought by Mohammed Al Fayed - on the grounds that it did not include enough affordable accommodation - has won plaudits.

If these feel like admirable, but small triumphs that is partly because of the limited authority granted to the mayoralty. But that record also omits the chief area of Mr Livingstone's activity: the battle to prevent the partial privatisation of the underground. This was the central plank of his winning platform and he has stuck doggedly to it. He is right to name as his most significant achievement the hiring of Bob Kiley as his transport boss. Mr Kiley's experience rescuing subway systems in the US has made the Livingstone case impossible to sweep aside: put simply, Mr Kiley has more credibility on this topic than either John Prescott or Gordon Brown.

These facts about the last year dictate the shape of the next three. They show that the mayor's most crucial task is to win the battle for the tube. As we argued earlier this week, the government's plan for the underground is wrongheaded and its pursuit is fast becoming dogmatic. Mr Livingstone is right to take his case to court and we hope he wins - unless Labour sees sense and cuts a deal.

But the parallel challenge of the rest of the term is to win the greater powers the mayor and assembly need to do their jobs properly. There are many odds and ends - arts and housing, for example - which ought to come under London's strategic authority. We wish Mr Livingstone well, less for his sake than for the devolution project itself. For if he can show it works in London, then Labour may be encouraged to devolve yet more power to the cities and regions of Britain.

webTitle: Cook defends policy on US shield

fields.headline: Cook defends policy on US shield
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Robin Cook was yesterday forced to defend the government's "wait-and-see" attitude towards American hopes to build an anti-missile defence shield in the face of almost unanimous disapproval among friends and foes around the world.
fields.body:
Robin Cook was yesterday forced to defend the government's "wait-and-see" attitude towards American hopes to build an anti-missile defence shield in the face of almost unanimous disapproval among friends and foes around the world.

After the overnight row over allegedly policy making remarks made by Alastair Campbell, the Downing Street press secretary, the foreign secretary had to answer an emergency Commons question to stress that the government has made no decision on whether to endorse US plans for President Bush's "son of star wars" concept.

"Our answer is not inevitable," Mr Cook told the Commons in a statement demanded by his Conservative shadow, Francis Maude, who has made effective use of disarray in Labour's ranks over both Mr Campbell's role and ill-ease about the missile shield. While recognising what he called "a growing challenge of missile proliferation", the foreign secretary - privately known to be extremely sceptical about the US plan - said the technology for missile defence would take years to develop.

With Labour MPs, including Tony Benn and Peter Kilfoyle, both warning against the risks to global stability, and Ryedale Tory, John Greenway, worrying about the impact of upgrading radars at Fylingdales in his Yorkshire constituency, Mr Cook was also forced to assure MPs that no interceptor missiles will be stationed in Britain or anywhere in Europe - at least not under current US plans.

Washington has yet to confirm what technical option to pursue, he reminded MPs. "Nor do we yet know the diplomatic context to any final decision, such as the potential for agreement with Russia," he said amid repeated Tory jeers and cries of "What about Alastair?"

On what would have been election day Mr Maude had accused Mr Blair of deliberate equivocation during Wednesdaty's question time in contrast to Mr Campbell's later exchanges with reporters.

Mr Blair said it was "important and right that we wait for a firm proposal before giving a firm decision". Asked later whether Mr Blair thought the missile defence plan was a good idea, Mr Campbell replied: "Broadly, yes", though he went on to qualify his remark.

fields.headline: Crouching Tigers, hidden war
fields.standfirst: Suppression of news about Sri Lanka's violent conflict helps neither government nor guerrillas
fields.trailText: Of the roughly three dozen armed conflicts under way around the world, only a handful get attention and even then it is spasmodic rather than sustained.
fields.body:
Satellite uplinks bring live TV pictures of street battles in Gaza and the West Bank into our homes, but the march of technology has not reduced the volatility of editorial decision-making on foreign issues. Of the roughly three dozen armed conflicts under way around the world, only a handful get attention and even then it is spasmodic rather than sustained.

Top place in this league of unreported wars surely goes to the struggle between the Sri Lankan government and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) who want their own homeland. Close to 300 troops were killed in a single battle last week.

Armies tend to inflate their claims of enemy dead and underplay their own, but here was the government acknowledging the loss of 221 men, while the Tigers admitted losing 75.

Internet surfers could find these figures in despatches filed by Colombo-based reporters for the international wire services, but they did not make their way into many newspapers or TV bulletins, even though the army offensive which produced these casualties was not only colossal (and futile) in military terms but significant politically. It marked the end of a four-month ceasefire, threatening the start of another bloody chapter in a conflict already in its 18th year.

Yet blame for this war's lack of coverage does not rest mainly with journalists. It lies with the Sri Lankan government which runs the tightest censorship in the world, at least for a functioning democracy. When troops wounded Marie Colvin of the Sunday Times as she made the perilous illegal crossing out of Tiger-held territory last month, her bravery reminded people that no reporter has been allowed near the front lines, let alone to cross them, for almost six years. This wretched phenomenon of "crouching Tiger, hidden war" equally restricts Sri Lankan journalists who are invariably denied permission to reach the area.

A few independent reports from Tiger-controlled territories emerge via aid organisations. They tell of great hardship for more than 300,000 displaced Tamils, living without permanent shelter and suffering from a government-imposed embargo which limits medical supplies and kerosene. But they also speak of growing disillusionment with the LTTE which taxes the few supplies which enter or insists they are sold in its own shops at high prices. The Tigers still recruit children as young as 12.

On the government side there are repeated accounts of people "disappearing" or being tortured while held under the repressive emergency regulations brought in last year. Sri Lanka is second to Iraq in unexplained disappearances. Although most of the 12,000 cases precede President Chandrika Kumaratunga's election in 1994, at least 540 have happened in her time.

Her government has also failed to act against security officials named in commissions of inquiry, some of whom remain in high places. One hope is a peace mission by Erik Solheim, a Norwegian facilitator, which is modelled on the Oslo process which got Israel and the Palestinians together.

Earlier talks soon after Kumaratunga took power collapsed because they were hasty, personalised, and unprepared. The new approach is snail-like and by involving a third party may produce more. Solheim is trying to inject a vital human rights component into what is otherwise an elite diplomatic affair by persuading the government to relax its embargo.

The government has made concessions but its failure to respond to the ceasefire was disappointing, even though the Tigers halted the appalling atrocities of suicide bombing in Colombo and other southern cities. But the concept of "talking while fighting" is still upheld by both sides, and neither has repudiated the Solheim process.

Another cause for hope is that Sri Lanka's vibrant civil society has not been silenced or split into ethnic laagers by the war. Independent bodies such as the National Peace Council have Sinhalese and Tamil representation and, even after the worst bombings, reprisals were not taken by Sinhalese civilians on Tamils. The Tigers appear willing to accept something short of independence for their homeland and almost every Tamil politician who stands for non-violence has come out in support of the Tigers' right to sit down as an equal party with the government. Even the main Tamil party, the Tamil United Liberation Front, which lost a valued MP, Neelan Thiruchelvam to a presumed Tiger bomb in 1999, acknowledges the Tigers as the Tamils' main representative in the Solheim process and the talks which should flow from it.

Like all wars, this one has profiteers. Most people in Colombo are convinced the defence ministry and army command are full of men who take backhanders from the huge arms purchases of recent years. Kumaratunga has a hard task, but it would be easier if she opened the war and its devastating human impact, as well as the business deals which prolong it, to the scrutiny of the Sri Lankan and foreign press. She should also ensure that those already named for human rights abuse or corruption are made to resign and face the courts.

 Martin Woollacott is away

fields.headline: 'Brave' choice of prisons inspector praised
fields.trailText: A leading human rights expert, Anne Owers, was yesterday named by the home secretary, Jack Straw, as the surprise successor to Sir David Ramsbotham as chief inspector of prisons.
fields.body:
A leading human rights expert, Anne Owers, was yesterday named by the home secretary, Jack Straw, as the surprise successor to Sir David Ramsbotham as chief inspector of prisons.

Penal reformers praised Ms Owers's appointment, saying her respected campaigning record over the past 20 years, particularly on refugees and reform of the criminal justice system, proved she would bring the independence of mind needed to resist ministerial interference. She will take up the job in August.

The appointment of Ms Owers as the first female chief inspector prompted comparisons with Elizabeth Fry, the 19th century Quaker whose prison inspections led to better conditions across Europe.

She follows in the footsteps of Sir David and Sir Stephen Tumim who both clashed with home secretaries over their critical reports. Some critics had feared that Mr Straw would prune the powers of the chief inspector of prisons, but Ms Owers's appointment and unchanged terms of reference dispelled those anxieties.

Ms Owers, 53, is the director of Justice, the all-party human rights and law reform organisation, in which job she has repeatedly expressed concern about Mr Straw's criminal justice policy. She played a key role on the government task force overseeing implementation of its human rights law, and also served on the commission on the future of multiethnic Britain.

Ms Owers said: "I am not just interested in what happens to people in prison but also what happens to them afterwards."

Frances Crook, director of the Howard League for Penal Reform, welcomed the appointment, saying Ms Owers had great integrity. "It is a very brave and interesting appointment and I hope that Anne will continue the tradition set by Sir David."

webTitle: 12 candidates, one mayor - where are they now?

fields.headline: 12 candidates, one mayor - where are they now?
fields.standfirst: It was the cuddliest British election and the cause of a weird roadshow of ageing ambition: 11 men and one woman battling to become London's first directly-elected mayor. But what happened to them after polling day? Julian Glover explains
fields.trailText: It was the cuddliest British election and the cause of a weird roadshow of ageing ambition: 11 men and one woman battling to become London's first directly-elected mayor. But what happened to them after polling day? Julian Glover explains.
fields.body:
As was obvious from the moment in March 2000 when Ken Livingstone announced that he would run as an independent candidate, the election of London's first mayor proved a rebuff for all Britain's main political parties and mini-triumph for fringe politics.

And that curious outcome led to another - inter-candidate solidarity survived the last 12 months as mayor Livingstone copied Tony Blair's "big tent" politics and brought his defeated rivals into office with him.

In his post-election speech Mr Livingstone offered jobs in his administration to defeated candidates from all three main parties. Today, four of the top eight candidates - Mr Livingstone, the Tory Steve Norris, Lib Dem Susan Kramer and the Green, Darren Johnson - play some part in governing London.

All this is thanks to the anti-party dynamic of the mayoral campaign.

Norris, with his bluff pro-gay, pro-hanging, anti-abortion policy slate and anarchic sense of humour, was hardly a typical Tory just as Dobson, equally funny, even more foul mouthed and sceptical of New Labour, was no Millbank clone.

Even Ms Kramer, an ambitious transport specialist married to an American banker, came from outside her party's traditional roots.

And three other candidates stood out, too. As well as Livingstone - whose status outside the big three parties was perhaps only nominal - the mayoral election brought into the limelight Darren Johnson, the Green candidate who campaigned from a bike.

He was beaten by an even more unexpected figure, Ram Gidoomal of the Christian People's Alliance, who gained 2.4% and plenty of respect, particularly from traditionalist Conservatives put off by Steve Norris' liberated attitude to sex.

Within weeks of the election, Ms Kramer, had accepted a post on the board of Transport for London, the body responsible for sorting out the tube.

Instead of seeking a seat in parliament - as was widely expected - she focussed her political energies on London and has, so far, worked closely with the mayor.

Her media presence has been at least as high as Mr Livingstone's nominal deputy, Labour's Nicky Gavron.

So has that of Steve Norris - once, as a Tory MP, a tabloid favourite for his sexual antics. He is now a vice chairman of the Conservative party and as such part of William Hague's campaign team for the general election.

However he also sits on the board of Transport for London and admits he finds the mayor an "engaging person privately who it is very easy to like" - although he opposes the mayor's plans to charge drivers entering central London.

Mr Norris has also spent the past year doing what he has always been good at - making money. He was tipped at one stage as the next chairman of Railtrack.

Mr Dobson, Labour's fall-guy in the election, has slipped from the public eye. Still well-connected and popular inside his party and at Westminster, he has become a rare sight in the media despite his nominal role as an official anti-Tory campaigner for his party. fields.headline: The gossip goes on as Popbitch appeal succeeds
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Celebrity gossip website Popbitch has raised enough cash to survive and will relaunch within weeks, writes Amy Vickers.
Useful link: Popbitch.com
fields.body:
Rumours of Popbitch's demise have been greatly exaggerated.

The much-loved celebrity gossip website has raised the required amount of cash to survive and says it is relaunching within weeks.

The anonymous Popbitch team are now transferring the website onto new servers, located in a former Ministry of Defence nuclear bunker.

"Yes - the appeal was a huge success and now we're in the middle of transferring but it's it's taking longer than we hoped," said Popbitch.

"The place looks utterly fantastic: blast doors, airlocks, scary concrete blockhouses, razorwire and so on."

Popbitch became a victim of its own success after gaining a cult following of more than 30,000.

Its servers reached meltdown, unable to cope with traffic demands and needed to be upgraded at a cost of £2,500.

The site's popularity stems from users posting gossip that is often followed up by the tabloids.

One coup was correctly predicting the name of Madonna and Guy Ritchie's baby, Rocco, but Popbitch has also had its fair share of libel threats from celebrities not best pleased to find themselves the subject of scurrilous gossip.

And the site was responsible for starting the debate on Geri Halliwell's body, and whether it was indeed her body, that features in her latest pop video.

Faced with closure, Popbitch launched a heartfelt plea to its fanbase to its fanbase to pledge £50 apiece to save the service.

"Bitchaid" was launched and a 'fundraising' party was held on April 18.

Popbitch, like all the best celebrity gossip websites, relies on its messageboard to spread salacious, fast-and-furious chatter. It also sends out a weekly emails containing updates on celebrity gossip and links to amusing websites.

Useful link
Popbitch.com

fields.headline: C4 plans prison football drama
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Channel 4 has commissioned a provocative new drama called Manslaughter United, reports Ben Dowell.
fields.body:
Channel 4 is planning a provocative new drama, Manslaughter United, based on the trials and tribulations of a prison football team.

It will "take a serious look at what happens to a man when he gets a life sentence for murder," said Jeff Pope, the head of factual drama at Granada.

"We want to do the football for real. It won't be like the film Escape to Victory where it was all staged."

"We want to film the course of a real football match between actors who can play football and real teams," added Mr Pope, who will produce the drama.

Other projects for Granada include Wall of Silence, a film about the murder of a teenager on a London estate.

The department is also making another film called the Insiders, a children's film in the mould of the Borrowers.

The Insiders will be made by Granada films, but Granada's head of children's programmes, Steven Andrew, hopes to develop it as a series.

Mr Pope and his fellow Bob Martin author Bob Mills are also writing a drama about the Victorian channel swimmer Captain Webb, which has yet to find a broadcaster.

If it is bought by ITV, Granada's drama boss, Nick Elliott, hopes to cast Ross Kemp as Webb.

fields.headline: Saatchi campaign highlights unwanted pregnancies
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Saatchi & Saatchi has created a new campaign to prevent unwanted pregnancies, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Nearly 30 years after it came up with the iconic pregnant man advert, the Family Planning Association has commissioned Saatchi & Saatchi to create a new campaign to prevent unwanted pregnancies.

Thousands of cards featuring a naked man with a finger-sized hole punched through his groin will go into bars and clubs next week to promote National Condom Week.

The campaign is intended to draw attention to unwanted pregnancies and sexually transmitted diseases.

According to the FPA, the UK now has the highest rate of teenage pregnancy in western Europe at 63 per thousand 15 to 19-year-olds and eight per thousand 13 to 25-year-olds in the last year.

Approximately one fifth of all pregnancies in the UK ends in abortion.

"These figures are alarming and highlight the amount of young people having unprotected sex," said Juliet Hillier, the director of communications at the FPA.

"The risks are not only unplanned pregnancies but an increase in contracting a sexually transmitted disease.

"We've seen a startling 6% increase in new HIV infections and over half a million new cases of STDs."

fields.headline: Ted Rogers
fields.standfirst:
Dogged comedian who played on despite bankruptcy and TV cuts

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Dogged comedian who played on despite bankruptcy and TV cuts.
fields.body:
Ted Rogers, who has died after prolonged heart trouble at the age of 65, was one of the personable but anonymous brand of British comedians who, from the 1960s, replaced genial and genuine oddities like the bumbling Rob Wilton, the flamboyant Max Miller and the chirpily tiny Arthur Askey.

He drew audiences of 17m as the host of the Yorkshire Television game show 3-2-1, in which, from 1978, his trademark was saying "Time's up" to his contestants while counting down on his fingers. Ironically, in 1965, after the BBC had given him his own show, And So To Ted, it was dropped after six weeks because it failed to find large enough audiences.

This was perhaps revealing. Rogers did best when playing the host, or attaching himself to stars with a powerful personal or group identity, such as on Bachelors' Night Out, the ITV series in which, from 1965, he presented the pop group, the Bachelors.

Likewise, his attachment to the Conservative Party in general, and to Mrs Thatcher in particular, ensured that, at one stage, he was virtually court jester at 10 Downing Street.

On the night of her first election victory, over James Callaghan, in 1979, he quipped: "We shall know in the morning if we have a silly old woman as prime minister, or whether Margaret Thatcher got in." He once told her that in one room she still had the same wallpaper that his mother had had for years in her bathroom.

At this point, Rogers was making £130,000 a year. But his life was subject to heights and troughs of fortune.

He was born in Kennington, south London, and at the age of 12, was inspired towards a show business career by a Danny Kaye comedy film. At 16, he won a holiday camp contest with his Danny Kaye impressions, but further progress was impeded by national service in the RAF, which he completed in 1950.

While working as a clerk, he looked for show business jobs, eventually becoming a Butlin's red coat, and graduating into pantomime. He appeared in Cinderella at the London Coliseum after the star of the show, Tommy Steele, hurt his ankle.

In 1960, Rogers was asked to compère the Prince of Wales' Show, and, three years later, began an association with radio's The Billy Cotton Band Show. As compère of the ITV show, Sunday Night At The London Palladium, from 1974, he was in his element as anchorman to other people's talents.

The same applied when he began presenting 3-2-1, where he vied for popularity with the animated Dusty Bin, into which wrong answers were placed. The show was dropped after 10 years, and when Yorkshire TV mooted its return in 1996, they took the view that Rogers would no longer be right - "something of a has-dusty bin," said one executive unkindly.

In the intervening years, Rogers's career had plummeted. At his peak, he had a large house, five polo ponies, a Rolls-Royce and 12 Mercedes. He launched a production company, which collapsed with debts of £50,000 - to his credit, Rogers ruled out evading the debts by making him self bankrupt, and all debtors were paid. He moved into a smaller rented house, and then a cottage. His last Mercedes was repossessed while he was signing autographs for fans.

But he soldiered on. Even in the depths of financial depression, he insisted on treating all the staff to buns and cakes every time he visited the offices of his agent Phil Dale, who found him "an absolute gentleman". To the last, he also gave the once-traditional presents to everyone appearing with him on a show.

Rogers was still working almost to the time of his death, principally in pantomimes and on ocean cruises, and was expecting to go to the United States next Christmas to play in a show called Vaudeville with his friend, the comedian Jackie Mason. He may not have had overwhelming individuality, but he was a professional slogger who deserved better than fashion and his misjudgments decreed.

Rogers is survived by his wife Marion, and their son and daughter, and by two daughters from his first marriage.

 Ted Rogers, comedian and presenter, born July 20 1935; died May 2 2001
