webTitle: If we build it, they will come

fields.headline: If we build it, they will come
fields.standfirst: Norman Foster's new Wembley should be built not only as a monument to the nation's favourite sport, but to regenerate one of the most deprived areas in the country, argues Sir Stuart Lipton, chairman of the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment
fields.trailText: Norman Foster's new Wembley should be built not only as a monument to the nation's favourite sport, but to regenerate one of the most deprived areas in the country, argues Sir Stuart Lipton, chairman of the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment.
fields.body:
Norman Foster's designs for the new Wembley meet the aspiration of a world class stadium that would make a major contribution to the regeneration of the London Borough of Brent.

When the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment (Cabe) reviewed the project in 1999, we were convinced that the approach would lead to not only an inspirational building but also to an appropriate environment for the UK's favourite sport. At the same time, we were also pleased that the scheme would act as a regenerator for one of the poorest London boroughs.

This holistic approach to the commissioning of new buildings is Cabe's strategy. Cabe believes that construction is about more than buildings alone; it is about an appropriate design which is effective and efficient, stimulates the user and adds to the community.

Brent is in the top 20 most deprived boroughs in the country. It needs the new Wembley to stimulate wider regeneration and while Cabe strongly supports regeneration in all regions the obvious location for a national stadium is our capital city. If we are serious about attracting global sporting events on the scale of the World Cup and the Olympics, we must stick with Wembley.

On top of all this, Lord Foster is a highly skilled architect and can be trusted to provide the country with one of the best stadiums in the world, if he is allowed to deliver against a clear and simple brief. The current problem lies not in the site or the architect, but in the muddled mess of motives and ambitions which have been allowed to accumulate.

A high-quality new building at Wembley will have a huge positive impact on the area. There is now overwhelming statistical evidence to prove what Cabe has always believed - investing in high-quality new landmark buildings and public spaces around them will boost the local economy, crime rates will fall, and businesses and residents will start to move into the area. Statistical evidence from the USA and Spain back up these claims.

It is estimated that the Frank Gehry-designed Guggenheim museum in Bilbao has boosted the Basque region's GDP by approximately 0.5%, more than justifying the initial investment made in the project. In its first year, the museum attracted more than a million visitors, double the expected figure. Similarly, a stylish contemporary extension to the Rose Centre for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, led to a 58% increase in visitors and a 200% increase in membership applications. The new building put the museum back on the cultural map.

There are other examples closer to home. When Walsall metropolitan council floated the idea of building a world class art gallery next to a derelict canal in this impoverished and increasingly depressed borough, some people might have been forgiven for thinking that the idea was doomed. Similarly, when the London borough of Southwark decided that Peckham High Street would be the best place to put a new state-of-the-art library and media centre, more than a few eyebrows were raised. But both these projects have excelled and more than prove the point - well designed and planned new buildings can provide a real focus for regeneration in areas which have been rapidly losing hope.

In Walsall the takings of the shops next door to the gallery have increased dramatically and evening events in the gallery have lured people away from the multiplexes they had been channeled towards, and back to the town centre. The result is social and economic regeneration, and a reduction of crime. Peckham Library has also produced dramatic results. The figures for the first six months of the new library compared to the two closed libraries it replaced show that annual visits are up from 171,000 to 450,000 and loans from 80,000 to approximately 340,000. Local people are proud of their new building and make the most of it.

Wembley can produce the same effect, and without the complex of exhibition centres and hotels which have muddled the proposal latterly. The Peckham and Walsall buildings were realised because there was a simple and energetic vision behind them. This is exactly what Wembley had initially and now needs to regain. The government and the Football Association must not to lose sight of the vibrant and purposeful brief which initiated the project.

If we look at recent experience of building football stadiums elsewhere, there does not seem to be a good reason why a new stadium at Wembley should cost £600m. The costs seem to have escalated because of the additional facilities which have been proposed. Based on other projects a 90,000-seat stadium on this site, built to high quality specifications, should cost around £400m. Extra facilities, like conference centres and hotels can be added later, when finances allow, and the building itself should be designed with flexibility in mind to generate extra revenue in the early years.

This cost is well in line with that of other major new stadiums, including the Stade de France and Stadium Australia. Although these two projects provide nowhere near so much space or so many visitor facilities outside the main bowl, when factors are brought into line construction costs are very similar. Investment in both these stadiums has more than paid off - they are world famous sporting venues, which instil pride into their nations and have provided jobs, directly and indirectly. I believe that we can learn from them when we look at investing in our own national stadium.

Let's return to a simpler stadium brief for Wembley and keep the vision clearly in mind. Investing in a high-quality building on this site will reap rewards for us all in the future.

 Sir Stuart Lipton is chairman of the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment.

fields.headline: US job figures spread gloom
fields.standfirst:
Services on brink of recession in Britain  Record rate of sackings in America

Special report: global recession
fields.trailText: Services on brink of recession in Britain | Record rate of sackings in America.
fields.body:
Share prices slumped on both sides of the Atlantic yesterday after gloomy US jobs data prompted fresh worries about the health of the world's largest economy.

New entrants to the American jobless queue reached an eight-year high last month, according to government figures. A separate survey showed firms sacking workers at the fastest rate on record. Nearly 166,000 jobs were lost in April as companies attempted to restore profitability by slashing payrolls.

An important indicator of the health of US service firms also collapsed last month, suggesting that large parts of the economy which have escaped recession are contracting. The monthly index of activity in the service sector fell to 47.1 in April, from 50.3 in March, the lowest reading in the survey's four years. Readings below 50 suggest the sector is in recession.

By midday renewed pessimism about the economy had sent the benchmark Dow Jones industrial average down nearly 135 points, to 10,741, a 1.25% decline.

In London the gloomy news from the US added to worries over the health of the British economy prompted by a survey showing service sector firms on the brink of recession.

Investors fled the market, sending the FTSE 100 index down 138 points or 2.34% to 5,765 - its lowest finish for nearly three weeks.

"The foot and mouth outbreak has exacerbated the slowdown in service sector growth, making firms compete harder for business," said Roy Ayliffe, director of professional practice at the institute.

Some City analysts believe the Bank of England may respond with a 0.5% cut to borrowing costs at its monthly rate setting meeting next week. Service sector firms account for more than two thirds of the economy, dwarfing the manufacturing sector.

webTitle: Japan holds man claiming to be son of North Korea's ruler

fields.headline: Japan holds man claiming to be son of North Korea's ruler
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: Immigration officials at Tokyo's Narita airport risked stirring up a diplomatic hornet's nest yesterday by seizing a man claiming to be the son of North Korea's leader Kim Jong-il.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts  in Tokyo  and John Gittings  in Pyongyang
fields.body:
Immigration officials at Tokyo's Narita airport risked stirring up a diplomatic hornet's nest yesterday by seizing a man claiming to be the son of North Korea's leader Kim Jong-il.

According to local media, the man was detained as he attempted to enter Japan on a forged Dominican Republic passport. He is said to have flown in on a Japan Airlines flight from Singapore with two women and a child.

The authorities have refused to comment but the illegal immigrant has told police that he is Kim Jong-nam, the eldest son of North Korea's ruler who is reportedly being groomed to inherit the communist dynasty.

"There is a possibility that he may indeed be Kim Jong-nam, the son of Kim Jong-il. But we are still collecting intelligence and we cannot say for sure," a source in the South Korean government said.

If confirmed, the news will have been doubly unwelcome for Mr Kim on the day that he devoted many hours to his newly discovered diplomatic skills with the visit of a top-level EU delegation.

Mr Kim, like his late father Kim Il-sung, was until recently thought to have left his country only twice. This earned him the reputation of being reclusive. But speaking last year to South Korean journalists, Mr Kim said he had travelled abroad many times, presumably incognito. If this is so, his son might have been attempting to see Japan in the same way.

The justice ministry plans to expel the man to China within a couple of days.

If his identity is confirmed as Kim, the case would have to be handled with great sensitivity, given the status of their captive and the tense relations between Japan and its reclusive neighbour.

In North Korea, Kim Jong-nam was nicknamed "the Little General" as a child. Two years ago, South Korean media reported that he had entered the north's intelligence services as a first step towards inheriting his father's and his grandfather's position.

Mr Kim's role as heir apparent to Kim Il-sung was an official secret for many years: his name was not mentioned publicly, even though his birthday was celebrated by officials.

Mr Kim is said to have three children by different mothers, though there is no way of verifying reports about Mr Kim's family, including lurid tales about his alleged affairs.

After the north-south rapprochement last year, many experts came to believe that such stories had been largely concocted by South Korean black propaganda.

Japan's prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, reportedly held an emergency meeting with senior foreign ministry officials to discuss the first big diplomatic test of his week-old administration.

Kim Jong-nam is believed to have been educated in Geneva and, secretly, in Japan. He speaks French and Japanese and is reportedly a computer enthusiast.

Most of his life has been spent overseas, including a spell in Russia. According to his adopted sister, Lee Nam-ok, Kim Jong-nam is bespectacled and portly and looks like his father. "He has a good mind and sense of humour. He is very energetic. He is a permanent optimist and a pleasant young man who can laugh all day long from morning to evening. He also has an artistic sense like his father," she said in an interview.

fields.headline: Marriott quits battle for Meridien
fields.trailText: The Japanese bank Nomura looks likely to clinch a deal for the Meridien hotel chain, following the withdrawal last night of rival bidder Marriott International.
fields.body:
The Japanese bank Nomura looks likely to clinch a deal for the Meridien hotel chain, following the withdrawal last night of rival bidder Marriott International.

US-based Marriott dropped its £1.7bn offer after failing to secure "preferred bidder" status in the long-running auction for the business, which has been put up for sale by hospitality firm Compass.

The Meridien chain includes London landmarks such as Cafe Royal, the Waldorf and the Grosvenor House Hotel.

Nomura's bid of £1.85bn gave it priority in carrying out due diligence for the purchase, though bankers say that because of the huge volume of paperwork involved, a final deal is weeks rather than days away.

Sources close to Compass said there were other interested parties in the auction, but they were some way behind in carrying out detailed scrutiny of the chain and would be unlikely to overtake Nomura.

The 146-strong Meridien chain of four and five-star hotels stretches across 55 countries. It will make Nomura one of Europe's biggest hotel operators. The bank owns 17 Principal Hotels, some of which are likely to be rebranded as Meridiens.

Nomura has lined up Jürgen Bartels to run the chain. Mr Bartels is a former head of US group Starwood, which owns Sheraton hotels.

Nomura's structured finance arm, headed by Guy Hands, is Britain's biggest pub landlord with more than 5,500 properties.

The company, financed by bonds, specialises in businesses which have poor short-term growth prospects, making them unattractive to public companies.

Compass has sold the Posthouse, Signature and Heritage hotel chains for £1.36bn to concentrate on roadside restaurants and catering.

fields.headline: Lottery-backed film company under fire
fields.trailText: A film company backed by £12m of National Lottery money and one of Britain's wealthiest families will today be asked to explain allegations that details of deals were not fully disclosed to investors.
fields.body:
A film company backed by £12m of National Lottery money and one of Britain's wealthiest families will today be asked to justify to shareholders a series of director-related transactions and explain allegations that details of those deals were not fully disclosed to investors.

The board of Civilian Content faces questions at the annual general meeting on the valuation of three film companies bought from its chairman and largest shareholder, Richard Thompson, the former Queens Park Rangers football club chairman and son of David Thompson, founder of the Hillsdown food empire.

Civilian says the deals were approved by independent directors and were in the best interests of all shareholders.

Roger Abraham, a small shareholder, doubts the wisdom of the deal that saw Civilian, then a meat processing business called Whitchurch, pay £3.3m for firms which went on to lose £2.4m. At the same time Civilian sold the meat businesses to one of Mr Thompson's private companies for £6.5m. The deal gave Mr Thompson five years to pay up and he still owes Civilian £1.9m.

Two weeks after Mr Thompson bought the meat businesses he sold them to two former Whitchurch directors for £5.25m in cash. Two days later the two former directors sold the business on to Prosper De Mulder, another meat packing, for a £250,000 profit.

Mr Abraham has written to Civilian demanding to know why the meat business was not sold direct to Prosper De Mulder and why the film businesses were not independently valued. He is also demanding that Mr Thompson pay immediately the £1.9m he still owes Civilian.

Last night Tim Willis, a director of Civilian, said: "These transactions were done in the best interests of all shareholders and ratified by independent directors.

"We are now in a fast-growing industry offering shareholders much better prospects."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Brewery hit by foot and mouth
fields.body:
Brewery hit by foot and mouth

The foot and mouth outbreak has cost Britain's biggest brewer, Scottish & Newcastle, about £3m as its rural pubs and overall beer sales have been hit.

The Edinburgh-based group also said in a trading update that its recent Kronenbourg sales in France had suffered owing to exceptionally poor weather. It added that its profits would be in line with market expectations of £420m-£430m.

Nigel Popham, at brokers Teather & Greenwood, described the outlook for the brewer and hotel operator as a mixed picture and advised shareholders to reduce holdings. The shares lost 12p to 479.5p.

Bus maker to cut 700 jobs

Seven hundred jobs are to be lost in a restructuring announced yesterday by the bus and coach manufacturer TransBus.

The company said it was ceasing manufacturing at its plant in Scarborough, saying coach sales had been hit hard by the impact of foot and mouth.

Halifax signs up new asset chief

Halifax, Britain's largest mortgage bank, has appointed Douglas Ferrans as new chief executive of its subsidiary Clerical Medical.

He was previously marketing director of Britannic Asset Management, and his new appointment follows recent expansion of Clerical Medical's asset management business.

Hugo Boss sees 32% profit rise

Hugo Boss of Germany said first quarter net profit rose 32% to €55.8m. The exclusive clothing group said sales in the period rose 22% to €342.5m, compared with €280.5m in the same quarter last year.

Boss reiterated its forecast of 16% growth in 2001 sales to €1.075bn, and a rise of 13% in net profit to €112m.

First Choice director quits

First Choice Holidays finance director, David Howell, yesterday unexpectedly quit the holiday firm. A company spokeswoman said the decision had been mutually agreed between the board and Mr Howell and he was now looking for a position that offered similar challenges. Mr Howell will be receiving compensation in line with his one year contract. Last year the finance director was paid £308,000.

BA watches numbers drop

Passenger numbers are continuing to fall on British Airways flights as the US slowdown bites, figures showed yesterday.

A drop in the number of Americans flying across the Atlantic contributed to a 13.3% fall in April, compared with the same month last year. The impact of foot and mouth and a computer glitch that hit the booking system also had a big impact.

Last month BA reported an 8.9% drop in March, which it said would hit revenues by £15m to £20m.

webTitle: British woman killed by own bomb

fields.headline: British woman killed by own bomb
fields.standfirst: Athens police investigate links to local gangland chiefs
fields.trailText: A British woman with close ties to the Athens underworld was killed in the Greek capital yesterday when a homemade bomb she was carrying in her BMW accidentally exploded.
fields.byline: Steven Morris in London and  Michael Howard in Athens
fields.body:
A British woman with close ties to the Athens underworld was killed in the Greek capital yesterday when a homemade bomb she was carrying in her BMW accidentally exploded.

Detectives believe Susan Aristides, who was brought up in west London but had lived in Athens for 20 years after marrying a Greek Australian, was on her way to plant the device in a revenge attack after a spate of gangland killings.

Aristides, 48, whose maiden name was Weymouth, was thrown from the car by the blast, which rocked the southern suburb of Voula in the early hours of the morning. The mother-of-two was wearing black gloves and had cotton wool plugged in her ears.

The bomb had been placed near the handbrake and a remote control device was found in a bag. Detectives believe she accidentally set the bomb off when she stopped to check it or to move it. It is also possible that her pet rottweiler, which was in the car, sat on the detonator or bit it.

Initially there were fears that the explosion could be connected to the visit of the Pope today, which has led to protests by Greek Orthodox extremists. It was also thought she may have been targeted by the terrorist group November 17, which claimed responsibility for the murder of a British military attache, Brigadier Stephen Saunders, last year.

But when police found a stash of bombmaking equipment at her penthouse home they dismissed the idea that terrorists were to blame. Instead, to the amazement of the woman's family and friends in London who had no idea of her connections, police began investigating her links with gangs suspected of running protection rackets in cabaret nightclubs

A police source said: "It looks like she was carrying it somewhere when it went off. But at the moment we don't know why it went off or what the target was going to be."

She was known by police for her friendship with the Grigorakos clan, a leading criminal family in Athens, which runs drugs and extortion rackets in hotels and nightclubs along the capital's south-eastern coast.

The gang's "godfather" was Vassillis Grigorakos, a kingpin of the capital's cocaine trade. His son Niko ran a private army that carried out murders and beatings. Both were killed last summer in a gangland war, and Aristides was photographed comforting relatives at the scene of Niko's murder.

Yesterday British relatives expressed shock at her extraordinary end as they tried to puzzle out how an ordinary girl from a decent west London family had become a friend of a criminal clan.

She grew up on the Wesley Estate, north Acton, and attended the local state school, where she was considered a bright girl. When she was 16, however, her mother, Myra Bermingham, emigrated with Susan and her other three children to Australia.

Susan got back in touch with her father five years ago and introduced him to her two adult sons, Steven and Paul. She showed him photos of her sumptuous Athens home and said she had married a Greek Australian but had separated from him. She was vague about what she did, telling her father, David, only that she "ran her own business".

Mr Weymouth said when he heard on the radio that a British woman had been killed in Athens he told his wife: "I hope that's not Susan. I couldn't believe it when they said her name. I last heard from her when she sent an Easter card. I can't begin to understand what has happened."

Since the collapse of the Soviet bloc, organised crime in the Balkans has flourished and Greece, which boasts the region's most vibrant economy, has been a natural target. Many syndicates with international connections have also been attracted by the potential for profit from the expected business boom ahead of the 2004 Olympic Games.

A major crackdown on Athens criminal gangs was announced last summer after a wave of bloodletting among gangland leaders provoked fierce criticism of police, who were accused of being happy to stand by as the godfathers wiped each other out. Five gangland bosses were killed as rivals exploded bombs in homes and cars, with little regard for innocent bystanders.

The police were also accused of incompetency and corruption. Now they believe that most of the crime bosses are either dead or in prison.

A bill to counter organised crime and terrorism is expected to become law by the end of the month.

fields.headline: Cancer test errors shock
fields.standfirst: Audit reveals one-third of cases may be missed
fields.trailText: The true scale of errors in the NHS cervical screening programme became clear yesterday as a routine audit showed that up to a third of women who go to their GP for regular smear tests may have cancers missed.
fields.body:
The true scale of errors in the NHS cervical screening programme became clear yesterday as a routine audit showed that up to a third of women who go to their GP for regular smear tests may have cancers missed.

The audit was carried out by Leicester Royal Infirmary, where standards of screening are as high as anywhere in the country. Yet a study of 324 women who developed cervical cancer despite regular screening found that 122 had been given at least one - and in some cases more than one - smear test result which was either negative or suggested a milder level of disease than was the case.

Fourteen women died and 64 had to have a radical hysterectomy because the nature of their cancer was not recognised.

Yesterday the national cancer director, Professor Mike Richards, acknowledged that what had happened in Leicester could be the pattern elsewhere."We can assume that around the rest of the country, there will be other cases where abnormalities on the same sort of scale were not picked up," he said.

But he and the cancer charities urged women not to boycott the programme, which saves around 1,300 lives a year. "It is a very successful programme in that there has been a marked decrease in deaths," he said. He praised Leicester for its honesty and openness, which he hoped other areas would imitate.

It was impossible, he said, to pick up 100% of cervical cancers through screening, which looks for pre-cancerous changes under the microscope in a sample of cells from the neck of the cervix. But without screening, more patients would have died and a lot more would have required radical treatment," he said.

The women in Leicester who had undergone avoidable hysterectomies and the relatives of those who died were told yesterday that their previous smear tests had been wrongly reported as negative. Julietta Patnick, co-ordinator of the national screening programme, said every woman who developed cervical cancer would in future be told if she had been the victim of a wrongly-read smear test, potentially opening the floodgates to more litigation.

Prof Richards said the deaths had been tragic, but Leicester's cervical screening service was not failing. "It performs well on all qualitative assurance measures, and death rates from cervical cancer are falling in line with national trends.

Ms Patnick said that audits like that in Leicester, which she hoped to see repeated round the country, could help scientists work out why cancers were being missed: "What we need to do is find out why these women who have had an adequate smear history go on to develop cervical cancer."

The audit studied 403 women who developed cervical cancer between 1993 and last year. Of those, 79 had not been for regular smears, and in 122 cases there had been an error in the way the screeners had reported the slide results. In 44 of the 122, there had been no adverse consequences - the cancer had been diagnosed soon afterwards. But the other 78 suffered a worsening of their condition before it was diagnosed, and 14 died.

The Imperial Cancer Research Fund and the Cancer Research Campaign urged women to continue to go for screening. "Though cervical screening may not be perfect, it is preventing many thousands of cancers," said Dr Peter Sasieni of the ICRF.

webTitle: TV review: A Life Of Grime Special

fields.headline: The filth and the fury
fields.trailText: A Life Of Grime Special
fields.body:
Dirt, I learned in a sociology lecture one day long ago, is just matter out of place. To illustrate his point, the lecturer noted that in a flowerbed, mud is mud, but smeared across a white cotton duvet cover, it is dirt. Similarly, we may think that travelling people who poo in fields are weird and unsanitary, but to some, went the logic, having a room in your house dedicated to the evacuation of one's bowels - the same room in which you perform your ablutions - is equally foul and strange. It is all down to cultural norms, apparently.

Well I didn't believe it then and I don't believe it now. Bathrooms are lovely places, it is wrong to poo in fields - unless you're a cow or a fox or something - and mud in flowerbeds is just muck waiting to happen. Dirt is dirty.

Eighty-three-year-old Edmund Trebus would disagree with me. As A Life Of Grime Special (BBC1) showed, he lives in 10 sq ft of a five-bedroom Victorian villa in north London. The rest of the house is packed, ceiling to floor, with bags and bags of rubbish. The garden too is strewn with all sorts of garbage from old window panes to geriatric fridges filled with broken biscuits. The place looks like a theme park designed by Stig of the Dump.

Not that Mr Trebus calls it rubbish, or even matter out of place. The bags and fridges and window panes are his personal belongings and he is engaged in a fight with his local council to keep them in the place they're in at the moment. The council has already cleared his garden once, a story detailed in the original A Life Of Grime series, but now the garden is back to its manky state and the council have been called in again. Mike Cording from the council's environmental health department - henceforth referred to as Exasperated Mike - has been charged with dealing with Mr Trebus, which isn't an easy task, given that the old man's response to papers from the magistrates' court is "stick it up your chuffer".

I'm not really sure what the point of A Life Of Grime Special is. With John Peel narrating in his aren't-we-Brits-eccentric, Home-Truths tones, I think we were supposed to empathise with Mr Trebus. A survivor of the German occupation of Poland, he was an old soldier who was being hassled by local government to conform. "I'm sorry I am still alive", he wailed before warning Exasperated Mike that he didn't know what it was like fighting a war, and "even the blooming Dad's Army wouldn't let you in." In some respects, he was quite admirable - the way he got a building firm to repair his house on the (unfulfillable) promise they could then convert it into flats, for example. But then again, he was a dirty old man who, despite passing a psychiatric test as to his sanity, was clearly "unusual". I mean, he lives in a house with hundreds of plastic bags filled with junk and doesn't even know where his telly is. That is not normal or even mildly eccentric.

Cultural relativity be damned, it is out there with David Icke. And it is very, very unhygenic.

In fact, it was quite an unrewarding documentary to watch. The old man's children were mentioned in passing, which raised the question of their non-involvement, yet this question wasn't answered. Rather than examining his state of mind and whether people in his situation should be hosed down with Dettol for their own benefit, we were instead treated to what was, at best, a celebration of irresponsibility and at worst, no more than an exploitative freak show.

The kind of man who gives elderly folks a bad name with his "I fought in a war" nonsense, Mr Trebus didn't even need a couple of pet pythons to become the archetypal weird old bloke whose house neighbourhood children throw stones at. (Actually, the neighbourhood kids probably do throw stones at his house but they get lost among the carrier bags.)

Watching A Life Of Grime Special, I mused upon three things. First, I wondered if his neighbours were tuning in. Second, I thanked God I wasn't one of his neighbours. And third, I hoped that perhaps somewhere, an old lady whose house is filled with piles of newspapers and smells of 15 different varieties of cat pee had fallen in love.

webTitle: Porridge? Ronnie Biggs just wants curry and a pint

fields.headline: Porridge? Ronnie Biggs just wants curry and a pint
fields.trailText: Ronnie Biggs, the Great Train Robber who has been on the run for 35 years, was warned yesterday that there would be no amnesty for him if he left Brazil to return home.
fields.body:
Ronnie Biggs, the Great Train Robber who has been on the run for 35 years, was warned yesterday that there would be no amnesty for him if he left Brazil to return home.

The Home Office, the Prison Service and Scotland Yard, indicated that he would be arrested as soon as he entered the UK, taken to jail and might even face extra charges.

Biggs, 71, who is living in Rio de Janiero, still has 29 years to serve on a sentence for his role in the 1963 heist, one of the most audacious crimes of the post-war era.

There is a warrant for his arrest, which was renewed in the late 1990s, and he could still be charged over his escape from Wandsworth prison in a furniture van in 1965.

Biggs yesterday issued a statement, saying: "I fully intend to go back to the United Kingdom at the earliest opportunity. I have asked the Sun to independently facilitate my return to Britain."

He added: "I have been in contact with the Metropolitan police and am prepared to hand myself over to the authorities when I land in the UK. I can make no further comment at this time."

In an interview in yesterday's Sun newspaper, Biggs, who has suffered three strokes in the last 18 months and is in debt, said he did not want to end his life as a fugitive.

He said he hoped that the authorities "would show mercy" if he flew home, so that he could enjoy simple pleasures, such as a pint of beer and a curry.

"I just want to go back to Eng land. I want to be free. I want to be part of the English culture again. It's been too long. I am a sick man. My last wish is to walk into a Margate pub as an Englishman and buy a pint of bitter. I hope I live long enough to be able to do that."

On Wednesday evening Biggs sent an email to Detective Chief Superintendent John Coles, head of Scotland Yard's serious and organised crime group, signalling his willingness to return.

It read: "I would like to give myself up to you. What I need is passport documentation to travel back to Britain.

"I'm prepared to be arrested when I arrive at Heathrow airport to submit myself to the due process of the law."

The Met yesterday confirmed that the message had been received.

Detectives will not be flying to Rio to speak to Biggs, but a source said: "If he returns to the UK, he will be arrested, no question about that. The warrant for his arrest is still live and as far as we are concerned he is unlawfully at large."

The Prison Service added: "This is an unusual case because of the length of time involved, but there is no reason why he should not go straight to jail if and when he returns."

Jack Straw, the home secretary, has discretionary powers under the 1991 Criminal Justice Act to release prisoners in "exceptional circumstances."

"Someone has to be very ill for the home secretary to intervene," said a spokesman. "Normally, it happens when someone is about to die."

fields.headline: Police reopen 1975 child murder case
fields.trailText: Police in Yorkshire are to reopen an inquiry into the murder of an 11-year-old girl whose death 26 years ago resulted in one of the worst miscarriages of justice in legal history.
fields.body:
Police in Yorkshire are to reopen an inquiry into the murder of an 11-year-old girl whose death 26 years ago resulted in one of the worst miscarriages of justice in legal history.

Lesley Molseed, of Rochdale, Greater Manchester, was stabbed 12 times and then sexually assaulted in 1975. Her body was dumped on the moors above Ripponden in West Yorkshire. The brutal killing outraged local people.

In December 1975, detectives arrested and charged Stefan Kiszko, a tax clerk from Rochdale who had never been in trouble with the law.

After two days of questioning he signed a confession. He later complained that the confession had been bullied out of him but was convicted of murder and jailed for life.

Fourteen years later his lawyer urged the Home Office to reopen the case, which was then referred back to West Yorkshire police.

New inquiries showed that semen found on Lesley's body contained heads of sperm. Mr Kiszko, however, was infertile.

He was freed in 1992 but died a year later. His mother Charlotte, who had campaigned tirelessly to prove his innocence, died six months after him.

A West Yorkshire police spokesman said yesterday: "The murder investigation is being relaunched on Tuesday May 8 when an increased number of officers will be working from an incident room at Halifax police station.

"Detective Chief Superintendent Max McLean has asked officers to look at a number of new lines of inquiry.

"The case has never been closed. Thousands of documents from the original inquiry back in 1975 are being looked at by officers and transferred to the Holmes system."

The Holmes system, which was not available at the time of Lesley's murder, allows comparisons and patterns to be drawn from information recorded on a database by police forces from across the country.

"We have a list of suspects that we intend to pursue and we continue to liaise closely with the Molseed family," added the police spokesman.

"Now is the time for people to come forward with information."

webTitle: Comment: Out of Israel - a vision of peace

fields.headline: Out of Israel - a vision of peace
fields.standfirst: Palestine at war: A veteran Israeli peace activist proposes an end to the region's mutual blindness and hatreds
fields.trailText: The peace process has collapsed - and taken down with it a large part of the Israeli peace camp. Transient circumstances, such as personal or party-political matters, failures of leadership, political self-interest, domestic and global political developments - all these are like foam over the waves. Important as they may be, they cannot adequately explain the total collapse.
fields.body:
The peace process has collapsed - and taken down with it a large part of the Israeli peace camp. Transient circumstances, such as personal or party-political matters, failures of leadership, political self-interest, domestic and global political developments - all these are like foam over the waves. Important as they may be, they cannot adequately explain the total collapse.

The true explanation can only be found beneath the surface, at the roots of the historical conflict between the two nations.

The Madrid-Oslo process failed because the two sides were seeking to achieve conflicting goals. The goals of each side emanated from their basic national interests. They were shaped by their historical narratives, by their disparate views of the conflict over the past 120 years. The Israeli national historical version and the Palestinian national historical version are entirely contradictory, both in general and in every single detail.

The negotiators and the decision-makers on the Israeli side were completely oblivious to the Palestinian national narrative. Even when they sincerely wished to reach a solution, their efforts were doomed to fail as they could not understand the national desires, traumas, fears and hopes of the Palestinian people. While there is no symmetry between the two sides, the Palestinian attitude was similar.

Resolution of such a long historical conflict is possible only if each side is capable of understanding the other's spiritual-national world and willing to approach it as an equal. An insensitive, condescending and overbearing attitude precludes any possibility of an agreed solution.

The Barak government, which had inspired so much hope, was afflicted with all these attitudes, hence the enormous gap between its initial promise and the disastrous results. A significant part of the old peace camp (also called the "Zionist left" or the "sane constituency") is similarly afflicted and therefore collapsed along with the government it supported.

Therefore, the primary role of a new Israeli peace camp is to get rid of the false myths and the one-sided view of the conflict. This does not mean that the Israeli narrative should automatically be rejected and the Palestinian narrative unquestionably accepted. But it does require open-minded listening and understanding of the other side's position in the historical conflict, in order to bridge the two national narratives.

Any other way will lead to a perpetuation of the conflict, with periods of ostensible tranquility and conciliation frequently interrupted by violent hostile actions between the two nations and between Israel and the Arab world. Considering the pace of development of weapons of mass destruction, further rounds of hostility could lead to the destruction of all sides to the conflict.

Since the end of the first world war, there has been an ongoing struggle between two nationalist movements, the Jewish-Zionist and the Palestinian-Arab, both of which aspired to accomplish their goals - which entirely negate each other - within the same territory. This situation remains unchanged to this day.

As Jewish persecution in Europe intensified, and as the countries of the world closed their gates to the Jews attempting to flee the inferno, so the Zionist movement gained strength. The Holocaust, which took the lives of 6m Jews, gave moral and political force to the Zionist claim that led to the establishment of the state of Israel.

The Palestinian people, witnessing the growth of the Jewish population in their land, could not comprehend why they were required to pay the price for crimes committed against the Jews by Europeans. They violently objected to further Jewish immigration and to the acquisition of lands by the Jews.

The complete blindness of each of the two peoples to the national existence of the other inevitably led to false and distorted perceptions that took root deep in the collective consciousness of both. These perceptions affect their attitude towards each other to this day.

The Arabs believed that the Jews had been implanted in the country by western imperialism, in order to subjugate the Arab world and take control of its treasures. This conviction was strengthened by the fact that the Zionist movement, from the outset, strove for an alliance with at least one western power (Germany, Great Britain, France, the United States) to overcome the Arab resistance. The results were a practical cooperation and a community of interests between the Zionist enterprise and imperialist and colonialist forces, directed against the Arab national movement.

The Jews, on the other hand, were convinced that the Arab resistance to the Zionist enterprise - intended to save the Jews from the flames of Europe - was the consequence of the murderous nature of the Arabs and of Islam. In their eyes, Arab fighters were "gangs", and the uprisings of the time were called "riots".

The breakdown of the old peace camp necessitates the creation of a new Israeli peace camp that will be real, up-to-date, effective and strong, that can influence the Israeli public and bring about a complete re-evaluation of the old axioms in order to effect a change in the Israeli political system.

To do so, the new peace camp must lead public opinion towards a brave reassessment of the national "narrative" and rid it of false myths. It must strive to unite the historical versions of both peoples into a single "narrative", free from historical deceptions, which will be acceptable to both sides.

While doing this it must also make the Israeli public aware that along with all the beautiful and positive aspects of the Zionist enterprise, a terrible injustice was done to the Palestinian people. This injustice obliges us to assume responsibility and correct as much of it as is possible.

With a new understanding of the past and the present, the new peace camp must formulate a peace plan based on the following principles:

(a) An independent and free Palestinian state will be established alongside Israel.

(b) The Green Line will be the border between the two states. If agreed between the two sides, limited territorial exchanges may be possible.

(c) The Israeli settlements will be evacuated from the territory of the Palestinian state.

(d) The border between the two states will be open to the movement of people and goods, subject to arrangements made by mutual agreement.

(e) Jerusalem will be the capital of both states - West Jerusalem the capital of Israel and East Jerusalem capital of Palestine. The state of Palestine will have complete sovereignty in East Jerusalem, including the Haram al-Sharif (the Temple Mount). The state of Israel will have complete sovereignty in West Jerusalem, including the Western Wall and the Jewish Quarter. Both States will reach agreement on the unity of the city on the physical, municipal level.

(f) Israel will recognise, in principle, the Palestinian right of return as an inalienable human right. The practical solution to the problem will come about by agreement based on just, fair and practical considerations and will include return to the territory of the state of Palestine, return to the state of Israel and compensation.

(g) The water resources will be controlled jointly and allocated by agreement, equally and fairly.

(h) A security agreement between the two states will ensure the security of both and take into consideration the specific security needs of Israel as well as of Palestine.

(i) Israel and Palestine will cooperate with other states in the region, to establish a Middle Eastern community, modelled on the European Union.

The signing of a peace agreement and its honest implementation in good faith will lead to a historical reconciliation between the two nations, based on equality, cooperation and mutual respect.

 Extracted from 80 Theses for a New Peace Camp published by the peace group Gush Shalom.

The Barak government, which had inspired so much hope, was afflicted with all these attitudes, hence the enormous gap between its initial promise and the disastrous results. A significant part of the old peace camp (also called the "Zionist left" or the "sane constituency") is similarly afflicted and therefore collapsed along with the government it supported. Therefore, the primary role of a new Israeli peace camp is to get rid of the false myths and the one-sided view of the conflict. This does not mean that the Israeli narrative should automatically be rejected and the Palestinian narrative unquestionably accepted. But it does require open-minded listening and understanding of the other side's position in the historical conflict, in order to bridge the two national narratives. Any other way will lead to a perpetuation of the conflict, with periods of ostensible tranquility and conciliation frequently interrupted by violent hostile actions between the two nations and between Israel and the Arab world. Considering the pace of development of weapons of mass destruction, further rounds of hostility could lead to the destruction of all sides to the conflict. Since the end of the first world war, there has been an ongoing struggle between two nationalist movements, the Jewish-Zionist and the Palestinian-Arab, both of which aspired to accomplish their goals - which entirely negate each other - within the same territory. This situation remains unchanged to this day. As Jewish persecution in Europe intensified, and as the countries of the world closed their gates to the Jews attempting to flee the inferno, so the Zionist movement gained strength. The Holocaust, which took the lives of 6m Jews, gave moral and political force to the Zionist claim that led to the establishment of the state of Israel. The Palestinian people, witnessing the growth of the Jewish population in their land, could not comprehend why they were required to pay the price for crimes committed against the Jews by Europeans. They violently objected to further Jewish immigration and to the acquisition of lands by the Jews. The complete blindness of each of the two peoples to the national existence of the other inevitably led to false and distorted perceptions that took root deep in the collective consciousness of both. These perceptions affect their attitude towards each other to this day. The Arabs believed that the Jews had been implanted in the country by western imperialism, in order to subjugate the Arab world and take control of its treasures. This conviction was strengthened by the fact that the Zionist movement, from the outset, strove for an alliance with at least one western power (Germany, Great Britain, France, the United States) to overcome the Arab resistance. The results were a practical cooperation and a community of interests between the Zionist enterprise and imperialist and colonialist forces, directed against the Arab national movement. The Jews, on the other hand, were convinced that the Arab resistance to the Zionist enterprise - intended to save the Jews from the flames of Europe - was the consequence of the murderous nature of the Arabs and of Islam. In their eyes, Arab fighters were "gangs", and the uprisings of the time were called "riots". The breakdown of the old peace camp necessitates the creation of a new Israeli peace camp that will be real, up-to-date, effective and strong, that can influence the Israeli public and bring about a complete re-evaluation of the old axioms in order to effect a change in the Israeli political system. To do so, the new peace camp must lead public opinion towards a brave reassessment of the national "narrative" and rid it of false myths. It must strive to unite the historical versions of both peoples into a single "narrative", free from historical deceptions, which will be acceptable to both sides. While doing this it must also make the Israeli public aware that along with all the beautiful and positive aspects of the Zionist enterprise, a terrible injustice was done to the Palestinian people. This injustice obliges us to assume responsibility and correct as much of it as is possible. With a new understanding of the past and the present, the new peace camp must formulate a peace plan based on the following principles: (a) An independent and free Palestinian state will be established alongside Israel. (b) The Green Line will be the border between the two states. If agreed between the two sides, limited territorial exchanges may be possible. (c) The Israeli settlements will be evacuated from the territory of the Palestinian state. (d) The border between the two states will be open to the movement of people and goods, subject to arrangements made by mutual agreement. (e) Jerusalem will be the capital of both states - West Jerusalem the capital of Israel and East Jerusalem capital of Palestine. The state of Palestine will have complete sovereignty in East Jerusalem, including the Haram al-Sharif (the Temple Mount). The state of Israel will have complete sovereignty in West Jerusalem, including the Western Wall and the Jewish Quarter. Both States will reach agreement on the unity of the city on the physical, municipal level. (f) Israel will recognise, in principle, the Palestinian right of return as an inalienable human right. The practical solution to the problem will come about by agreement based on just, fair and practical considerations and will include return to the territory of the state of Palestine, return to the state of Israel and compensation. (g) The water resources will be controlled jointly and allocated by agreement, equally and fairly. (h) A security agreement between the two states will ensure the security of both and take into consideration the specific security needs of Israel as well as of Palestine. (i) Israel and Palestine will cooperate with other states in the region, to establish a Middle Eastern community, modelled on the European Union. The signing of a peace agreement and its honest implementation in good faith will lead to a historical reconciliation between the two nations, based on equality, cooperation and mutual respect.  Extracted from 80 Theses for a New Peace Camp published by the peace group Gush Shalom. www.gush-shalom.org

webTitle: Banks urges Greek lesson for Wembley

fields.headline: Banks urges Greek lesson for Wembley
fields.trailText: The Wembley fiasco will seriously affect any British bid for the 2012 Olympics, the former sports minister Tony Banks warned here yesterday.
fields.body:
The Wembley fiasco will seriously affect any British bid for the 2012 Olympics, the former sports minister Tony Banks warned here yesterday.

"Wembley would have an impact on the government's determination to go for the games," he said. "It [the latest Wembley update] would have sent ripples around the world."

The old stadium at Wembley was the venue for the 1948 Olympics and many International Olympic Committee members would like to see the location as the centrepiece of a bid from London. The president Juan Antonio Samaranch approached Banks three years ago urging him to get Britain to mount a bid based on Wembley.

The British Olympic Association is currently conducting a feasibility study on a possible bid for the games, which the IOC will award in 2005. But senior IOC members, currently in the Greek capital to check on preparations for the 2004 games, have admitted that Britain's reputation abroad has been damaged by doubts over the rebuilding of Wembley. "It's sending out the wrong signals," said one.

"We need to realise that the world watches you at times like this," said Banks, who was here to give a lecture to local journalists. "I said in July 1999, when I left my job as sports minister, that we cannot afford for this to go wrong, and it has."

When Banks left that role to head England's ultimately unsuccessful bid for the 2006 World Cup it was planned that Wembley would include an athletics track and stage the 2005 world championships. Yet Banks's blueprint was torn up within weeks of his leaving and athletics was evicted as the Football Association assumed control of the project.

Athletics is now set to build a stadium in north London but the future of Wembley looks in serious doubt after the FA pulled out of financing the project, claiming the cost might bankrupt the association. The government has so far ruled out financial support.

But Banks believes Wembley should return to its original plan of being a national stadium and that the government should pay for it. "If this is the national stadium, where is the national contribution?" he said. "I don't mean from the national lottery but from the exchequer. There is none and that is one of the problems.

"It is not the responsibility of football to deliver a national stadium. When I left, the culture minister [Chris Smith] called it a truly stunning design. It was a national stadium which would have formed the centrepiece of an Olympic bid.

"When it comes to grand projects we are not in it. The Channel tunnel and the Dome are other examples. It's no coincidence that they have also run into problems. There is a culture of doing things on the cheap."

In contrast the Greek government is committing more than $11bn (£7.7bn) to ensuring the infrastructure in Athens is given a complete overhaul before the 2004 games. Banks said: "They have less resources than us but there is a national determination to get things done."

webTitle: China blocks help for spy plane team

fields.headline: China blocks help for spy plane team
fields.standfirst:
Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Chinese officials failed yesterday to allow visiting American technicians to power up the damaged US spy plane stranded in southern China.
fields.body:
Chinese officials failed yesterday to allow visiting American technicians to power up the damaged US spy plane stranded in southern China.

A civilian technical team from the Lockheed Martin corporation spent a second day examining the plane, which remains on Hainan island where it landed on April 1.

People's Liberation Army officials unexpectedly failed to provide the technical support requested by the Americans which would have allowed it to start the engines and check systems, the Pentagon said.

The US team spent four hours on the plane on Wednesday, and was meant to carry out further inspections yesterday, the Pentagon official said. The team plans to make a further visit today.

Beijing did not explain why the requested support was not provided, the Pentagon said.

The latest hitch sparked speculation in Washington that the lack of help might be a response to Wednesday's confused efforts by the Pentagon to downgrade military cooperation with China.

The incident also coincided with Beijing's first official response to President George Bush's announcement on Tuesday that he intends to press ahead with a missile defence system. After 36 hours of silence, a Chinese spokesman denounced the move yesterday as opening the way to a new international arms race.

The Pentagon chilled an already cooling relationship ties with China on Wednesday by saying that it was suspending all military links with Beijing. A few hours later, the Bush administration retracted the statement, saying contacts were now being reviewed by the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, "on a case-by-case basis".

Admiral Craig Quigley, a Pentagon spokesman, said that the earlier announcement, written by a Rumsfeld aide, had been "an honest misrepresentation" of his boss's intentions.

The uncharacteristic confusion suggests underlying tensions between the diplomatic approach by the White House and a more confrontational mood in the Pentagon, under the hardline Mr Rumsfeld.

Beijing called Mr Bush's missile defence plan an attempt by the president to act tough to divert attention from his disputed election victory.

"Bush is trying to eradicate from his own mind the shadow of being a 'weak president'," said the People's Daily.

The criticism came as Chinese officials urged Washington not to scrap the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty which limits missile defences.

webTitle: Woman 'still shocked at losing royal job' when lover was killed

fields.headline: Woman 'still shocked at losing royal job' when lover was killed
fields.trailText: Jane Andrews was still suffering from the "great shock" of losing her job as dresser for the Duchess of York when her lover was killed nearly three years later, an Old Bailey jury heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Jane Andrews was still suffering from the "great shock" of losing her job as dresser for the Duchess of York when her lover was killed nearly three years later, an Old Bailey jury heard yesterday.

Andrews told the court that, despite later finding her "niche" with the jeweller Theo Fennell after her sudden dismissal in November 1997, she had not got over this by the time of Tom Cressman's death on September 16 last year.

"I don't think I still have," she added. "It's difficult to explain."

Andrews, 34, denies murdering Mr Cressman with a cricket bat and a kitchen knife.

When Bruce Houlder QC, prosecuting, pushed her on whether the dismissal dominated her life at the time, she said: "Dominate is a strong word to use. I would still say I missed the job. It was a very intense job for nine-and-a-half years. It was a very big part of my life - I found it incredibly difficult to find another job."

When Mr Houlder accused her of having invented the "story" that Mr Cressman, with whom she lived in Fulham, west London, anally raped her on the morning of his death and tried to do so again before he died, she replied: "No, not at all."

He asked why she had not mentioned the alleged rape to a doctor at Derriford hospital, where she was examined after being found in a west country layby four days after Mr Cressman's death, or to a female police doctor she saw three times - particularly as she wanted to impress on police that she had acted in self-defence.

"I was totally ashamed of what had happened," Andrews said. "I was too traumatised - I physically couldn't."

By the time she saw doctors the pain had subsided. There would not be the proof of anal intercourse, "because he had done it to me many times before - but not in the violent way." Mr Houlder asked why she had bought a thong in Penzance three days later, "if you had been anally raped. Is that the most comfortable garment to wear in those circumstances?"

"That's difficult to explain. It's something I have worn for many many years and, as I said, the pain had subsided by Tuesday," she replied.

About half an hour into the hearing, the trial was halted when Andrews broke down as she was questioned about sexual abuse she said she suffered when she was eight.

Insisting he wanted to clarify one point, Mr Houlder said: "It didn't involve penetration either of your vagina or anus?" "When I was a child?" she asked, beginning to cry. "Yes, it did." As she began to sob, the barrister asked: "Which?"

As her sobs continued, he mumbled: "I have not the slightest wish to discuss that, but I thought there was going to be no contention over it."

The trial continues today.

webTitle: Pathologist's errors reveal failures in hiring of locums

fields.headline: Pathologist's errors reveal failures in hiring of locums
fields.trailText: Hospitals throughout the country are risking patient safety by hiring locum doctors without checking their competence, references or employment history, according to a report from the government's inspectorate body yesterday.
fields.body:
Hospitals throughout the country are risking patient safety by hiring locum doctors without checking their competence, references or employment history, according to a report from the government's inspectorate body yesterday.

The commission for health improvement's "deeply disturbing" report was described by chief executive Peter Homa as a wake-up call for the NHS. "Hospitals up and down the country are not following the rules, which must raise concerns, inevitably and disturbingly, about patient safety," he said. The CHI recommended a national database holding all doctors' employment history and "smart cards" for locum doctors carrying the same information.

The report is the result of an investigation into the employment by four hospital trusts of a 78-year-old locum pathologist, James Elwood, who opted for voluntary erasure from the medical register after concerns were voiced about his performance.

A review of more than 10,000 of Dr Elwood's slides found that 223 patients had been wrongly diagnosed, with serious consequences for seven of them.

One was Carenza Lewis, a member of Channel 4's Time Team, who unnecessarily had one breast removed and then elected to have the second removed for fear that the cancer she wrongly believed she had would recur.

Nobody could say whether Dr Elwood was a competent doctor, the report said. The reviews of his work were designed only to find out whether patients needed alternative treatment. Since he was no longer working he would never be investigated.

But CHI's firepower was reserved for the hospital trusts that regularly employed him with no more formality than a word of mouth recommendation from consultants elsewhere.

Swindon and Marlborough NHS trust used Dr Elwood as a locum between 1995 and 1999, despite being told of an investigation into his work by the Royal United hospital in Bath in 1997 and that there was a litigation claim against him.

webTitle: Smear tests which failed to save lives

fields.headline: Smear tests which failed to save lives
fields.trailText: More than 3m women went to their GP for a smear test last year. The majority - 83.7% - of all women aged between 25 and 64 have been screened in the past five years. Most will have had a negative result and will think there is no chance they will develop cervical cancer.
fields.body:
More than 3m women went to their GP for a smear test last year. The majority - 83.7% - of all women aged between 25 and 64 have been screened in the past five years. Most will have had a negative result and will think there is no chance they will develop cervical cancer.

The Leicester exercise demonstrates that they are wrong. Cervical screening saves lives, but it does not save every life.

We have been told for a few years that a small number of cancers will inevitably be missed. If Leicester is typical of the rest of the country then that number may be larger than imagined. A third of the cervical cancers in Leicester over an eight year period were either missed or their severity was under- estimated, and 14 women died.

The sobering point about the Leicester audit is that it was not triggered by one of the regular scandals that break over cervical smear tests. It was not a damage limitation exercise, but a cool-headed audit by clinicians who are considered to run a good quality screening service.

They will not be making more errors than anyone else.

When a woman has a smear test, a sample of cells from the neck of the cervix is removed, smeared on to a slide, fixed with preservative and sent to the cytology laboratory to be examined.

But the slides are not always easy to read for the trained cytoscreeners employed in laboratories in hospitals around the UK. Sometimes abnormal cells can be missed among thousands of healthy ones and sometimes they are obscured. Adenocarcinoma, a form of cervical cancer that is increasing among young women, is particularly hard to spot. The task is a laborious and poorly remunerated one and some hospitals find it hard to recruit screeners.

If there is any doubt about a slide, the screener is supposed to refer it on to the consultant pathologist. But even where the procedures are correctly followed, some abnormalities will be missed.

The argument that has raged in courts after women have died is over what constitutes an acceptable miss. There are huge variations around the country in the proportion of slides reported as abnormal. Where women have sued, it is not unusual for both sides to bring in pathologists who disagree over whether the pre-cancerous cells are visible on the slide or not.

The biggest cervical cancer scandal of recent times broke at the Kent and Canterbury hospital in 1996 when the smear tests of 91,000 women were recalled, eight women died and 30 had hysterectomies. More than 50 compensation cases have been settled.

While the laboratory at the hospital was not up to standard, it does not follow that every missed cancer was down to poor practice. Faced with the anxieties of women around the country and the huge litigation bill, the Department of Health realised there was a need to change the perception of screening.

In December 1998, the then health minister, Lady Hayman, warned women that the smear test was like a seatbelt; it was not guaranteed to prevent you from dying but might help save your life or limit the damage in a car crash. Since the programme was set up in 1988, the coordinators said it had saved more than 8,250 lives. The incidence of cervical cancer dropped by 42% between 1988 and 1997 in England and Wales. Each year, they said, 1,300 women had cancer diagnosed and treated who without screening would have died. Women were called for screening every three to five years. In the US they are screened every year, but statistics show the increased cancer detection rate was only 2%.

Improvements in the detection rate will come about only through improved technology. The government last year launched a pilot scheme for liquid based cytology, a different way of preparing the slide which should make it easier to read.

It will also pilot screening for human papilloma virus which is sexually transmitted and present in 95% of cancer cases.

webTitle: Heathrow gave pilot in air miss '4 warnings'

fields.headline: Heathrow gave pilot in air miss '4 warnings'
fields.trailText: The civil aviation authority is looking into an incident at Heathrow airport this week when an Iberian Airlines jet was said to have come within 200ft of a United Airlines jumbo which was attempting to land.
fields.body:
The civil aviation authority is looking into an incident at Heathrow airport this week when an Iberian Airlines jet was said to have come within 200ft of a United Airlines jumbo which was attempting to land.

The Iberian plane appeared to ignore four warnings from air traffic control not to take off because doing so would put it in the path of the United Boeing 747 which was trying to land with hundreds of passengers on board.

A witness said: "The captain was told to stop four times."

The captain of the United 747 was forced to take evasive action, flying round the airport, before being allowed to land.

The CAA last night confirmed the incident had taken place. It had yet to call in the investigators, however.

It said the planes were a mile apart at the time and the air accident investigation board would not be examining the incident.

But sources at Heathrow said no official investigation could take place unless the CAA asked for it.

They said that investigators had shown an interest but were powerless to intervene unless invited to do so.

The incident shows up the increasing problems of takeoff and landing at Heathrow, particularly at busy times.

Industry sources said the incident showed that Heathrow was an extremely congested airport, and posed clear dangers to pilots on landing and takeoff.

fields.headline: Phoenix rises from the wings
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Philip Board, 42, runs Clarence Farm at Membury in Devon with his brother Fred and has been hand-rearing Phoenix the calf, famous for escaping the Maff mass cull. Phoenix has now been offered big money to star in a pantomime.
fields.body:
Philip Board, 42, runs Clarence Farm at Membury in Devon with his brother Fred and has been hand-rearing Phoenix the calf, famous for escaping the Maff mass cull. Phoenix has now been offered big money to star in a pantomime.

It's been mayhem, the phone has been going non-stop all week. The other day a woman rang and said: "This might sound a little strange, but I work for a pantomime company touring the west country." They were doing Jack and the Beanstalk and she asked if Phoenix could be in it. I said I didn't see any harm - not if it was just around the west country. A newspaper picked up on it and contacted the panto company. The paper was told (probably as a joke) that it was going to pay Phoenix £100,000, and it printed it. The paper also said that Shane Ritchie is starring in the show. I hope Phoenix doesn't upstage him.

There's been talk about her doing panto in London, but that wouldn't be fair on her. If we do it locally, she can come home after, or stay at a local farm - someone would put her up. I don't want to drag her around London. The west country's tourist industry has suffered because of foot and mouth, so if people want to see Phoenix, they can come here. The money raised could go to the local Green Welly Appeal to help farmers.

A local retired man has offered to take her to the agricultural shows, and if she attracts more people, all the better. We've had lots of offers, from making Phoenix mugs and dolls to her representing veterinary drugs, but we haven't had time to think about them yet.

Our postman's been loaded with mail. We've had letters thanking us for saving the calf and standing up to the Maff, grannies sending a few pounds and kids sending their pocket money. This morning I was sent a "she's a winner" medal to put round the calf's neck. On Tuesday, Phoenix's ear tags and birth certificate arrived, so she's fully legal now.

All the support really is moving. I've been on radio in Sydney, Washington DC, New York and Canada, and my son was in the papers in Iceland. He's as chuffed as anything about the attention because all the girls think he's fantastic. It all started when some people from the village saw my mug in the papers while they were on holiday in Barbados and the wife got upset about it and contacted the local paper.

I haven't been able to leave the farm all week because I'm on a 21-day quarantine. My wife, son and brother have licences to come and go, but they [Maff] won't give me one. I don't know why. I've had police at the end of the drive 24 hours a day. I'm not sure if they're to keep me from leaving or to stop other people coming in.

The calf, one horse and a dog are the only animals we have now, but I've still had lots of work; cleaning the machinery and stripping the barns. And the wife's given me things to do indoors - cooking, cleaning, putting the washing on and hanging it out. I'm turning into a house husband, which is strange. I'm a typical man, I'm afraid, and I can't even go out and have a pint. The wife's loving it, but at least I don't have to shop for food.

fields.headline: ScottishPower survives the blackout
fields.trailText: ScottishPower, Britain's largest electrical utility, yesterday brushed aside US power and other problems and claimed that it was making considerable progress in reducing its exposure to shortages on the west coast of America.
fields.body:
ScottishPower, Britain's largest electrical utility, yesterday brushed aside US power and other problems and claimed that it was making considerable progress in reducing its exposure to shortages on the west coast of America.

Its US business incurred extra costs of almost £300m in the year to March, £90m of which were caused by the breaking down of its Hunter generator plant in Utah. The 160-day closure forced the company to buy in power from other generators - at a time when prices were high.

ScottishPower said that the Hunter plant was now repaired and had been supplying customers since last weekend. The company plans to increase its generation capacity by 1,000MW, or 10%, in this financial year. A new plant in Gadsby, Salt Lake City, was the first to begin generation this week, while five more are in construction.

The company said its profits would continue to be significantly hit by power shortages in the US for the next two months, but increased generation capacity would reduce exposure by September.

For the year to March 2001, it posted underlying pre-tax profits of £628m, down from £736m the previous year and in line with analysts' forecasts. However, the City greeted news of a planned restructuring warmly, with shares in ScottishPower closing 6.5p higher at 448p.

A spokesman said that the utility firm was confident of recovering "most, though not all" of the £300m costs incurred during the US power shortage through increased charges to customers.

The proposed increases are subject to court proceedings, though most analysts consider ScottishPower to have a strong case.

Ian Russell, who took over as chief executive in March, said the balance between company's power generation and supply divisions had been "out of kilter", and added that in creased generation in the US was helping to redress that balance.

ScottishPower is thought also to be considering acquiring US firm Enron's Portland plant quoted at around $3bn.

"When we acquired PacifiCorp [Scottish Power's US business] we said it was a platform for further growth," Mr Russell said.

"Obviously Portland is right in our own back yard."

An acquisition could be funded by the proposed sale of its water business, Southern Water, which has proved ex pensive since the introduction of extra regulatory requirements. The company said it had received several expressions of interest for the business.

ScottishPower's acquisition of Southern Water formed part of its disastrous attempt to establish the company as a multi-utility provider - supplying customers not only with power, but with water, financial services (through a joint venture with Royal Bank of Scotland) and telecoms (through its partly spun-off business Thus).

Yesterday Mr Russell, who had backed these ambitious plans during his eight years at ScottishPower, outlined a more modest vision for the future.

"You have to limit what you take on," he said.

"Right now we are focusing on improving the businesses that we have got."

The now aborted plans to diversify across a host of utility services contributed to the loss of 200,000 customers in the UK last year in ScottishPower's core business. The figure has since stabilised at 3.5m.

 Powergen, the British utility that has agreed to a takeover by German power giant E.ON, yesterday said that its pre-tax profits for the first three months had fallen to £200m, compared with £233m the previous year.

Turnover was up 49% thanks to expanding UK business and a three months contribution from its US acquisition LG&E, though regulatory price caps in Britain had held back earnings.

fields.headline: 'Brave' choice of prisons inspector praised
fields.standfirst: Special report: prisons
fields.trailText: A leading human rights expert, Anne Owers, was yesterday named by the home secretary, Jack Straw, as the surprise successor to Sir David Ramsbotham as chief inspector of prisons.
fields.body:
A leading human rights expert, Anne Owers, was yesterday named by the home secretary, Jack Straw, as the surprise successor to Sir David Ramsbotham as chief inspector of prisons.

Penal reformers praised Ms Owers's appointment, saying her respected campaigning record over the past 20 years, particularly on refugees and reform of the criminal justice system, proved she would bring the independence of mind needed to resist ministerial interference. She will take up the job in August.

The appointment of Ms Owers as the first female chief inspector prompted comparisons with Elizabeth Fry, the 19th century Quaker whose prison inspections led to better conditions across Europe.

She follows in the footsteps of Sir David and Sir Stephen Tumim who both clashed with home secretaries over their critical reports. Some critics had feared that Mr Straw would prune the powers of the chief inspector of prisons, but Ms Owers's appointment and unchanged terms of reference dispelled those anxieties.

Ms Owers, 53, is the director of Justice, the all-party human rights and law reform organisation, in which job she has repeatedly expressed concern about Mr Straw's criminal justice policy. She played a key role on the government task force overseeing implementation of its human rights law, and also served on the commission on the future of multiethnic Britain.

Ms Owers said: "I am not just interested in what happens to people in prison but also what happens to them afterwards."

Frances Crook, director of the Howard League for Penal Reform, welcomed the appointment, saying Ms Owers had great integrity. "It is a very brave and interesting appointment and I hope that Anne will continue the tradition set by Sir David."
