fields.headline: £98m cushions final blow from Corus
fields.trailText: Attempts to save 6,000 steel jobs in Wales and the north-east finally collapsed yesterday, leaving unions and staff bitter at salvaging only modest pay-offs and a government retraining package.
fields.body:
Attempts to save 6,000 steel jobs in Wales and the north-east finally collapsed yesterday, leaving unions and staff bitter at salvaging only modest pay-offs and a government retraining package.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, joined the condemnation of Corus, the Anglo-Dutch heir to British Steel, which said that sums in a union-led rescue scheme simply did not add up.

Mr Byers said that many would share the bitterness felt by steelworkers at doomed plants, including Ebbw Vale and Llanwern in Wales and Redcar on Teesside. But he urged local people to turn their attention to new opportunities and different jobs by taking part in £98m worth of regeneration and training schemes.

Corus managers gave the thumbs-down at a meeting in London requested by steel unions, which were told that government-financed pay-offs of £2,500 a head would be made to the 6,000 staff, and to another 6,000 made redundant over the past two years.

Union leaders said the cash would bring a welcome boost to local economies in South Yorkshire and north-east Lincolnshire, as well as Wales and the north-east, but was no compensation for wrecked lives.

Michael Leahy, general secretary of the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation, said Corus's workforce had been betrayed by inept management which had lost the will to revive steel's flagging fortunes. He welcomed the government's planned review of employee consultation as a way of getting troubled firms to take workers' ideas more seriously.

"UK employees should never again be treated with the contempt that Corus has shown for its staff," he said. "New legislation cannot be introduced too early if UK workers are to be treated with the same dignity and respect as their European counterparts."

Corus said it had given the unions' proposals "full consideration and evaluation". A company spokesman said the decision was good news for the rest of the group because it would "now allow Corus to focus on the implementation of its restructuring programme, as well as supporting communities affected by the redundancies, in co-operation with the unions and government".

The regeneration packages total £48m for England and £5m voted for Wales by the Welsh Assembly. Wales Office minister David Hanson told steel workers: "You may have been treated badly by Corus but you're not going to be treated badly by the Welsh Assembly, the government or the unions."

First payments from the fund will be £2m for contractors and small supply firms whose businesses have been crippled by the closures.

fields.headline: Deutsche rises above turbulence
fields.standfirst: Bank bolsters global ranking with above-expectation profit
fields.trailText: Deutsche Bank yesterday underlined its claim to a place among the world's "bulge bracket" banks with a first-quarter profits performance that showed little signs of global market turbulence.
fields.body:
Deutsche Bank yesterday underlined its claim to a place among the world's "bulge bracket" banks with a first-quarter profits performance that showed little signs of global market turbulence.

Net profits reached €1.03bn (£639m), up 6% on the same quarter last year, and, though the figures were flattered by a change in accounting standards, the results were still some €400m ahead of market expectations.

"In a difficult environment we again demonstrated our stable and strong earnings power. Compared with our international competitors we turned in an excellent performance," said chairman Rolf Breuer.

Net interest income was up 12%, net commission income fell about 10% but trading profits climbed by a similar amount. Deutsche said the trading performance had been driven by the fixed-income and foreign exchange operations as well as the one-off accounting change which boosted earnings by €234m at the after-tax level.

"The extremely gratifying trading profit in a turbulent capital market during the last few months reflects Deutsche Bank's globally leading position as an investment bank," the bank said.

"I think they recognised the trend in time and were able to use the volatility of the market," Andreas Praezier, an analyst at Berenberg Bank, said.

However, the bank's cost-income ratio remains high, up from 74.2% to 75.9% (excluding goodwill amortisation) on the same period in 2000. Operating expenses were pushed up by exchange rate movements, preparations for the introduction of euro notes and coins, the European expansion of its retail banking arm, Deutsche Bank 24 and the roll-out of online broker Maxblue.

About 80% of the bank's trading income came from to customer-led dealing, according to chief financial officer Clemens Boersig. "This is primarily the result of a very strong customer flows and we have now very consistently demonstrated that we attract very strong customer flows."

Deutsche still has potential to gain in its advisory business, which includes the field of mergers and acquisitions.

In the first quarter of 2001, Deutsche was ranked number 14 in the global league tables of completed mergers and acquisitions compiled by Thompson Financial. Its ranking is expected to improve in the second quarter after it advised on the insurer Allianz's €22.8bn takeover of Dresdner Bank.

In Frankfurt the shares climbed in early trading but were dragged back by a falling wider market to close 2.2% lower at €89.75.

webTitle: Notebook: It's too easy to shout fire in Britain

fields.headline: Notebook: It's too easy to shout fire in Britain
fields.trailText: Steel workers pay price of flexibility | Rail delay | PR coup
fields.body:
Steel workers pay price of flexibility

The days of them and us were supposed to be over. Partnership was the buzz word in union and management circles. Last night, however, the new chumminess took a back seat to a renewed bout of old-fashioned class warfare.

The issue was lay-offs. As steel maker Corus slammed its doors in the face of a last-ditch rescue attempt, the CBI and TUC came to blows over whether Britain was more vulnerable to plant closures because of its easy hire and fire rules.

Digby Jones, the CBI's director general, says the "easy come, easy go" story about the British labour market is a myth. Companies make decisions to shut plants because of long-term concerns about profitability - not because of considerations about one-off redundancy costs.

There is a grain of truth in Mr Jones's argument: there is no doubt that many of the jobs lost in Britain in the past year were the result of global factors, not local conditions. World oversupply in the steel industry is the chief reason why 6,000 Corus workers are out of a job.

But the unions are right to ask why - when there is a global problem - the axe so often falls on British plants rather than European ones. Motorola is only the most recent example of a firm which had a choice between a European and British closure and chose the latter.

At the margin, when firms know they have to close a plant somewhere, they are bound to be motivated by local fac tors such as hire and fire rules. Britain's comparatively lightly regulated labour market has proved good at creating jobs. When times are tough, however, the downside of labour-market flexibility becomes more apparent.

Rail delay

It is now knocking on for six months since Britain's biggest corporate disaster area - Railtrack - started casting around for a new chairman.

There have now been more names linked with this executive position than models with Mick Jagger and there is still no sign that the embattled rail network company has any chance of attracting anything like the calibre of industrialist they had hoped for. There is a power vacuum at the top, although cynics might say there has been ever since Sir Philip "the invisible man" Beck took command two years ago. The list of people considered, approached and offered the "job from hell" reads like a who's who of British business.

The Railtrack headhunters and non-executives are said to have considered almost all the utility bosses. Ed Wallis of Powergen is understood to have turned it down. Ross Sayer of Innogy - who had a handy background in New Zealand Railways - was another alleged candidate, as was David Varney, the bulldog-like former boss of BG who is said to regard a bit of post-retirement chilling out as infinitely more appealing than mortal combat on behalf of the rail combine.

The nearest Railtrack has come to finding its man was with Sir John Parker of Lattice. He is understood to have virtually had his pen poised over the contract before a family illness made him think again. Now the names doing the rounds are John Armitt, the outgoing chief executive of the construction group Costain, and Sir Malcolm Field of the Civil Aviation Authority, although the Railtrack selection board is also now looking to the continent for a candidate - particularly at the men who run the German Bundesbahn and France's SNCF. They should be so lucky.

What they want is a candidate who can attract investment, operate in a commercial environment and has some understanding of working within a regulated business.

They also need a bruiser who can handle the grim possibility of corporate manslaughter charges and hang tough with the government, which, although it does not own a 51% stake, certainly acts as if it does. They will also need a giant ego, confidence in dealing with ministers and mandarins and an ability to trot out reassuring, macho sound bites.

The answer is simple. They need a politician. Step forward Steven Norris, Michael Heseltine or Kenneth Clarke.

PR coup

Taking of career moves: James Rubin, the assistant secretary of state for public affairs in the Clinton administration and best known as the mouthpiece for Madeleine Albright, is joining Brunswick, the City's biggest public relations outfit, next week as a partner.

This is a real coup for Alan Parker, Brunswick's founder, and underlines his determination to develop his PR business internationally.

Rubin's job, we assume, will largely be confined to the cocktail party circuit, along with his famous wife, the CNN war reporter Christiane Amanpour. But, hopefully, he will find some time to deal with the odd problematic Brunswick client - such as Railtrack.

webTitle: George Harrison has lung surgery to remove growth

fields.headline: George Harrison has lung surgery to remove growth
fields.trailText: Former Beatle George Harrison has undergone surgery to remove a cancerous growth from one of his lungs, it was announced last night.
fields.body:
Former Beatle George Harrison has undergone surgery to remove a cancerous growth from one of his lungs, it was announced last night.

The operation at a clinic in the US was successful, according to a statement from his solicitor. Harrison is now recovering in Tuscany, Italy, with his wife Olivia.

The 58-year-old's solicitor, Nick Valner, said: "The operation was successful and George has made an excellent recovery. He is in the best of spirits and on top form - the most relaxed and free since the attack on him in 1999."

Referring to the star's solo albums, the statement continued: "Although All Things Must Pass away, George has no plans right now and is still Living in the Material World, and wishes everyone all the very best. God bless and not to worry."

Harrison had previously been treated for throat cancer after he found a lump on his neck in July 1997. He had surgery the following month and radiation therapy.

Afterwards, he said: "I got it purely from smoking. I gave up cigarettes many years ago, but had started again for a while and then stopped in 1997."

In 1999 Harrison was stabbed by a fan who broke into his Oxfordshire mansion. Michael Abram was found not guilty, by reason of insanity, of attempted murder and was ordered to be held indefinitely in a psychiatric hospital.

fields.headline: Bare floors 'safer than carpets'
fields.trailText: Loft-dwelling urbanites who have abandoned wall-to-wall shagpile for bare floorboards or concrete appear to have made the right choice on medical grounds.
fields.body:
Loft-dwelling urbanites who have abandoned wall-to-wall shagpile for bare floorboards or concrete appear to have made the right choice on medical grounds.

Carpets could be killing us because they harbour toxins at levels far higher than those found on polluted city streets, environmental engineers in the US have warned. The concentration of pollutants is up to 10 times higher in homes than outdoors.

"If truckloads of dust with the same concentration of toxic chemicals as is found in most carpets were deposited outside, these locations would be considered hazardous waste dumps," said John Roberts, who has studied the problem for nearly 20 years.

He has found that on average a 10-year-old carpet will contain 2lb (900g) of dust, much of it made up of dangerous substances, including heavy metals such as lead, cadmium and mercury, pesticides, and carcinogenic polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and polychlorinated biphenols (PCBs).

"The carpet is the largest reservoir of dust in a house, so that a house with bare floors and a few area rugs will have about one-tenth of the dust found in a house with wall-to-wall carpet," Mr Roberts said.

Contaminants are brought in on on pets' paws or on shoes and become trapped deep in carpet fibres.

Cigarette smoke, cooking fumes, dust mites, mould and residues of solvents on dry cleaned clothes all exacerbate the problem. Attempts to clean the house can make matters worse because of the chemicals in cleaning products.

Britons are particularly at risk because of their fondness for Axminsters and Wiltons and because 90% of their homes are carpeted.

Children are worst affected because they often play on the floor and then put their hands in their mouths. They inhale 23 times as much air as adults, weight for weight, and can be damaged by even low levels of toxins. US studies have suggested that the average infant ingests 110 nanograms a day of the PAH benzopyrene - the equivalent of three cigarettes.

The most powerful weapons against pollutants are the doormat and vacuum cleaner, Mr Roberts said.

 Long-term exposure to increased levels of airborne pollution could shorten people's lives by up to six months, a report by the committee on the medical effects of air pollutants said yesterday. The report, based on US research, shows that residents of cleaner cities live longer than their peers in dirty ones.

fields.headline: Morse suffers delayed reaction
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Morse yesterday became the latest information technology firm to warn that the adverse economic environment had hit business and it would have to cut jobs.
fields.body:
Morse yesterday became the latest information technology firm to warn that the adverse economic environment had hit business and it would have to cut jobs.

The firm, which specialises in selling computer servers and consultancy services, said that, while it had weathered the "challenging" three months to March better than many in its sector, April had seen an increased number of orders cancelled or deferred.

"The primary reason behind this is customers' uncertainty about the economic environment," said chief executive Duncan McIntyre, adding that April trading was down 15% on last year.

Morse's biggest customers are telecommunications firms and investment banks, which analysts say are both reining in spending.

Morse has tended to do most of its business in its fourth quarter, towards the end of May and in June. Analysts say it will remain unclear how badly the firm has been affected by the slowdown until the end of that period.

In the meantime the company will cut an undisclosed number of jobs from its 1,300 European staff and regional office administration will be taken over by head office, cutting total costs by an estimated £5m.

Merrill Lynch, Morse's stockbroker, said it was downgrading its full-year revenue forecast by 10% to £591m and expected margins to slip in the following year.

Analyst Anna Bannon said the warning was "disappointing" but unsurprising given its exposure to telecoms and investment banking. She said spending in those areas was unlikely to improve in the next six months.

Shares fell by 20% in early trading but later rallied to close down just 17.5p at 300p.

webTitle: Arafat's wife: I always hated Israelis anyway

fields.headline: Arafat's wife: I always hated Israelis anyway
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Suha Arafat, the Palestinian first lady once famed for her outspoken remarks and a talent for embarrassing her husband, has confessed that she hates Israel, and never really believed in peace with the Jewish state.
fields.body:
Suha Arafat, the Palestinian first lady once famed for her outspoken remarks and a talent for embarrassing her husband, has confessed that she hates Israel, and never really believed in peace with the Jewish state.

Her remarks to the Saudi women's magazine, Sayidaty, break a lengthy silence from the 37-year-old convent-educated wife of Yasser Arafat. They were reprinted yesterday in Yediot Ahronoth, the largest circulation Hebrew newspaper, at a time when the Palestinians are trying to get Israel to agree to an Egyptian-Jordanian ceasefire plan.

"I hate the Israelis," Yediot quotes Mrs Arafat as saying. "I oppose normalisation with them. Israeli women have attempted to make contact with me and I rejected them.

"I am giving an unequivocal message to all Israeli women proposing help for our institutions: you are responsible for the problems our children have. How do you dare to offer donations?"

The interview is the first extensive airing of Mrs Arafat's opinions since 1999 when she embarrassed the then visiting American first lady, Hillary Clinton, by accusing Israel of poisoning Palestinian air and water, and causing cancer.

It also offers a new explanation for Mr Arafat's distinctive tremor: the quivering of his lower lip that press reports attribute to Parkinson's disease.

"This is the result of air pressure on aeroplanes - he is under pressure, and it is no wonder that the situation has had an effect on him." Mrs Arafat says her 71-year-old husband is in good health.

She makes plain that, even in the years before the intifada, she did not fully believe in the peace process. "I was never happy with the way negotiations with the Israelis were conducted. The way things are now, I do not believe we will ever achieve true peace."

Mrs Arafat's comments are bound to give succour to hardline Israelis who argue that the Palestinians are no fit partners for peace. But her remarks appear to be aimed more at ordinary Palestinians, as well as potential patrons during a visit to Saudi Arabia which was part religious pilgrimage, part fundraising mission for her husband's cash-strapped administration.

Mrs Arafat has not been seen at her seaside home for several months and is believed to have spent most of the intifada in Paris. Her absence has embittered ordinary people who had expected their first lady to remain by their side.

The daughter of a wealthy Christian family, she converted to Islam after her secret marriage to Mr Arafat in 1990.

Her trip to Saudi Arabia marked her first pilgrimage and she is pictured in Sayidaty in traditional dress.

The photo spread may also be an attempt to assure Palestinians about her marriage to Mr Arafat. She says they have grown closer despite disagreements including, she claims, her efforts to stamp out corruption in the Palestinian Authority. "I am not afraid Arafat will marry another wife at the same time he is married to me. He doesn't have the time."

webTitle: 27% of new HIV patients may be resistant to drugs

fields.headline: 27% of new HIV patients may be resistant to drugs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: More than a quarter of patients newly infected with HIV in Britain may be resistant to at least one of the powerful drugs used to fight the virus and Aids.
fields.body:
More than a quarter of patients newly infected with HIV in Britain may be resistant to at least one of the powerful drugs used to fight the virus and Aids.

A study of 69 patients diagnosed between 1994 and last autumn suggested that 14% of them possessed a mutation associated with drug resistance and the figure rose to 27% among those infected last year.

Although the incidence of Aids and death from HIV infection have declined rapidly in the UK since the introduction of anti-retroviral drugs in 1996, 3,000 people each year are still infected by the HIV virus. About 30,000 people in all are infected and there is concern at the apparent rise in high-risk sexual behaviour among homosexual men.

The study, reported in today's British Medical Journal, showed that 10 of the patients had a mutation of the virus indicating resistance to one of the three anti-retrovirals used in "last resort" cases and two appeared resistant to two drugs. Because they were new cases, none had started therapy.

Nine were men infected through sex between men and the other was a woman who was infected while injecting herself. The authors, members of a group monitoring transmission of HIV drug resistance, said no conclusions should be drawn from this. But as unprotected sex among those at highest risk continues, the likelihood of being infected by a patient who has taken anti-retrovirals increases.

webTitle: Toxic leak evacuees had kidney damage

fields.headline: Toxic leak evacuees had kidney damage
fields.trailText: Residents evacuated from a village contaminated by toxic gases from a nearby chemical dump had already suffered kidney damage, health experts revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Residents evacuated from a village contaminated by toxic gases from a nearby chemical dump had already suffered kidney damage, health experts revealed yesterday.

ICI advised evacuation of 26 homes in Weston, near Runcorn in Cheshire, 14 months ago after chemicals from its dump were discovered seeping through the ground. The chemical hexachlorobutadiene, or HCBD, is known to cause kidney damage in rats.

A further 200 homes were vacated voluntarily after ICI offered to buy any house in the village, even though HCBD was detected at dangerously high levels only in the original 26.

The chemical came from industrial waste from ICI's Runcorn factory which it dumped in disused quarries 25 years ago. Gas was detected in boreholes in December 1999.

North Cheshire health authority tested 70 people evacuated from the homes with high levels of HCBD; half had kidney abnormalities. It is hoped that the kidneys can repair themselves if they are away from further contamination.

Brian Staples, a doctor who headed the investigation, said: "For the people who had health checks, there was a small health risk associated with these findings. It has to be recognised that there are some uncertainties surrounding our results and we cannot be sure what we have observed is due to land contamination."

The residents will continue to be tested to see if their kidneys repair themselves after they have moved away from the contaminated houses. A spokesman for Weston Residents Action Group, Mike Price, said: "We must await further tests and hope that there is some improvement now that they have moved away from the contaminated area."

An ICI spokesman said the company supported the publication of information which "assists residents of Weston and extends the level of understanding", but added that it could not be shown that ICI was responsible.

"Health checks suggest minor kidney dysfunction in some of those tested. They say that the cause of these results is not clear and they cannot be sure that land contamination is responsible."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Young girls overweight | Medal case cabbie guilty | Army bullying trial halted | Plea to aid stowaway cat | PR row over Big Brother
fields.body:
Young girls overweight

One in three 11-year-old girls is now overweight and more than one in 10 is obese, according to Leeds University research published in the British Medical Journal today. The number of youngsters considered fat or obese have almost doubled in 10 years.

Medal case cabbie guilty

Taxi driver Terry Sandford, 41, of Bexleyheath, Kent, was yesterday found guilty at Isleworth crown court of trying to steal a briefcase containing Olympic rowing hero Matthew Pinsent's gold medal. Sandford, who had pleaded not guilty, will be sentenced on May 25.

Army bullying trial halted

The trial of Liverpool army cadet instructor Brian Herbert, 21, accused of bullying recruits, was halted yesterday at Liverpool crown court and the jury discharged. Herbert denied kicking Merseyside cadets and threatening to castrate them at Otterburn, Northumberland. Judge Bryn Holloway ordered a retrial on July 16.

Plea to aid stowaway cat

The RSPCA is appealing for someone to adopt a cat that survived a six week journey from Israel to Britain inside a shipping container and foot the £800 bill for its six month quarantine.

PR row over Big Brother

James Herring, the PR consultant who promoted Channel 4's Big Brother, has had an injunction taken out by his employer, Avalon, to stop him working for rival firms. Mr Herring is working a year's notice. Part of this year's Big Brother campaign will be run by his wife Cath Taylor's rival company.

fields.headline: Macedonia strikes at rebels
fields.standfirst:
Nato and British envoy urge people to isolate extremists trying to provoke war

Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: The government of Macedonia appeared to have abandoned hope of finding a peaceful solution to its conflict with ethnic Albanian extremists yesterday, launching an offensive against the Albanian rebels after two of its soldiers were killed and at least one kidnapped.
fields.byline: Nicholas Wood in Kumanovo Macedonia, and agencies in Brussels
fields.body:
The government of Macedonia appeared to have abandoned hope of finding a peaceful solution to its conflict with ethnic Albanian extremists yesterday, launching an offensive against the Albanian rebels after two of its soldiers were killed and at least one kidnapped.

The offensive was provoked by the ambush of an army patrol early yesterday morning in the village of Vaksince, where the rebels had taken over, and it was there in the north that the government struck back.

Some houses were on fire in Vaksince after attacks by helicopter gunships in and around the village. There and in other villages around the city of Kumanovo, the government vowed to reclaim land seized by the Albanians' hardline National Liberation Army (NLA).

In Vaksince, the two soldiers were killed and another captured after their seven-man convoy moved aside barricades erected to keep the federal authorities out of the village. The extremists later proclaimed they had created a "free zone" in the area.

The government responded by issuing ultimatums to people living in 10 Albanian-dominated villages to leave their homes, and register with the police. The aim was to clear the way for the army assault, and to distinguish between residents and interlopers.

"We believe the terrorists are using these villages as cover," said one senior government official, who asked not to be named. "The aim of this [attempt to move people out of the area] is to give us broader scope to be able to execute this operation."

Some people were reported to be heeding the government deadlines to leave, which fell at 3pm and 6pm for two separate groups of villages.

But it was unclear whether those who remained were staying in solidarity with the NLA. In at least one village people were being used as a civilian shield by the hardliners. "We are not going to let a chicken leave here," said a gunman. Around him strolled others in a mix of uniforms carrying AK-47s. One had a grenade launcher over his shoulder.

Britain's ambassador to Macedonia, Mark Dickenson, condemned the National Liberation Army but appealed on television for sanity on the part of all the ethnic groups.

"This so-called NLA wants a civil war. Do not let them," he said. "Ninety-nine per cent of the citizens, most Macedonians and Albanians, reject the NLA."

In Brussels, Nato put out a statement in the name of its secretary general, Lord Robertson, calling the attacks on the security forces cowardly and saying they could harm the peace "in a country that is a successful example of a well-functioning democracy in the Balkans".

He urged all ethnic groups "to unite in solidarity against extremists and to isolate them ... The legitimate aspirations of the ethnic Albanian community can only be achieved through political means."

The minority Albanians say their special linguistic and other rights in Macedonia are insufficient and must be expanded by the Slav majority.

Mainstream Albanian politicians in the republic have pressed this cause through parliament, but it has been taken into the realm of arms by extremists believed to be getting help and weaponry - and in some cases manpower - from Albanian groups in Kosovo and Serbia proper.

In the fields west of Kumanovo yesterday, the Macedonian security forces deployed armoured personnel carriers and set up checkpoints. Some could be seen wearing flak jackets with British army camouflage, recently donated by the government in London.

In one village police vehicles stood 700 metres from the NLA front line. Neither side was dug in.

The emergence of hardliners around Kumanovo is a big setback for the Macedonian government which was in negotiation with opposition Slav and Albanian parties on the creation of a new government.

But a series of killings and disturbances since last weekend look almost certain to put an end to that process. That may have been the intent of the orchestrators.

Parliament in Skopje was scheduled to hold a special session today to discuss measures to deal with the explosive situation in the country.

fields.headline: Old Mutual in incentives row
fields.trailText: Fund management and stockbroking firm Old Mutual is embroiled in a fat-cat row in South Africa.
fields.body:
Fund management and stockbroking firm Old Mutual is embroiled in a fat-cat row in South Africa.

The London-listed firm owns 53% of South African bank Nedcor which is facing criticism in Johannesburg for an executive pay scheme which allows at least 16 executives to reap the rewards of investment in technology companies.

The incentive scheme is being challenged for failing to link the rewards of the unidentified executives to the performance of Nedcor. A former South African finance minister, Chris Liebenberg, is chairman of Nedcor.

South Africa-based Old Mutual owns British broking firms Capel Cure Sharp and Gerrard, and its chairman, Mike Levett, who also holds the post of chief executive, is on the board of Nedcor.

Mr Levett is under pressure from British investors to divide his roles, but is not thought to be one of the 16 Nedcor executives who are participants in the remuneration scheme.

Details of the pay plan were revealed in South Africa earlier this week. The incentive scheme links the performance of a number of executives to their technology investments on behalf of Nedcor.

They stand to share in the equivalent of 5% of the profits of these investments, the most prominent of which is reportedly in Dimension Data.

Old Mutual in London referred inquiries to South Africa yesterday, where officials were unavailable for comment.

However, in South Africa, Mr Liebenberg has been quoted as defending the scheme. He has said that the pay deal was important to retain staff and keep them in South Africa.

webTitle: Ikea takes flat packs to more places

fields.headline: Ikea takes flat packs to more places
fields.trailText: The Ikea flatpack furniture chain plans two more British stores, in Southampton and Sheffield, creating up to 1,450 jobs and taking the total number of outlets to 14.
fields.body:
The Ikea flatpack furniture chain plans two more British stores, in Southampton and Sheffield, creating up to 1,450 jobs and taking the total number of outlets to 14.

There will also be a £40m distribution warehouse in Peterborough.

The two stores are part of an expansion programme announced last summer, when the Swedish retailer, which has revolutionised British furniture and homeware shopping, announced it wanted to build 20 new stores in the next 10 years which would ultimately create 10,000 jobs.

The company is already working on new outlets in Glasgow and Cardiff, with the Glasgow store now hiring staff for an autumn opening.

Many potential Ikea shoppers are put off by the prospect of a long journey to their nearest store and a similarly long queue at the checkout.

The company said the new stores would mean more people would be able to shop at Ikea and that their "shopping experience" would be better. It said it would then be able to cut prices further. In the last four years, the chain claims, it has reduced prices by 15%.

The two new stores will be the largest to date, trading from some 28,000 square metres. The present stores are 19,000-22,000 square metres.

Goran Nilsson, managing director of Ikea UK, said: "We are building on largely derelict and abandoned brown field sites where we can contribute to the regeneration of Sheffield, Southampton and Peterborough."

Ikea's plans were welcomed by the government. The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said they were "further proof that the UK is an excellent location for international companies looking to invest and expand and demonstrates the benefits brought by the creation of a stable economy".

The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, said: "Ikea's huge popularity in this country is bringing great benefits for the UK jobs market".

The Cardiff, Sheffield and Southampton stores, together with the Peterborough distribution centre, are scheduled to open in 2003, subject to planning approval.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Steve Nickell is an interesting fellow.. Musing on the problems of Britain's north-south divide, he suggests moving the apparatus of government out of the capital, lock, stock and barrel.
fields.body:
 Steve Nickell is an interesting fellow, despite being an economist and a member of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee. Musing on the problems of Britain's north-south divide, he suggests moving the apparatus of government out of the capital, lock, stock and barrel.

But what about his employers at the Bank? Yes, Steve thinks the Bank should be shunted en masse to Newcastle. Why not? The Old Lady of Grey Street has a charming ring to it. Deputy governor Mervyn King would surely enjoy a few bottles of Brown, a kebab and a spot of irrational exuberance in Bigg Market of a Saturday night.

While they are about it, they could do what Gordon Brown should have done back in 1997 when he made the Bank independent: change its name from the Bank of England to the Bank of the UK. The initials of the new Bank would be very catchy in a new slogan for Tyneside: "The BUK stops here."

 To help the Bank of England prepare for the idea of moving to its new region: a sign recently seen promoting a special offer on black pudding at William Wight's butcher in Tyne and Wear: "Nice and spicy and no lumps of fat - just like the wife."

 There is no excuse for the above, and neither is there any excuse for this antediluvian press release from Peoples Choice insurance retailer: "Lady driver slashes insurance and goes on Easter spending spree." So presumably Peoples Choice does not want to get business from women, unless they are ladies.

 A package from Dow Jones, publisher of the Wall Street Journal, arrives. "We saw in today's City Diary that you believe the Wall Street Journal could be described as the world's most boring newspaper," reads the letter from Helen Hawkins, Dow Jones's PR manager.

Well, I did, although I did say that Lloyd's List shipping newspaper was worse. "We'd like to persuade you to reconsider your opinion," says Helen. "We are therefore taking the liberty of sending you a copy of the Wall Street Journal ... for the next week." Thanks Helen.

My colleagues and I are grateful because, of course, we don't get the WSJ here. In fact, my boss muttered something about not knowing it was on sale in this country. So, for however long Helen keeps sending them, we will carry a daily selection of the WSJ's top un-boring headlines.

 From page 30 of yesterday's Wall Street Journal: "Turkish gas deregulation aims to meet aid guidelines". Well, that's not quite as good as the FT's all-time classic "Turkey has change of heart on hazelnut price support". But it's early days, Helen, early days.

 Somebody at the WSJ reads this diary, and so do at least two people in Scotland, based on the mail received about yesterday's item on the use of the word "retiral" by Scottish & Newcastle. I suggested this might be a misprint for "retrial", and wondered who'd been nicked.

Anton Cox emails to say the Oxford English Dictionary mentions retiral - the act of withdrawing from an office - as "now chiefly Scottish". That's perfectly appropriate, then, and we've all learned something. And S&N's group finance director is not being banged up. He's just retiraling.

 Now a word to any readers who might belong to the BBC's staff pension fund. There is no truth to the rumour that the BBC directors are planning a "pensions holiday" and want to avoid making the corporation's contributions to the fund, to keep their hands on the cash. It's not true, we've asked them, and are assured that the BBC isn't going to act like some penny-pinching private-sector company looking to get their hands on money that should go into the staff pension. Of course, if anyone knows otherwise, please give us a ring.

richard.adams@theguardian.com

fields.headline: No 1,873
fields.standfirst: Eva Sannum
fields.trailText: Pass notes: Eva Sannum
fields.body:
Age: 26.

Appearance: Icy, six-foot Norwegian blonde.

Status: Impending constitutional disaster.

This isn't another tale of Buckingham Palace-based jiggery-pokery, is it? Because if it is, I'm heading straight for page four: You'll be relieved to hear that the Windsors' grubby fingerprints are nowhere near this one, which concerns the Spanish crown. Although they're presumably close cousins or something, European royal families being what they are.

All right then. This better be good. The House of Bourbon has been rocked to its very foundations by the news that Miss Sannum, the daughter of an import-export salesman, may be about to marry the Iberian peninsula's most eligible bachelor, Prince Felipe. And for the Bourbons that really would take the biscuit, constitutionally speaking.

Why? Furious monarchists say an ancient clause compels the heir to choose another royal, as opposed, say, to an icy Norwegian heiress to an import-export business.

Don't tell me - the rentaquote constitutional experts have come storming out of the woodwork. Have they ever. "It would be inconceivable for this to happen," fumes Carlos Seco Serrano, a sort of Spanish Lord St John of Fawsley. Eva "does not have the most suitable name [and] has not received the correct education to be a princess and has to share a flat," scolds Hola! magazine. The prince and his dad, Spain's King Juan Carlos, are rumoured to be bickering.

How bad could this major geopolitical crisis get? Well, royal biographer Jose Luis de Vilallonga fears the marriage would "put us on the same level as the English", although in royal matters that particular fate seems some way off.

Not to be confused with: Eva Braun, Eva Peron, Eva Herzigova, Camilla Parker-Bowles.

webTitle: Tom Cruise sues wrestler for gay 'slur'

fields.headline: Tom Cruise sues wrestler for gay 'slur'
fields.trailText: Tom Cruise is suing an "erotic wrestler" who has starred in films such as The Cockpit Club and Hot Submissions and claims that he had a gay romance with the movie actor.
fields.body:
Tom Cruise is suing an "erotic wrestler" who has starred in films such as The Cockpit Club and Hot Submissions and claims that he had a gay romance with the movie actor.

Chad Slater, a 25-year-old Britney Spears fan whose professional name is Kyle Bradford, told a French entertainment magazine that their relationship broke up Cruise's marriage to the actress Nicole Kidman.

The $100m (£70m) lawsuit filed in the Los Angeles superior court alleges defamation, and says Slater told Actustar that "he had a continuing homosexual relationship during Cruise's marriage and that the relationship was discovered by Cruise's wife, who ended the relationship".

Kidman, 33, says that she does not know why her husband decided three months ago to end their 10-year marriage. The couple have two adopted children, eight-year-old Isabelle and Conor, six.

"While Cruise thoroughly respects others' right to follow their own sexual preference, he is not a homosexual, had no relationship of any kind with Kyle Bradford, and does not even know him," says the lawsuit.

The claim could damage Cruise's career, the lawsuit says, because fans might boycott his movies "particularly since he tends to play parts calling for heterosexual romance and action/adventure".

The magazine, which carried the porn actor's claim that Kidman walked in on an encounter he had with Cruise, has agreed to publish a retraction, said Bert Fields, a lawyer for the Hollywood star, who has been nominated three times for an Oscar.

Slater told Actustar that they met when Cruise called him out of the blue, using the assumed name of Tom Finigham, and requested a bout in a wrestling ring: the ring was rented and the two became intimate later.

Other stars have gone to some lengths to assert their heterosexuality. Richard Gere placed an advertisement in The Times 10 years ago to say that he and his then wife, Cindy Crawford, "remain very married" - they split soon after - and Jason Donovan sued The Face when it claimed that he was gay.

Slater's story has disrupted the choreography of the Cruise-Kidman split.

Dominic Barbara, a New York divorce lawyer, said: "Right after the divorce announcement there's a story about Tom being heartbroken because Nicole left.

"The following week there's a Nicole story on how she lost the baby and Tom doesn't care.

"Remember, 60% of movie-ticket buyers are women, so a guy like Cruise doesn't want to turn off the woman in the midwest... It's all about bankability, acceptability and morality."

Cruise, 38, is currently earning $25m plus a share of the profits from Minority Report, which he is making with Steven Spielberg, and is said to have a fortune of more than $100m, twice that of his wife.
fields.bodyText: Tom Cruise is suing an "erotic wrestler" who has starred in films such as The Cockpit Club and Hot Submissions and claims that he had a gay romance with the movie actor. Chad Slater, a 25-year-old Britney Spears fan whose professional name is Kyle Bradford, told a French entertainment magazine that their relationship broke up Cruise's marriage to the actress Nicole Kidman. The $100m (£70m) lawsuit filed in the Los Angeles superior court alleges defamation, and says Slater told Actustar that "he had a continuing homosexual relationship during Cruise's marriage and that the relationship was discovered by Cruise's wife, who ended the relationship". Kidman, 33, says that she does not know why her husband decided three months ago to end their 10-year marriage. The couple have two adopted children, eight-year-old Isabelle and Conor, six. "While Cruise thoroughly respects others' right to follow their own sexual preference, he is not a homosexual, had no relationship of any kind with Kyle Bradford, and does not even know him," says the lawsuit. The claim could damage Cruise's career, the lawsuit says, because fans might boycott his movies "particularly since he tends to play parts calling for heterosexual romance and action/adventure". The magazine, which carried the porn actor's claim that Kidman walked in on an encounter he had with Cruise, has agreed to publish a retraction, said Bert Fields, a lawyer for the Hollywood star, who has been nominated three times for an Oscar. Slater told Actustar that they met when Cruise called him out of the blue, using the assumed name of Tom Finigham, and requested a bout in a wrestling ring: the ring was rented and the two became intimate later. Other stars have gone to some lengths to assert their heterosexuality. Richard Gere placed an advertisement in The Times 10 years ago to say that he and his then wife, Cindy Crawford, "remain very married" - they split soon after - and Jason Donovan sued The Face when it claimed that he was gay. Dominic Barbara, a New York divorce lawyer, said: "Right after the divorce announcement there's a story about Tom being heartbroken because Nicole left. "The following week there's a Nicole story on how she lost the baby and Tom doesn't care. fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Milosevic won't read indictment | Barenboim firm on Wagner | Bonino ends hunger strike | Uphill work for Mbeki minister
fields.body:
Milosevic won't read indictment

The Belgrade district court tried yesterday to give Slobodan Milosevic the charge sheet against him from the UN war crimes tribunal, so that he could learn first-hand what it said. There was no mention of the tribunal arrest warrant being sent too.

Yugoslavia's jailed former leader refused to look at the indictment, an assistant to his lawyer said: "It was left on the bars of his cell, he did not want to take it."
Reuters, Belgrade

Barenboim firm on Wagner

Daniel Barenboim said yesterday that it was out- rageous and undemocratic that Israel's parliament was trying to prevent him from staging The Valkyries by Richard Wagner at a fes tival in Jerusalem in July, on the grounds that Hitler liked the opera.

Placido Domingo features and tickets are selling fast.
Reuters, Jerusalem

Bonino ends hunger strike

The Italian politician Emma Bonino resumed eating yesterday, saying after six days on hunger strike that her health was getting more attention than her cause. She is in hospital in Milan.

A former EU commissioner, Bonino, 53, was publicising the scant time given by Italian TV to small parties - such as her Radicals - running for election on May 13.
Reuters, Rome

Uphill work for Mbeki minister

The South African security minister who launched the investigation into alleged ANC plotting against President Thabo Mbeki tried to persuade MPs yesterday that the inquiry was his idea, not the president's.

Opposition parties ridiculed Steve Tshwete's testimony as "pitiful and pathetic".
Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

webTitle: Real-life rush-hour hijack becomes prime-time TV drama in Los Angeles

fields.headline: Real-life rush-hour hijack becomes prime-time TV drama in Los Angeles
fields.trailText: Los Angeles watched a real-life Keanu Reeves film unfold live on television as police chased a hijacked bus through the city centre crowded with evening rush-hour traffic.
fields.byline: Leon Drouin Keith in Los Angeles
fields.body:
Los Angeles watched a real-life Keanu Reeves film unfold live on television as police chased a hijacked bus through the city centre crowded with evening rush-hour traffic.

One woman was killed and seven people hurt when the bus ploughed into a minibus at a crossroads and careered into a delivery van. The bus came to a halt only after crashing into cars in a car park.

Police cornered the suspect and shot at him several times before arresting him.

The drama started when the man, allegedly involved in a nearby shooting, hijacked the vehicle with five passengers aboard, including a four-year-old girl, at a bus stop.

The woman driver was forced to drive with a gun held to her head.

Rolando Hernandez Gandara, 21, said the bus "kept going, like an earthquake, it just kept going... There was stuff flying everywhere."

The bus driver, the five passengers and the van driver were injured. The minibus driver was a woman in her 30s, police said.

fields.headline: Footballer suspended for 'slave' link
fields.trailText: Jonathan Akpoborie, a Nigerian striker with VfL Wolfsburg, has been suspended following revelations that he owns the ship allegedly involved in the trafficking of African child-workers last month.
fields.body:
A top-flight German football club has suspended one of its star players following revelations that he owns the MV Etireno, the ship allegedly involved in the trafficking of child-workers off the west African coast last month.

Jonathan Akpoborie, a Nigerian striker with VfL Wolfsburg, admits that he owns the ship which was found carrying at least a dozen children destined to be sold into slavery.

VfL Wolfsburg let Akpoborie continue to play, after he initially dismissed the allegations as "rubbish" and a "misunderstanding". But when the MV Etireno was proved to have been involved in a child-slave network, club managers this week insisted that he travel to Benin's capital, Cotonou, where the ship has been impounded, to shed light on the apparent scandal.

Requests by Akpoborie to take leave were declined; instead he has been officially suspended until further notice.

"Jonathan Akpoborie will be released indefinitely from his contractual obligations so that he can use his time to clear up the allegations," the club said.

Volkswagen, the club's main sponsor, was reported to have put pressure on Wolfsburg management to suspend the player, after its initial inaction.

"Of course we used our influence to pull the ripcord," a VW spokesman, Kurt Rippholz, said.

VW has confirmed that Akpoborie, who is married with two children, will be dismissed from the club if he cannot prove his innocence.

"If there's any stain on the player's character through this matter, neither the [football] union nor the company [VW] would be able to ignore it," Bernd Sudholt, an executive at VW who is on the club's board, told the football magazine Kicker. "In that case, it would be very difficult for Mr Akpoborie to fulfil his contract with Wolfsburg."

Akpoborie, 32, has repeatedly insisted he is not involved in the slave trade and has denied that he knew the ship was carrying child-workers.

Speaking on German television earlier this week he said the allegations were "invented by competitors". "I'll see anyone who says further untruths against me in a court of law."

Hoping to secure the vessel's release, Akpoborie has been in close contact with authorities in Benin ever since it was impounded.

Since joining Wolfsburg in June 1999, Akpoborie, its second leading scorer, has earned a reputation as one of the better so-called "African goal merchants" playing in Europe.

According to his official website after he arrived in Benin yesterday morning, Akpoborie said he was confident of putting a lid on the scandal.

"I've spoken to the interior ministry and police authorities and I now hope to get official confirmation that my ship was not involved in this affair," he said.

fields.headline: 'Playboy prince' tells of tiring workload
fields.trailText: The Duke of York, portrayed as a playboy prince, has hit back at his critics and revealed he worked regular 14 hour days which became "a little bit wearing at times".
fields.body:
The Duke of York, portrayed as a playboy prince, has hit back at his critics and revealed he worked regular 14 hour days which became "a little bit wearing at times".

He claimed in the Ministry of Defence Focus magazine: "It became very evident in the summer of last year that I was doing too much."

His comments that he has had to juggle the joint roles of a career in the Royal Navy with carrying out official royal duties came as a surprise to some royal observers. Tabloid newspapers gleefully printed a series of pictures of him sunbathing, partying and playing rounds of golf.

The duke, 41, who is soon to leave the navy after 22 years and begin a new job promoting British trade overseas, told the magazine of the strain of long stints away at sea.

"I suppose the separations played a significant part in my life." Without referring to the pressure put on his marriage, which ended in divorce, he said: "Being apart for so much of the time is a fact of life. There were other pressures on me that aren't on other sailors. That's the card I've been dealt so you just get on with it."

The duke dismissed any suggestion that his royal status had made it easier for him to succeed as a naval commander. "I've not been carried. I've not been additional, there is no other expectation. If you can do the job, then get on with it," he said.

The Queen's second son, who is fourth in line to the throne, said people would be surprised that his life was "a great deal more ordinary" than portrayed in the media.

But he accepted media scrutiny and said: "As a member of the royal family you can't be anything other than a public figure."

The duke said he thought people had the wrong idea about royalty. "It's one of those things where if you don't live it, it's very difficult to explain what it's like," he said. "If I were to ask you what it's like to be a member of the royal family you wouldn't have a clue.

"People have an expectation of how they should behave. And it's up to us to make them feel relaxed and to feel they should be perfectly normal.

"We're the same as everybody else. It's just by an accident of birth in that it's a cross we have to bear. Or a position that you have to hold with pride."
Press Association

fields.headline: Unwelcome mat out for pope
fields.standfirst:
Visits criticised by Orthodox hardliners of Greece and Ukraine. Keep out, says Russia

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: In the twilight of his papacy, John Paul II embarks today on one of the most ambitious and contentious missions of his celebrated career, heading into the heartlands of Orthodoxy, first in Greece and next month in Ukraine.
fields.body:
In the twilight of his papacy, John Paul II embarks today on one of the most ambitious and contentious missions of his celebrated career, heading into the heartlands of Orthodoxy, first in Greece and next month in Ukraine.

If the Vatican project is aimed at laying the foundations for overcoming the great schism that sundered Catholic and Orthodox Christians almost a thousand years ago, the impact of the pope's trip looks more likely to divide than unite.

Eighty years old and clearly infirm, the most widely travelled pope ever has been almost homebound for the past year, but the pilgrimage starting today marks a return to his obsessive globetrotting after an uncharacteristically long period in Rome.

The visit to Greece, though agreed by the Greek Orthodox church hierarchy, has aroused outpourings of fury and suspicion among the Greek clergy, with Orthodox priests denouncing the pope as a heretic, the devil's envoy, and a monster.

Anti-Vatican demonstrations are expected during the visit which took two years of painstaking official diplomacy to organise.

The visit to Ukraine next month is even more contested and unparallelled in that it is taking place despite the formal and bluntly stated opposition of the Russian church hierarchy and the main Ukrainian Orthodox church which comes under Moscow's jurisdiction.

"This is the first time ever that the Vatican has in fact chosen to ignore the views of the Orthodox church," says Felix Corley who monitors religious affairs in the former Soviet Union for the Keston Institute. "Patriarch Alexy said the pope can't come, the time is not right. And the pope said I'm coming anyway."

For the first Slav pope who did so much to further the end of communism across much of the Orthodox world, the visits to Athens, Kiev, and Lviv in western Ukraine appear to have taken on great personal importance.

Historic suspicions

But for suspicious Orthodox leaders, the papal visits are all about intrusion, proselytising, and seeking ultimately to assert Vatican hegemony over the Orthodox world.

"These visits are very historic," says Father Igor Vyzhanov, the official at the Moscow patriarchate responsible for relations with Roman Catholicism. "But if a Catholic sees them as a positive sign, it's a negative signal to the Orthodox believer. There are great historical wounds and the pope is rubbing salt into them."

In John Paul's long campaign to woo the Orthodox, the big prize is a visit to Moscow - which Russian believers call the Third Rome - and a meeting with Patriarch Alexy, the hardline leader of the world's biggest Orthodox church.

The Russian Orthodox Church is larger than all the other Orthodox churches combined which helps explain why the pope is so keen to come to Moscow.

But the chances of such a meeting before John Paul dies have been reduced to almost nil; during the recent Orthodox Easter celebrations, the patriarch reiterated his opposition to hosting a papal visit.

In visits to the Vatican, Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, and prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, have resisted Catholic pressure to agree to a papal trip.

"The arrival of the pope in Russia would cause an even greater reaction than we are currently seeing in Greece," says Father Vyzhanov. "And the Ukraine trip makes things even worse, more impossible."

Under pressure from the Moscow patriarchate, Russia is the only post-communist country not to have established full diplomatic relations with the Vatican in the decade since the iron curtain disintegrated in eastern Europe.

Mr Corley says that Patriarch Alexy has concluded that he will never meet the Polish pope and that this realisation has spurred the Vatican to snub Moscow and go ahead with the Ukraine visit.

The pope is to go to Lviv, the stronghold of Ukrainian nationalism in the west of the country where Greek Catholicism - the Uniates - is the dominant church.

Historically, the Greek Catholics were established on the east European fringes of the Catholic Austro-Hungarian empire in the 17th century as part of imperial Vienna's attempt to convert the Orthodox.

The Greek Catholics owe their loyalty to the Vatican while using Orthodox rites in their services. Since communism collapsed, the Orthodox and Uniates have been clashing, sometimes violently, over church property.

Earlier this year the pope named two new cardinals in Ukraine, including the head of the Greek Catholics, of whom there are 5m. It emerged that one of the cardinals had been consecrated in 1998, but that his appointment had been kept secret.

Paranoia

Such arcane Vatican political manoeuvring feeds Orthodox paranoia and the suspicion that the Greek Catholics are being used as a Trojan horse with the aim of seeking converts from Orthodoxy to Roman Catholicism.

The visit to Greece today is the first by a pope since the great schism of 1054 split christianity into Orthodox and Catholic churches and is expected to result in an ecumenical message issued jointly by the Vatican and Greek Orthodox leaders.

But the chances of healing the rift between Rome and Constantinople are now looking as frail as Pope John Paul's health.

webTitle: Satellite, cable & digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable & digital: The Prince Of Egypt | The Shawshank Redemption | Unforgiven | The Last Broadcast
fields.body:
Films

The Prince Of Egypt (Brenda Chapman, Simon Wells, Steve Hickner, 1998) 9.15am, 4.30pm, Sky Premier
DreamWorks' animated story of Moses is an epic affair: a cast of thousands and thousands is a cinch when they're all drawn. So the big set-pieces - the plague of locusts, the parting of the red sea, a chariot race - are majestic creations, but it's a testimony to the emotional content that some of the best scenes are quieter and more reflective, such as Moses wandering in the monolithic night-time palace of the pharaohs. Voiced by the likes of Val Kilmer, Ralph Fiennes and Michelle Pfeiffer.

The Shawshank Redemption (Frank Darabont, 1994) 10pm, FilmFour
A richly emotive tale of male comradeship. Tim Robbins is accountant Andy Defresne, convicted of wife-murder in the 40s, despite protesting his innocence; Morgan Freeman is Red, the fixer, who befriends him at the brutal Shawshank state prison. With just a poster of Rita Hayworth and a tiny geological hammer to call his own, Defresne survives the sadistic regime of governor Bob Gunton by becoming his bookkeeper - but will he and Red realise their dream of boatbuilding on the beach? Beautifully acted, and crafted in fine detail by Darabont, all the way to the unlikely denouement.

Unforgiven (Clint Eastwood, 1992) 10.10pm, Sky Cinema
Eastwood's Will Munny is a gunman turned pig-farmer, tempted into one last job - $1,000 to avenge an attack on a prostitute. With old buddy Morgan Freeman and brash young gun Jaimz Woolvett he sets out for Big Whiskey, where brutal Sheriff Daggett (Gene Hackman) rules with an iron fist. It's a harsh, brooding western which questions the old myths and the genre itself before reasserting both, Eastwood's penchant for natural lighting creating suitably sombre visuals.

The Last Broadcast (Stefan Avalos, Lance Weiler, 1998) 12.30am, FilmFour
A $900 movie about people meeting gruesome ends in the woods - sounds familiar? Released months before The Blair Witch Project, there was much inconclusive debate about whether any copycatting had occurred. Whatever, this is a gripping and creepy tale. A filmmaker (David Beard) is making a documentary about the bloody murders of a pair of cable show hosts (played by the directors) and their soundman (Rein Clabbers) in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey, while searching for the mythic Jersey Devil. The weird fourth of the party, the psychic Jim Seward, was convicted of the killings - but a more horrifying truth is revealed.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live cricket 10.30am Sky Sports 1
The start of the Benson & Hedges Cup and it's a rerun of last year's final, between Gloucestershire and Glamorgan. Matthew Maynard stood out last time, scoring a century for Glamorgan but ending on the losing side as Gloucestershire secured a third successive Lord's final win, thanks largely to Ian Harvey's five-wicket haul. They can claim to be the country's one-day specialists, but for how long?
Simon Burnton

It's a harsh, brooding western which questions the old myths and the genre itself before reasserting both, Eastwood's penchant for natural lighting creating suitably sombre visuals. The Last Broadcast (Stefan Avalos, Lance Weiler, 1998) 12.30am, FilmFour A $900 movie about people meeting gruesome ends in the woods - sounds familiar? Released months before The Blair Witch Project, there was much inconclusive debate about whether any copycatting had occurred. Whatever, this is a gripping and creepy tale. A filmmaker (David Beard) is making a documentary about the bloody murders of a pair of cable show hosts (played by the directors) and their soundman (Rein Clabbers) in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey, while searching for the mythic Jersey Devil. The weird fourth of the party, the psychic Jim Seward, was convicted of the killings - but a more horrifying truth is revealed. Paul Howlett Sports Live cricket 10.30am Sky Sports 1 The start of the Benson & Hedges Cup and it's a rerun of last year's final, between Gloucestershire and Glamorgan. Matthew Maynard stood out last time, scoring a century for Glamorgan but ending on the losing side as Gloucestershire secured a third successive Lord's final win, thanks largely to Ian Harvey's five-wicket haul. They can claim to be the country's one-day specialists, but for how long? Simon Burnton

fields.headline: Don't let it get you down
fields.trailText: Radio review: Peter Stringfellow does talkSPORT
fields.body:
Only a handful of people are so happy with their lot that they can say: "Now I've got a radio show on talkSPORT and my life is complete." Peter Stringfellow is one of them. "I have a club full of beautiful girls," he says, "eat and drink what the hell I want, go where the hell I want, when the hell I want." This week, Stringfellow added the sweetest icing to his already multi-storey cake of contentment. On Monday night he got to sit in for James Whale on talkSPORT.

His theme for the phone-in was, unsurprisingly, sex, and he was worried - as a radio virgin, losing his innocence in a very public one-night stand - about saying things he ought not to. "Can we use 'ovulate' at this time of night?" he panicked. When he sought an alternative for "sexual intercourse", his producer suggested the wonderfully romantic "business". I think that tells us all we need to know about talkSPORT

And indeed it was the night's business, with Stringfellow a compelling oracle of his own brand of sexual wisdom. "I'd rather see a beautiful girl take her clothes off than not," he revealed, not long before he paid Doncaster a rather back-handed compliment. "I don't think you'll be in too much trouble there", he told frisky Janet, 50, who insists on practising safe sex to avoid, as she put it, "STDs".

Tilly and Amanda called to enter a best fake-orgasm competition, with Stringfellow joining in with the winner ("now Amanda, now, oh, ahhh, Peter, there, there, A-A-Amandaaaaaaaa....") Graham from Dundee phoned in with a perky Bonaparte quotation ("women are nothing but machines for producing children") which made Stringfellow forget his earlier ovulation fears: "No wonder he got the shit beaten out of him at Waterloo!"

One caller had to go because he was "parked awkward", Joy took the news that "men have got willies and you haven't" from Stringfellow badly, and Emma called to say her husband had been unfaithful with a woman who was "40, fat and short". You could hear Stringfellow's mind boggling at the idea of bedding one of these qualities, let alone all three. "Wow," he said in a low whisper.

Best of all was sad Martin, 32 (last sex: six months ago). He and Stringfellow had an archetypal talkSPORT conversation, that choppy sea of contradiction and mateyness. "Women, they'll see you down the river - they are so materialistically minded", grumped Martin. "I love women, don't get me wrong", he added, nanoseconds later. Stringfellow, thought sad Martin, with all his girls and fun and now a radio show, should be "as happy as sand papers".

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Radio: Jazz Legends | Discovery | Evening Concert
fields.body:
A famous Belgian at last figures among Julian Joseph's Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3), the guitarist Django Reinhardt. Born to a family of nomadic gypsies, Reinhardt began his career as a violinist. Not long after he had switched to guitar his right hand was crippled in a caravan fire. He promptly devised a unique three-finger style which impressed Jean Sablon enough to make Reinhardt his accompanist. That, of course, led on to the guitarist's golden years with the Hot Club de France.

In the earliest days of America's space programme, Nasa briefly played around with materials capable of the "shape memory effect". The project was shelved for a couple of decades until someone woke up to the lucrative potential of metals that always revert to their original shape. In a new series for Discovery (8.05pm, World Service, and Saturday 2.05am, Radio 4) Tracey Logan discusses how such alloys offer a prospect of aircraft with flapping wings, and skyscrapers able to bend against the wind.

The 70th birthday of the pianist and conductor Gennadi Rozhdestvensky is celebrated by Nicholas Tresilian with an Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM). He was only 20 when he first conducted the Bolshoi Theatre Orchestra . Subsequently he directed both the BBC and the Vienna symphony orchestras. The evening's choice of composers includes Tchaikosvky, Stenhammar, and Nielsen.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: After 30 years of marriage, my husband had an affair. He has agreed never to see her again, but am I mad to let him stay?
fields.trailText: After 30 years of marriage, my husband had an affair. He has agreed never to see her again, but am I mad to let him stay?
fields.body:
I was shocked to discover that my husband of 30 years had been having an affair with a colleague for six months. Most hurtful was that he fell in love with her. He says he loves me and wants to stay with me. I realise I had taken him for granted. We went away for a weekend and our sexual relationship has returned to a mature honeymoon state. We agreed to try again and my husband promised not to see this woman. But I am a mess. I can't confide in my best friend or my three adult children. I don't want to visit Relate, but desperately want advice. Can our marriage work? Can I trust him? Am I mad to let him stay?

Give him another chance

You are not mad - everyone makes mistakes and one can't throw away 30 years, which I presume were good, even for something so damaging. You can make things better if you both want to and are willing to work at it. Trust is hard. When the same thing happened to me 15 years ago one of the worst things was realising that my husband was not entirely the person I thought he was. Who does know everything about anyone? It showed me that I couldn't take our settled situation for granted.

He has rebuilt my trust. I believe he was at a point where he felt chances had passed him by. Lack of work satisfaction, with no prospect of improvement meant his self-esteem was very low. The affair gave his ego a great boost.

I was devastated. Like you, I had no one I could talk to. My mind was in turmoil for months. I knew I wanted our marriage to continue - the fact that I didn't want anyone to know what had happened seemed to confirm this. For at least two years, each significant date was painful, and it was five years or more before the affair faded. Had I had a trustworthy friend it might have helped. Unfortunately, perhaps, my husband was, and still is, my best friend. Poetry helped, and writing down all the sad, unhappy, angry, resentful, hopeful thoughts.

Do give both of you a second chance. I hope it works out and you will again be happy, as I am.
Name and address withheld

Talk to someone about it

Five years ago, my wife of 10 years admitted she'd been having an affair for a year. The realisation that my trusted partner could betray me so profoundly as to fall in love with another sent me into a strange place where none of the old rules applied.

My immediate reaction was forgiveness and a determination to make the marriage work. Her behaviour seemed so out of character that I ascribed it to an extreme of empty-nest syndrome. Two years later, after the most abject misery of living through her deliberate destruction of what had been re-established, she left me for her lover. Without good friends, I know I would have killed myself.

Do what you think is best for you. I've learned that we are born alone and die alone and are more alone in the middle bit than we think. The dilemma is that, to make your marriage work, you must learn to trust an untrustworthy person implicitly. If you can, your marriage might just be worth fighting for.

It took two years to overcome my breakdown. I am now in a rewarding relationship (with thrilling sex!). I am secure, happy and fulfilled. I could have become embittered, but my friends kept my faith in human nature alive. It is essential that you talk to someone - the Samaritans or your best friend. You need to evaluate aspects of your situation that will be blindingly obvious to a relative outsider who knows you. The pain will subside; you will know joy and truth again. Don't sell yourself short - you have rights and needs, too.
Name and address withheld

It is all his fault

I notice the words "remorse" and "forgive me" are absent from your husband's account of his behaviour. Not only has he come out unscathed from this affair, he has ensured that the only person feeling guilty is you. Trust me, this is his fault, not yours.

You say he took you away for the weekend and the sex was fabulous. Well, great. How was the talk? Do you believe this was the first time he strayed? I don't, but I'm a cynic.

One of the reasons you're in a mess is that this betrayal has not been addressed except on the surface. A lot more talking is going to have to take place, and perhaps not only with your husband. Do you have a woman friend you can talk to? You were probably brought up, like me, to believe that talking about one's marriage is disloyal, and that's a valid view. But his disloyalty is worse.

My advice is that you ditch the bastard and get your self-esteem back. But you don't have to take anyone's advice - you just need to find out what you want most.
Name and address withheld

Next week

We have a five-year-old daughter, and have been trying for a second child. In the past three years my wife, who is 41, has had two miscarriages and although doctors say there is every chance she could carry a child for the full term, she has decided she does not want to try any longer.

I understand her feelings and am supportive of her decision, but I am devastated. My wife understands how I feel, but cannot face bringing up another baby.

I know we are luckier than some who are not able even to have one child, but I so wanted a brother or sister for my little girl. How can I overcome the feeling that there will be a massive hole in my life?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020-7239 9935, or email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

fields.headline: As mad as a wet hen
fields.standfirst: Tetbury
fields.trailText: Country diary: Tetbury
fields.body: Were this a work of detective fiction, which it is patently not, then this chapter might be entitled The Case of the Solitary Moorhen. Since the turn of the year we have watched, on a particularly squalid patch of water beside a main road, the odd behaviour of a solitary moorhen, which has maintained a presence there and scuttled into hiding every time we have sought to check on its continuing residence. The water is always lightly perfumed by the tailings of the septic tank serving a farm some 200 yards uphill. Heavy lorries thunder past at regular intervals. Add a few abandoned oil cans, plastic trash, and windblown debris and you get the picture. What an odd bird, we have thought, checking moorhen behaviour in the bird books, and speculating on what occasions such a pattern of atypical bird activity. It has always been something to look out for on a walk that often starts this way before reaching quieter lanes. There have not been many occasions when a few moments observation has not seen the bird scuttling off into the cover of an overhanging hawthorn bush, now in the light green cover of new leaf. But all of a sudden, a more normal pattern of behaviour has asserted itself. This solitary moorhen has been joined by another, presumably male, moorhen, and we may expect a clutch of eggs and a family of infant moorhens soon to be encouraged out onto this tiny patch of water, even more squalid as summer heat dries up the area. Just a few miles away, on the Avon at Malmesbury, we have watched, with pleasure, the classic nesting behaviour of a pair of mute swans - almost regal by comparison.

webTitle: Zambia's neighbours edgy at leader's bid to stay in power

fields.headline: Zambia's neighbours edgy at leader's bid to stay in power
fields.trailText: The Zambian president, Frederick Chiluba, has defied his own high court and expelled his vice-president and eight other cabinet ministers from the ruling party for opposing plans for a constitutional amendment allowing him to cling to power for another five years.
fields.body:
The Zambian president, Frederick Chiluba, has defied his own high court and expelled his vice-president and eight other cabinet ministers from the ruling party for opposing plans for a constitutional amendment allowing him to cling to power for another five years.

South Africa and Botswana are pressing Mr Chiluba to abandon his bid to perpetuate his increasingly unpopular decade-long rule, fearing that it will further destabilise a region already afflicted by the crisis in Zimbabwe and similar tampering with the constitution in Namibia.

The expulsion of 22 officials from Zambia's ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) defied a Lusaka high court injunction. Another court hearing is scheduled for today at which the ousted ministers want to overturn the purge.

One of those expelled, labour secretary Edith Nawakwi, accused Mr Chiluba of wanting an unending presidency.

"The president knows the action is illegal. We have a court order restraining the party. But we also know how desperate he is to cling to power," she said.

The South African president, Thabo Mbeki, first told Mr Chiluba a month ago that it would be a bad idea for him to amend the constitution and run again in elections later this year.

Mr Mbeki and the Botswanan president, Festus Mogae, telephoned the Zambian leader last weekend ahead of a special MMD convention on Monday to amend party rules and adopt Mr Chiluba as its presidential candidate.

The move lays the ground to change the country's constitution which limits the president to two five-year terms.

About 200 delegates boycotted the convention after Mr Chiluba placed a ban on campaigning against the rule change, saying it would divide the party. Those that remained voted overwhelmingly to support the proposal. Some opponents who did attend, including three cabinet ministers, were beaten up by the president's supporters.

But Mr Chiluba is far from assured of the two-thirds support he needs in parliament to alter the constitution. About half of Zambia's 158 parlia mentarians have signed a petition opposing the plan. Mr Chiluba is hoping to bolster support by threatening dissenting MPs with the loss of their seats.

Armed police were deployed around the capital after demonstrations broke out at the news of the purge.

The unions, churches and foreign aid donors have all criticised Mr Chiluba's plan to hang on to power 10 years after he ended more than two decades of one-party rule under Kenneth Kaunda by promising to be a very different kind of African leader.

Many Zambians are angered by their president's actions particularly because he said several times he had no such plans.

Mr Chiluba's opponents intend to try to recall parliament and seek a no-confidence vote.

"We, the leaders who oppose the amendment of the constitution, will employ every legal means to stop the president from going for another term of office," Ms Nawakwi said.

Mr Chiluba was also condemned by the country's trade union confederation which first lifted him to power.

"History has taught us that the continued stay of presidents in office has built them into dictators and that dictators often survive by resorting to large scale abuse," said the confederation's general secretary, Derrick Chaala.
