fields.headline: Sir Charles Madden
fields.standfirst: Initially overshadowed by his family's naval pedigree, he rose to be a distinguished battleship commander and military chief
fields.trailText: Initially overshadowed by his family's naval pedigree, he rose to be a distinguished battleship commander and military chief.
fields.body:
Admiral Sir Charles Madden, who has died aged 94, was the former commander-in-chief (C-in-C) of the Home Fleet. He would rather have been an artist but, inevitably, followed his father, Admiral of the Fleet Sir Charles Madden, into the Royal Navy as a cadet of 13.

He was born with an assortment of nautical silver spoons in his mouth; his mother was the daughter of shipowner Sir Charles Cayzer, and his aunt was the wife of Admiral of the Fleet Earl Jellicoe. Yet Madden ascended the career ladder on merit, most prominently displayed in his role as commander (executive officer) of the battleship Warspite in the Mediterranean in 1940-42.

Since this modernised 1913 vessel was then the flagship of Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham - commander-in-chief of the Mediterranean fleet and Britain's most successful fighting admiral of the second world war - merit alone was not enough. Charm, modesty and tact were also needed to deal with the fearsome "ABC", as he was unsurprisingly known on the lower decks. By then, Madden was engaged to Olive Robins, but the war kept them apart for another two years.

Cunningham acknowledged Madden's contribution to the smooth running of one of the navy's busiest warships - she wore out three sets of eight 15-inch gun barrels in the Mediterranean alone - by giving him an official mention in dispatches. Warspite and Madden took part in such major engagements as the carrier attack on the Italian port of Taranto in November 1940, and, early in 1941, the battles of Calabria and Cape Matapan, the navy's last battlefleet action, and the shelling of Tripoli.

The successful evacuation of British forces from Crete in May 1941, in the teeth of locally overwhelming Axis air superiority, was, for the Royal Navy, a disaster in instalments. Altogether, 50% of Cunningham's fleet, already reduced by earlier fighting - and soon to take more punishment - was hit. A carrier and two battleships, including Warspite, which was bombed, were put out of action, three cruisers were sunk and five damaged, six destroyers lost and seven crippled.

The bomb struck Warspite's starboard side, starting a large fire and killing 40 men. As the ship crawled back towards Alexandria, Madden coolly took command of the firefighting and damage control, a task that culminated in the extrication of the dead from a tangle of twisted and scorched metal on both his own ship and a shattered cruiser. He stayed with the ship while she was patched up and sent to America for a complete refit, and was still aboard when she sailed to the Indian ocean to become Admiral Sir James Somerville's flagship.

Having fallen in with paternal wishes, Madden was educated at the Royal Naval College, Osborne, and duly graduated from Dartmouth, at a ceremony where his father, then C-in-C, Home Fleet, handed out the prizes. By gaining a posting to China in a cruiser, he did, however, manage to frustrate his father's plan to find him a soft berth on the royal yacht.

Madden became a first-class gunnery specialist, then still the best route to promotion, and served in battleships and cruisers in the Far East and the Mediterranean. An appointment as gunnery officer on the battlecruiser Hood was cancelled, which saved his life; the flagship of the British fleet was sunk by the Bismarck with the loss of all but three hands in May 1941.

When his father died in 1935, Madden inherited the baronetcy and, in 1939, was promoted to commander at the early age of 33, joining Warspite within a year. After that, he spent two years as deputy director of the gunnery division at the Admiralty. In the winter of 1944, as an acting captain, he was given his first command, of the escort-carrier Emperor, in the Far East fleet. He was mentioned in dispatches for his work in providing air cover for operations in Malaya and Burma.

After the war, Madden was once again subjected to the blast of the personality of ABC, by then first sea lord, when he served as his naval assistant. He stayed on to support the unrelated Sir John Cunningham in the same post. In 1947, he took command of the 6th destroyer flotilla, specialising in anti-submarine warfare.

After staff appointments in London, Madden's career took an unusual turn in 1953, with an assignment, in the honorary rank of commodore, as chief of staff of the New Zealand navy, which was about to expand. Two years later, he was promoted rear-admiral and given a post on the Board of Admiralty, where he was instrumental in streamlining the structure of the officer corps into one general list. In 1957, he became flag officer, Malta, where his diplomatic skills were fully engaged in dealing with the fiery nationalist leader, Dom Mintoff.

A two-year stint as C-in-C, Plymouth was followed in 1963 by promotion to C-in-C, Home Fleet, his last assignment before retirement in 1965, when he was made GCB. He was simultaneously Nato C-in-C of Naval Forces, Eastern Atlantic, and created the Standing Naval Force, Atlantic, still a successful, multinational formation of frigates and destroyers.

Throughout his life, Madden was a gifted amateur painter, and did much charitable work after retiring. His wife died in 1989; they had one daughter.

fields.headline: CMG walks in Sema's shoes
fields.trailText: With the Techmark and the FTSE 100 both posting significant losses yesterday it was perhaps inevitable that the performance of CMG would set tongues wagging.
fields.body:
With the Techmark and the FTSE 100 both posting significant losses yesterday it was perhaps inevitable that the performance of CMG would set tongues wagging.

The Anglo-Dutch software group ended just 2.5p lower at 405p, propped up by speculation that it could meet the same fate as rival Sema.

Market watchers will remember that Sema was forced, after a disastrous profits warning in November, to accept a £3.6bn takeover offer from United States oil services group, Schlumberger.

Like Sema, CMG recently warned on profits and despite its recent recovery - the shares have risen 40p since the news on trading - many dealers think it is vulnerable to an opportunistic approach.

With a market capitalisation of £2.5bn and a leading position in text messaging soft ware, CMG would be a tasty morsel for a bigger rival intent on expansion.

All told, speculative stories were not in short supply yesterday. Independent Insurance advanced 12.5p to 140.5p on talk that American firm Chubb is casting an eye over the group, while Spirent, the telecoms testing firm, fell back 28.5p to 360p on talk that a gloomy trading update is on the way.

A number of tales were also being put forward by puzzled traders to explain the poor performance of the wider market.

The most popular was that Merrill Lynch, the stockbroking powerhouse, had put through a massive sell programme. Others said Wednesday's mammoth placing in Vodafone , off 9.75p at 189.25p, had forced institutions involved to sell large, liquid stocks like BP , down 24.5p at 591p, and Shell , 23p weaker at 560p, to replenish their cash balances.

Of course, it could all have been profit-taking. "Some things have risen by 20% or 30% since early April; it is hardly surprising some people are taking profits," one dealer said.

Whatever the explanation, a poor performance on Wall Street did not help matters. The FTSE 100 index ended 2.3% lower at 5,765.8, while the Techmark 100 index fell 61.58 points to 2,042.26. Market turnover was 2.5bn, with Vodafone accounting for 36% of that total.

HSBC, down 24p to 853p, was again on offer, unsettled by talk that it is considering a bid for Merrill Lynch.

The title-tattle was based on news that the international banking group is planning to ask its shareholders for permission to raise its share capital by 20%. Such a move would leave HSBC with $17bn (£11.8bn) on its books, not enough to buy Merrill Lynch but certainly enough to make a dent in the price tag.

A deal, however, is thought unlikely. Last year HSBC asked its shareholders for permission to do exactly the same thing and acquired nothing.

News that passenger traffic had dropped 13.3% in April sent British Airways into a tailspin. BA blamed the combined effects of the US economic slowdown and the foot and mouth epidemic for the decline. The shares dived 23.25p to 331.75p.

An early 2.7% fall on Nasdaq index sparked selling of tech and telecom issues. Energis dipped 25.5p to 329p, while Sage dropped 20p to 277p and Telewest fell 8.75p to 123.75p.

Among the few risers was ICI , up 15.5p to 427.5p on relief that first-quarter results were not worse than expected, and Bank of Scotland , 13p higher at 811p on hopes that its merger with Halifax , up 3p to 793p, will be sealed today.

Lower down, a badly executed buy order pushed London Bridge Software up 22.5p to 207.5p, while Wolseley, the building materials group, added 14.75p to 468p after UBS Warburg raised its target price to 550p. The Swiss broker believes the appointment of Charlie Banks as chief executive is a positive move.

Aberdeen Asset Management rose 26p to 531p after the 37% stake held by Scottish Provident was placed in the market at a higher than predicted 500p.

fields.headline: At this price? ICI
fields.trailText: Chemicals group ICI yesterday claimed it was putting in a "competitive performance" as it reported a £5m - 6% - drop in profits to £85m for the first quarter of this year.
fields.body:
Chemicals group ICI yesterday claimed it was putting in a "competitive performance" as it reported a £5m - 6% - drop in profits to £85m for the first quarter of this year.

ICI is heavily exposed to the US downturn and suffered a 2% decline in US sales, but a strong performance in Asia and "solid progress" in Europe and Latin America helped offset that decline.

Three years ago its shares were changing hands at more than £12. Over the past six months they have been around and below 400p, levels not seen in 10 years.

The company once regarded as standard bearer for the British economy has a market capitalisation of just £3.1bn, about half that of Bass or Marks & Spencer.

It is no longer a bulk chemicals business but a completely overhauled speciality chemicals concern, focusing on smaller markets with higher margins. But it underperformed mainland European chemicals companies by 17% in 2001.

Its best performances in the past three months have come from its Quest, performance specialities and paints divisions. At Quest, which makes fragrances and flavours, profits rose from £26m to £29m. Performance specialities, which makes surfactants, was also ahead £3m while paint profits were up £1m, with strong sales in the US offset by a downturn for of exterior paints in Europe caused by the bad weather.

Profits at the company's core National Starch division, which makes adhesives, food starches and polymers, were down 19%, although that was an improvement on the last quarter of last year.

"These results bear out what we have been saying about the company being resilient," said finance director-designate Tim Scott.

Those actions include pushing up prices and cutting travel costs throughout the group.

Analysts, remain unsure, however, especially about National Starch, and most recommend a hold.

fields.headline: Insecure investment
fields.trailText: After its recent, and some would say excessive recovery, Baltimore, the internet security specialist, should be avoided, according to analysts' advice.
fields.body:
After its recent, and some would say excessive recovery, Baltimore, the internet security specialist, should be avoided, according to analysts' advice.

Some believe the company is about to give the market details of a reorganisation plan to save cash, while others claim there have been high-level resignations at Content Technologies, the email security firm Baltimore acquired last year for £700m. Apparently one of Content's founders and five members of the sales team have walked out.

Baltimore was expected to lose £20m this year before its profits warnings in March and April. Analysts subsequently downgraded their revenue forecasts to £107m from £157m, which means Baltimore has to cut £48m of costs to keep its losses in line with market expectations.

Baltimore shares closed down 0.25p at 88p yesterday.

fields.headline: The robber's return
fields.standfirst: Why Biggs could not do it today
fields.trailText: The tourist authorities have spent millions trying to persuade potential overseas visitors - particularly in the Americas - to brave foot and mouth disease and give Britain another chance.
fields.body:
The tourist authorities have spent millions trying to persuade potential overseas visitors - particularly in the Americas - to brave foot and mouth disease and give Britain another chance. Now they have scored a success, albeit not one they were expecting. Ronnie Biggs, one of the great train robbers (class of 63), who has been on the run for 35 years, wants to return to Britain. He has told the Sun that he will face whatever punishment awaits him. Speaking from Brazil, he said: "My last wish is to walk into a Margate pub as an Englishman and buy a pint of bitter." No one had the heart to tell him they all drink lager these days. Whether his desire for Margate over Copacabana beach will revive the town's fortunes is unclear, but it is a start.

Ronnie Biggs is the last of those still at large who stole £2.8m (over £35m in today's prices) in a daring robbery of the Glasgow-to-London train on August 8, 1963. Masterminded by Bruce Reynolds, it was one of the most carefully planned robberies of the century - right down to the detailed timetabling of the trains. It is also one of the most romanticised crimes, spawning numerous books and a film - despite the fact that the train driver, Jack Mills, died later from wounds inflicted during the robbery.

In terms of the charmed life he has led, Mr Biggs, who could still serve 28 years in jail, has lots to give thanks for: the people who helped him escape from Wandsworth after serving 15 months, the woman who gave birth to his child enabling him to avoid extradition from Rio in 1974 and the government of Barbados in 1981, which refused to send him back to Blighty after he had been kidnapped by UK mercenaries. But, above all, he ought to give thanks for something that has probably never occurred to him. He and his gang quite simply could not have pulled off a similar robbery today for one simple reason. The unreliability of Railtrack's timetables makes a precision operation of that kind impossible.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The new US "regulations tsar", John Graham, came from the Harvard Centre for Risk Analysis, not Johns Hopkins University as we said in the G2 cover story, All the president's businessmen, April 27. Rather than carrying out his own study there on passive smoking, he questioned a report by the Environmental Protection Agency which concluded that there were dangers from secondhand smoke and cited it as an example of overregulation. He did solicit $25,000 from Philip Morris, but the money was handed back.
fields.body:
The new US "regulations tsar", John Graham, came from the Harvard Centre for Risk Analysis, not Johns Hopkins University as we said in the G2 cover story, All the president's businessmen, April 27. Rather than carrying out his own study there on passive smoking, he questioned a report by the Environmental Protection Agency which concluded that there were dangers from secondhand smoke and cited it as an example of overregulation. He did solicit $25,000 from Philip Morris, but the money was handed back.

In Pass Notes, page 3, G2, yesterday, we refer to "Councillor Bill Roberts of Woolton, Liverpool". Mr Roberts is, in fact, a former councillor who left Liverpool council last year.

Peter Sansom, one of the judges of the Online text poetry competition, pages 10 and 11, Online, yesterday, referred to the haiku as Chinese rather than Japanese, an aberration for which he apologises.

We misspelt the name of the deputy editor of the magazine Nova in reporting its closure, page 5, yesterday. It is Rachel Cooke. In the same report we referred to You magazine, curiously calling it U.

The caddy pictured next to the golfer Jack Nicklaus, page 24, May 2, is not Tip Anderson, but Jimmy Dickenson.

fields.headline: More tit-for-tat on voting
fields.trailText: There is a simple way the Labour party could instantly remove the "threat" posed by tactical voters (Millbank attacks tactical vote 'myth', May 3). If it reformed the election system, we could all vote for the party that we really support.
fields.body:
There is a simple way the Labour party could instantly remove the "threat" posed by tactical voters (Millbank attacks tactical vote 'myth', May 3). If it reformed the election system, we could all vote for the party that we really support. Voting Labour in Cheltenham would only increase the Tory's chance of taking the seat back from the Lib Dems.

Labour should not fear a fairer voting system, it has the potential to be supported by a real majority of the electorate. It should learn from our European partners who, by having less confrontational political systems based on proportional representation, have avoided the tit-for-tat policy changes that have bedevilled Britain's public services.
Brian Hughes
Leckhampton, Glos brian.hughes1@virgin.net

 Tactical voters will exercise this power regardless of Mill bank's protestations. And turnout will continue to plummet as the rest of us realise the futility of voting in safe seats where the result is known before the election is even announced. fields.headline: Nice or nasty? MS sufferers must wait and see
fields.trailText: I am a qualified nurse who has given up work because of the onset of multiple sclerosis. Beta interferon, which I buy privately, has halted the progress of my disease.
fields.body:
I am a qualified nurse who has given up work because of the onset of multiple sclerosis. Beta interferon, which I buy privately, has halted the progress of my disease. Fellow patients on the drug for much longer have had their symptoms reversed by beta interferon and their quality of life restored.

Peter Cardy of the MS Society quoted Michael Rawlins, chairman of the national institute for clinical excellence, as saying that £3,000 per annum per patient is an acceptable price for beta interferon (Drug cost dithering 'lets MS get worse', April 30). Sir Michael also made this claim at a meeting of Nice in Nottingham on March 21, when I asked him what is the cost-effective price for the drug. Patients are now very concerned because the actual cost of the drug is £10,000. With such a wide gap between the figures there is little prospect of Nice approving this treatment, so why has it extended the time it requires to appraise it? Is there political influence in the background? Mary Pearson
Long Eaton, Notts

 Your article on our appraisal of medicines for people with multiple sclerosis is misleading in some important aspects. Although the price at which a drug is sold will influence its cost-effectiveness, at no stage has Professor Rawlins, or any other member of the institute, speculated on an appropriate cost for the beta interferons or glatiramer acetate. Drug pricing is not our responsibility.

We have clear processes for undertaking our appraisals. It allows for consultation and for appeal before guidance is issued to the NHS in England and Wales. Appeals do not delay the process, they are an integral part of the production of robust guidance; and the fact that we use an independently prepared review of the evidence should leave all those involved in our work feeling confident of its objectivity.

The evidence we use for our appraisals is critical to making an informed decision. It is for this reason that in the case of the medicines for MS, we commissioned further work on an important element of it. We are clear that the current economic models, on which we would rely to make our judgment of cost-effectiveness, are flawed and do not constitute a suitable basis to form a robust judgment. We can improve on them and we are doing so in a fully transparent manner. This work involves all consultees and we will review the results in July.

The current situation for people with MS is that health authorities in England have clear guidance from the Department of Health on the arrangements they should be making for people with this distressing condition. They have been instructed to continue with these local arrangements until Nice guidance becomes available.

Further information, together with the appeal panel's decision and minutes of committee meetings, are published on www.nice.org.uk. Andrew Dillon
Chief executive, national institute for clinical excellence

fields.headline: Insurers' gene test policy
fields.trailText: Helena Kennedy's comments regarding the use of genetic testing are extremely encouraging (Insurer 'broke code on gene information', May 2).
fields.body:
Helena Kennedy's comments regarding the use of genetic testing are extremely encouraging (Insurer 'broke code on gene information', May 2). At last there is recognition of the serious public concern about the use of genetic tests for insurance purposes. We are concerned that women with breast cancer will be deterred from being tested for fear of difficulties in obtaining insurance afterwards.

A positive result for one of the genes linked to hereditary breast cancer is no guarantee that a woman will develop the disease - or, if so, when. We are also concerned that the establishment of the genetics and insurance committee to oversee the use of these tests has pre-empted a full public debate on the issue. We strongly urge the government to pursue a moratorium on the use of genetic testing by insurers, backed by legislation if necessary.
Delyth Morgan
Chief executive, Breakthrough

 The human genetics commission response to the issue of the use of genetic tests in insurance is far too weak. A three-year voluntary moratorium will not give the public confidence required because the insurance industry has already shown itself to be untrustworthy by ignoring its own guidelines.

The principle that genetic makeup should not be used as a basis for discrimination is not going to change over the next three years. Freedom from genetic discrimination should be a human right and people should be able to take genetic tests if they wish, confident that the information will be kept private and not used as a justification for refusing insurance cover or employment. As the recent report from the Commons science and technology committee made clear, the insurance industry's game plan is to open the way for widespread use of genetic tests as they are developed. And, judging by experiences in the US, employers are likely to want to follow suit. We will only be able to go forward confidently with the new genetic technologies if the government puts proper safeguards in place. A ban on the use of genetic tests to discriminate in employment and insurance is urgently needed.
Dr Sue Mayer
Gene Watch UK

 Your report fails to recognise the significance of the positive step the insurance industry has just taken to allay public concern about genetics and insurance. Our proposed moratorium on policies up to £300,000 will cover the vast majority of insurance business in the UK and give everyone time to agree a longer-term solution to these sensitive issues.

On a more technical point, it is wrong to suggest that Norwich Union, or any other company, has broken the ABI's code of practice on genetic tests. The code specifically allowed companies to take account of the results of the tests submitted to the government's genetics and insurance committee for assessment but not yet approved. The code also made clear that if the committee subsequently ruled against a particular test, companies would re-underwrite any policies which relied on it.

Your article also criticises Professor Sandy Raeburn's dual role as genetics adviser to the ABI and a member of the genetics and insurance committee. The GAIC's website describes Sandy Raeburn as "a geneticist nominated by the Association of British Insurers". Ultimately this is a matter for the health secretary, who makes the appointments, but in our view it is only sensible for the committee to include members with a knowledge of both genetics and insurance. Other members of the GAIC bring other, equally relevant, expertise to bear.
Stephen Sklaroff
Deputy director general, Association of British Insurers
stephen.sklaroff@abi.org.uk

fields.headline: Reopen tube talks
fields.trailText: On Wednesday, Bob Kiley wrote that "well-intentioned people" were urging him to "give a little so that we can get on with the critical task of rebuilding the tube" (Comment, May 2).
fields.body:
On Wednesday, Bob Kiley wrote that "well-intentioned people" were urging him to "give a little so that we can get on with the critical task of rebuilding the tube" (Comment, May 2). Over recent months, we have met with Mr Kiley, Ken Livingstone and ministers on numerous occasions. It seemed to us that we were close to reaching agreement at the end of February, when certain principles were laid down accepting that Bob Kiley would get unified management control. A deal would have ensured both the desperately needed investment in London Underground and the highest standards of safety management by the public sector.

Ministers say that Bob Kiley then put forward new demands, Bob Kiley accuses the government of backtracking. Either way, the result appears to be deadlock. Both sides say that their "doors remain open" to discussion, even allowing for the decisions on preferred bidders this week, but someone needs to make the moves which will take us forward. We do not believe this matter should be resolved in the courts, or imposed from above. If Transport for London is to take over the running of the underground soon, it must be satisfied with the structures it is to work within.

We urge both sides to return to the formula which brought us so close in February. This offers the right combination of private sector investment and technical expertise, underpinned by the government's £700m annual subsidy; with public sector management control and the ability for TfL to be involved in the detailed development of the contractors' plans.

Karen Buck MP, Andrew Dismore MP, Iain Coleman MP, Clive Efford MP

webTitle: Hollywood reporter: The three year glitch

fields.headline: The three year glitch
fields.standfirst: Why Warren Beatty's $63m flop is unlikely to be his last
fields.trailText: Why Warren Beatty's $63m flop is unlikely to be his last
fields.body:
Warren Beatty's new film Town and Country has been greeted with such extreme critical opprobrium that one doubts if his Teflon-coated reputation can survive the fallout.

Town and Country was subjected to three years of delays, 13 rewrites, multiple reshoots, and cost $63m to complete (and yet it's a rich-white-folks sex comedy without pricey special effects or Julia Roberts). Even director Peter Chelsom has walked away, saying: "It's a mess." Reviews have been scathing, vengeful screeds, and attendance has been woeful. Commentators have been digging into WB's previous excursions as writer-director-star and there's no shortage of evidence that he is prone to creative monomania and post-production tinkering.

Tell it to Beatty's former collaborators: Trevor Griffiths on Reds, Elaine May on Ishtar, James Toback, and Buck Henry, a man whose career since the mid-70s has been dedicated to Beatty bail-outs, starting with Heaven Can Wait and concluding here (Henry was third rewrite hack on Town and Country).

But look at the timing. T&C was shot after Love Affair. But T&C was shelved before Beatty made Bulworth, his magnificently confused masterpiece, which remains (chronologically) his most recent effort. From this I must deduce that WB isn't finished yet. You need patience to wait for the next Bulworth-type project, but I think it'll be worth it.

webTitle: Director Lewis Gilbert recalls the making of Alfie

fields.headline: All about Alfie
fields.standfirst: As his classic piece of 1960s cinema is re-released, the director  Lewis Gilbert recalls making the world's first cockney film
fields.trailText: As his classic piece of 1960s cinema is re-released, the director Lewis Gilbert recalls making the world's first cockney film
fields.body:
For me, Alfie started when my wife went to see the play, just as an ordinary punter. When she came back she said, "You've got to make this into a film." I'm an east end boy, so the play appealed to me greatly. It also possessed what I always look for in a film, in that it was funny but had a touch of sadness, too. Terence Stamp was in the running for the part, which seems strange now, because he shared a flat with Michael Caine. But when Terry did the play on Broadway, which didn't go well, he decided he couldn't carry on with it.

We were desperate for a cockney to play the part, and my son - who was associate producer and a friend of Caine's - said: "What about Michael?" Michael hadn't done a lot at that point. But when I saw The Ipcress File, I was impressed. So I rang Paramount and said: "There's only one person who can play this part, and that's Michael Caine." "Michael who?" they said. "We've never heard of him." "You will," I said, "Trust me." They said: "OK, it's just a cheap little British film, you go ahead and make it."

Our first idea, which was pretty revolutionary at the time, was that Alfie should talk to the camera. In my early films, it was always stressed: "Don't let your eyes hit the lens - that would make it false." But TV audiences became used to people looking at them out of a screen. In the event, they quickly cottoned on.

Of course, you never know if a film will be successful. My Bond pictures [You Only Live Twice, The Spy Who Loved Me and Moonraker] are the only ones where I've known there's a huge audience waiting to see the film. With Alfie, we never had that knowledge - but it was a very smooth shoot. Everything went according to plan, except one thing: the police weren't as cooperative then as they are today about filming in the street.

We spent an entire night shooting those scenes on London Bridge at the beginning and end of the film. I was sitting on a crane at 6am, having been there since five the previous evening. It had been a long night for everybody. We were wet, cold and miserable, but we had to get that last shot. To do that, we had to hold up all the traffic on the bridge, mostly truck drivers. The poor chap at the sharp end was on his walkie-talkie, saying: "I've got to let them go!" Eventually we got the shot and let the traffic through. A lorry stopped and its driver looked at me and said: "Why don't you get yourself a proper job?" It was so funny, it cheered me up a bit.

The premiere was at the Plaza, and the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and George Best were there. It was incredible. Alfie is rooted into the world of the swinging 60s. My son was only 24 at the time but he was into the Chelsea scene and knew all the people: Michael, Terry Stamp, Jean Shrimpton. Suddenly young people were the centre of the world - not 30- or 40-year-olds.

When we first screened it in America - to 400 people at Paramount - my anxiety was that they wouldn't understand the cockney. But they loved it. The head of the studio said: "When I read the script, I wanted to scrap this picture. I couldn't understand it. I'm amazed the way it's turned out."

They were still worried about the cockney, though. The chief of distribution said, "When we open the film in America, we ought to dub it. What about Tony Curtis?" I said: "No, you mustn't do that! It's the fact that it's cockney that makes itinteresting." He replied: "You'll see I'm right when we open in New York." We broke the house record in two cinemas when we opened in New York.

At that time, there had never been a cockney film. In cinema, the cockney was the man who said: "Guvnor, your car's outside." You never saw a cockney family with real problems. In the 60s, we were beginning to make films that reflected something of the British way of life. Before Alfie and its contemporaries, British film was all Noël Coward and drawing rooms.

Like everything else, censorship was changing fast in England in the 60s. But in the States you couldn't mention abortion in a film, never mind see someone perform one. Alfie showed both sides of the question. We showed the disaster of using a back-street abortionist, but also showed Alfie's conscience when he saw the results of a botched operation. The US censor rang me and said: "We like the film, we want to pass it, and we are trying to change our code." And they did - not just because of Alfie, but it helped. In a way, that pushed their cinema into the 20th century. Until then, it had been Doris Day playing virgins at 45!

It is amazing how the film reflects its time. The attitude of women to men was so different then. Women jumped around as much as men, of course. But the difference is that they were dependent on men, because it was unheard of for a woman to be the head of a company. Men can no longer behave as badly as they did in the 60s.

Actually, Alfie was an infinitely sad character. His philosophy could only spell disaster for himself. That's where Bill Naughton's script was clever. Alfie was a charming rogue - he was good-looking and he knew how to "pull the birds". He was immoral, but the damage he inflicted was on himself. That comes out at the end of the film, although by then he isn't able to change and will probably end up a 60-year-old man still trying to do what he's been doing all along, but failing. That's not a very good life, is it? He's a bit like James Bond, but in a totally different way. Men envy Bond because he has all these adventures and he gets all these wonderful women. Can you imagine having a scene where he's walking along saying, "My life is so awful"? But that's the strength of Alfie.

The film had a big effect on my career. I was offered everything; I was flavour of the month in Hollywood. And Alfie was nominated for five Academy awards. It amazed me how seriously the Americans took the whole ceremony. It was lovely being there, but I never felt as if winning was a matter of life and death. I remember that, going in, everyone was telling Burt Bacharach, who wrote the theme song: "Burt, you're going to win it tonight, best song, no question." Up comes the award - "Best song: Born Free". Well, the poor man was absolutely shattered. I said: "Burt, are you coming out afterwards?" He said: "I think I'll go straight home."

To have it all again, 35 years later, is more exciting for me than being at the Oscars. This week I sat in the theatre where Alfie premiered, at a BFI preview of the re-release. People were laughing and enjoying it, and I was awarded with a fellowship of the BFI, which was a hell of a surprise. It was as if I were dreaming a silly dream that they brought back Alfie and we all went to the same cinema and some of the same people were there, as well as others who weren't even born back then. I thought: "This must be a dream, it's so weird." It was one of the best nights of my life.

Alfie is re-released next Friday.

That's not a very good life, is it? He's a bit like James Bond, but in a totally different way. Men envy Bond because he has all these adventures and he gets all these wonderful women. Can you imagine having a scene where he's walking along saying, "My life is so awful"? But that's the strength of Alfie. The film had a big effect on my career. I was offered everything; I was flavour of the month in Hollywood. And Alfie was nominated for five Academy awards. It amazed me how seriously the Americans took the whole ceremony. It was lovely being there, but I never felt as if winning was a matter of life and death. I remember that, going in, everyone was telling Burt Bacharach, who wrote the theme song: "Burt, you're going to win it tonight, best song, no question." Up comes the award - "Best song: Born Free". Well, the poor man was absolutely shattered. I said: "Burt, are you coming out afterwards?" He said: "I think I'll go straight home." To have it all again, 35 years later, is more exciting for me than being at the Oscars. This week I sat in the theatre where Alfie premiered, at a BFI preview of the re-release. People were laughing and enjoying it, and I was awarded with a fellowship of the BFI, which was a hell of a surprise. It was as if I were dreaming a silly dream that they brought back Alfie and we all went to the same cinema and some of the same people were there, as well as others who weren't even born back then. I thought: "This must be a dream, it's so weird." It was one of the best nights of my life. Alfie is re-released next Friday.

webTitle: Why Cannes is still the best film festival in the world

fields.headline: The agony and the ecstasy
fields.standfirst: With Cannes days away,  Derek Malcolm describes why - despite the snobbery, the crime and the crowds - it's still the best film festival in the world
fields.trailText: With Cannes days away, Derek Malcolm describes why - despite the snobbery, the crime and the crowds - it's still the best film festival in the world
fields.body:
Progressing along the Croisette at Cannes one morning, on the way to an interview with a famous Hollywood actor, I observed a crowd outside the Carlton hotel gazing with more than the usual curiosity at a fifth-floor window. Out of it protruded two large and bare backsides. One is prepared for almost anything at the world's glitziest film festival, but this seemed a trifle more surprising than usual. They were, I was assured, the bottoms of two very well-known actors, one American, one French. I have no absolute certainty as to their identities. Nor could I ever establish conclusively whether the twin gestures, the conclusion of a night on the tiles that had clearly still not ended at 10 the next morning, involved the star I was about to meet.

All I knew was that it was a bad omen for my interview. Sure enough, when I finally tore myself away from the scene and proceeded to my destination, a harassed press officer told me first that the star would be a little late and, half an hour later, that the interview had unfortunately to be cancelled since "the talent has overslept".

This was not, however, the most embarrassing moment of my 20 years or so at Cannes. That came when, in the middle of a particularly awful movie, I could restrain myself no longer and said to my neighbour: "God, isn't this crap?" "Yes, I know," he said. "I wrote it." I've kept my lips sealed at screenings ever since.

I have to say that at Cannes a peculiar form of madness often beckons, brought on by too many films too early in the day - the first one starts at 8.30am - too many 20-minute interviews with a weary star or director alongside eight or nine others, not all of whom want the interviewee to say anything remotely sensible, and too many late nights grumbling over too much wine about the enormities of one's day.

Make no mistake, Cannes is a tough job, even though a lot of water has flowed under the bridge since the late John Gillett, scion of the British Film Institute, left his seat in the main auditorium at Cannes to complain about a less than precise screening, only to be dismissed by a projectionist threatening him with a loaded gun. It seems a long time, too, since Sylvester Stallone, then at his peak as the toughest of action stars, skipped Cannes for fear of terrorist attack, and the Palais was guarded by police with dogs, as likely to set upon late-arriving critics as on any undesirable elements.

In the late 1980s and early 1990s, Cannes was a fairly dangerous place to be, despite the fact that terrorists never came near the place. The danger actually came from the peevish overpolicing, the thugs at the door who seemed to delight in turning people away rather than letting them in, and the hordes of thieves and cutthroats who came to town to make merry among the well-lined, either on the streets or in the grander hotels. One such hotel had an entire floor robbed room by room in a single night. And two female friends of mine, relaxing in a cafe at the end of the festival, were Maced and divested of their handbags over dessert.

There will still be a lot of police about next week, and you still don't leave your passport and money unguarded in your room. Nor, if you are wise, do you walk the back streets alone after midnight, particularly if you are a woman. But they say "Bonjour" to you at the theatre doors these days, and the atmosphere is considerably more relaxed.

On the other hand, it is never advisable to be too relaxed at Cannes. Blink and you'll miss something, whether you are there for the sake of art or commerce. And because the art is about the best you can get at film festivals these days, and the commerce gets more frenetic year by year, Cannes remains the mecca for both. No other festival equals it, despite the fact that Hollywood, not wishing to spend an inordinate amount of money on a film that fails to win a prize, has kept its participation less than large-scale.

The days are long gone when a big Hollywood film was supported not only by its star but by a dozen executives and their wives, often at a cost of hundreds of thousands of dollars. It's even longer since you could meet a world-famous director casually sipping coffee somewhere and sit down to talk with him about his new film. Now literally hundreds of journos will want to see him, and one-to-one interviews are at a premium.

Whatever you do, it's an expensive place to be. At the Hotel du Cap, a convenient distance from the milling throng on the Croisette, where many of the stars and rich producers are housed, you can pay only in cash. Here, critics and reporters due for interviews are ushered in through the staff entrance and discouraged from mixing with the guests. It was here that I once interviewed Madonna, who told me that the coffee and croissants she was offering me were more expensive than her shoes.

And it was in Cannes itself that I heard the following conversation in a hotel lobby between an American guest and the concierge: "I want to change my room. There's water dripping from the ceiling on to my bed, the carpets are worn out and the shower has no hot water." "What do you expect, madam, for $400 a night?"

Nothing is quite what you might expect at Cannes. And it has to be said that some of the surprises are pleasant. It is nice having lunch on the beach, even if the result can be a terrible urge to close your eyes during the afternoon film - to which some people have been known to go simply to have a nap. Naps, it must be said, are common at the end of a long festival. Once, during the final competition film, a distinguished critic was snoring so loudly that someone tapped her on the shoulder and complained: "Madam, could you please stop snoring? You're waking us all up." Critics, like everyone else, can't help themselves sometimes.

Generally, however, we behave ourselves reasonably well, as befits those who get in free and can say what they like afterwards in print. Cannes is capable of boring you stiff and irritating you almost beyond measure, but it can also impart in the most cynical of souls a renewed faith in the power and strength of cinema. There is nothing quite like it, and we progress next week to the best festival in the world in the certainty that we will see half a dozen films at least that make even the travails of its present commerciality worthwhile.

webTitle: Hollywood reporter: The worst of times

fields.headline: The worst of times
fields.standfirst: The era of ugliness has returned to LA
fields.trailText: The era of ugliness has returned to LA
fields.body:
May Day has just passed, and in LA the Writers' Guild may well be on strike by the time Ken Loach's LA- based labour-dispute movie Bread and Roses is released next week. In Washington, meanwhile, our glove-puppet president has completed his first 100 days of vandalism - and I'm having one of my "I hate America" weeks.

There's so much political ugliness in the air that it's hard to know where to start. Salt II, like the Kyoto agreement, is in ribbons. The US Supreme Court is rolling back the 1964 Civil Rights Act, to the delight of the rightwing Federalist Society, whose membership includes some of the most reactionary - and strategically best positioned - judges and corporate lawyers in the country, and whose ultimate aim appears to be to roll back every social advance since the New Deal.

Not pissed off enough yet? Dick Cheney - the power behind the throne, the hand up Dubya's arse - seems to want a derrick in every national park, which should delight oil-services giants (including his former employer, Haliburton). And defence secretary Donald Rumsfield says he'll build his missile shield in four years flat - a tacit acknowledgement that Bush can't be re-elected and that the corporations who now own the government have but one term in which to loot the US treasury like the officer class of some banana republic. The next time the secret service shoots a deranged sniper on the White House lawn I have this nasty feeling it's going to be me.

In LA, Bread and Roses arrives just as we learn that AOL Time Warner boss Gerald Levin last year earned stock options worth $153m, $53m more than the entire Writers' Guild membership is seeking over the next three years. The studio heads - none of whom earned less than $60m last year - seem happy to endure strikes that the LA mayor's office estimates will cost the Los Angeles economy $6bn. And while the majors are counselling fiscal austerity, Disney is spending $5m (a tax- deductible expense) on its Pearl Harbor premiere - to be held on a specially-converted aircraft carrier - just as it announces 4,000 layoffs, the kind of fuck-you, scorched-earth management of which Walt would heartily approve.

Bread and Roses celebrates the victory of the hugely important Justice For Janitors campaign several years ago. The poorest workers in LA, those who clean downtown LA's corporate offices, defeated propery giants in an innovative campaign that simply shamed them into paying up. I worked the downtown area back then, and knowing roughly the pay scales of these independently contracted wage slaves, it seemed to me that these corporate skyscrapers became vertical sweatshops after 7pm.

My employer was Gibson, Dunn and Crutcher, the oldest law firm in California and one of the most powerful in America. My job was to examine inactive cases - some a century old - and discard obsolete documents. GD&C was one of the powerhouses that built modern California, specialising in union-busting and corporate enrichment, representing everyone from Disney and the Vietnam-bloated aerospace conglomerates to the owners of the Los Angeles Times. The files offered mesmerising glimpses into the hidden history of the Golden State.

GD&C's de facto post- second world war chieftain, William French Smith, who became Ronald Reagan's first attorney-general in 1981, breakfasted on broken-backed unions and put striking air traffic controllers in chains (literally) - making the fullest use of the US's already draconian anti-union laws - when they walked out in 1981. My illusions about LA (not to mention LA Law) were serially shattered with every file. Pre-war 16mm film cans marked "private detective footage" showed picketers outside car plants in Van Nuys. Development brochures for the emerging city of Whittier (which blessed us with Richard Nixon) boasted: "No one whose blood is not entirely of the Caucasian race will be permitted to buy or rent property here."

For decades GD&C made a mint enforcing these "restrictive covenants" for its clients. One storeroom housed the entire print run of a suppressed Walt Disney biography. (All of this was within the law, and GD&C was far from the only law firm to do this.) I understand the need for legal advocacy to remain essentially amoral, but in my mind I repeatedly heard Jack Nicholson's question to robber-baron John Huston in Chinatown: "How much better can you eat, Mr Cross? What more can you buy?" And the rapacious Cross's response: "The future, Mr Gittes, the future!"

The future is now, and GD&C is building it whether we want it or not. Theodore Olsen, Dubya's new solicitor general and the most visible federalist, was spawned by GD&C. He directed the Arkansas Project, the well- financed campaign to dethrone Bill Clinton, was legal adviser to Paula Jones and the man who persuaded the supreme court to hand the White House to Bush. This despite the fact that US supreme court justice Antonin Scalia, a judge on the Bush-Gore election case, has a son, Eugene, who also works for GD&C (compare Bush and Vicente Fox and ask yourself: which country had the real Mexican election?). Oh, and Olsen's mentor Ken Starr? Another GD&C alumnus. Like any neo-conservative Beltway thinktank, GD&C seems to be an incubator for ideas on how to strengthen even further the corporate stranglehold on our lives. It will take more than courageous janitors or Ken Loach to break that.

I have one pleasant memory of my time at GD&C. At the Christmas party my date and I sneaked past building security and danced on the large dot at the centre of the rooftop helipad, 60 floors up, surrounded by even taller skyscrapers. Flashing back to that moment, I like to readjust it mentally to resemble the last reel of Fight Club, when the hero holds hands with a beautiful girl on a rooftop as the entire corporate skyline - insurance firms and credit-agency HQs - is dynamited and reduced to rubble. Corporations have their own dreams for our future, and in darker moments I have mine for theirs.

fields.headline: Commons committee censures Robinson
fields.trailText: The former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson was today  censured for misleading the Commons standards and  privileges committee over an agreement he made with the late  Robert Maxwell.
fields.body:
The former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson was today censured for misleading the Commons standards and privileges committee over an agreement he made with the late Robert Maxwell.

The committee said that Mr Robinson had failed to provide full answers when it originally investigated an alleged payment of £200,000 which he was said to have received from a company controlled by the publishing tycoon.

But the committee gave Mr Robinson an additional three months to provide further evidence as to whether he did actually receive the payment - a claim which he denies. Mr Robinson said he accepted the committee's findings but added: "I am determined to prove I did not receive the payment."

He said he would trawl Pergamon company records to find the disputed cheque.

The allegation surfaced in a recent biography of Mr Robinson, MP for Coventry North West, by the investigative journalist, Tom Bower.

The committee's finding sparked immediate calls from the Conservatives for Mr Robinson to have the whip withdrawn, since this was the fourth inquiry into his business affairs since the 1997 election.

The Tory trade and industry spokesman, David Heathcoat-Amory, said: "If they are serious about cleaning up sleaze in the Labour party then I think they ought to take action against a serial offender. It really ought to be four strikes and you're out, otherwise I think the whole Labour party stance on sleaze is simply a joke." He called on the government to take action "immediately" or he warned that the next parliament "would be dragged into sleaze".

The committee described Mr Robinson's denial that he received the £200,000 payment as a "subsidiary point".

"Mr Robinson has told us that he will seek the agreement of the administrators of Pergamon AGB plc (a Maxwell company) to his carrying out a thorough search of that company's records in the hope of finding the cheque which is at the centre of the allegations and thereby establishing to who it was made payable and who received it," the committee reported.

The original agreement related to a deal Mr Robinson struck with Maxwell in 1990 for his company, TransTec, to provide management services to Lock - including his own services as executive chairman.

In October 1990, Mr Robinson sent an invoice to the parent company, Hollis, asking for his fee of £200,000 - with the cheque to be made payable to TransTec.

"Whether the payment was intended to be made to Mr Robinson or TransTec is immaterial. The October 1990 invoice confirmed the agreement. Both demonstrate the registrable interest," the committee said.

When Mr Robinson was questioned by the committee about the affair, he failed to make available documents relating to the Lock agreement or the invoice which he sent to Hollis. He did not volunteer any information about the negotiations or the transaction.

When he was questioned again about it this year, he claimed he had "forgotten" about the agreement at the time of the original 1998 inquiry, however the committee cast doubt on that explanation.

"He had put considerable effort into negotiating it and had made several attempts to secure the agreed payment for it. He should have provided that information," the report said.

"We agree with the commissioner's findings ... that he failed to provide the then commissioner and the committee with full and accurate responses to their questions."

fields.headline: Camelot chief to head marketing institute
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Camelot chief executive Dianne Thompson is to be the new president of the Chartered Institute of Marketing, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Camelot chief executive Dianne Thompson is to be the new president of the Chartered Institute of Marketing.

The appointment comes just one week after she was named businesswoman of the year and two weeks after she joined the advertising watchdog, the Advertising Standards Authority.

Ex-marketeer Ms Thompson will take over the presidency of the CIM in June from the current president Baroness O'Cathain.

The CIM is the world's professional body for marketeers and represents 60,000 members.

As president Ms Thompson will champion marketing as a key driver to competitive business.

She will also work with the institute to promote professionalism in marketing through qualifications, membership and chartered status.

Ms Thompson said: "I hope that having worked in a wide variety of industries during my career I can, as president, continue the invaluable work that Baroness O'Cathain has undertaken during the last three years to promote the cause of marketing."

The Camelot chief started her career as a marketing trainee at the Co-operative Wholesale Society and worked as marketer for companies including ICI Paints and the Signet Group.

She was also lecturer at Manchester Polytechnic for seven years during which time she ran her own advertising agency.

webTitle: Weakest Link drives out ITV garage

fields.headline: Weakest Link drives out ITV garage
fields.trailText: TV overnights: The return of the Weakest Link helped BBC1 to peaktime ratings victory, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The return of the Weakest Link helped BBC1 to a peaktime ratings victory last night, with the Anne Robinson-hosted quiz show beating ITV's Garages From Hell 3.

The Weakest Link was on between 8pm and 8.45pm last night; while ITV's look at the tricks of the second hand car trade ran for 60 minutes from 8pm.

The BBC1 quiz show had 7.6m viewers and a 36% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

Garages From Hell 3 could only muster 6.7m and a 31% share.

Other BBC1 winners included Mr Trebus's Life of Grime, a documentary between 9.20pm and 10pm updating the story of a Polish war veteran's epic battle with Haringey Council over his penchant for hoarding rubbish.

The Life of Grime special had 6.6m viewers and a 29% audience share.

The ITV opposition, medical drama A&E, had 6.2m.

Overall, BBC1 had a 34.4% share of viewing between 6pm and 10.30pm; while ITV had 28.5%.

fields.headline: Camelot refuses to hand over £3m
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Camelot today stood by its decision not to hand over a £3m jackpot to a couple who lost their winning lottery ticket despite a call to pay up from Chris Smith, the Culture Secretary.
fields.body:
Camelot today stood by its decision not to hand over a £3m jackpot to a couple who lost their winning lottery ticket despite a call to pay up from Chris Smith, the Culture Secretary.

Mr Smith said he hoped the lottery organisers would "see reason" and give the cash to Kay and Martyn Tott, from Watford, Herts, who missed out because they did not register a claim within the stipulated 30-day period.

"There is no legal requirement on them to do so, but if I were them, I would," he said during BBC1's Question Time.

Asked if he would use his powers to persuade Camelot to pay up or face losing its licence he said: "Well, they've got their licence back, but I hope that they will actually see reason in this matter."

But Camelot later said its position remained "unchanged".

"It is not a question of 'seeing reason' - it is about upholding rules that protect the national lottery and its ability to raise funds for the public good."

Kay, 24, and Martyn, 33, had answered a TV appeal on March 5 over an unclaimed jackpot ticket bought in their area for the midweek draw on September 6 last year.

By then there were just hours left before the 180-day claims deadline for winning tickets ran out, but they could not find the all-important slip.

After weeks of investigations, Camelot decided to stick to the 30-day rule and reject the claim.

Publicist Max Clifford, who is representing the couple, said he had tapes of telephone conversations showing Camelot built up their hopes over seven weeks, only to disappoint them.

"Most of the British public are totally behind them and now Chris Smith is as well. Now it is time for them to be reasonable and do what they know is right," he said.

Camelot's head of external affairs, Sue Slipman, acknowledged that the law did not stop the company from paying the couple out of their own profits. But that would "open the floodgates" to claims worth millions of pounds, which could jeopardise the whole game.

Mr Tott told GMTV today: "I am encouraged very much for someone of Chris Smith's stature to support us."

He claimed that a previous lottery player who did not have a ticket received payment from Camelot after four months.

"There was a precedent before us they conveniently failed to mention," Mr Tott said.

Asked whether it was fair that the claim could not be accepted because it would open the way for many other claims, Mr Tott said: "No ... because I think that is the reason their security department is there."
